f.d: @#/ /'dul ba ka bzhugs so/ /
Vinayavastu (ka) [The chapter on going forth]
['go brjod]
Prologue
@##/ /rgya gar skad du/ bi na ya bstu/ bod skad du/ 'dul ba gzhi/
In the language of India, this scripture is called Vinayavastu. In the language of Tibet, it is called Dulwa Shi.
bam po dang po/
dkon mchog gsum la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to the Three Jewels.
gang gis 'ching rnams yang dag rab bcad cing / / mu stegs tshogs rnams thams cad rab bcom ste/ / sde dang bcas pa'i bdud rnams nges bcom nas/ / byang chub 'di brnyes de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
Homage to him who severed the bonds, Destroyed the whole host of tīrthikas, Vanquished the armies of Māra, And thus discovered this awakening.

khyim don che chung spangs te dang por rab 'byung dka'/ / rab byung thob nas yul spyad dag gis dga' thob dka'/ / mngon dga' ji bzhin don bskyed yang dag byed pa dka'/ / ngur smrig gos 'chang mkhas pa tshul las nyams pa dka'/ / gzhi rnams kyi spyi sdom la/

At first to renounce a householder’s concerns and go forth is hard. For a hedonist to be happy among renunciants is hard. For the joyful set on perfection to act perfectly is hard. For a learned wearer of the saffron robes to fall is hard.

rab 'byung gso sbyong gzhi dang ni/ / dgag dbye dbyar dang ko lpags gzhi/ / sman dang gos dang sra brkyang dang / / kau shAm bI dang las kyi gzhi/ / dmar ser can dang gang zag dang / / spo dang gso sbyong bzhag pa dang / / gnas mal dang ni rtsod pa dang / / dge 'dun dbyen rnams bsdus pa yin/ /

The Chapters on Monastic Discipline includes chapters on: Going forth, purification, Lifting restrictions, the rains, leather, Medicine, robes, turning cloth into robes, The monks of Kauśāmbī, formal acts of saṅgha, A group of troublesome monks, types of persons, Probations, suspension of the purification, Housing, [F.2.a] disputes, and schisms in the saṅgha.[53]
rab tu 'byung ba'i gzhi'i spyi sdom la/ shA ri'i bu dang mu stegs can/ / dge tshul gnyis dang bya rog skrod/ / dgra bcom bsad dang lag rdum gyi/ / sde tshan yang dag bsdus pa yin/ /
The whole of “The Chapter on Going Forth” Is told in sections on: Śāriputra, tīrthikas, The two novices, scaring a crow, Killing an arhat, and missing hands.
[shA ri'i bu]
Śāriputra
sdom la/ shA ri'i bu dang rab 'byung dang / / bsnyen par rdzogs par gnang ba dang / / nye sdes tshogs ni bsdus pa dang / / lnga pa'i sde tshan bsdus pa yin/ /
The Śāriputra section is told over five chapters: Śāriputra, going forth, refuge, a summary of Upasena’s collection, and a summary of the fives.
[shA ri'i bu]
Śāriputra

byang chub sems dpa' dga' ldan gyi gnas na bzhugs pa na/ yul ang ga dag na ang ga'i rgyal po zhes bya bas rgyal srid 'byor pa/ rgyas pa bde ba lo legs pa skye bo dang mi mang pos gang ba byed du bcug go/ / yul ma ga d+hA dag na yang rgyal po pad ma chen po zhes bya bas/ rgyal srid 'byor pa rgyas pa bde ba lo legs pa skye bo dang mi mang pos gang ba byed du bcug go/ / res 'ga' ni ang ga'i rgyal po dpung dang mthu che ba yin la/ res 'ga' ni rgyal po pad ma chen po dpung dang mthu che ba yin no/ /

While the Bodhisattva was dwelling in the Abode of Tuṣita, the King of Aṅga ruled over the lands of Aṅga. Under his rule, the kingdom prospered and thrived, crops were bountiful and the land teemed with animals and people. Meanwhile, King Mahāpadma ruled over the lands of Magadha. Under his rule, the kingdom prospered and thrived, crops were bountiful and the land teemed with animals and people. At times, the King of Aṅga and his armies were dominant. At other times, King Mahāpadma and his armies were dominant.

gang gi tshe ang ga'i rgyal po dpung dang mthu che ba de'i tshe na/ des dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa/ glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te/ yul ma ga d+hA rgyal po'i khab ma gtogs pa bcom nas phyir ldog par byed do/ /

At a time when the King of Aṅga and his armies were dominant, he called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and laid waste to all of Magadha, save Rājagṛha, before returning.

gang gi tshe rgyal po pad ma chen po dpung dang mthu che ba de'i tshe na/ des kyang dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa/ glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te/ yul ang ga tsam pa ma gtogs pa bcom nas phyir ldog par byed do/ / de nas dus gzhan zhig na ang ga'i rgyal po dpung dang mthu che bar gyur nas/ des dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te/ yul ma ga d+hA gzhom par brtsams pa dang / ma ga d+hA na gnas pa'i skye bo'i tshogs kyis rgyal po pad ma chen po la lha ang ga'i rgyal pos dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te/ yul ma ga d+hA 'joms par bgyid do zhes sbron pa dag btang ngo / /

At a time when King Mahāpadma and his armies were dominant, he too called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and [F.2.b] laid waste to all of Aṅga, save Campā, before returning. At yet another time when the King of Aṅga and his armies were dominant, he again called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and began again to lay waste to the land of Magadha, prompting the people of Magadha to send a message to King Mahāpadma, saying, “Your Majesty, the King of Aṅga has called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and is laying waste to the lands of Magadha.”

rgyal po pad ma chen pos kyang thos nas dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te/ ang ga'i rgyal po dang g.yul sprad pa'i phyir 'phags so/ / de nas ang ga'i rgyal pos rgyal po pad ma chen po'i glang po che pa'i tshogs thams cad phrogs shing / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang /dpung bu chung gi tshogs thams cad kyang phrogs so/ / rgyal po pad ma chen po yang pham pa dang / skrag pa dang / bcom pa dang / gzhan rgyal ba dang / rgyab kyis phyogs par byas te/ rgyal po'i khab tu zhugs nas sgo bcad de/ ra ba dag gi khar sbrengs nas 'dug go/ /

When King Mahāpadma heard this, he too called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and rode out to meet the King of Aṅga in battle. The King of Aṅga captured King Mahāpadma’s entire elephant corps and proceeded to capture the whole of his cavalry, charioteer corps, and infantry. Defeated and frightened, destroyed and conquered, King Mahāpadma retreated. Entering Rājagṛha, he closed the gates and shut himself up within the walls of his fortress.

ang ga'i rgyal pos rgyal po pad ma chen po la pho nya btang ste/ gal te phyir 'byung na de lta na legs/ gal te phyir mi 'byung na ji ste steng gi nam mkha' la 'gro na ni mda' brgyud pas khyod ltung bar bya'o/ / ji ste sa'i 'og tu 'gro na ni mchil pa dang drang ba'i tshul gyis drang bar bya'o/ / ji ste ri'i rtse mor 'dzeg na ni der yang khyod thar pa med do zhes spring ngo / /

The King of Aṅga sent an envoy to King Mahāpadma with the message, “It would be good were you to come out. If you do not surrender, and instead take flight into the sky above, I will fell you with a volley of arrows. Tunnel beneath the earth and I will yank you up as if with a hook. Flee to the mountaintops, and even there you shall find no escape.”

rgyal po pad ma chen pos phrin yig bklags nas de mi bde bar gyur te/ lag pa la 'gram pa gtad nas sems khong du chud cing 'dug 'dug nas/ des blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag ang ga'i rgyal po 'di ni gdug pa/ pha rol gnon pa/ dpung dang mthu che bar gyur la/ des yu bu cag la 'di dang 'di skad ces spring na/ de la yu bu cag gis ji ltar bsgrub par bya/

King Mahāpadma was unsettled by the message he heard.[54] Head in hands, he sat and sat, absorbed in thought.[55] Then he said to his ministers, “Gentlemen, this King of Aṅga [F.3.a] is belligerent, ruthless, and his military might is great. If he gives an order, how can we not obey?”
de dag gis tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ yul dang srog la gnod gyur na/ / skyes bus kun du srog bsrung bya/ / blo yis gnyis ka dpyad byas na/ / yul ni yang rnyed srog rnams min/ /
They spoke in verse: “When land and life are threatened, Seek always to protect life. When the wise look at both, they see Land, but not life, can be found again.”
lha rnam pa thams cad du slar 'byung bar bgyi'o/ / de ral gri mgul du thogs te phyir byung ba dang / ang ga'i rgyal pos de la lo thang dang dpya phab ste de nyid du bzhag go/ /

They then implored him, “Your Majesty, any way you look at it, you must go out!” King Mahāpadma hung his sword from his neck in surrender and went out, where the King of Aṅga imposed an annual tribute and tax upon him.

gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' dga' ldan gyi gnas na bzhugs pas gzigs pa lnga po dag la gzigs nas 'dod pa na spyod pa'i lha drug po dag la lan gsum bsgo ba mdzad de/ glang po che ltar snang bar bsgyur te/ yum gyi lhums su zhugs pa de'i tshe na sa chen po shin tu g.yos par gyur cing 'jig rten 'di thams cad kyang sum bcu rtsa gsum pa'i lha rnams kyi kha dog gi mthu bas lhag pa'i snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur cing / 'jig rten gyi 'jig rten gyi bar gang na nyi ma dang zla ba 'di ltar rdzu 'phrul che ba/ 'di ltar mthu che ba 'di gnyis kyi 'od dag nyams su mi myong ba'i mun pa mun gnag mun par byed pas/ gnag par gyur pa gang dag yin pa de dag kyang de'i tshe na snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur nas/ sems can gang dag der skyes pa dag gis rang gi lag pa brkyang ba yang mi mthong ba de dag gis kyang 'od des sems can gcig gis gcig mthong nas shes ldan dag sems can gzhan yang 'dir skyes so/ / shes ldan dag sems can gzhan yang 'dir skyes so zhes shes par gyur to/ /

While the blessed Bodhisattva was dwelling in the Abode of Tuṣita, he saw five sights[56] and thrice gave notice to the six classes of gods who revel in the desire realm. Assuming an elephant’s appearance, he entered his mother’s womb as the earth shook and this world and all others too were bathed in a vast light more luminous than the glow of the gods of the Thirty-Three. So great was this miraculous manifestation, it was as if the sun and moon shone in the gulf between worlds.[57] So great was its strength that darkness everywhere, even the pitch-black darkness of dark places dark from never knowing the light of the sun and moon, was filled with a vast light. Beings born in those places had never even seen so far as their outstretched hands, yet by this light these beings saw one another and exclaimed, “You there! There are others who have been born here! There are others who have been born here!”

gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' bltam pa de'i tshe na grong khyer chen po bzhi po dag tu rgyal po chen po bzhi dag gi bu yang btsas par gyur te/ rgyal po'i khab tu rgyal po pad ma chen po'i bu btsas so/ / mnyan yod du ni rgyal po rtsibs kyis 'phur tshangs byin gyi bu btsas so/ / 'phags rgyal du ni rgyal po mu khyud mtha' yas kyi bu btsas so/ / kau shAm bIr ni rgyal po dmag brgya pa'i bu btsas so/ /

At the same time as the blessed Bodhisattva was born, sons were also born to four great kings in four great city-states. In Rājagṛha the son of King Mahāpadma was born. In Śrāvastī the son of King Arāḍa Brahmadatta was born. In Ujjayinī [F.3.b] the son of King Anantanemi was born. In Kauśāmbī the son of King Śatānīka was born.

bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' bltam pa na 'jig rten thams cad sum bcu rtsa gsum pa'i lha rnams kyi kha dog gi mthu bas lhag pa'i snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur cing 'jig rten gyi 'jig rten gyi bar gang na nyi ma dang zla ba 'di ltar rdzu 'phrul che ba/ 'di ltar mthu che ba 'di gnyis kyi 'od dag nyams su mi myong ba'i mun pa mun gnag mun par byed pas gnag par gyur pa gang dag yin pa de dag kyang de'i tshe na snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur nas/ sems can gang dag der skyes pa dag gis rang gi lag pa brkyang ba yang mi mthong ba de dag gis kyang 'od des sems can gcig gis gcig mthong nas shes ldan dag sems can gzhan yang 'dir skyes so/ / shes ldan dag sems can gzhan yang 'dir skyes so zhes shes par gyur to/ /

When the blessed Bodhisattva was born, the entire universe was bathed in a vast light more luminous than the glow of the gods of the Thirty-Three. So great was this miraculous manifestation, it was as if the sun and moon shone in the gulf between worlds. So great was its strength that darkness everywhere, even the pitch-black darkness of dark places dark from never knowing the light of the sun and moon, was filled with a vast light. Beings born in those places had never even seen so far as their outstretched hands, yet by this light these beings saw one another and exclaimed, “You there! There are others who have been born here! There are others who have been born here!”

rgyal po pad ma chen pos bsams pa/ bdag gi bu btsas pa na 'jig rten nyi ma'i gzugs shar ba ltar snang zhing 'di btsun mo gzugs can gyi bu yin pas gzhon nu 'di'i ming gzugs can snying por gdags so snyam nas bu de'i ming gzugs can snying po zhes bya bar btags so/ / rgyal po rtsibs kyis 'phur tshangs byin gyis bsams pa/ bdag gi bu btsas pa na 'jig rten gsal ba gsal ba ltar snang bas gzhon nu 'di'i ming gsal rgyal du gdags so snyam nas bu de'i ming gsal rgyal zhes bya bar btags so/ / rgyal po dmag brgya pas bsams pa/bdag gi bu btsas pa na 'jig rten nyi ma shar ba ltar snang bar gyur pas gzhon nu 'di'i ming shar bar gdags so snyam nas bu de'i ming shar ba zhes bya bar btags so/ / rgyal po mu khyud mtha' yas kyis bsams pa/ bdag gi bu btsas pa na 'jig rten rab tu snang bas snang bar gyur pas gzhon nu 'di'i ming rab snang zhes bya bar gdags so snyam nas bu de'i ming rab snang zhes bya bar btags so/ /

King Mahāpadma thought, “When my son was born, the world was lit as if by the gold of the rising sun. And as he is the son of Queen Bimbī (Goldie), I shall name this prince Bimbisāra (Essence of Gold).” And so the boy was named Bimbisāra. King Arāḍa Brahmadatta thought, “When my son was born, the world was lit as if by the light of lights, so I shall name this prince Prasenajit (Supreme Light).” And so the boy was named Prasenajit. King Śatānīka thought, “When my son was born, the world was lit as if by the rising sun, so I shall name this prince Udayana (Rising).” And so the boy was named Udayana. King Anantanemi thought, “When my son was born, the world was lit by a brilliant light, so I shall name this prince Pradyota (Brilliant Light).” And so the boy was named Pradyota.

rgyal po re res bsams pa yang bdag gi bu 'di'i mthu yin no/ / bdag gi bu 'di'i mthu yin no snyam mod kyi/ de ni de lta ma yin te/ 'di ltar de dag thams cad ni byang chub sems dpa'i mthu yin pa'i phyir ro/ /
And so each king attributed the light to the birth of his own son. [F.4.a] Though each attributed it to his own son, it was not so. For all that occurred, occurred because of the Bodhisattva.
gang gi nyin mo gzhon nu gzugs can snying po btsas pa de nyid kyi nyin mo blon po lnga brgya dag gi bu lnga brgya yang btsas te/ de dag kyang rigs dang mthun par ming btags so/ /
On the very same day that Prince Bimbisāra was born, five hundred sons of five hundred ministers were also born and were given names appropriate to their patrilineage. [S.2.a]

gzhon nu gzugs can snying po ma ma brgyad po pang na 'tsho ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / nu ma snun pa'i ma ma gnyis dang / dri ma 'phyi ba'i ma ma gnyis dang /rtsen grogs kyi ma ma gnyis la rjes su gtad do/ / de ma ma brgyad po dag gis 'o ma dang / zho dang / mar dang / zhun mar dang / mar gyi snying khu dang / gzhan yang yo byad kyi bye brag gtso bo gtso bo dag gis sring bar byed/ skyed par byed cing rdzing na gnas pa'i pad ma bzhin myur du skyed par byed do/ / de gang gi tshe chen por gyur pa de'i tshe yi ge dang / grangs dang / rtsis dang / lag rtsis dang / dbyung ba dang / gzhug pa dang / gzhag pa la nye bar zhugs nas/ de yi ge'i mthar phyin cing 'byed pa dang / klog pa dang / mkhas pa dang / skyod pa gsal ba dang / brtag pa brgyad po 'di lta ste/ rin po che brtag pa dang / gzhi brtag pa dang / gos brtag pa dang / shing brtag pa dang / glang po che brtag pa dang / rta brtag pa dang / bud med brtag pa dang / skyes pa brtag pa la mkhas par gyur to/ /

Prince Bimbisāra was entrusted to eight nursemaids:[58] two to cuddle him, two to breastfeed him, two to change his diapers, and two to play with him.[59] Fortified with milk, curd, butter, ghee, cream, and other nourishing foods, he grew quickly, shooting up like a lotus in a pond. When he was old enough, he was introduced to letters, number names, calculation, counting by hand, expenditures, revenues, and deposits.[60] After he finished letters, he became skilled in exegesis, recitation, knowledge, proper conduct,[61] and the way to assess gems, sites, fabrics, woods, elephants, horses, women, and men.

rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba ljongs kyi dbang phyug mthu dang brtson 'grus thob pa/ sa chen po'i dkyil 'khor mngon par rgyal bar byas te gnas pa rnams kyi bzo'i gnas dang / las kyi gnas tha dad par gyur pa gang dag yin pa 'di lta ste/ glang po che'i gnyar bzhon pa dang / rta bzhon pa dang / shing rta'i thabs dang / ral gri'i thabs dang / 'phong dang / phyir bsnur ba dang / mdun du bsnur ba dang / lcags kyi bsgyur thabs dang / zhags pa gdab pa dang / mda' bo che 'phen thabs dang / 'dzin stangs dang / gom stangs dang / thor tshugs dang / gcad pa dang / dral ba dang / dbug pa dang / gnas lnga po 'di lta ste/ rgyang nas 'phog pa dang / sgra grags par 'phog pa dang / gnad du 'phog pa dang / mi 'chor bar 'phog pa dang /tshabs che ba de dag la yang zhugs shing byang bar gyur to/ / blon po'i bu lnga brgya po de dag kyang bzo'i gnas dang /las kyi gnas dag la byang bar gyur to/ /

He trained in and mastered the different fields of arts and skills of anointed kṣatriya kings, or a ruler of the realm endowed with the might and vigor to conquer the wide face of the earth, such as riding on the neck of an elephant, riding horseback, charioteering, swordsmanship, archery, advancing, yielding, wielding a hook, throwing a lasso, casting a spear, and how to hold a weapon, march, tie a topknot,[62] [F.4.b] slash, quarter, pierce, and strike in five ways‍—striking from a distance, striking a target using acoustic location, striking a fatal blow, striking without hesitation, and striking forcefully. These arts and skills were also mastered by the five hundred sons of the five hundred ministers.
de phas bzo sbyang ba bcwa brgyad po dag la bcug nas de'i ming bzo sbyangs gzugs can snying po/ bzo sbyangs gzugs can snying po zhes bya bar gyur to/ /
Bimbisāra’s father enrolled him in the eighteen guilds, due to which he was named and became known as Bimbisāra of the Guilds.[63]

de nas dus gzhan zhig na gzhon nu gzugs can snying po glang po che la zhon te ljongs su byung ba dang / des ang ga'i rgyal po'i zho shas 'tsho ba dag lo thang dang dpya sdud pa mthong nas/ des smras pa/ shes ldan dag lo thang dang dpya sdud pa 'di dag su'i yin/ de dag gis smras pa/ lha ang ga'i rgyal po'i lags so/ /

Later Prince Bimbisāra set out astride an elephant where he saw the King of Aṅga’s officers collecting tributes and taxes, prompting him to inquire of his men, “Gentlemen, for whom are these tributes and taxes being collected?” “Your Majesty! For the King of Aṅga.”
des smras pa/ ci yu bu cag de la lo thang 'bul ba yin nam/ de dag gis smras pa/ lha lo thang 'bul ba lags so/ / des smras pa/ shes ldan dag zho shas 'tsho ba de dag bos shig /
“What? Will we be offered tribute?” “No, Your Majesty, we are the ones to offer the tribute.” “Gentlemen, summon those officers.”

de dag gis bos pa dang / des smras pa/ shes ldan dag de yang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba yin la/ nged kyang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba yin na/ ci'i phyir khyed cag lo thang dang dpya sdud par byed/ deng la phyin chad lo thang dang dpya ma sdud cig /

When the officers were summoned, he said, “Gentlemen, the King of Aṅga is crowned and an anointed kṣatriya king. If I too am crowned and an anointed a kṣatriya king, why is it you are collecting tributes and taxes here? I forbid you to collect tributes and taxes from this day forth.”
de dag gis bsams pa/ gzhon nu 'di ni rgyus mi shes pa yin pas bdag cag rgyal po pad ma chen po'i gan du 'dong zhing song nas bsnyad par bya'o snyam nas/
“The prince fails to appreciate the situation,” they thought. “Let us go submit the matter to King Mahāpadma.”

de dag rgyal po pad ma chen po'i gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ lha bdag cag ang ga'i rgyal po'i zho shas 'tsho ba lo thang dang dpya sdud pa na gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos bkag na/ ci bsdu bar 'tshal lam/ 'on te slar mchi bar 'tshal/ des smras pa/ shes ldan dag gzhon nu de ni rgyus mi shes pa yin pas khyed cag sngon ji ltar lo thang dang dpya sdud pa de bzhin du sdus shig /

They went to King Mahāpadma and said, “Your Majesty, when we officers of the King of Aṅga were collecting tributes and taxes, Prince Bimbisāra stopped us from doing so. Shall we collect them or not?” “Gentlemen, the prince doesn’t understand the situation. Continue to collect tributes and taxes as you have done before.”

de dag gis yang bsdu bar brtsams te/ de dag 'ongs nas phyir ldog pa gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos mthong nas smras pa/ shes ldan dag ngas khyed la phyin chad lo thang dang dpya ma sdud cig ces ma bzlog gam/ ci'i phyir yang khyed lo thang dang dpya sdud/ gal te re zhig 'khod na de lta na legs/ gal te mi 'khod na mtshams chen po gcad par bya'o/ /

They [F.5.a] had begun their collection again when Prince Bimbisāra spotted them on their way back and said, “Gentlemen, have I not already prohibited you from collecting tributes and taxes? Why are you collecting them again? You are to desist. Fail to desist and I shall close the borders.”

de dag skrag nas bsams pa/ gzhon nu 'di ni gdug pa pha rol gnon pa yin pas bdag cag la gnod pa byed par 'gyur ba gang yin pa de lta bu'i gnas yod par 'gyur gyis/ bdag cag ang ga'i rgyal po'i gan du dong ste sbran par bya'o snyam nas
Frightened, they thought, “The prince is dangerous and ruthless. In time he may pose a serious risk to us. We must go warn the King of Aṅga.”

de dag ang ga'i rgyal po'i gan du dong ste phyin nas smras pa/ lha bdag cag lha'i zho shas 'tsho ba lags te/ bdag cag lha'i lo thang dang dpya sdud pa na rgyal po pad ma chen po'i bu gzhon nu gzugs can snying po des bzlog lags na/ da gal te lhas btang snyoms mdzad na slad kyis gnod pa chen po bgyid par 'gyur ba gang lags pa de lta bu'i gnas mchis par 'gyur ro/ /

They went before the King of Aṅga and said, “Your Majesty, as officers of the court, we were collecting tributes and taxes on your behalf when King Mahāpadma’s son, Prince Bimbisāra, stopped us. If Your Majesty [S.2.b] ignores the prince’s actions, he may, in time, pose a serious risk to us.”
tshigs su bcad pa yang smras pa/ ji srid shing ni gzhon pa'i tshe/ / sen mo dag gis gcad nus pa/ / de nyid chen por skyes pa na/ / sta re brgyas kyang gcad par dka'/ /
Then they spoke in verse: “When a tree is small, Fingernails may fell it. Yet when the tree is large, Even a hundred axes may fail.”

ang ga'i rgyal pos rgyal po pad ma chen po la gzhon nu gzugs can snying po mgul pa nas thogs la tshur bkri ba'am/ yang na rtswa dang chas sta gon gyis shig dang /nga nyid 'o nir 'ong ngo zhes phrin yig spring ngo / /
The King of Aṅga sent a letter to King Mahāpadma: “Send Prince Bimbisāra with his sword hung from his neck‍—or prepare your pyre and shroud, for I myself will come!”

rgyal po pad ma chen pos phrin yig bklags nas de mi bde bar gyur te lag pa 'gram pa la gtad nas/ sems khong du chud cing 'dug 'dug nas/ des gzhon nu gzugs can snying po bos nas smras pa/ ci'i phyir khyod kyis ang ga'i rgyal po'i zho shas 'tsho ba dag lo thang dang dpya sdud pa zlog/ des khros te nga la 'di dang 'di skad ces spring ngo / /

King Mahāpadma heard this letter read and was troubled. Head in hands, he sat and sat, absorbed in thought. Then he summoned Prince Bimbisāra and said, “Son, why did you stop the King of Aṅga’s officers from collecting tributes and taxes? They have sent me a letter expressing their anger.”
des smras pa/ lha ci skol de la lo thang 'bul ba lags sam/ bu lo thang 'bul ba yin no/ /
“Your Majesty, why do we pay tribute and taxes to him?” “Son, we are tributaries.”

des smras pa/ lha de yang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba lags la/ skol kyang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba lags na/ ci'i slad du skol de la lo thang dang dpya 'bul/ lhas bdag la dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa stsal ba 'ba' zhig mdzod cig dang /bdag gis ang ga'i rgyal po dang lhan cig g.yul ngor g.yul sprad par bgyi'o/ /

“If the King of Aṅga is an anointed a kṣatriya king and we too [F.5.b] are anointed kṣatriya kings, why do we offer tribute and taxes to him? Give me an army of just four divisions, Your Majesty, and I will meet the King of Aṅga in battle.”

de nas rgyal po pad ma chen pos ang ga'i rgyal po la khyod kyi mthu dang / dpung dang / brtson 'grus dang /pha rol gnon pa gang dag yin pa de dag thams cad ma nyams par gyis shig ces phrin yig spring ngo / / ang ga'i rgyal pos thos nas mi bzod pa skyes te blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag de'i yul 'khor gzhom par byas/ dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa go skon cig /

King Mahāpadma then sent a message to the King of Aṅga, saying, “You had best hope all the power, forces, will, and authority you possess do not fail you!” The King of Aṅga found this message intolerable and commanded his ministers, “Gentlemen, lay waste to those lands! Call up the four branches of the armed forces.”

des dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang / dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te yul ma ga d+hA gzhom par brtsams pa dang / ma ga d+hA na gnas pa'i skye bo'i tshogs kyis rgyal po pad ma chen po la lha ang ga'i rgyal po 'di dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa glang po che pa'i tshogs dang / rta pa'i tshogs dang / shing rta pa'i tshogs dang /dpung bu chung gi tshogs go bskon te yul ma ga d+hA 'joms par bgyid do zhes sbron pa dag btang ngo / /

Having called up the four branches of the armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—they began to lay waste to the land of Magadha. The people of Magadha sent a message to King Mahāpadma, saying, “Your Majesty, the King of Aṅga has called up the four branches of his armed forces‍—the elephant corps, the cavalry, the charioteer corps, and the infantry‍—and is laying waste to the lands of Magadha.”

rgyal po pad ma chen pos thos nas de mi bde bar gyur te lag pa 'gram pa la gtad nas/ sems khong du chud cing 'dug 'dug nas/ des gzhon nu gzugs can snying po bos te/de la dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa byin no/ / gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos blon po'i bu lnga brgya bsdus te smras pa/ shes ldan dag nga ni ang ga'i rgyal po dang lhan cig g.yul ngor g.yul sprod par byed na shes ldan dag ci byed/

King Mahāpadma was troubled by this news and, head in hands, sat and sat, absorbed in thought. He summoned Prince Bimbisāra and gave him charge over the four branches of the armed forces. Prince Bimbisāra gathered the five hundred ministers’ sons and said, “Gentlemen, what if I were to meet the King of Aṅga in battle? What would you do?”
de dag gis smras pa/ gzhon nu khyod kyi gnas skabs gang lags pa de bdag cag gi yang lags so/ /
“Prince, your struggle shall be our struggle!” they responded.
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ mi gang la ni khyim dpal gnas/ / de ni kun gyis yongs bsrung bya/ / de nyams na ni kun nyams te/ lte ba chag pas rtsibs rnams bzhin/ /
Then they said in verse: “In whose house dwells glory, It is he we should protect. If he falls, then all fall, As spokes at a hub’s collapse.”
da khyed kyis kun nas yongs su bsrung bar bya'o/ / de dag gis smras pa/ lha'i gnas skabs gang lags pa de bdag cag gi yang lags la/ lha'i zhabs gang na ba de na bdag cag gi mgo mchis so/ /

Prince Bimbisāra said, “Now [F.6.a] you must do all you can to protect me.” “Whatever Your Majesty’s plight may be, that too shall be ours. Wherever Your Majesty’s foot may fall, there shall we bow our heads.”

de nas des dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa go bskon te/ rgyal po'i khab nas byung ngo / / rgyal po pad ma chen po steng gi khang bzangs kyi gzhir gtogs pa na blon po'i tshogs kyis bskor cing 'dug pa des de byung ba mthong nas des blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag dmag 'di su'i yin/

The four branches of the armed forces were then called up and they set out from Rājagṛha. When King Mahāpadma, who sat shut up in his upper citadel surrounded by his council, saw them depart, he asked his ministers, “Gentlemen, whose army is this?”

de dag gis smras pa/ lha gzhon nu gzugs can snying po'i lags so/ / des smras pa/ shes ldan dag e ma 'di dmag mang po dang ldan no zhes smras pas/ de'i ming dmag ldan gzugs can snying po/ dmag ldan gzugs can snying po zhes bya bar gyur to/ / de na kha cig gis ni bzo sbyangs gzugs can snying po zhes bya bar shes so/ / kha cig gis ni dmag ldan gzugs can snying po zhes bya bar shes so/ /

“Your Majesty, it is Prince Bimbisāra’s.” “Gentlemen! It is awesome to behold!” Hence, the prince was named and became known as Bimbisāra of the Army. Some knew him as Bimbisāra of the Guilds while some knew him as Bimbisāra of the Army.

gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos blon po'i bu lnga brgya po dag la smras pa/ shes ldan dag ang ga'i rgyal po 'di ni gdug pa pha rol gnon pa dpung dang mthu che bar gyur pa yin pas yu bu cag gis 'di dang lhan cig g.yul sprad par ni mi nus kyis/ 'di ltar de bag yangs su go phud pa'i phru ma brdzi zhing bzhabs te gsad par bya'o/ /

Prince Bimbisāra said to the five hundred sons of the ministers, “Gentlemen, this King of Aṅga is belligerent, ruthless, and his military might is great so we cannot meet him in battle. Therefore, we will sneak in, overrun his exposed camp, and kill him while their guard is down and their armor off.”

de dag gis de bag yangs su go phud pa'i phru ma brdzis nas de dag gis ang ga'i rgyal po bzhabs te bsad do/ / ang ga'i rgyal po'i dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa phyogs bzhir byer ba dang / gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos phyogs bzhir pho nya rta pa dag bkye ste/ shes ldan dag de yang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba yin la/ nged kyang rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba yin gyis phyir log shig dang /shes ldan dag ngas shes ldan dag la 'tsho ba'i rgyu sbyin par bya'o zhes spring ba dang de dag phyir log go/ /

They overran the King of Aṅga’s exposed camp while their guard was down and their armor off, sneaking up and killing him. The four branches of the King of Aṅga’s armed forces scattered to the four directions. Prince Bimbisāra sent mounted emissaries in the four directions with the message, [S.3.a] “Gentlemen, you are anointed kṣatriya kings, and I too am an anointed kṣatriya king, so return! Gentlemen, I will support you!”

de nas ang ga'i rgyal pos grong khyer tsam pa bsrung ba bzhag pa des ang ga'i rgyal po ji ltar bsad pa thos nas des sgo bcad de ra ba dag gi khar sbrengs nas 'dug go/ / gzhon nu gzugs can snying po yang mthar gyis grong khyer tsam par phyin nas des shing ring po la ang ga'i rgyal po'i mgo btags te bstan nas smras pa/ ngas khyod kyi jo bo gang yin pa de gnas skabs 'di lta bur byas kyis/ gal te je phyir 'byung na de lta na legs/ gal te phyir mi 'byung na khyod kyang gnas skabs 'di lta bur byas par 'gyur ba gang yin pa de lta bu'i gnas yod par 'gyur ro/ /

He whom the King of Aṅga left to defend the city of Campā [F.6.b] heard how the King of Aṅga had been killed, prompting him to close the gates and take cover within the walls of the fortress. When at last Prince Bimbisāra reached Campā, the prince fixed the King of Aṅga’s head onto a long pole and displayed it, saying, “It is I who has brought your lord to this state. Come out immediately and I shall look favorably upon you. Fail to appear and you too will soon find yourself in this state.”
des thos nas mi bde bar gyur te/ des bsams pa/ yul dang srog la gnod gyur na/ / skyes bus kun du srog bsrung bya/ / blo yis gnyis ka dpyad byas na/ / yul ni yang rnyed srog rnams min/ /

It distressed the steward of Campā to hear this, and he thought of this verse: “When land and life are threatened, Seek always to protect life. When the wise look at both, they see Land, but not life, can be found again.”

snyam nas de ral gri mgul du thogs te phyir byung ngo / / de na gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos ang ga'i rgyal po bsad de grong khyer tsam pa rang gi lag tu thob nas des rgyal po pad ma chen po la lha bdag gis ang ga'i rgyal po bkum ste grong khyer tsam pa rang gi sug par thob lags na/lha yongs su ma grub pa gzhan ci mchis bka' stsol cig dang yongs su bsgrub par bgyi'o zhes phrin yig spring ngo / /

With that thought he hung his sword from his neck in surrender and came out. With the King of Aṅga slain, Campā fell into Prince Bimbisāra’s hands, at which point he sent a message to King Mahāpadma, saying, “Your Majesty, I have slain the King of Aṅga and Campā is now in my hands. Your Majesty, tell me what else needs to be done and I shall see to it.”
de mgu nas des de la gdugs dang / cod pan dang / thod bskur te/ bu khyod kyis 'o ni nyid du rgyal srid byed du chug shig /ngas kyang 'di nyid du rgyal srid byed du gzhug go zhes spring ngo / /
Pleased, King Mahāpadma sent Prince Bimbisāra a parasol, a turban, and a coronet with the message, “Son, you must take the reins of power there. I, for my part, will assume the reins of power here.”
de nas gzhon nu gzugs can snying pos yul ang ga dag tu rgyal srid 'byor pa rgyas pa bde ba lo legs pa skye bo dang mi mang pos gang ba byed du bcug go/ /
And so Prince Bimbisāra assumed the reins of power. Under him, the kingdom prospered and thrived, crops were bountiful and the land teemed with animals and people.

dus gzhan zhig na rgyal po pad ma chen po dus la bab nas rgyal po'i khab kyi blon po rnams kyis rgyal po gzugs can snying po la lha khyod kyi yab dus la bab po zhes spring nas/de ang ga dang ma ga d+hA pa'i blon po rnams kyis rgyal srid la dbang bskur ba chen pos dbang bskur to/ /

Once King Mahāpadma’s time had come, the ministers of Rājagṛha sent a message to King Bimbisāra, saying, “Your Majesty, your father’s time has come.” In a great coronation ceremony, the ministers of Rājagṛha and Magadha granted him sovereignty over the lands of Aṅga and Magadha.

de nas rgyal po gzugs can snying pos yul ang ga dang ma ga d+hA dag tu rgyal srid 'byor pa/ rgyas pa/ bde ba/ lo legs pa/ skye bo dang mi mang pos gang ba/ thab mo dang / tha ba dang / phyi dgra dang / nang 'khrug rab tu zhi ba/ chom rkun dang / mu ge dang / nad dang bral ba/ sA lu dang / bu ram shing gi phreng ba dang / ba lang dang / ma he phun sum tshogs pa byed du bcug ste/chos dang ldan pa chos kyi rgyal pos chos kyi rgyal srid byed du bcug go/ /

Under King Bimbisāra’s rule, the kingdoms of Aṅga and Magadha prospered and thrived, crops were bountiful and the land teemed with animals and people. He completely pacified conflict, [F.7.a] aggressors, and enemies from without as well as disturbances from within. He rid the land of brigands, thieves, famine, and illness, and brought a wealth of rice, sugar cane, cattle, and buffalo; thus the just Dharma king established a just kingdom.

de nas bram ze'i khye'u gsang tshig 'dod pa gsang tshig tshol ba zhig yul dbus nas lho phyogs su song ngo / / de na bram ze rig byed dang rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol du son pa yul tha dad pa na gnas pa'i bram ze rnams kyi ston par gyur pa zhig 'dug nas/

There was a young brahmin who, desiring and in search of esoteric instruction, left the Middle Country and went to the South, where there was a brahmin to whom the Vedas and the limbs of the Vedas had been entrusted, who had been a teacher to brahmins living in a country to the south.[64]

bram ze'i khye'u de bram ze de'i drung du song ste phyin nas zhi ba dang spyod lam zhi bas mgo bos phyag 'tshal te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / de nas bram ze des bram ze'i khye'u de la 'ongs pa legs so zhes bya ba'i tshig gis kun du spyad nas smras pa/ kye bram ze'i khye'u khyod ga las 'ongs ci zhig 'dod/

The young brahmin went to see this teacher of brahmins. Serene, the young brahmin bowed his head calmly and sat off to one side. The brahmin teacher warmly greeted him with words of welcome, and asked, “Young brahmin, where have you come from and what do you desire?”
bram ze'i khye'us smras pa/ bdag yul dbus nas mchis te/ mkhan po'i zhabs la sri zhu bgyid par 'tshal lo/ / ci zhig gi phyir/ rig byed bklag pa'i slad du'o/ /
“I hail from the Middle Country and I seek to serve at the feet of a preceptor.” “Why?” “So that I may study the Vedas.”

bu legs kyis de bzhin du gyis shig /de ni bram zes bya ba yin no/ / bram ze'i khye'u des bram ze de'i drung du rig byed bklag par bya bar brtsams so/ / bram ze'i khye'u rnams kyi kun du spyod pa ni 'di yin te/
“Excellent, my son. You should do just that, for that is a brahmin’s duty.” And so, the young brahmin began to study the Vedas with the teacher of brahmins.
gang gi tshe mi klog par gyur pa de'i tshe na lan 'ga' ni chu ngogs su nye reg byed du 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni grong khyer ltar 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni yam sreg shing thur 'dong ngo / /
The brahmins’ students were in the habit, when not occupied with their studies, of going to the riverbank to bathe, visiting the city, or collecting wood for use in fire pūjas.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na de dag mi klog par gyur nas de'i tshe de dag yam sreg shing thur dong ba dang / de dag la lam gyi bar du bar skabs kyi gtam brjod pa 'di lta bu 'di byung ste/ kye kud sa'i bu dag /bad sa'i bu dag /shan di li'i bu dag /ba ra dwa dza'i bu dag /lnga pa'i bu dag /nye lnga'i bu dag /je khyed cag las gang ni yul ga las 'ongs pa dri bar bya'o/ /

Once, when not occupied with their studies, they went to collect wood for fire pūjas. On the way they had the following conversation. “Sons of Kutsa, sons of Vātsa, sons of Śāṇḍili, sons of Bhāradvāja, sons of the Five, sons of the Further Five.[65] To begin with, let us share where we come from, from which land we hail.”
de na bram ze'i khye'u gcig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni yul shar nas so/ / gzhan zhig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni lho phyogs nas so/ /
“I am from the East,” one young brahmin responded. [F.7.b] “I am from the South,” said another.
yang gzhan zhig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni nub phyogs nas so/ / yang gzhan zhig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni byang phyogs nas so/ /
“I am from the West.” “I am from the North.”
bram ze'i khye'u des smras pa/ kho bo ni yul dbus nas so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ shes ldan dag bdag cag gis yul thams cad mthong zhing thos na yul dbus ni ma mthong ma thos so/ /

The young brahmin then said, “I am from the Middle Country.” To him they said, [S.3.b] “Sir! We have seen and heard of all those other countries, but have neither seen nor heard of the Middle Country.”
shar na blo can gnas pa ste/ / lho phyogs na ni g.yon byed 'dug / nub kyi yul na phra ma can/ / byang phyogs na ni tshig rtsub bo/ / zhes tshigs su bcad pa yang smras so/ /
And then they added this verse: “In the East they are wise, In the South they are cunning, In the West they stir division, In the North they speak roughly.”

de nas dris pa/ bram ze'i khye'u yul dbus ci 'dra/ shes ldan dag yul dbus ni yul rnams kyi mchog yin te/ sA lu dang / bu ram shing gi phreng ba dang / ba lang dang / ma he phun sum tshogs pa/ slong mo pa brgyas khyab pa/ dbus pa'i skye bos gang ba/ mtha' 'khob pa'i skye bos spangs pa/ skye bo mkhas pas bsten pa/ de na chu klung gang gA kha rje dang / bsod nams dang / bkra shis dang / gtsang ba dang / gtsang ba nyid kyi gnas su grags pa/ 'gram gnyis nas rlan 'phyo ba/ drang srong rnams kyi bsti gnas zhes bya ba chu dgur bcwa brgyad 'bab pa yod de/ der drang srong rnams kyis dka' thub spyad na rang gi lus nyid kyis mtho ris su 'dong ba yin no/ /

“Young brahmin,” they asked, “what is the Middle Country like?” “Gentlemen, the Middle Country is the best of all lands, abounding in rice, sugar cane, cattle, and buffalo, thronging with hundreds of honest women and filled with upstanding men, devoid of foreign savages, and guided by learned men. The river Gaṅgā, bountiful, meritorious, auspicious, and clean, flows through this famed land, irrigating both shores. At one point, where sages are known to gather, the river flows through eighteen bends. There, sages seek to bodily rise to the heavens through their practice of austerities.”[66]

kye bram ze'i khye'u de ni mjal gyis gzhan 'di 'dri'o/ / yul dbus na mkhas par bgrang ba dag yod dam/ shes ldan dag kho bos dang po nyid nas shes ldan dag yul dbus ni dbus pa'i skye bos gang ba/ mtha' 'khob pa'i skye bos spangs pa/ skye bo mkhas pas bsten pa'o zhes ma smras sam/ bram ze'i khye'u khyod kyis de skad smras so/ /

“Young brahmin, having met you, we have another question. Do you have men counted as learned in the Middle Country?” “Gentlemen, from the first did I not say, ‘Gentlemen, the Middle Country is filled with upstanding men, devoid of foreign savages, and guided by learned men’?”

bram ze'i khye'u yul dbus na 'di lta ste dper na bdag cag gi mkhan po dang 'dra ba smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag yod dam/ shes ldan dag yul dbus na bdag cag gi mkhan pos gang dag gi gdong du lta bar yang mi nus pa/ snyan par smra ba/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag yod do/ /

“Young brahmin, you did say that. Young brahmin, are there any in the Middle Country like our preceptor, a bull among teachers?” “Gentlemen, in the Middle Country, the teachers are such that our teacher could not even look them in the face, so eloquently do they speak, so wise are they.”

bram ze'i khye'u des de dag la de lta de ltar yul dbus kyi bsngags pa brjod pa dang /'di ltar de dag thams cad yul dbus su 'dong 'dod par gyur to/ / de nas bram ze'i khye'u de dag yam sreg shing dag btsal te/ yam sreg shing gi khur thogs nas bram ze'i khyim ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas yam sreg shing gi khur dag mtha' gcig tu bzhag ste/ bram ze de ga la ba der dong nas phyin pa dang /bram ze de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / mkhan po mkhyen par mdzod cig /bram ze'i khye'u 'dis ci nas kyang bdag cag thams cad yul dbus su mchi 'tshal bar gyur pa de ltar yul dbus kyi bsngags pa brjod do/ /

On hearing the young brahmin speak so highly of the Middle Country, [F.8.a] they were moved by the desire to visit it. The young brahmins then went off to collect wood for use in fire pūjas. Bearing their loads of wood, they came to the house in which the teacher of brahmins lived. On arriving, they set their loads of wood off to one side, went to him, and said, “Preceptor, please listen. The young brahmin from the Middle Country speaks so highly of it that we are moved by the desire to visit.”
bram ze des smras pa/ bu dag ji snyed thos pa de snyed bgrod par bya ba yin nam/'di ltar yul dag ni thos na dga' bar 'gyur ba yin pas mnyan par bya'i bgrod par ni mi bya'o/ /

The brahmin said, “Boys, would you visit every place of which you hear? Since you seem to derive so much pleasure from hearing of other countries, I would suggest you not visit those places you hear about.”
mkhan po bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i mchid nas yul dbus na bdag cag gi mkhan pos gang dag gi gdong du lta bar yang mi nus pa/ snyan par smra ba/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag mchis so zhes mchi'o/ /
“Preceptor, according to this young brahmin, in the Middle Country the teachers are such that you, our teacher, could not even look them in the face, so eloquently do they speak, so wise are they.”

bu dag ci kho bo na re sa'i steng na kho bo gcig pu kho na smra ba yin gyi/ smra ba gzhan 'ga' yang med do zhes zer ram/ sa ni rin po che mang po 'dzin pa yin pas sa gzhi ni mdzes pa mdzes pa dag gis gang ba yin no/ /
“My sons, do I say I am the one and only teacher on this earth, that there are no other teachers? After all, since the earth contains many gems, its surface is covered with one beauty after another.”

mkhan po re zhig yul de yang mthong bar 'gyur zhing chu ngogs su nye reg kyang bgyi/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de dag la yang bsnyen bkur bgyi/ rgol ba dag kyang tshar gcad par bgyi/ rang gi grags pa yang bsgrag par bgyi/ rnyed pa yang bsgrub par bgyis/ bdag cag yul dbus su mchi'o/ /

“We will see that country yet, Preceptor, if only for a short while. We will bathe on the banks of the river, we will serve the bull among teachers, we will defeat opponents, we will make a name for ourselves and find our fortune, too. We will go to the Middle Country.”

bram ze de slob ma la rjes su chags pa dang bcas pa dang / 'khor nyung ba yin pas des bram ze'i khye'u de dag la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bu dag gal te de lta na g.yang gzhi dag dang / shing shun dag dang / dbyu gu dag dang / blugs gzar dag dang / dgang gzar dag dang /ril ba dag long shig dang yul dbus su 'dong ngo / /

As the brahmin was attached to his students and his circle of students was small, he said to the young brahmins, “In that case, my sons, let us gather our hides, bast robes, staffs, water jugs, ladles, and bowls and go to the Middle Country.”[67]

de dag gis de dag blangs nas bram ze de bram ze'i khye'u de dag dang lhan cig yul dbus su 'phags pa dang / des rgol ba kha cig ni tshar bcad de rgol ba'i shing rta la sbyor bar byed/ kha cig ni mgor thal ba'i bum pa dag gis bsnun/ kha cig ni 'phong gi dpong sar khwa bzhin du thag ring po nas yongs su spong bar byed/ kha cig ni gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dag gis bsu bar byed/ kha cig ni slob ma nyid du khas len par byed cing de mthar gyis grong dang / grong khyer dang / grong rdal dang / dbye tshongs dang / tshong rdal dag tu rgol ba 'dul zhing rgyal po'i khab tu phyin to/ /

Having collected their things, the brahmin set off with the young brahmins for the Middle Country. [F.8.b] Along the way, he defeated an opponent in debate, and then bound him to his chariot. He poured ashes from a pot on another’s head. Another steered clear of him like a crow does an archery range. Another received him with parasols, victory banners, and standards. Another made a pledge to become his student. As he went, he vanquished one opponent after another in villages, cities, towns, marketplaces, and hamlets until he reached Rājagṛha. [S.4.a]

bram ze des bsams pa/ bdag gis ci'i phyir rtsa ba spangs te yal ga dang / 'dab ma dang / lo ma la nyug par bya/ rgol ba gang dag dang / mkhas par bgrang ba gang ji snyed pa de dag thams cad kyang rgyal po dang nye ba yin gyis/ bdag kyang rgyal po'i gan du 'gro'o snyam nas

The brahmin thought, “Why bother pulling off the branches, petals, and leaves while leaving the root? Since all worthy opponents and anyone counted as learned will be close to the king, it is the king I shall see.”

bram ze de rgyal po gzugs can snying po ga la ba der song ste phyin nas rgyal po gzugs can snying po la rgyal ba dang tshe spel ba byas te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / phyogs gcig tu 'dug nas rgyal po gzugs can snying po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / lha bdag la bla ma las yi ge nyung shas shig blangs pa mchis te/ de'i slad du lha'i spyan sngar rgol ba dag dang lhan cig bka' mchid rnam par gtan la dbab par 'tshal lo/ /

With that, the brahmin went to see King Bimbisāra. On arriving, he wished King Bimbisāra success and long life, took a place off to one side, and addressed him: “Your Majesty, from my guru I have received a few teachings. And so I seek to settle a matter in debate with an opponent in Your Majesty’s presence.”
rgyal pos blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag nga'i yul na bram ze 'di dang lhan cig gtam rnam par gtan la 'bebs par byed pa'i rgol ba 'ga' yod dam/
The king asked his ministers, “Gentlemen, are there any opponents in my kingdom capable of settling a matter in debate with this brahmin?”

blon po rnams kyis smras pa/ lha grong na la da na bram ze gnas len gyi bu zhes bgyi ba rig byed dang rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol tu mchis pa zhugs lta bu'i shes pas rang gi smra ba gsal bar bgyid/ gzhan gyi smra ba tshar gcod par rngo thog pa zhig mchis te/ des bstan bcos gnas len gyi bu zhes bgyi ba nye bar sbyar to/ /

“Your Majesty, in the village of Nālada there is a brahmin known as Māṭhara who has been entrusted with the Vedas and the limbs of the Vedas. With blazing intelligence, this capable man illuminates his own assertions and smashes those of others. He has put together a work known as Māṭhara’s Treatise.”
mkhan po gnas len gyi bu de bos shig /lha bod par bgyi'o zhes
“Summon Master Māṭhara.” “As you wish, Your Majesty.”

de dag gis de bos nas de rgyal po gzugs can snying po ga la ba der song ste phyin nas rgyal po gzugs can snying po la rgyal ba dang tshe spel ba byas te phyogs gcig tu 'dug pa dang / blon po rnams kyis smras pa/ lha mkhan po de 'di lags so/ /

Māṭhara received the summons and went to see King Bimbisāra. On arrival, he wished King Bimbisāra success and [F.9.a] long life then took a place off to one side. The ministers said, “This is the preceptor, Your Majesty.”

rgyal pos 'ongs pa legs so zhes bya ba'i tshig gis kun du spyad de smras pa/ mkhan po khyod kho bo'i mdun du bram ze 'di dang lhan cig gtam rnam par gtan la dbab par byed nus sam/ gnas len gyi bus smras pa/ bdag gis rngo thog pas/ rgyal po dgyes par bgyi'o/ /

The king greeted him with words of welcome and asked, “Preceptor, can you settle a matter in debate in my presence with this brahmin?” “I, as a capable man, shall do as the king pleases,” replied Māṭhara.
rgyal pos blon po rnams la bsgo ba/ shes ldan dag rgol ba'i dkyil 'khor shoms shig /phyogs dang gzhan gyi phyogs dag rnam par zhog shig /
The king ordered the ministers, “Gentlemen, prepare the debate arena and assign the disputants their roles.”

blon po rnams kyis rgol ba'i dkyil 'khor bshams shing phyogs dang gzhan gyi phyogs dag rnam par bzhag go/ / de nas blon po rnams kyis rgyal po'i rkang pa gnyis la phyag 'tshal te smras pa/ lha phyogs snga ma gang bgyid du stsal/ rgyal pos smras pa/ bram ze 'di 'gron pa yin gyis 'di phyogs snga ma byed du chug shig /

The ministers prepared the debate arena and assigned the disputants their roles. The ministers then prostrated at the king’s feet and asked, “Your Majesty, who would you have defend a position first?” “This brahmin is a visitor so have him defend a position first.”

bram ze de phyogs snga ma byed du bcug nas des rgyud chags lnga brgya bzlas so/ / gnas len gyi bus phyir bzlas te/ khyod kyi 'di ni rigs pa med pa yin no/ / 'di ni mi mthun pa yin no/ / 'di ni mi 'thad pa yin no zhes skyon btags pa dang bram ze de cang mi smra bar 'dug go/ /

Having been assigned to defend a position first, the brahmin proceeded to recite five hundred lines. Māṭhara repeated them and then said, “This position of yours is devoid of logic. It is inconsistent and incoherent.” The brahmin remained silent as Māṭhara pointed out the position’s flaws.
tshar gcad pa'i gnas rnams kyi nang na 'di lta ste lan la spobs pa med pa 'di ni tha chad yin no/ / rgyal pos blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag su rgyal/ lha mkhan po gnas len gyi bu'o/ /
That the brahmin had no confidence to respond was damning and among the reasons he was vanquished. The king asked the ministers, “Gentlemen, who won?” “Māṭhara, Your Majesty.”

de nas rgyal po yid dga' zhing yid dga' nas ro stod bsrang ste/ lag pa g.yas pa brkyang nas bdag gi yul na smra ba'i khyu mchog 'di lta bu dag yod pa ni bdag gis rnyed pa legs par rnyed do zhes ched du brjod pa ched du brjod nas smras pa/
This pleased the king, who straightened up, extended his right arm, and declared, “It is a fine discovery for me to find this bull among teachers in my kingdom!”
mkhan po khyod gnas gang na gnas/ gnas len gyi bus smras pa/ lha grong na la da na'o/ / khyod song la grong de khyod kyis rgol ba'i longs spyod gyis shig /
He saluted Māṭhara and asked, “Preceptor, where do you live?” “Your Majesty, in Nālada.” “Go, and let that village be your victor’s prize.”[68]

gnas len gyi bu rangs pa dang dga' ba dang mchog tu dga' bar gyur nas skye bo mkhas pa rnams kyis yongs su bskor te/ grong der song ngo / / 'jig rten ni 'byor pa 'dod cing rgud pa la ma dad pa yin pas de la bram ze du ma zhig gis bu mo chung mar len du bcug pa dang / de nas gnas len gyi bu des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs te/ de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i chung ma la bu ro stod ring ba ring ba zhig btsas nas de'i nye du dag 'dus shing lhags nas nyi ma bdun gsum nyi shu rtsa gcig tu btsas pa'i btsas ston rgya cher byas te/ khye'u'i ming cir gdags zhes ming 'dogs par byed do/ / nye du rnams kyis smras pa/ khye'u 'di ro stod ring ba ring bar gyur pas khye'u 'di'i ming stod rings su gdags so zhes de'i ming stod rings su btags so/ /

Māṭhara was thrilled, delighted, and overjoyed. Surrounded by learned men, he returned to his village. And since the world desires success [F.9.b] and distrusts failure, several brahmins pressed their daughters on him in marriage. Māṭhara then took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself gave birth to a son with an extraordinarily long torso. Three weeks or twenty-one days after the birth, relatives came and gathered to celebrate his birth in grand style, during which time they chose a name for the boy. The relatives said, “Since this boy has an extraordinarily long torso, he should be named Koṣṭhila (Long Torso).”

bram ze'i khye'u stod rings ma ma brgyad po pang na 'tsho ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / nu ma snun pa'i ma ma gnyis dang / dri ma 'phyi ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / rtsen grogs kyi ma ma gnyis la rjes su gtad do/ / de ma ma brgyad po dag gis 'o ma dang / zho dang / mar dang / zhun mar dang / mar gyi snying khu dang / gzhan yang yo byad kyi bye brag gtso bo gtso bo dag gis sring bar byed/ skyed par byed cing rdzing na gnas pa'i pad ma bzhin myur du skyed par byed do/ / de gang gi tshe chen por gyur pa de'i tshe yi ge dang / grangs dang / rtsis dang / lag rtsis dang / dbyung ba dang / gzhug pa dang / gzhag pa dang / 'byed pa dang / klog pa'i pha rol tu son cing / de'i tshe na bram ze'i spyod tshul dang / spyod pa dang / gtsang sbra dang / kun du spyod pa dang / thal ba blang ba dang / bya ma bum blang ba dang / sa blang ba dang / lag stangs dang / thor tshugs dang / rab bsngags bya ba dang / kye zhes bya ba dang / nges brjod kyi rig byed dang / mchod sbyin gyi rig byed dang / snyan tshig gi rig byed dang / srid srung gi rig byed dang / bram ze'i las drug po mchod sbyin byed pa dang / mchod sbyin byed du 'jug pa dang / klog pa dang / klog tu 'jug pa dang / sbyin pa dang / len pa la mkhas pa'i bram ze rig byed dang / rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol tu son pa me lta bu'i shes pas rang gi smra ba gsal bar byed pa/gzhan gyi smra ba tshar gcod par byed nus par gyur to/ /

The young brahmin was entrusted to eight nursemaids: two to cuddle him, two to breastfeed him, two to change his diapers, and two to play with him.[69] Fortified with milk, curd, butter, ghee, cream, and other nourishing foods, he grew quickly, shooting up like a lotus in a pond. When he was old enough, he was introduced to letters, number names, calculation, counting by hand, how to exclude, to add, and to leave,[70] and to parse until he had mastered reciting. Then, he was instructed in the ways of brahmins: their conduct, ritual purity, and observances; the handling of ashes, the handling of ritual vases, and the handling of sites; hand gestures, turbans, offering praise, and salutations; the Ṛgveda, the Yajurveda, the Sāmaveda, and the Atharvaveda; and a brahmin’s six duties‍—making fire sacrifices, officiating over fire sacrifices, studying, teaching, giving, and receiving. The Vedas the limbs of the Vedas were entrusted to him, and with his blazing intelligence he could illuminate his own assertions [F.10.a] and vanquish those of others.

yang de rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa'i chung ma la bu mo mig gnyis bya shA ri kA 'dra ba zhig btsas nas de'i nye du dag 'dus shing lhags nas nyi ma bdun gsum nyi shu gcig tu btsas pa'i btsas ston rgya cher byas te/ bu mo'i ming cir gdags zhes ming 'dogs par byed do/ / nye du rnams kyis smras pa/ bu mo 'di'i mig gnyis bya shA ri kA 'dra bas bu mo 'di'i ming shA ri kAr gdags so zhes de'i ming shA ri kAr btags so/ / bu mo shA ri kA bsrings shing bskyed de chen mor gyur to/ / de phas yig 'bru'i yi ge la nye bar sbyar nas des yig 'bru'i yi ge dag lobs so/ /

The wife with whom Māṭhara had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself again gave birth, this time to a girl with eyes like a śārī bird. Three weeks or twenty-one days after the birth, relatives came and gathered to celebrate her birth in grand style, during which time they chose a name for the girl. The relatives said, “Since this girl has eyes like a śārī, this girl should be given the name Śārikā.” [S.4.b] The girl Śārikā was nurtured and grew. Her father taught her how to combine letters into words so she became proficient in reciting.

dus gzhan zhig na bram ze'i khye'u stod rings shA ri kA dang lhan cig 'gyed par byed pa na shA ri kAs de tshar bcad nas/ phas stod rings la smras pa/ bu khyod skyes pa yin na bud med kyis tshar bcad dam/ nga 'das nas rgol ba'i longs spyod dag phrogs par 'gyur ro/ / de nas yang bram ze'i khye'u gsang tshig 'dod pa gsang tshig tshol ba zhig yul dbus nas lho phyogs su song ngo / /

Later, when the young brahmin Koṣṭhila was debating Śārikā, Śārikā vanquished him and their father said to Koṣṭhila, “Son, if you are a male, how has a female vanquished you? Once I’m gone, the spoils I’ve won in debate will be taken away.” At that the young brahmin Koṣṭhila, desiring and in search of esoteric instruction, set off from the Middle Country for the South.

de na bram ze skar rgyal zhes bya ba 'jig rten rgyang 'phen la mkhas pa/ rig byed dang rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol tu son pa yul tha dad pa na gnas pa'i bram ze rnams kyi ston par gyur pa zhig 'dug nas/
There, in a country not his own, lived a brahmin named Tiṣya who was learned in Lokāyata philosophy,[71] a teacher of brahmins to whom the Vedas and the limbs of the Vedas were entrusted.
bram ze'i khye'u de bram ze de'i drung du song ste phyin nas zhi ba dang spyod lam zhi bas mgo bos phyag 'tshal te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ /
Koṣṭhila went to see the brahmin Tiṣya. Serene, the young brahmin Koṣṭhila bowed at Tiṣya’s feet and sat off to one side.

de nas bram ze skar rgyal gyis bram ze'i khye'u de la 'ongs pa legs so zhes bya ba'i tshig gis kun du spyad nas smras pa/ kye bram ze'i khye'u khyod ga las 'ongs ci zhig 'dod/ bram ze'i khye'us smras pa/ bdag yul dbus nas mchis te/ mkhan po'i zhabs la sri zhu bgyid par 'tshal lo/ /

Tiṣya warmly greeted Koṣṭhila with words of welcome, asking, “Young brahmin, where have you come from and what do you desire?” “I hail from the Middle Country and I seek to serve at the feet of the preceptor.”
ci zhig gi phyir/ 'jig rten rgyang 'phen gzung ba'i slad du'o/ /
“Why?” “So that I may uphold the Lokāyata philosophy.”

bram ze'i khye'u legs kyis de bzhin gyis shig /de ni bram zes bya ba yin no/ / bram ze'i khye'u des bram ze skar rgyal gyi drung du 'jig rten rgyang 'phen gzung bar brtsams so/ / bram ze'i khye'u rnams kyi kun du spyod pa ni 'di yin te/ gang gi tshe mi klog par gyur pa de'i tshe na lan 'ga' ni chu'i ngogs su nye reg byed du 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni grong khyer ltar 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni yam sreg shing thur 'dong ngo / /

“Excellent, my son. You should do just that, for that is a brahmin’s duty.” And so, the young brahmin Koṣṭhila began to study Lokāyata philosophy in the presence of the brahmin Tiṣya. [F.10.b] The brahmins’ students were in the habit, when not occupied with their studies, of going to the riverbank to bathe, visiting the city, or collecting wood for use in fire pūjas.[72]

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na de dag ma klog par gyur nas de'i tshe de dag yam sreg shing thur dong ba dang / de dag la lam gyi bar du bar skabs kyi gtam brjod pa 'di lta bu 'di dag byung ste/ kye kud sa'i bu dag /bad sa'i bu dag /shan di la'i bu dag /ba ra dwa dza'i bu dag /lnga pa'i bu dag /nye lnga pa'i bu dag je khyed cag las gang ni yul ga las 'ongs pa dri bar bya'o/ /

Once, when not occupied with their studies, they went to collect wood for fire pūjas. On the way they had the following conversation. “Sons of Kutsa, sons of Vātsa, sons of Śāṇḍili, sons of Bhāradvāja, sons of the Five, sons of the Further Five.[73] To begin with, let us share where we come from, from which land we hail.”
de na bram ze'i khye'u gcig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni yul shar nas so/ / gzhan zhig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni lho phyogs nas so/ /
“I am from the East,” one young brahmin responded. “I am from the South,” said another.
yang gzhan zhig gis smras pa /kho bo ni nub phyogs nas so/ / yang gzhan zhig gis smras pa/ kho bo ni byang phyogs nas so/ /
“I am from the West.” “I am from the North.”
bram ze'i khye'u des smras pa/ kho bo ni yul dbus nas so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ shes ldan dag bdag cag gis yul thams cad mthong zhing thos na yul dbus ni ma mthong ma thos so/ /
The young brahmin then said, “I am from the Middle Country.” To him they said, “Sir! We have seen and heard of all those other countries, but have neither seen nor heard of the Middle Country.”
shar na blo can gnas pa ste/ / lho phyogs na ni g.yon byed 'dug / nub kyi yul na phra ma can/ / byang phyogs na ni tshig rtsub bo/ / zhes tshigs su bcad pa yang smras so/ /
And then they added this verse: “In the East they are wise, In the South they are cunning, In the West they stir division, In the North they speak roughly.”

de nas dris pa/ bram ze'i khye'u yul dbus ci 'dra/ shes ldan dag yul dbus ni yul rnams kyi mchog yin te/ sA lu dang / bu ram shing gi phreng ba dang / ba lang dang / ma he phun sum tshogs pa/ slong mo pa brgyas khyab pa/ dbus pa'i skye bos gang ba/ mtha' 'khob pa'i skye bos spangs pa/ skye bo mkhas pas bsten pa/ de na chu klung gang gA kha rje dang / bsod nams dang / bkra shis dang / gtsang ba dang / gtsang ba nyid kyi gnas su grags pa/ 'gram gnyis nas rlan 'phyo ba/ drang srong rnams kyi bsti gnas zhes bya ba chu dgur bcwa brgyad 'bab pa yod de/ der drang srong rnams kyi dka' thub spyad na rang gi lus nyid kyis mtho ris su 'dong ba yin no/ /

“Young brahmin,” they asked, “what is the Middle Country like?” “Gentlemen, the Middle Country is the best of all lands, abounding in rice, sugar cane, cattle, and buffalo, thronging with hundreds of honest women and filled with upstanding men, devoid of foreign savages, and guided by learned men. The river Gaṅgā, bountiful, meritorious, auspicious, and clean, flows through this famed land, irrigating both shores. At one point, where sages are known to gather, the river flows through eighteen bends. There, sages seek to bodily rise to the heavens through their practice of austerities.”[74]

kye bram ze'i khye'u de ni mjal gyis gzhan 'di 'dri'o/ / yul dbus na mkhas par bgrang ba dag yod dam/ shes ldan dag kho bos dang po nyid nas shes ldan dag yul dbus ni dbus pa'i skye bos gang ba/ mtha' 'khob pa'i skye bos spangs pa/ skye bo mkhas pas bsten pa'o zhes ma smras sam/ bram ze'i khye'u khyod kyis de skad smras so/ /

“Young brahmin, [F.11.a] having met you, we have another question. Do you have men counted as learned in the Middle Country?” “Gentlemen, from the first did I not say, ‘Gentlemen, the Middle Country is filled with upstanding men, devoid of foreign savages, and guided by learned men’?”

bram ze'i khye'u yul dbus na 'di lta ste dper na/ bdag cag gi mkhan po dang 'dra ba smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag yod dam/ shes ldan dag yul dbus na bdag cag gi mkhan pos gang dag gi gdong du lta bar yang mi nus pa snyan par smra ba/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag yod do/ / bram ze'i khye'u des de dag la de lta de ltar yul dbus kyi bsngags pa brjod pa dang / 'di ltar de dag thams cad yul dbus su 'dong 'dod par gyur to/ /

“Young brahmin, you did say that. Young brahmin, are there any in the Middle Country like our preceptor, a bull among teachers?” “Gentlemen, in the Middle Country, the teachers are such that our teacher could not even look them in the face, so eloquently do they speak, so wise are they.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u de dag gis yam sreg shing dag btsal te/ yam sreg shing gi khur thogs nas bram ze de'i khyim ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas yam sreg shing gi khur mtha' gcig tu bzhag ste/ bram ze de ga la ba der dong nas phyin pa dang / bram ze de la 'di skad ces smras so/ / mkhan po mkhyen par mdzod cig /bram ze'i khye'u 'dis ci nas kyang bdag cag thams cad yul dbus su mchi 'tshal bar gyur pa de ltar yul dbus kyi bsngags pa brjod do/ /

On hearing the young brahmin speak so highly of the Middle Country, they were moved by the desire to visit it. The young brahmins then went off to collect wood for use in fire pūjas. Bearing their loads of wood, they came to the house in which the teacher of brahmins lived. On arriving, they set their loads of wood off to one side, went to him, and said, “Preceptor, please listen. The young brahmin from the Middle Country speaks so highly of it that we are moved by the desire to visit.”
bram ze skar rgyal gyis smras pa/ bu dag ji snyed thos pa de snyed bgrod par bya ba yin nam/ 'di ltar yul dag ni thos na dga' bar 'gyur ba yin pas mnyan par bya'i bgrod par ni mi bya'o/ /

The brahmin Tiṣya said, “Boys, would you visit every place of which you hear? Since you seem to derive so much pleasure from hearing of other countries, I would suggest you not visit those places you hear about.”
mkhan po bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i mchid nas yul dbus na bdag cag gi mkhan pos gang dag gi gdong du lta bar yang mi nus pa/ snyan par smra ba/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de lta bu dag mchis so zhes mchi'o/ /
“Preceptor, according to this young brahmin, in the Middle Country the teachers are such that you, our teacher, could not even look them in the face, so eloquently do they speak, so wise are they.”

bu dag ci kho bo na re sa'i steng na kho bo gcig pu smra ba kho na yin gyi smra ba gzhan 'ga' yang med do zhes zer ram/ sa ni rin po che mang po 'dzin pa yin pas sa gzhi ni mdzes pa mdzes pa dag gis gang ba yin no/ /

“My sons, do I say I am the one and only teacher on this earth, that there are no other teachers? After all, since the earth contains many gems, its surface is covered with one beauty after another.” [F.11.b]

mkhan po re zhig yul de yang mthong bar 'gyur zhing chu ngogs su nye reg kyang bgyi/ smra ba'i khyu mchog de dag la yang bsnyen bkur bgyi/ rgol ba dag kyang tshar gcad par bgyi/ Rang gi grags pa yang bsgrag par bgyi/ rnyed pa yang bsgrub par bgyis/ bdag cag yul dbus su mchi'o/ /

“We will see that country yet, Preceptor, if only for a short while. We will bathe on the banks of the river, we will serve the bull among teachers, we will defeat opponents, and we will make a name for ourselves and find our fortune, too. We will go to the Middle Country.”

bram ze de slob ma la rjes su chags pa dang bcas pa dang / 'khor nyung ba yin pas des bram ze'i khye'u de dag la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bu dag gal te de lta na g.yang gzhi dag dang / shing shun dag dang / dbyu gu dag dang / blugs gzar dag dang / dgang gzar dag dang / ril ba dag long shig dang yul dbus su 'dong ngo / /

As the brahmin was attached to his students and his circle of students was small, he said to the young brahmins, “In that case, my sons, let us gather our hides, bast robes, staffs, water jugs, ladles, and bowls and go to the Middle Country.”[75]

de dag gis de dag blangs nas bram ze de bram ze'i khye'u de dag dang lhan cig yul dbus su 'phags pa dang / des rgol ba kha cig ni tshar bcad de rgol ba'i shing rta la sbyor bar byed/ kha cig ni mgor thal ba'i bum pa dag gis bsnun/ kha cig ni 'phong gi dpong sar khwa bzhin du thag ring po nas yongs su spong bar byed/ kha cig ni gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dag gis bsu bar byed/ kha cig ni slob ma nyid du khas len par byed cing de mthar gyis grong dang / grong khyer dang / grong rdal dang / dbye tshongs dang / tshong rdal dag tu rgol ba 'dul zhing rgyal po'i khab tu phyin to/ /

Having collected their things, the brahmin set off with the young brahmins for the Middle Country. Along the way, he defeated an opponent in debate, and then bound him to his chariot. He poured ashes from a pot on another’s head. Another steered clear of him like a crow does an archery range. Another received him with parasols, victory banners, and standards. Another made a pledge to become his student. As he went, he vanquished one opponent after another in villages, cities, towns, marketplaces, and hamlets until he reached Rājagṛha.

bram ze skar rgyal gyis bsams pa/ bdag gis ci'i phyir rtsa ba spangs te yal ga dang / 'dab ma dang / lo ma la nyug par bya/ rgol ba gang dag dang / mkhas par bgrang ba gang ji snyed pa de dag thams cad kyang rgyal po dang nye ba yin gyis/ bdag kyang rgyal po'i gan du 'gro'o snyam nas

The brahmin Tiṣya thought, “Why bother pulling off the branches, petals, and leaves while leaving the root? Since all worthy opponents and anyone counted as learned will be close to the king, it is the king I shall see.” [S.5.a.6]

bram ze skar rgyal rgyal po gzugs can snying po ga la ba der song ste phyin nas/ rgyal po gzugs can snying po la rgyal ba dang tshe spel ba byas te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / phyogs gcig tu 'dug nas rgyal po gzugs can snying po la 'di skad ces smras so/ / lha bdag la bla ma las yi ge nyung shas shig blangs pa mchis te/ de'i slad du lha'i spyan sngar rgol ba dag dang lhan cig bka' mchid rnam par gtan la dbab par 'tshal lo/ /

In time the brahmin Tiṣya went to see King Bimbisāra. On arriving, he wished the king success and long life, took a place off to one side, and addressed him: “Your Majesty, from my guru I have received a few teachings. And so [F.12.a] I seek to settle a matter in debate with an opponent in Your Majesty’s presence.”
rgyal pos blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag mkhan po gnas len gyi bu de gang na 'dug /lha grong na la da na'o/ /
The king asked the ministers, “Gentlemen, where is Preceptor Māṭhara?” “In Nālada, Your Majesty.”
mkhan po gnas len gyi bu de bos shig /lha bod par bgyi'o zhes
“Summon Preceptor Māṭhara.” “As you wish, Your Majesty.”

de dag gis de bos nas de rgyal po gzugs can snying po ga la ba der song ste phyin nas/ rgyal po gzugs can snying po la rgyal ba dang tshe spel ba byas te phyogs gcig tu 'dug pa dang blon po rnams kyis smras pa/ lha mkhan po de 'di lags so/ /

On receiving the summons, Māṭhara went to see King Bimbisāra. On arrival, he wished the king success and long life then took a place off to one side. The ministers said, “This is the preceptor, Your Majesty.”

rgyal pos 'ongs pa legs so/ / zhes bya ba'i tshig gis kun du spyad de smras pa/ mkhan po khyod kho bo'i mdun du bram ze skar rgyal dang lhan cig gtam rnam par gtan la dbab pa byed nus sam/ gnas len gyi bus smras pa/ bdag gis rngo thog gis rgyal po dgyes par bgyi'o/ /

The king greeted him with words of welcome and asked, “Preceptor, can you settle a matter in debate in my presence with this brahmin Tiṣya?” “I, as a capable man, shall do as the king pleases,” replied Māṭhara.

rgyal pos blon po rnams la bsgo ba/ shes ldan dag rgol ba'i dkyil 'khor shoms shig /phyogs dang gzhan gyi phyogs dag rnam par zhog shig /blon po rnams kyis rgol ba'i dkyil 'khor bshams shing phyogs dang gzhan gyi phyogs dag rnam par bzhag go/ / de nas blon po rnams kyis rgyal po'i rkang pa gnyis la phyag 'tshal te smras pa/ lha phyogs snga ma gang bgyid du stsal/ rgyal pos smras pa/ bram ze skar rgyal 'di 'gron pa yin gyis/ 'di phyogs snga ma byed du chug shig /

The king ordered the ministers, “Gentlemen, prepare the debate arena and assign the disputants their roles.” The ministers prepared the debate arena and assigned the disputants their roles. The ministers then prostrated at the king’s feet and asked, “Your Majesty, who would you have defend a position first?” “The brahmin Tiṣya is a visitor so have him defend a position first.”

bram ze skar rgyal gyis smras pa/ lha bram ze gnas len gyi bu 'di rgan pa lags pas 'di phyogs snga ma bgyid du stsal par gsol/ bram ze gnas len gyi bus bsams pa/ bram ze skar rgyal 'di gzhung gsar la byed pa gsal bas bdag gis 'di dang lhan cig smra bar mi nus kyis/ je 'di dang lhan cig tshig 'gred pa zhig bya'o snyam nas des rgyud chags lnga brgya bzlas so/ /

“Your Majesty,” said he brahmin Tiṣya, “as the brahmin Māṭhara is the elder, I ask that you have him defend a position first.” The brahmin Māṭhara thought, “This brahmin Tiṣya is clearly acquainted with new treatises so I cannot debate him on them. I shall focus on an old text.” And with that he recited five hundred lines.

bram ze skar rgyal gyis phyir bzlas te/ khyod kyi 'di ni rigs pa med pa yin no/ / 'di ni mi mthun pa yin no/ / 'di ni mi 'thad pa yin no zhes skyon btags pa dang / bram ze gnas len gyi bu cang mi smra bar 'dug go/ /

The brahmin Tiṣya repeated them and [S.5.b] then declared, “This position of yours is devoid of logic. It is inconsistent and incoherent.” The other brahmin remained silent as Tiṣya pointed out the text’s flaws. [F.12.b]

tshar bcad pa'i gnas rnams kyi nang na 'di lta ste len la spobs pa med pa 'di ni tha chad yin no/ / rgyal pos blon po rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag su rgyal/ bram ze skar rgyal rgyal lo/ / shes ldan dag bram ze skar rgyal la rgol ba'i longs spyod byin cig /

That Māṭhara had no confidence to respond[76] was damning and among the reasons he was vanquished. The king asked the ministers, “Gentlemen, who won?” “The brahmin Tiṣya, Your Majesty.” “Gentlemen, give the brahmin Tiṣya a victor’s prize.”

de dag gis smras pa/ lha gal te skol gyis rgol ba mchis shing lhags dgu la rgol ba'i longs spyod stsal bar gyur na ring po mi thogs par skol gyi yul ang ga dang ma ga d+hA dag rgol ba'i longs spyod du 'gyur bas/ 'di ltar grong na la da 'di nyid rgol ba'i longs spyod kyi ba dan du bgyis la bram ze gnas len gyi bu las phrogs te/ bram ze 'di la stsal cing 'di bas kyang ches rgyal ba gzhan 'ga' zhig mchis na yang skol gyis de la stsal bar bgyi'o/ /

“Your Majesty,” they replied, “if you give a prize to everyone who wins a debate, before long your lands of Aṅga and Magadha will themselves be victors’ prizes. Therefore make the village of Nālada the standard victor’s prize. Take it from the brahmin Māṭhara and give it to this brahmin. And if any other should best Tiṣya, then award it to the victor.”

rgyal pos smras pa/ shes ldan dag de bzhin gyis shig /de dag gis de gnas len gyi bu las phrogs te bram ze skar rgyal la byin no/ / gnas len gyi bus bsams pa/ bdag gis rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis bdag rjes su ma bsrungs kyis/ bdag gzhan du 'gro'o snyam nas

“Gentlemen,” said the king, “that is what I shall do.” The village was then taken from the brahmin Māṭhara and given to the brahmin Tiṣya. The brahmin Māṭhara thought, “Though I have done much for this king, he has not taken care of me. I shall go elsewhere.”
des chung ma la smras pa/ bzang mo kho bos rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis kho bo rjes su ma bsrungs kyis kho bo gzhan du 'gros khyim gyi so nam dag sdus shig /
He said to his wife, “Noble lady, though I have done much for this king, he has not taken care of me. I shall go elsewhere. So pack up our household.”

des khyim gyi so nam dag bsdu bar brtsams pa dang / de'i nye du dag gis mkhan po gnas len gyi bu gzhan du 'gro'o/ /zhes thos nas de dag de'i gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ mkhan po ci'i slad du khyim gyi so nam dag sdud/
With that they began packing up their household. When their relatives heard that the master Preceptor was leaving, they went to see him and asked, “Preceptor, why are you packing up your household?”

des smras pa/ shes ldan dag kho bos rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis kho bo rjes su ma bsrungs kyis kho bo gzhan du 'gro'o/ / de dag gis smras pa/ mkhan po khyod gzhan du ma bzhud par re zhig nye du'i nang 'di nyid du bde bar bzhugs shig /

“Gentlemen, though I have done much for this king, he has not taken care of me. Therefore, I shall go elsewhere.” “Preceptor, do not leave for other parts. Remain for a while, at your leisure, in the home of your relatives.”
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ mi ni gzhan gyi yul na gnas bla yi/ / rang gi yul na zil gnon gnas pa min/ / mi ni gang na zil gnon med gnas pa/ / de nyid rang yul de na gnyen yang yod/ /
Māṭhara replied in verse: “Better to live in another’s land Than to be oppressed in one’s own. There where a man lives free Is the place he finds his home and friends.” [F.13.a]

bram ze skar rgyal gyis mkhan po gnas len gyi bu gzhan du 'gro'o zhes thos nas de de'i gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ bdag ni blo bur du 'ongs pa yin pas ring po mi thogs pa kho nar 'gro ste/ 'di khyod nyid kyi rgol ba'i longs spyod du 'gyur gyis gzhan du ma 'gro bar 'dug shig /

When the brahmin Tiṣya heard that the preceptor Māṭhara was to leave, he went to him and said, “I have come only for a short time[77] and before long am certain to go. Let this remain your victor’s prize. Do not leave, you must stay.”
des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u 'gro'o/ / mkhan po gal te de lta na grong 'di phyed khyod snoms shig /phyed bdag 'tshal lo/ /
Māṭhara replied, “I intend to leave, young brahmin.” “Preceptor, if that is how you feel, you should keep half of this village and I shall keep claim to the other half.”

bram ze gnas len gyi bus bsams pa/ bdag gis rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis bdag rjes su ma bsrungs te/ 'di ltar bram ze skar rgyal 'dis bdag la 'di lta ste/ longs spyod dag gis longs spyod kyi bgo bsha' byas pa ni phan mang du btags pa yin gyis/ 'di la shA ri kA de chung ma'i don du sbyin no snyam nas

Māṭhara thought, “Though I have done much for this king, he has not taken care of me. Yet out of consideration for me, this brahmin Tiṣya has offered to share our prize‍—a most beneficial arrangement. I will give Śārikā to him as a wife.”

des chung ma la smras pa/ bzang mo kho bos rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis kho bo rjes su ma bsrungs te/ 'di ltar bram ze skar rgyal 'dis kho bo la 'di lta ste/ longs spyod dag gis longs spyod kyi bgo bsha' byas pa ni phan mang du btags pa yin gyis/ 'di la shA ri kA de chung ma'i don du sbyin no/ / des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u stod rings la dri'o/ /

Māṭhara then said to his wife, “Noble lady, though I have done much for this king, he has not taken care of me. Yet out of consideration for me, this brahmin Tiṣya has offered to share our prize‍—a most beneficial arrangement. I shall give Śārikā to him as a wife. Call our son, Koṣṭhila.”

de gnyis kyis de bos te smras pa/ bu bdag cag gis rgyal po 'di la phan mang du btags na rgyal po 'dis bdag cag rjes su ma bsrungs te/ 'di ltar bram ze skar rgyal 'dis bdag cag la 'di lta ste/ longs spyod dag gis longs spyod kyi bgo bsha' byas pa ni phan mang du btags pa yin gyis/ 'di la shA ri kA de chung ma'i don du sbyin par bya'o/ /

His parents summoned Koṣṭhila and said, “Son, though we have done much for this king, he has not taken care of us. Yet, out of consideration for me, this brahmin Tiṣya has offered to share our prize‍—a most beneficial arrangement. I shall give Śārikā to him as a wife.”
