des smras pa/ yab yum de ltar dgra bo la mdza' bshes su bgyis na 'di lta ste/ des longs spyod rnams las nyams par bgyid pa'am/ thams cad kyi thams cad du srog dang 'bral bar bgyid par yang 'gyur la/ des bdag cag longs spyod dag las nyams par bgyis na/ ci'i slad du skol gyis 'di la shA ri kA mchis brang gi don du stsal bar bgyi/

Koṣṭhila replied, “Father! Mother! How could I accept this enemy into our family? Hasn’t he robbed[78] us of our livelihood? Anyone else in our position would try to take his life. If he has robbed us so, why would you give Śārikā to him in marriage?”

de gnyis kyis smras pa/ blun po khyod ci shes zhes de gnyis kyis de'i tshig tshig ma yin par byas te shA ri kA bram ze skar rgyal la chung ma'i don du byin no/ / des de dpal gyi 'byor pa chen pos bag mar blangs so/ /
His parents [F.13.b] said, “Fool! What do you know?” Ignoring what he said, they gave Śārikā to the brahmin Tiṣya as a wife. In a lavish ceremony, Tiṣya took Śārikā as his bride.

bram ze'i khye'u stod rings kyis bsams pa/ 'di dag gis bdag brnyas par gyur pa gang yin pa de thams cad ni thos pa nyung ba las gyur pa yin no snyam nas 'di ltar bram ze skar rgyal ci zhig shes snyam na/ 'jig rten rgyang 'phen shes so snyam nas
The young brahmin Koṣṭhila thought, “This insult is all due to my lack of learning.” He thought, “What does the brahmin Tiṣya know? He knows Lokāyata philosophy.”
des smras pa/ shes ldan dag 'jig rten rgyang 'phen shes pa ga la yod/ lho phyogs na'o/ /
He asked around, “Gentlemen, where is the Lokāyata philosophy known?” “In the South,” he was told.

de 'jig rten rgyang 'phen gyi don du lho phyogs su 'phags nas de mthar gyis lho phyogs su phyin pa dang / de der song ste dris pa/ shes ldan dag 'jig rten rgyang 'phen shes pa su dag yin/ kun du rgyu dag go/ /
He set out into the realm, for the South,to learn Lokāyata philosophy. On arrival, he inquired, “Gentlemen, who knows the Lokāyata philosophy?” “The wandering mendicants.”
de de dag gi gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ bdag shes ldan dag gi zhabs la sri zhu bgyid par 'tshal lo/ / ci zhig gi phyir/ 'jig rten rgyang 'phen gzung ba'i slad du'o/ /
He went to them and said, “I seek to serve you, gentlemen.” “Why?” “So that I may grasp the Lokāyata philosophy.”
de dag gis smras pa/ kho bo cag ni khyim pa la 'jig rten rgyang 'phen mi ston to/ / des smras pa/ gal te de lta na rab tu 'byung ngo / /
“We do not teach Lokāyata philosophy to householders.” “In that case, I shall go forth.”

de dag gis de rab tu phyung nas des bdag gis ji srid du 'jig rten rgyang 'phen ma bzung ba de srid du bdag gis sen mo mi gcad do zhes des sen mo ring po ring por bzhag nas de'i sen mo ring ba ring bar gyur pas de'i ming kun du rgyu sen rings kun du rgyu sen rings zhes bya bar gyur to/ /

After they allowed his going forth, he said, [S.6.a] “So long as I uphold the Lokāyata philosophy, I will not cut my fingernails.” So he let his fingernails grow extraordinarily long and for this he became known as the wandering mendicant Dīrghanakha (He Who Has Long Fingernails).

shA ri kA yang bram ze skar rgyal dang lhan cig 'gyed par byed pa na skar rgyal gyis de tshar bcad do/ / bram ze skar rgyal shA ri kA dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa na sems can srid pa tha ma pa spyod pa tshol ba/ thar pa'i snying po bzung ba/ mya ngan las 'das pa la phyogs pa/ 'khor ba las phyir phyogs pa/ srid pa'i 'gro ba thams cad du 'chi 'pho dang skye ba don du mi gnyer ba/ lus tha ma 'dzin pa zhig kyang lha'i ris bzang po zhig nas shi 'phos te shA ri kA'i mngal du zhugs so/ /

When Śārikā challenged her husband Tiṣya, he vanquished her. Later, as Tiṣya and Śārikā played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another, a sentient being in search of his final rebirth, who had grasped the essence of liberation, who had turned to nirvāṇa and away from saṃsāra, who had seen that all births end in death, who did not seek to be reborn, and who was to take his last body, died and passed from the lofty heights of a god and entered Śārikā’s womb.

shA ri kAs rmi lam du mi lag na sgron ma thogs pa zhig gis bdag gi dku dral te zhugs shing bdag ri chen po'i spo la 'dzeg go/ / bdag steng gi nam mkha' la 'gro'o/ / bdag la skye bo phal po che'i tshogs phyag 'tshal lo zhes zer ba rmis so/ / rmis nas des bram ze skar rgyal la smras pa/ bdag gis rmi lam 'di dang 'di lta bu zhig rmis so/ / 'di ltar bram ze skar rgyal nyid rmi ltas kyi dpyad la mkhas pa yin mod kyi/ des bram ze rmi ltas kyi dpyad 'don pa gzhan dag la smras pa/ bdag gi bram ze mos rmi lam 'di dang 'di lta bu zhig rmis na ci la lta/

Śārikā dreamed that a man carrying a torch [F.14.a] rent and entered her belly. She climbed to a mountain peak. She moved through the sky above. An assembly of great men prostrated to her. She then told Tiṣya about her dream. Though Tiṣya was expert at interpreting dreams and omens, he consulted other brahmins who interpreted them. “What does it portend,” he asked, “if my brahmin wife has had such a dream?”

de dag gis smras pa/ mkhan po g.yar lam de bzang ste/ mi lag na sgron ma thogs pa zhig gis bdag gi dku dral te zhugs zhes mchi ba ni bu btsa' bar 'gyur zhing des lo brgyad gnyis kyis dbang po'i brda sprod pa bklags nas rgol ba thams cad tshar gcod par 'gyur ba la lta'o/ / bdag ri chen po'i spo la 'dzeg go/ / bdag steng gi nam mkha' la 'gro'o/ / bdag la skye bo phal po che'i tshogs phyag 'tshal lo zhes mchi ba gang lags pa ni rab tu byung nas brtul zhugs grub pa'i bdag nyid chen por 'gyur ba la lta'o/ /

They replied, “Preceptor, that is an excellent portent. Her statement, ‘A man carrying a torch rent and entered my belly,’ indicates a son will be born. It portends that, after twice eight years, he will have studied the Aindra school of grammar[79] and will vanquish all opponents. She said, ‘I climbed to a mountain peak. I moved through the sky above. An assembly of great men prostrated to me.’ These statements indicate her son will go forth and become a great saint who perfects his vow.”

dus gzhan zhig na bram ze skar rgyal shA ri kA dang lhan cig 'gyed par byed pa na shA ri kAs de tshar bcad nas/ des bsams pa/ sngon bdag gis 'di tshar bcad na da 'dis bdag tshar bcad pa'i sbyor ba gang yin snyam nas des bsams pa/ de ni 'di'i mthu ma yin gyi/ 'di ltar 'di'i mngal du sems can zhugs pa gang yin pa de'i mthu yin no snyam mo/ /

The next time Tiṣya and Śārikā engaged in debate, Śārikā vanquished him, making him wonder, “If I have vanquished her in the past, what now has allowed her to vanquish me?” He thought, “It is because of the being who has entered her womb.”

de nas zla ba brgyad dam dgu 'das te khye'u gzugs bzang ba/ blta na sdug pa/ mdzes pa/ gsal ba/ gser gyi mdog 'dra ba/ mgo gdugs lta bu dang ldan pa/ lag pa ring ba/ 'phral ba'i dbyes che ba/ smin ma 'jar ba/ sna'i gzengs mtho ba zhig btsas so/ / btsas nas des bram ze skar rgyal la smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u 'di mes po'i gan du phul na de 'di'i ming 'dogs par 'gyur ro/ /

After eight or nine months, a boy was born, well proportioned, pleasing to the eye, handsome, radiant, with a golden complexion, a head shaped well like a parasol, long arms, a broad forehead,[80] eyebrows that met, and a prominent nose. After his birth, Śārikā said to Tiṣya, “If we present this brahmin boy to his grandfather, he will give him a name.”

des mes po'i gan du khrid pa dang des khye'u'i ming cir gdags zhes bsams na/ bram ze'i khye'u 'di bram ze skar rgyal gyi bu yin pas/ bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i ming nye rgyal du gdags so snyam nas de'i ming nye rgyal zhes bya bar btags so/ /

They took him to his grandfather Māṭhara, who [F.14.b] thought about what he should name the baby boy. “This brahmin boy is the son of the brahmin Tiṣya so I shall name this brahmin boy Upatiṣya.” And with that he named him Upatiṣya (Tiṣya’s Heir).

bram ze skar rgyal gyis smras pa/ mes pos bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i ming cir btags nye rgyal zhes bya bar btags so/ / des bsams pa/ mes pos bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i ming pha las dras te btags kyis/ bdag gis 'di'i ming ma las dras te gdags so snyam nas bram ze'i khye'u 'di ma shA ri kA'i bu yin pas 'di'i ming shA ri'i bur gdags so snyam nas de'i ming shA ri'i bu zhes bya bar btags so/ /

Tiṣya said, “His grandfather thought of a name for this brahmin boy and chose Upatiṣya.” He thought, “His grandfather has named this brahmin boy after his father so I shall name him after his mother. Since this brahmin boy is the son of his mother Śārikā, I shall name him Śāriputra.” And with that he was named Śāriputra (Śārikā’s Son).
de na kha cig gis ni bram ze'i khye'u shA ri'i bu zhes bya bar shes so/ / kha cig gis ni bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal zhes bya bar shes so/ /
It was thus that the young brahmin was known to some as Śāriputra, while to others he was known as Upatiṣya.

bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal ma ma brgyad po pang na 'tsho ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / nu ma snun pa'i ma ma gnyis dang / dri ma 'phyi ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / rtsen grogs kyi ma ma gnyis la rjes su gtad do/ / de ma ma brgyad po dag gis 'o ma dang / zho dang / mar dang / zhun mar dang / mar gyi snying khu dang / gzhan yang yo byad kyi bye brag gtso bo gtso bo dag gis sring bar byed/ skyed par byed cing rdzing na gnas pa'i pad ma bzhin myur du skyed par byed do/ / de gang gi tshe chen por gyur pa de'i tshe yi ge dang / grangs dang / rtsis dang / lag rtsis dang / dbyung ba dang / gzhug pa dang / gzhag pa dang / 'byed pa dang / klog pa'i pha rol du son cing / de'i tshe na bram ze'i spyod tshul dang / spyod pa dang / gtsang sbra dang / kun du spyod pa dang / thal ba blang ba dang / bya ma bum blang ba dang / sa blang ba dang / lag stangs dang / thor tshugs dang / rab bsngags bya ba dang / kye zhes bya ba dang / nges brjod kyi rig byed dang / mchod sbyin gyi rig byed dang / snyan tshig gi rig byed dang / srid srung gi rig byed dang / bram ze'i las drug po mchod sbyin byed pa dang / mchod sbyin byed du 'jug pa dang / klog pa dang / klog tu 'jug pa dang / sbyin pa dang / len pa la mkhas pa'i bram ze rig byed dang rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol du son pa/ me lta bu'i shes pas rang gi smra ba gsal bar byed pa/ gzhan gyi smra ba tshar gcod nus par gyur to/ /

Upatiṣya was entrusted to eight nursemaids: two to cuddle him, two to breastfeed him, two to change his diapers, and two to play with him.[81] Fortified with milk, curd, butter, ghee, cream, [S.6.b] and other nourishing foods, he grew quickly, shooting up like a lotus in a pond. When he was old enough, he was introduced to letters, number names, calculation, counting by hand, and how to exclude, to add, to leave, and to parse until he had mastered reciting. He was then instructed in the ways of brahmins: their conduct, ritual purity, and observances; the handling of ashes, the handling of ritual vases, and the handling of sites; hand gestures, turbans, offering praise, and salutations; the Ṛgveda, the Yajurveda, the Sāmaveda, and the Atharvaveda; and a brahmin’s six duties‍—making fire sacrifices, officiating over fire sacrifices, studying, teaching, [F.15.a] giving, and receiving. The Vedas and the limbs of the Vedas were entrusted to him, and with his blazing intelligence he could illuminate his own assertions and vanquish those of others.
des phas rig pa'i gnas thams cad slob tu bcug nas des lo brgyad gnyis kyis dbang po'i brda sprod pa bklags nas rgol ba thams cad tshar bcad par gyur to/ /
His father made him study all fields of knowledge, and thus by the age of sixteen he had studied the Aindra school of grammar and could vanquish all opponents.

de dus gzhan zhig na pha dang lhan cig rig byed 'don par byed pa na smras pa/ yab smras pa 'di'i don ci lags/ bu kho bos kyang smras pa 'di'i don mi shes te 'di ltar gsang tshig gi gzhi 'di dag ni sngon gyi drang srong rnams kyis bstod pa bsgrags pa yang dag par sbyar ba ste/ de dag ni da ltar bram ze rnams kyang rjes su sgrogs shing rjes su rjod par byed do/ /

At another time when he was reciting the Vedas with his father, he asked, “Father, what is the meaning of this statement?” “Son, even I do not know the meaning of this statement. But these sacred mantra[82] have been recited with praise, sung, and furnished by past sages. Nowadays brahmins simply recite and repeat them.”

yab gsang tshig gi gzhi sngon gyi drang srong de rnams kyis bstod pa bsgrags pa yang dag par sbyar ba gang dag da ltar bram ze rnams rjes su sgrogs shing rjes su rjod pa de dag don ma mchis lags snyam mam/ ci 'di ltar smras pa 'di'i don ni 'di lags so/ / smras pa/ 'di'i don ni 'di lags so/ /

“Father, do you think there is no meaning to these sacred mantra, which have been recited with praise, sung, and furnished by past sages, but nowadays are simply recited and repeated by brahmins? This is what such statements mean,” and he proceeded to explain.

bram ze skar rgyal yid dga' zhing yid dga' nas bsams pa/ bus bya ba ni 'di lta ste/ pha'i gzhung srongs par bya ba'am/ khyad par lhag par rtogs par bya ba de tsam du zad na bram ze'i khye'u 'dis ni bdag pas khyad par lhag par rtogs so snyam nas/

Tiṣya was delighted and in his delight thought, “This is what a son should do: he should carry on his father’s tradition or develop his insight even further. Were he to accomplish only this, this brahmin boy’s insight would surpass my own.”

de bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug pa de dag kyang des yid dga' zhing dga' bas de nyid la gtad do/ / bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug pa na des rig byed ring po ring po gang dag yin pa de dag ni thung ngur rnam par bzhag go/ / rig byed thung ngu thung ngu gang dag yin pa de dag ni ring por rnam par bzhag ste tshig dang yi ge phri zhing don dang nges pa'i tshig tu rnam par bzhag go// //

He shared this insight with the five hundred young brahmins he was teaching to recite brahmanic mantras and they too were delighted and happily turned to Upatiṣya. When the young brahmin Upatiṣya taught the five hundred young brahmins to recite brahmanic mantras, he summarized the longer Vedas, abridging their words and phrases, and expanded on the shorter Vedas, explaining their meaning and etymologies.
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po gnyis pa/

grong shing thags can na bram ze mdun na 'don gru 'dzin ces bya ba phyug pa nor mang ba longs spyod che ba/ yongs su bzung ba/ yangs shing rgya che ba/ rnam thos kyi bu'i nor dang ldan pa/ rnam thos kyi bu la nor gyis 'gran pa zhig 'dug ste/ des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas/ de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de la bu yang med bu mo yang med nas/ de bu med cing bu mngon par 'dod pas zhi ba dang / chu lha dang / lus ngan dang / brgya byin dang / tshangs pa la sogs pa dag la gsol ba 'debs shing / lha'i bye brag gzhan 'di lta ste/ kun dga' ra ba'i lha dag dang / tshal gyi lha dag dang / bzhi mdo'i lha dag dang / sum mdo'i lha dag dang / gtor ma len pa'i lha dag dang / lhan cig skyes pa dag dang / chos mthun pa dag dang / rtag tu rjes su 'brang ba'i lha dag la yang gsol ba 'debs so/ /

In the village of Kāṣṭhavāṭa, there lived a royal priest [F.15.b] named Potalaka who was wealthy with many riches and goods, with holdings both vast and extensive, with riches to rival Vaiśravaṇa. He took a wife of equal caste and with her played, took pleasure, and amused himself. After their play, lovemaking, and the indulgence of all their desires resulted in no child, male or female, the childless couple, badly wanting a child, propitiated Śiva, Varuṇa, Kubera, Śakra, Brahmā, and others. Among the different gods were gods of park shrines, gods of the forest, gods of crossroads, gods of intersections, gods who take votive offerings, birth totem gods, gods who adhere to the Dharma, and gods who always shadow you.

'jig rten na gang gsol ba 'debs pa'i rgyu las bu dang bu mo dag skye'o zhes bya ba'i gtam de lta bu yod de/ de ni de lta ma yin te gal te de ltar 'gyur du zin na re re la yang 'di lta ste dper na 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po bzhin du bu stong yod par 'gyur ro/ / 'di ltar gnas gsum po dag mngon du gyur pa las bu dang bu mo dag skye bar 'gyur te/ gsum po de dag gang zhe na/ pha dang ma gnyis chags par gyur cing 'dus pa dang / ma dus la bab cing zla mtshan dang ldan pa dang / dri za nye bar gnas shing 'jug par 'dod pa ste/ gnas gsum po de dag mngon du gyur pa las bu dang bu mo dag skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

There is a saying, “Boys and girls are born in the world because they are prayed for.” But that is not so, for if it were, then each and every man would have a thousand sons, as do the kings of the world. Rather, boys and girls are born when three circumstances are present. What are those three? The mother and father feel desire and couple; it is the right time and the mother is ovulating; and a gandharva is near and wants to be reborn. And so it is that boys and girls are born when those three circumstances are present.[83]

de de ltar gsol ba 'debs pa lhur len cing 'dug pa na/ sems can srid pa tha ma pa spyod pa tshol ba/ thar pa'i snying po bzung ba/ mya ngan las 'das pa la phyogs pa/ 'khor ba las phyir phyogs pa/ srid pa'i 'gro ba thams cad du 'chi 'pho dang / skye ba don du mi gnyer ba/ lus tha ma 'dzin pa zhig kyang lha'i ris bzang po zhig nas shi 'phos te de'i skye dgu'i bdag mo'i mngal du zhugs so/ /

As Potalaka sat engrossed in prayer, a being in search of his final rebirth, who had grasped the essence of liberation, who had turned to nirvāṇa and away from saṃsāra, who had seen that all births end in death, who did not seek to be reborn, and who was to take his last body, died and passed from the lofty heights of a god and entered his wife’s womb.

bud med mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can la la la ma 'dres pa'i chos lnga yod de/ lnga gang zhe na/ skyes pa chags par gyur pa shes shing chags pa dang bral ba shes pa dang / dus shes shing zla mtshan shes pa dang / mngal na gnas pa zhugs par shes pa dang / gang las mngal na gnas pa zhugs pa de shes pa dang / khye'u shes shing bu mo shes pa ste/ gal te khye'u yin na dku g.yas par rten cing 'dug la/ gal te bu mo yin na dku g.yon par rten cing 'dug pa'o/ /

Certain women, endowed with natural intelligence, have five unique qualities. What are the five? [F.16.a] They know when a man feels desire and when he does not; they know when the time comes and when they are ovulating; they know when they have conceived; they know whence the conceived child came; and they know whether it is a boy or a girl. If it is a boy, he lies with his head to the right side of the womb. If it is a girl, she lies with her head to the left side of the womb.

de yid dga' zhing yid dga' nas khyim thab la smras pa/ rje'i sras bdag la sems can zhugs par gyur pa ni 'di ltar bdag gis dku g.yas par rten cing mchis pas nges par khye'ur 'gyur gyis dgyes pa bskyed du gsol/
Delighted, Potalaka’s wife joyfully told her husband, “Son of a lord! I am with child! And as it lies with its head to the right side of my womb, it is sure to be a boy, so pray be happy!”

de yang yid dga' zhing yid dga' nas ro stod bsrang ste lag pa g.yas pa brkyang nas 'di skad ces kho bo yun ring po nas mngon par 'dod pa bu'i ngo mthong ba dang / kho bo dang mthun par skye zhing mi mthun par mi skye ba dang / kho bo'i bya ba dag byed pa dang / gsos pas phyir gso ba dang / bgo skal la spyod pa dang / kho bo'i rigs rgyud ring du gnas par sgrub pa dang / bdag cag shi zhing dus la bab pa dag la nyung ngu'am/ mang po yang rung ba'i sbyin pa dag byin zhing bsod nams dag byas nas 'di de gnyis gang du skyes shing 'gro ba'i rjes su 'gro bar gyur cig ces ming gis yon sngo ba byed par gyur cig ces ched du brjod pa ched du rjod par byed do/ /

Potalaka too was delighted. He sat straight up, raised his right hand, and exclaimed with great joy, “At last, I shall look on the face of the son I have wanted for so long! May we get along and not disagree. May he carry on my work and, having been nurtured, nurture in return. May he enjoy his inheritance and ensure that my line lasts long. When our time comes and we die, may he make the appropriate offerings, neither too few nor too many. And may he dedicate the merit he thus accrues to us by name, saying, ‘May this merit follow the two of them wherever they be born, wherever they go.’ ”

de la sems can zhugs par rig nas 'di lta ste/ mngal na gnas pa yongs su smin par bya ba'i phyir steng gi khang bzangs kyi gzhir grang ba na grang ba'i yo byad dag dang / dro ba na dro ba'i yo byad dag dang / sman pas bcas pa'i zas ha cang yang mi kha ba dang / ha cang yang mi skyur ba dang / ha cang yang lan tshwa mi che ba dang / ha cang mi mngar ba dang / ha cang mi tsha ba dang / ha cang mi bska ba dang / kha ba dang / skyur ba dang / lan tshwa dang / mngar ba dang / tsha ba dang / bska ba rnam par spangs pa'i zas dag dang / do shal dang / se mo do dang / rgyan gyis bklubs pa'i lus lha'i bu mo dga' ba'i tshal na rnam par spyod pa lta bu dang / khri nas khrir dang / khri'u nas khri'ur rgyu zhing shod kyis gzhir mi 'bab pa dang / des sgra yid du mi 'ong ba cung zad kyang mi thos par gnod pa med pa nyid du rim gro byed du 'dzud do/ /

Knowing she was with child, to ensure she carried the child to term he installed his wife on the top story of their mansion where he saw that she was tended to and did not come to harm. When it was cold, she was given what she needed for the cold. When it was hot, she was given what she needed for the heat. On the doctor’s advice, her food was not to be too bitter, too sour, too salty, too sweet, too spicy, or too astringent; and so she was given food that was not bitter, sour, salty, sweet, spicy, or astringent. Her body was festooned in garlands, necklaces, and jewelry, like a goddess at play in a garden. [F.16.b] She moved from bed to throne, from pedestal to pedestal, the soles of her feet never touching the floor, and she never heard anything even slightly unpleasant. [S.7.a]

de zla ba brgyad dam dgu 'das te khye'u gzugs bzang ba/ blta na sdug pa/ mdzes pa/ gsal ba gser gyi mdog 'dra ba/ mgo gdugs lta bu dang ldan pa/ lag pa ring ba/ 'phral ba'i dbyes che ba/ smin ma 'jar ba/ sna'i gzengs mtho ba zhig btsas so/ / btsas nas de'i nye du dag 'dus shing lhags nas nyi ma bdun gsum nyi shu gcig tu btsas pa'i btsas ston rgya cher byas nas khye'u'i ming cir gdags zhes ming 'dogs par byed do/ / khye'u 'di lha pang du blangs nas thob pas/ bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i ming pang nas skyes su gdags so snyam nas de'i ming pang nas skyes zhes bya bar btags so/ /

After eight or nine months had passed, a boy was born, well proportioned, pleasing to the eye, handsome, radiant, with a golden complexion, a head shaped well like a parasol, long arms, a broad forehead, eyebrows that met, and a prominent nose. Three weeks or twenty-one days after the birth, relatives came and gathered to celebrate his birth in grand style, during which time they chose a name for the boy. As this boy had come to them from the lap of the gods, they thought the young brahmin should be named Kolita (Born from the Lap), and so he was named Kolita.
gzhan yang maud gal gyi rigs yin pas bram ze'i khye'u 'di'i ming maud gal gyi bur gdags so snyam nas de'i ming maud gal gyi bu zhes bya bar yang btags so/ /
Also, because he was a descendent of Mudgala, they thought the young brahmin should be named Maudgalyāyana (Son of Mudgala’s descendants), and so he was named Maudgalyāyana.
de na kha cig gis ni bram ze'i khye'u maud gal gyi bu zhes bya bar shes so/ / kha cig gis ni bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes zhes bya bar shes so/ /
Thus it was that some knew the young brahmin as Maudgalyāyana while others knew him as Kolita.

bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes ma ma brgyad po pang na 'tsho ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / nu ma snun pa'i ma ma gnyis dang / dri ma 'phyi ba'i ma ma gnyis dang / rtsen grogs kyi ma ma gnyis la rjes su gtad do/ / de ma ma brgyad po dag gis 'o ma dang / zho dang / mar dang / zhun mar dang / mar gyi snying khu dang / gzhan yang yo byad kyi bye brag gtso bo gtso bo dag gis sring bar byed/ skyed par byed cing rdzing na gnas pa'i pad ma bzhin myur du skyed par byed do/ / de gang gi tshe chen por gyur pa de'i tshe yi ge dang / grangs dang / rtsis dang / lag rtsis dang / dbyung ba dang / gzhug pa dang / gzhag pa dang / 'byed pa dang / klog pa'i pha rol du son cing / de'i tshe na bram ze'i spyod tshul dang / spyod pa dang / gtsang sbra dang / kun du spyod pa dang / thal ba blang ba dang / bya ma bum blang ba dang / sa blang ba dang / lag stangs dang / thor tshugs dang / rab bsngags bya ba dang / kye zhes bya ba dang / nges brjod kyi rig byed dang / mchod sbyin gyi rig byed dang / snyan tshig gi rig byed dang / srid srung gi rig byed dang / bram ze'i las drug po mchod sbyin byed pa dang / mchod sbyin byed du 'jug pa dang / klog pa dang / klog tu 'jug pa dang / sbyin pa dang / len pa la mkhas pa'i bram ze'i rig byed dang rig byed kyi yan lag gi pha rol du son pa me lta bu'i shes pas rang gi smra ba gsal bar byed pa/ gzhan gyi smra ba tshar gcod nus par gyur to/ /

The young brahmin Kolita was entrusted to eight nursemaids: two to cuddle him, two to breastfeed him, two to change his diapers, and two to play with him.[84] Fortified with milk, curd, butter, ghee, cream, and other nourishing foods, he grew quickly, shooting up like a lotus in a pond. When he was old enough, he was introduced to letters, number names, calculation, counting by hand, and how to exclude, to add, to leave, and to parse. Once he had finished letters, he was instructed in the ways of brahmins: their conduct, ritual purity, and observances; [F.17.a] the handling of ashes, the handling of ritual vases, and the handling of sites; hand gestures, turbans, offering praise, and salutations; the Ṛgveda, the Yajurveda, the Sāmaveda, and the Atharvaveda; and a brahmin’s six duties‍—making fire sacrifices, officiating over fire sacrifices, studying, teaching, giving, and receiving. He mastered and became learned in the Vedas and all branches of Vedic knowledge. The Vedas and the limbs of the Vedas were entrusted to him, and with his blazing intelligence, he could illuminate his own assertions and vanquish those of others.

de phas rig pa'i gnas thams cad slob tu bcug go/ / de dus gzhan zhig na pha dang lhan cig rig byed 'don par byed pa na smras pa/ yab smras pa 'di'i don ci lags/ bu kho bos kyang smras pa 'di'i don mi shes te/ 'di ltar gsang tshig gi gzhi 'di dag ni sngon gyi drang srong rnams kyis bstod pa bsgrags pa yang dag par sbyar ba ste/ de dag ni da ltar bram ze rnams kyang rjes su sgrogs shing rjes su rjod par byed do/ /

His father made him study all fields of knowledge. Once, when he was reciting the Vedas with his father, he asked, “Father, what does this statement mean?” “Son, even I don’t know the meaning of this statement. Sages of the past recited with praise, sung, and furnished these sacred mantra, but nowadays brahmins simply recite and repeat them.”

yab gsang tshig gi gzhi sngon gyi drang srong de rnams kyis bstod pa bsgrags pa/ yang dag par sbyar ba gang dag da ltar bram ze rnams rjes su sgrogs shing rjes su brjod pa de dag don ma mchis pa lags snyam mam ci/ 'di ltar smras pa 'di'i don ni 'di lags so/ /

“Father, do you think there is no meaning to these sacred mantra, which have been recited with praise, sung, and furnished by past sages, but nowadays are simply recited and repeated by brahmins? This is what such statements mean,” and he proceeded to explain.

bram ze gru 'dzin yid dga' zhing yid dga' nas bsams pa/ bus bya ba ni 'di lta ste/ pha'i gzhung srongs par bya ba'am/ khyad par lhag par rtogs par bya ba de tsam du zad na/ bram ze'i khye'u 'dis ni bdag pas khyad par lhag par rtogs so snyam nas

Potalaka was delighted and in his delight thought, “This is what a son should do: he should carry on his father’s tradition or develop his insight even further. Were he to accomplish only that, this brahmin boy’s insight would surpass my own.”

bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug pa de dag kyang des yid dga' zhing yid dga' bas de nyid la gtad do/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug go/ /

Potalaka shared this insight with the five hundred young brahmins he was teaching to recite brahmanic mantras and they too were delighted and happily turned to Maudgalyāyana. The young brahmin Maudgalyāyana then taught the five hundred young brahmins to recite the brahmanic mantras.

bram ze'i khye'u rnams kyi kun du spyod pa ni 'di yin te/ gang gi tshe mi klog par gyur pa de'i tshe na lan 'ga' ni chu ngogs su nye reg byed du 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni grong khyer ltar 'dong ngo / / lan 'ga' ni yam sreg shing thur 'dong ngo / /
The five hundred young brahmins were in the habit, [F.17.b] when not occupied with their studies, of going to the riverbank to bathe, visiting the city, or collecting wood for use in fire pūjas.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na de dag mi klog par gyur nas/ de'i tshe de dag grong khyer ltar dong ba dang / bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyi bram ze'i khye'u dag gsang tshig dag klog cing mdun du 'dong ngo / / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi bram ze'i khye'u dag kyang gsang tshig dag klog cing phyi bzhin 'brang zhing 'dong ngo / / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi bram ze'i khye'u de dag gis bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyi bram ze'i khye'u de dag gsang tshig gi gzhi dag klog pa thos nas de dag gis smras pa/ ci'i phyir khyed cag gsang tshig gi gzhi dag nyams par byas te klog /

Once, when not occupied with their studies, the students of the young brahmin Upatiṣya walked, reciting mantras on their way to the city. Meanwhile, trailing behind, the students of the young brahmin Maudgalyāyana walked, reciting mantras on their way to the city. When the students of the young brahmin Maudgalyāyana heard the students of the young brahmin Upatiṣya reciting the sacred mantra, they asked, “Why do you recite the sacred mantra in such a debased way?”
de dag gis smras pa/ ji ltar bklag par bya/ gsang tshig gi gzhi 'di dag ni 'di dang 'di skad ces bklag par bya'o/ /
“How should they be recited?” “The sacred mantra should be recited as we do.”

de dag gis smras pa/ khyed cag gis su las gsang tshig gi gzhi 'di dag bklags/ de dag gis smras pa/ gang gis de mi shes pa des ni nyi ma dang zla ba gnyis mi shes pa yin no/ / grong na la da na bram ze skar rgyal zhes bya ba zhig 'dug pa de'i bu bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal zhes bya ba de las bdag cag gis bklags so/ / khyed cag gis kyang su las gsang tshig gi gzhi 'di dag bklags/

“From whom did you learn these sacred mantra?” “Not to know him is not to know the sun or the moon. In the village of Nālada lives the brahmin Tiṣya. We have learned them from his son, the young brahmin Upatiṣya. And from whom did you learn these sacred mantra?”

de dag gis smras pa/ gang gis de mi shes pa des kyang nyi ma dang zla ba gnyis mi shes pa yin no/ / grong shing thags can na bram ze mdun na 'don gru 'dzin ces bya ba zhig 'dug pa de'i bu bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes zhes bya ba de las bdag cag gis bklags so/ /
“Not to know him is not to know the sun or the moon. In the village of Kāṣṭhavāṭa, there lives a royal priest named Potalaka. We have learned them from his son, the young brahmin Kolita.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyi bram ze'i khye'u rnams spa gong zhing mi dga' ba dang / mi 'jigs pa med par gyur te/ bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal ga la ba der dong ba dang des thag ring po kho na nas mthong nas smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag 'di lta ci nyes/ mkhan po cang ma nongs so/ /

With that, the young brahmin students of Upatiṣya became dispirited, upset, and daunted. They went to Upatiṣya, who saw them off in the distance and asked, “What troubles you, young brahmins? Your preceptor is never wrong.”
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ bsam pa nang na yod pa kun/ / phyi rol nas ni nye bar dmigs/ / skad mdog dbang po'i rnam pa dag / rnam par sba bar mi nus so/ /
Then he spoke in verse: [F.18.a] “Those things you feel from within Are clearly seen from without. You cannot mask your voice, Your complexion, or your mien.

bram ze'i khye'u dag gor ma chag par ci zhig nyes so/ / de dag gis skabs de rgyas par brjod pa dang des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag de de bzhin te/ ji ltar bram ze'i khye'u de dag gsang tshig gi gzhi de dag klog pa bzhin du de dag bklag par bya ba yin mod kyi/ kho bos rig byed ring po ring po gang dag yin pa de dag ni thung ngur rnam par bzhag go/ / rig byed thung ngu thung ngu gang dag yin pa de dag ni ring por rnam par bzhag ste/ tshig dang yi ge phri zhing don dang nges pa'i tshig tu rnam par bzhag go/ /

“Young brahmins, clearly something troubles you.” After they explained the situation at length, Upatiṣya said, “Young brahmins, allow me to explain. Although the sacred mantra should be recited in the manner those young brahmins recite them, I have summarized the longer Vedas, abridging their words and phrases, and expanded on the shorter Vedas, explaining their meaning and etymologies.”

bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi bram ze'i khye'u rnams kyang spa gong zhing mi dga' ba dang mi 'jigs pa med par gyur te/ bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes ga la ba der dong ba dang des kyang thag ring po kho na nas mthong nas smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag 'di lta ci nyes/ mkhan po cang ma nongs so/ /

The students of Kolita had also become dispirited, upset, and daunted. They went to Kolita, who too, on seeing them off in the distance, asked, “What troubles you, young brahmins? Your preceptor is never wrong.”

He too then spoke the verse: “Those things you feel from within Are clearly seen from without. You cannot mask your voice, Your complexion, or your mien.

“Young brahmins, clearly something troubles you.” [S.7.b] After they explained the situation at length, he said, “Young brahmins, allow me to explain. Although the sacred mantra should be recited in the manner we have recited them, that young brahmin Upatiṣya is wise for he has he summarized the longer Vedas, abridging their words and phrases, and expanded on the shorter Vedas, explaining their meaning and etymologies.”

de gnyis gcig gis gcig thos ma thag kho nar mthong 'dod par gyur nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal pha'i gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ yab bdag grong shing thags can du mchi 'tshal lo/ / ci zhig gi phyir bram ze mdun na 'don gru 'dzin ces bgyi ba zhig mchis pa de'i bu bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes zhes bgyi ba de blta ba'i slad du'o/ /

On hearing of the other, both Kolita and Upatiṣya formed a singular desire to meet the other. Upatiṣya went to his father and said, “Father, I [F.18.b] wish to visit the village of Kāṣṭhavāṭa, for there lives a royal priest named Potalaka whose son is called Kolita. I shall go to see him.”
bu de khyod pas ches shes rab can zhig yin nam ci/ yab de ni bdag pas ches shes rab can ma lags te/ 'di ltar de ni ches phyug pa lags so/ /
“Son, is he wiser than you?” “Father, he is not wiser than I. It is rather that he is wealthier.”
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ mi gang rigs kyis rgan pa dang / / na tshod rgan dang nor gyis rgan/ / de kun thos pas rgan pa yi/ / sgo na don kun gnyer bas sdod/ /
His father replied: “Some are greater due to pedigree, Others because of age or riches. But they all seek to sit At the doorstep of the learned.
bu gal te de 'ong na thos pas bgo bsha' bya'i bgrod par ni mi bya'o/ /
“Son, if he should come here you should share your learning but you mustn’t go to him.”

bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyang pha'i gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ yab bdag grong na la dar mchi 'tshal lo/ / ci zhig gi phyir de na bram ze skar rgyal zhes bgyi ba zhig mchis pa de'i bu bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal zhes bgyi ba de blta ba'i slad du mchi'o/ /
Kolita also went to his father and said, “Father, I wish to visit the village of Nālada, for there lives a brahmin Tiṣya whose son is called Upatiṣya. I shall go to see him.”
bu de khyod pas ches phyug pa zhig yin nam ci/ yab de ni bdag pas ches phyug pa ma lags te/ 'di ltar de ni ches shes rab can lags so/ /
“Son, is he wealthier than you?” “Father, he is not wealthier than I. It is rather that he is wiser.”
des kyang tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ mi gang rigs kyis rgan pa dang / / na tshod rgan dang thos pas rgan/ / de kun nor gyis rgan pa yi/ / sgo na ci bya snyam pa sdod/ /
His father replied: “Some are greater due to pedigree, Others because of age or learning. But they all sit subservient At the doorstep of the rich.
bu gal te 'ong na nor gyis bgo bsha' bya'i bgrod par ni mi bya'o/ /
“Son, if he should come here you should share your riches but you mustn’t go to him.”

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na rgyal po'i khab tu klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston la bab bo/ / rgyal po gzugs can snying po'i kun du spyod pa ni gang gi tshe klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston la bab pa de'i tshe na bdag nyid kyis nyams su myong bar byed pa'am/ yang na gzhon nu ma skyes dgra gtong bar byed do/ /

Some time later, in Rājagṛha, the feast day of the nāga kings Giri and Valguka approached. As the day neared, King Bimbisāra wondered whether he should join in the festivities himself, as was his wont, or send Prince Ajātaśatru in his stead.

ci tsam dus gzhan zhig na rgyal po gzugs can snying po la bya ba chung zhig byung nas des gzhon nu ma skyes dgra la smras pa/ bu song la klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston nyams su myong bar gyis shig /
A short time later, a small task came up, prompting King Bimbisāra to say to Prince Ajātaśatru, “Son, go and join in the festivities for the nāga kings Giri and Valguka.”

bram ze gru 'dzin gyis rgyal po gzugs can snying pos gzhon nu ma skyes dgra klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston nyams su myong bar byed du btang ba/ thos nas des bsams pa/ gzhon nu ma skyes dgra 'di pha 'das nas rgyal por 'gyur la/ bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes 'di yang bdag 'das nas mdun na 'don du 'gyur bas/ de bsten na dus su 'bras bu ster bar 'gyur ro snyam nas

When the brahmin Potalaka heard that King Bimbisāra [F.19.a] had sent Prince Ajātaśatru to join in the festivities for the nāga kings Giri and Valguka, he thought, “Prince Ajātaśatru will become king once his father dies and Kolita will become royal priest when I die. Thus their acquaintance will in time bear fruit.”

des bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la smras pa/ bu song la klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston nyams su myong bar gyis la de na stan bzhi po rgyal po'i stan dang / mdun na 'don gyi stan dang / rgol ba'i stan dang / mchog thob pa'i stan bshams pa las khyod kyis rgyal po'i gdan gcig pu zhog la mdun na 'don gyi stan la 'dug shig /de der song nas rgyal po'i stan gcig pu bzhag ste mdun na 'don gyi stan la 'dug go/ /

He said to Kolita, “Son, go join the festivities for the nāga kings Giri and Valguka. There, they will have arranged four seats, one for the king, one for the royal priest, one for the challenger, and one for the reigning champion. Leave the king’s seat be, and take your place in the royal priest’s seat.” On arriving, he left the king’s seat be and sat on the royal priest’s seat.

bram ze skar rgyal gyis kyang rgyal po gzugs can snying pos gzhon nu ma skyes dgra klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston nyams su myong bar byed du btang ba thos nas des kyang bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal la smras pa/ bu song la klu'i rgyal po ri bo dang / yid 'ong gnyis kyi dus ston nyams su myong bar gyis la/ de na stan bzhi po rgyal po'i gdan dang / mdun na 'don gyi stan dang / rgol ba'i stan dang / mchog thob pa'i stan bshams pa las khyod kyis rgyal po'i gdan dang / mdun na 'don gyi stan zhog la mchog thob pa'i stan la dbyi gu dang ril ba zhog ste rgol ba'i stan la 'dug shig /ji tsam na nyi ma 'char ba nas ji tsam na nub par 'gyur ba de'i bar du khyod dang 'dra ba'i rgol ba gzhan med do/ /

When the brahmin Tiṣya heard that King Bimbisāra had sent Prince Ajātaśatru to join in the festivities for the nāga kings Giri and Valguka, he too said to Upatiṣya, “Son, go join the festivities for the nāga kings Giri and Valguka. There, they will have arranged four seats, one for the king, one for the royal priest, one for the challenger, and one for the reigning champion. Leave the king’s seat and the royal priest’s seat be, but place a small stick and vase on the reigning champion’s seat before sitting down on the challenger’s seat. From the time the sun rises to the time it sets, there shall be no challenger to equal you.”

de yang song ste rgyal po'i stan dang / mdun na 'don gyi stan bzhag ste/ mchog thob pa'i stan la dbyi gu dang ril ba bzhag ste rgol ba'i stan la 'dug go/ / rol mo'i sgra dag byung ba na gar mkhan dag gis to Ta ka'i rgyud du glu blangs pa dang / mi dag gis bro brdung ba dang / glu blang bar brtsams pa dang bram ze'i khye'u de gnyis dbang po dag phyir blan te/ 'khod pa skye bo phal po che'i tshogs kyis mthong nas de dag gis smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u 'di gnyis yang na ni blun po gnyis shig go/ / yang na ni shes pas mi 'khrug pa gnyis shig go/ /

When Upatiṣya arrived, he passed the king’s and the royal priest’s seats, placed a small stick and vase on the seat for the reigning champion, and sat down on the challenger’s seat. When the music began, the dancers sang in Toṭaka meter.[85] The people began to dance [F.19.b] and sing, while the two young brahmins sat in repose. When the great crowd of people saw this, they exclaimed, “Either those two young brahmins are fools or they’re unflappable!”

rol mo'i sgra dag zhi zhing mi dag gis bro brdung zhing glu blangs te dong ba dang / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyis bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal la smras pa/ ji ltar khyod la bro legs par brdungs pa dang / glu legs par blangs pa dang / rol mo'i sgra legs par bsgrags par snang ngam/ des smras pa/ gang gis mthong ba'am/ thos pa la snang ngo / /

As the music wound down and the people went off dancing and singing, Kolita asked Upatiṣya, “Did it seem to you that the dances were well danced, the songs well sung, and the music well played?” Upatiṣya replied, “It seemed so to those who saw and heard them.”
des smras pa/ dbang po nang du bsdus pa dag gis ma mthong ba ni bden na ji ltar ma thos/
“If it is true that those who withdraw into repose do not see, how then do they not hear?” asked Kolita.
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ shi lpags shi ba'i rgyus pa dang / / 'chir 'gyur bzhad gad 'jo sgeg gi/ / 'chi ba'i skye bo 'dus pa la/ / mkhas pa su zhig bag med byed/ /
Upatiṣya replied in verse: “In a crowd of people destined for death, Who laugh and flirt Though their dead skin and dead flesh will die, What wise man would not be vigilant?”

des smras pa/ khyod nye rgyal yin nam/ kho bo skye bo dag gis de ltar shes so/ / bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyis kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la smras pa/ ji ltar khyod la yang bro legs par brdungs pa dang / glu legs par blangs pa dang / rol mo'i sgra legs par bsgrags par snang ngam/

Kolita asked, “Are you Upatiṣya?” “People know me thus.” “And you?” Upatiṣya asked Kolita. “Did it seem to you that the dances were well danced, the songs well sung, and the music well played?” [S.8.a.5] [86]
des kyang smras pa/ gang gis mthong ba'am/ thos pa la snang ngo / / des smras pa/ dbang po nang du bsdus pa dag gis ma mthong ba ni bden na ji ltar ma thos/
“It seemed so to those who saw and heard them.” “If it is true that those who withdraw into repose do not see, how then do they not hear?”
des kyang tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ rgyan rnams thams cad khur yin te/ / gar rnams thams cad mtho 'tsham pa/ / glu rnams thams cad kyal ba ste/ / gzugs kun mi rtag nyid yin no/ /
Kolita replied in verse: “All adornment is a weight, All dance a competition. All songs nonsense, And all bodies but impermanent.”

des smras pa/ khyod pang nas skyes yin nam/ kho bo skye bo dag gis de ltar shes so/ / bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la smras pa/ tshur shog bdag cag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / /
Upatiṣya asked, “Are you Kolita?” “People know me thus.” Upatiṣya said to Kolita, “Come. Let us go forth from home into homelessness so that we may rely solely on what is correct.”

des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u gang gi don du mchod sbyin sbyin par byed/ sbyin sreg sreg par byed/ dka' thub kyis gdung bar byed pa'i mdun na 'don de bdag gi lag mthil du 'ongs shing glang po ches 'gro ba'i rigs su skyes na ci'i phyir rab tu 'byung /

“Young brahmin,” replied Kolita, [F.20.a] “the royal priesthood, for which I have made offerings to the gods, performed fire pūja, and suffered through austerities, is within reach. Having been born into a caste borne about by elephants, why would I renounce it?”
des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ ljon shing rdib par gyur pa'i tshe/ / yal ga 'dab mas ci zhig byed/ / de bzhin skyes bu 'chi ba'i tshe/ / yongs su bzung bas ci zhig byed/ /
Upatiṣya recited a verse: “When a tree rots, What use has it for blossoms and boughs? When a person dies, What use has he for possessions?”

tshur shog bdag cag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / / des smras pa/ je pha ma la dri bar bya'o/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes pha ma gnyis ga la ba der song ste phyin nas smras pa/ yab yum mkhyen par mdzod cig /bdag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / /

He enjoined Kolita again, “Come. Let us go forth from home into homelessness so that we may rely solely on what is correct.” “I must first consult my parents,” replied Kolita. The young brahmin Kolita went to his parents and said, “Father, Mother, please listen. As I have faith in only what is perfect, I shall go forth from home into homelessness.”

bu gang gi don du mchod sbyin sbyin par byed/ sbyin sreg sreg par byed/ dka' thub kyis gdung bar byed pa'i mdun na 'don de khyod kyi lag mthil du 'ongs shing glang po ches 'gro ba'i rigs su skyes na ci'i phyir rab tu 'byung /

“Son, the royal priesthood, for which you have made offerings to the gods, performed fire pūja, and suffered through austerities, is within reach. Having been born into a caste borne about by elephants, why would you renounce it?”

des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ nags na shing shun rtswa gyon zhing / / rtsa ba 'bras bu 'cha' ba dang / / ri dgas gdug pa rnams dang ni/ / lhan cig gnas pa mchog lags kyi/ / 'jig rten pha rol 'jigs byed pa'i/ / mkhas pas rgyal srid slad du ni/ / gsod dang bcing dang rdeg pa dag / bgyid pa de lta ma lags so/ /

Kolita spoke in verse: “To live in the forest, Clad in bark or grass, Eating roots and fruit Among beasts, is best. Fearing the future, The wise refuse To kill, imprison, or torture For temporal power.”

de gnyis kyis smras pa/ bu khyod nged kyi bu gcig pa sdug pa/ yid du 'ong ba/ bzod pa/ mthong na mi mthun pa med pa yin pas khyod shi bar gyur na nged mi 'dod bzhin du 'bral grang / gson bzhin du gtang ba lta smos kyang ci dgos/

His parents replied, “Son, you are our only boy, beloved, handsome, patient, and agreeable to the eye. Even if you were to die, we would fight to keep you with us. [S.8.b] Why, then, do you think we’d let you go while you’re still alive?”

yab yum gal te gnang na de lta na legs/ gal te mi gnang na deng slan chad bdag 'tshal ma yang mi 'tshal/ phyag la yang mi 'tshal lo/ / bu gzhon nu mi gnang gis ji srid nged gson gyi bar du khyod nged kyi mig lam na 'dug la bya ba gzhan ma sems shig /

“Father, Mother, it is best you let me go. For if you do not, from this day forth, I shall neither eat your food nor honor you.” “Dear boy, we will not let you leave. So long as we live, you will remain within sight. Do not think of disobeying!” [F.20.b]

de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyis nyi ma gcig kyang zan gcad pa byas so/ / gnyis dang / gsum nas drug gi bar du yang zan gcad pa byas so/ / de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bu gzhon nu shes par gyis shig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba 'dod pa yin pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi shes te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben pa bya dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha' dag tu gnas par mnags par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa yang sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang lhan cig gnas par bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang rtsed mo dag las dben par bya dgos so/ / bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur shog 'di nyid du 'dug la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig /sbyin pa dag kyang byin cig /bsod nams dag kyang gyis shig /

Kolita refused food for one day, then for a second, and for a third until the sixth day. At that point Kolita’s parents went to him and said, “Dear boy, please listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure, and you do not know what it is to suffer. It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy! Kolita! Come home. There is pleasure to be had while living here, too. Here, too, you may give generously. Here, too, you may act meritoriously.”

de skad smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis kyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du 'di skad ces smras so/ / bu gzhon nu shes par gyis shig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba 'dod pa yin pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi shes te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben pa bya dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang /bas mtha' dag tu gnas pa khong du chud par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang / lhan cig gnas par bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bya dgos so/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang rtsed mo dag las dben par bya dgos so/ / bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur shog khyod 'di nyid du 'dug la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig /sbyin pa dag kyang byin cig /bsod nams dag kyang gyis shig /

Despite their pleading, Kolita remained silent. Kolita’s parents again entreated him, a second and a third time, saying each time, “Dear boy, please listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure, and you do not know what it is to suffer. It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. [F.21.a] You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy! Kolita! Come home. There is pleasure to be had while living here, too. Here, too, you may give generously. Here, too, you may act meritoriously.”

de skad lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis kyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi nye du rnams la bsgo ba/ kye nye du dag tshur shog bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes slong shig /
Yet though they thus entreated him a second and a third time, Kolita remained silent. Kolita’s parents then enjoined his relatives, “Family! Come! Talk sense into our dear boy Kolita.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi nye du dag bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la 'di skad ces smras so/ / sras gzhon nu mkhyen par mdzod cig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba bzhed pa lags pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi mkhyen te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben pa bgyi dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha' dag tu gnas pa khong du chud par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang / lhan cig gnas par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang rtsed mo dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / sras gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur spyon khyod 'di nyid du bzhugs la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig /sbyin pa dag kyang stsol cig /bsod nams dag kyang mdzod cig /

At this, Kolita’s relatives went to him and said, “Dear boy, please listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure and don’t know what it is to suffer. It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy, Kolita, come home! Among your relatives, [F.21.b] there is pleasure to be had while living there too. There too you may give generously. There too you may act meritoriously.”

de skad smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi nye du dag gis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du 'di skad ces smras so/ / sras gzhon nu mkhyen par mdzod cig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba bzhad pa lags pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi mkhyen te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben par bgyi dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha' dag tu gnas pa khong du chud par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang lhan cig gnas par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang / rtsed mo dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / sras gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur spyon khyod 'di nyid du bzhugs la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig /sbyin pa dag kyang stsol cig /bsod nams dag kyang mdzod cig /

Despite their pleading, Kolita did not say a thing. Kolita’s relatives again entreated him, a second and a third time, saying each time, “Dear boy, please listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure, and you do not know what it is to suffer. It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy! Kolita! Come home. Among your relatives, there is pleasure to be had while living there, too. There, too, you may give generously. There, too, you may act meritoriously.”

de skad lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis kyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi ne'u ldangs rnams la bsgo ba/ kye gzhon nu dag tshur sheg bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes slong shig /

Yet though they thus pleaded with him a second time and a third time, Kolita still remained silent. Kolita’s parents then enjoined his childhood friends, “You must come! Talk sense into our dear boy Kolita.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi ne'u ldangs dag bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la 'di skad ces smras so/ / sras zhi ba gzhon nu mkhyen par mdzod cig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba bzhed pa lags pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi mkhyen te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben par bgyi dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha' dag tu gnas pa khong du chud par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang lhan cig gnas par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang rtsed mo dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / sras gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur spyon khyod 'di nyid du bzhugs la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig / sbyin pa dag kyang stsol cig /bsod nams dag kyang mdzod cig /

At this, the young brahmin Kolita’s childhood friends went to him and said, “Dear boy, listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure and do not know what it is to suffer. [F.22.a] It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy! Kolita! Come home. There is also pleasure to be had while living among your relatives. There too you may give generously. There too you may act meritoriously.”

de skad smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi ne'u ldangs rnams kyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du 'di skad ces smras so/ / sras gzhon nu mkhyen par mdzod cig /khyod ni shin tu gzhon pa bde ba bzhed pa lags pas khyod kyis sdug bsngal mi mkhyen te/ tshangs par spyod pa spyad dka'o/ / rab tu dben par bgyi dka'o/ / gcig pu nyid la mngon par dga' bar dka'o/ / gnas mal dgon pa nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha' dag tu gnas pa khong du chud par dka'o/ / gcig pu dgon par gnas pa sdug bsngal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ri dgas gdug pa dag dang lhan cig gnas par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du gzhan gyis byin pas 'tsho bar bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i 'dod pa dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / khyod kyis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du mi'i dga' ba dang rtsed mo dag las dben par bgyi 'tshal lo/ / sras gzhon nu pang nas skyes tshur spyon khyod 'di nyid du bzhugs la 'dod pa dag la yang yongs su spyod cig /sbyin pa dag kyang stsol cig /bsod nams dag kyang mdzod cig /

Yet though they thus entreated him, Kolita remained silent. His childhood friends again entreated Kolita a second and a third time, saying each time, “Dear boy, please listen. You are very young and have lived a life of leisure, and you do not know what it is to suffer. It is hard to live the holy life. It is hard to live in solitude. It is hard to be happy all on your own. It is hard to make your bed in distant forests, at the foot of mountains, and in remote places. Living alone in the wilderness is very trying. You will have to spend the rest of your life living among wild animals. You will have to spend the rest of your life living on others’ handouts. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from human pleasures. You will have to spend the rest of your life away from the fun and games of ordinary people. Dear boy! [F.22.b] Kolita! Come home. Among your relatives, there is pleasure to be had while living there, too. There, too, you may give generously. There, too, you may act meritoriously.”

de skad lan gnyis lan gsum gyi bar du smras kyang bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes cang mi smra'o/ / de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi ne'u ldangs rnams bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis la 'di skad ces smras so/ / yab yum dag mkhyen par mdzod cig /zhi ba gzhon nu pang nas skyes gum pas ci zhig bgyi rab tu 'byung ba ni mkhas pas bsngags pa lags pas gal te rab tu byung nas mngon par dga' bar gyur na yang de gson po nyid du gzigs par 'gyur la/ mngon par dga' bar ma gyur na yang drang srong dag ni slar ldog pa lags pas bu'i gnas pha ma gnyis las ma gtogs pa gzhan su zhig mchis par 'gyur gyis rab tu byung na legs so/ /

Yet though they thus entreated him a second and a third time, Kolita still remained silent. Kolita’s childhood friends then went to his parents and said, “Father, Mother, please listen. What good can come from the death of the serene youth Kolita? The wise have praised going forth, so if going forth makes him happy, then at least you will see him alive. If he isn’t happy, he can always give up the life of a sage. And since he will have no home but yours, it is better that you let him go forth.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi pha ma gnyis kyis bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes la 'di skad ces smras so/ / bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes khyod la rab tu 'byung ba legs pa byed pa yin la/ khyim na gnas pa legs pa byed pa ma yin nam/ yab yum bdag la rab tu 'byung ba legs pa bgyid pa lags la/ khyim na gnas pa legs pa bgyid pa ma lags so/ /

Kolita’s parents then asked Kolita, “Dear boy, Kolita, [S.9.a] do you think it better to go forth than to remain at home?” “Father, Mother, it is not good for me to live at home. It is good for me to go forth.”

bu gzhon nu pang nas skyes 'o na da de'i dus la bab par shes par gyis shig /de nas bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes pha ma gnyis kyis gnang nas 'bras khu'i rim gyis lus kyi mthu dang / stobs dang / brtson 'grus bskyed de/ grong shing thags can nas phyir byung nas/ grong na la dag la ba der 'phags so/ /

“Well then, dear boy, Kolita, know that the time for such a change has come.” Having obtained his parents’ consent, the young brahmin Kolita slowly regained his strength, vigor, and determination by drinking rice gruel. He left the village of Kāṣṭhavāṭa and set out for the village of Nālada.

bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dben pa la dga' bas gnas mal dgon par song ste/ bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug go/ / bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes mthar gyis grong na la dar phyin nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyi pha ma gnyis la smras pa/ yab yum bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gar mchis/

As the young brahmin Upatiṣya enjoyed solitude, he had gone to live in the forest, where he gave instruction to five hundred young brahmins in the reciting of mantras. In time, the young brahmin Kolita reached the village of Nālada and asked Upatiṣya’s parents, [F.23.a] “Father, Mother, where is Upatiṣya?”
de gnyis kyis smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dben pa la dga' bas gnas mal dgon par song ste/ bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jug go/ /
They replied, “Upatiṣya enjoys solitude so he has gone to live in the forest, where he instructs five hundred young brahmins in the reciting of mantras.”

bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal ga la ba der song ste phyin nas smras pa/ nye rgyal tshur shog bdag cag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / /
Kolita went to Upatiṣya and said, “Come, Upatiṣya. We shall go forth from home into the homelessness so that we may rely solely on what is correct.”
des smras pa/ khyod pha ma gnyis kyis gnang ngam/ gnang ngo / / des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u kho bos pha ma gnyis la dris te 'ong gi bar du re zhig sdod cig /
“Did your parents give their consent?” “They did.” “Young brahmin, please stay until I have asked my parents.”
des smras pa/ nye rgyal kho bo ni dus de srid kyis pha mas gnang na khyod da ji srid kyis gnang bar 'gyur/ des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u kho bo da kho na gnang bar byas te 'ong ngo / /
“Upatiṣya, it took a long time for my parents to give their consent. How long will it be until you have consent?” “Young brahmin, I will see that they give their consent right away and return.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal pha ma gnyis ga la ba der song ste phyin nas pha ma gnyis la 'di skad ces smras so/ / yab yum mkhyen par mdzod cig /bdag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / / de gnyis kyis smras pa/ bu khyod la rab tu 'byung ba legs pa byed pa yin nam/

Upatiṣya went to his parents and said, “Father, Mother, please listen. I shall go forth from home into homelessness so that I may rely solely on what is correct.” “Son, is it good for you to go forth?”
yab yum bdag la rab tu 'byung ba legs pa bgyid pa lags so/ / bu 'o na song la rab tu byung shig /
“Father, Mother, it is good for me to go forth.” “Then go forth, son.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyi gan du song ste smras pa/ pang nas skyes tshur shog bdag cag yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung ngo / / des smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u khyod pha ma gnyis kyis gnang ngam/ gnang ngo / /
Upatiṣya went to Kolita and said, “Come, Kolita. We shall go forth from home into homelessness so that we may rely solely on what is correct.” “Did your parents give their consent?” “They did.”

nye rgyal kho bo ni dus de srid kyis pha ma gnyis kyis gnang na khyod pha ma gnyis kyis myur du gnang ba'i sbyor ba gang yin/ 'di ltar khyod ni 'ching ba dam pa dang / 'ching ba brtan pa dang / 'ching ba ma rul ba dang / gags shing sbom pa yin gyi/ kho bo ni 'ching ba stobs med pa dang / 'ching ba stobs chung ba dang / 'ching ba rul ba dang / gags shing phra ba yin no/ /

“Upatiṣya, it took a long time for my parents to give their consent. How did you get the consent of yours so quickly?” “Allow me to explain. You were hindered by heavy bindings, tight, secure, and imperishable, while I was hindered by light bindings, powerless, weak, and perishable.” [F.23.b]
'di ltar tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu ni tshe rabs lnga brgyar rab tu byung bar gyur cing 'di ltar tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bus smon lam 'di skad ces/
The venerable Śāriputra had gone forth in five hundred previous lives because he had made this prayer:
ha cang phyug pa'i khyim dang ni/ / dbul po'i khyim du mi skye bar/ / bar ma'i khyim du skye 'gyur zhing / / rtag tu rab byung mang bar shog / ces btab pa'i phyir ro/ /
“May I be born, not in a wealthy house Nor in one that is poor; Let it be rather in a house of moderate means And always among many renunciants.”

bram ze'i khye'u pang nas skyes kyis bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal la smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u bdag cag ni bram ze rab tu grags pa dag yin pas bdag cag gang yang rung ba rab tu 'byung bar mi nus kyis/ 'di ltar legs par brtag par bya ste rab tu 'byung bar bya'o zhes de gnyis mthar gyis rgyal po'i khab tu phyin to/ /

Kolita said to Upatiṣya, “Young brahmin, as we are well-known brahmins, we cannot join just any renunciant order. We must properly scrutinize the different renunciant orders and only then join one.” With that they made their way to Rājagṛha.

de'i tshe na rdzogs byed la sogs pa ston pa drug po thams cad mkhyen pa ma yin par thams cad mkhyen par mngon pa'i nga rgyal can 'di lta ste/ 'drob skyong gi bu rdzogs byed dang / gnag lhas kyi bu kun du rgyu dang / smra 'dod kyi bu mo'i bu yang dag rgyal ba can dang / mi pham skra'i la ba can dang / ka t+ya'i bu nog can dang / gnyen gyi bu gcer bu dag rgyal po'i khab na nye bar rten cing gnas so/ /

Meanwhile there were six tīrthika teachers living in Rājagṛha who entertained the conceit of omniscience although they were not omniscient: Pūraṇa Kāśyapa; [S.9.b] Gośālīputra, the wandering mendicant; Sañjayin, son of Vairaṭṭī; Ajita of the hair shawl; Kakuda, a descendant of Kātyāyana; and Jñātiputra, the Nirgrantha.

de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dang / pang nas skyes gnyis 'drob skyong gi bu rdzogs byed ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas 'drob skyong gi bu rdzogs byed la 'di skad ces smras so/ / shes ldan khyod kyi chos kyi tshul ni gang yin/ slob ma la gdams pa ni gang yin/ tshangs par spyod pa'i 'bras bu ni gang yin/ phan yon ni gang yin/

The young brahmins Upatiṣya and Kolita went to Pūraṇa Kāśyapa and asked him, “Sir, what is your approach to the Dharma? What instructions do you give to your students? What is the result of living a holy life? What are its benefits?”

rdzogs byed kyis smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag kho bo ni 'di ltar lta zhing 'di skad smra ste/ sbyin pa med do/ / mchod sbyin med do/ / sbyin sreg med do/ / legs par spyad pa med do/ / nyes par spyad pa med do/ / legs par spyad pa dang nyes par spyad pa'i las rnams kyi 'bras bu dang rnam par smin pa med do/ / 'jig rten 'di med do/ / 'jig rten pha rol med do/ / ma med do/ / pha med do/ / sems can rdzus te skye ba med do/ / 'jig rten na dgra bcom pa yang dag par song ba yang dag par zhugs pa gang dag tshe 'di nyid la rang gi mngon par shes pas 'jig rten 'di dang 'jig rten pha rol mngon sum du byas nas bsgrubs te bdag cag ni skye ba zad do/ / tshangs par spyad pa bsten to/ / bya ba byas so/ / srid pa 'di las gzhan mi shes so zhes go bar byed pa dag med do/ / srog ni 'di nyid la 'tsho zhing de phyis chad par 'gyur/ zhig par 'gyur te shi ba'i 'og tu mi 'byung ngo / / skyes bu'i lus ni 'byung ba chen po bzhi las gyur pa yin te/ de ni gang gi tshe dus byed pa na de'i sa'i lus ni sa'i bag la zha/ chu'i lus ni chu'i/ me'i lus ni me'i/ rlung gi lus ni rlung gi bag la zha bar 'gyur ro/ / dbang po rnams ni nam mkha'i rjes su 'gro bar 'gyur ro/ / skyes bu'i ro ni khri dang lnga'i mi dag gis khyer te dur khrod du 'gro zhing bsregs phan chad mi mngon par 'gyur ro/ / bsreg bya dag ni thal bar 'gyur ro/ / rus pa dag ni thi ba'i mdog 'dra bar gnas so/ / 'di ltar rmongs pas nye bar bsten pa ni sbyin la/ mkhas pas nye bar bsten pa ni len to/ / de la gang dag yod par smra ba de dag thams cad ni gsob gsog brdzun du gdol pa dag yin no/ / 'di ltar byis pa dang mkhas pa de gnyis ni phyis chad par 'gyur/ zhig par 'gyur te shi ba'i 'og tu mi 'byung ngo / /

“Young brahmins,” replied Pūraṇa, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: There is nothing to alms, oblations, fire sacrifices, good deeds, or bad deeds. There are no results or fruitions from performing good deeds or bad deeds. There is no present life. There is no afterlife. There is no mother. There is no father. Sentient beings are not born miraculously.[87] In the world [F.24.a] there are no arhats who have reached perfection, who have entered perfection, who can knowingly say that through their heightened insight they have seen this and future lives, and proclaim, ‘We have overcome birth. We have lived the holy life. We have done what needed to be done. We will know no life other than this.’ One’s life-force persists for the duration of this life but is annihilated after that. It will perish and after death will not arise again. A person’s body is forged from the four great elements, for once its time is up, the body’s solid structures recede[88] into earth, the body’s fluids recede into water, the body’s heat recedes into fire, and the body’s vital energies recede into wind. The senses fade into space. A person’s corpse is borne on a bier carried by four men and taken to the charnel ground where it is burned, never to be seen again. What burns turns to ash. The bones turn a pigeon-like grey. Those who are confused about these things counsel giving alms, while the wise counsel receiving them. Those who argue that such things exist are all vainly debating what is empty and hollow. Both the childish and the wise will cease to be. They will perish and after death will not live again.”

de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dang / pang nas skyes gnyis 'di snyam du sems te/ ston pa shes ldan 'di ni lam gol bar zhugs pa/ lam ngan pa legs par sgrub pa yin te/ lam 'jigs pa dang bcas pa ji lta ba bzhin du mkhas pa rnams kyis sprang bar bya ba yin no

The young brahmins Upatiṣya and Kolita thought, “This noble teacher has strayed onto a spurious path. He pursues fully a ruinous path. This is exactly the kind of dangerous path the wise say must be rejected.”
snyam du rig nas tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ blo ngan log par ston byed pa/ / dman pa ston par grags pa ste/ / gang gi chos ni de 'dra ba/ / de yi chos min ci zhig 'dra/ /
Knowing this, they spoke in verse: “He who teaches a wrong and ruinous path Is known to be an inferior teacher. If this is his Dharma, What, for him, is antithetical to Dharma?”

zhes smras nas snod stong pa bzhin du brdabs te dong ngo / / de nas bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis gnag lhas kyi bu kun du rgyu ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas gnag lhas kyi bu kun du rgyu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / shes ldan khyod kyi chos kyi tshul ni gang yin/ slob ma la gdams pa ni gang yin/ tshangs par spyod pa'i 'bras bu ni gang yin/ phan yon ni gang yin/

Pūraṇa’s teaching heard, they cast it aside like an empty bottle and moved on. Upatiṣya and Kolita then went to Gośālīputra the wandering mendicant [F.24.b] and asked, “Sir, what is your approach to the Dharma? What instructions do you give to your students? What is the result of living the holy life? What are its benefits?”

kun du rgyus smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag kho bo ni 'di ltar lta zhing 'di skad smra ste/ sems can rnams kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur ba la rgyu med rkyen med do/ / sems can rnams rgyu med rkyen med par kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur ro/ / sems can rnams rnam par dag par 'gyur ba la rgyu med rkyen med do/ / sems can rnams rgyu med rkyen med par rnam par dag par 'gyur ro/ / sems can rnams shes pa med par 'gyur ba dang / mthong ba med par 'gyur ba la rgyu med rkyen med do/ / sems can rnams rgyu med rkyen med par shes pa med pa dang / mthong ba med par 'gyur ro/ / sems can rnams shes par 'gyur ba dang / mthong bar 'gyur ba la rgyu med rkyen med do/ / sems can rnams rgyu med rkyen med par shes pa dang / mthong bar 'gyur ro/ / stobs med do/ / brtson 'grus med do/ / stobs dang brtson 'grus med do/ / skyes bu'i rtsal med do/ / pha rol gnon pa med do/ / skyes bu'i rtsal dang pha rol gnon pa med do/ / bdag gi rtsal med do/ / gzhan gyi rtsal med do/ / bdag gi rtsal dang gzhan gyi rtsal med do/ / sems can thams cad dang / srog thams cad dang / 'byung po thams cad mthu med/ stobs med do/ / dbang med do/ / brtson 'grus med do/ / pha rol gnon pa med do/ / 'gro ba mtshams sbyor ba'i srid pa dag nges par gyur to/ / 'di ltar 'gro ba drug po dag tu bde ba dang sdug bsngal so sor myong bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Young brahmins,” replied the wandering mendicant, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: That sentient beings are afflicted has nothing to do with causes and conditions.[89] The affliction of sentient beings has nothing to do with causes and conditions. That sentient beings are purified has nothing to do with causes and conditions. The purification of sentient beings occurs randomly and by chance. That sentient beings lack understanding and insight has nothing to do with causes and conditions. Their lack of understanding and insight occurs randomly and by chance. That sentient beings acquire understanding and insight has nothing to do with causes and conditions. Their acquisition of understanding and insight occurs randomly and by chance. It is not due to vigor. It is not due to determination. It is not due to a combination of vigor and determination. It is not due to a person’s skill. It is not due to his overpowering ability. It is not due to a combination of a person’s skill and overpowering ability. It is not due to one’s own skill. It is not due to another’s skill. It is not due to a combination of one’s own skill and another’s skill. All beings, all living things, and all elements are powerless. They lack strength, influence, determination, and the ability to overcome. [S.10.a] A being’s life is predetermined. That is why we experience the unique pleasures and pains of each of the six realms.”

“Young brahmins,” replied Sañjayin, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: A person may act or make another person act, maim or make another person maim, burn or make another person burn, flog or make another person flog, endanger life, take what has not been given, engage wrongfully in acts of desire, knowingly speak falsehoods, imbibe intoxicating drinks, break into a house, pick a lock,[90] rob at knifepoint, block a road and lie in wait, sack a town, sack a city, sack a region, or slaughter, dismember, flog, and tear apart every last being on this earth with the edge of a cakra blade,[91] and then, having cut up, dismembered, flogged, and torn apart all beings, lay all the flesh out on a single plane, in a single mound, in a single pile, or a single heap. In having laid all the flesh out on a single plane, [F.25.b] in a single mound, in a single pile, or a single heap, and having done all those things, there would be no sin in that nor would any sin come from it. One could walk along the south bank of the river Gaṅgā and slaughter, dismember, flog, and tear apart everything, or walk along the north bank of the river Gaṅgā and give alms and oblations, and there would be no sin or merit in either, nor would sin or merit come from either. Even if one practices generosity, discipline, perfect restraint, and acts with purpose and integrity, one still does not gain merit.”
