“Young brahmins,” replied Ajita, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: Seven bodies are not products, they are not by-products, they are not apparitions, they are not by-products of apparitions, they are not subject to harm, they are everlasting, and they are still and solid like a pillar. [F.26.a] What are the seven? The seven are thus: the body of earth, the body of water, the body of fire, the body of wind, pleasure, pain, and the vitality of life. Those seven bodies are not products, are not by-products, are not apparitions, are not by-products of apparitions, are not subject to harm, are everlasting, and are still and solid like a pillar. Those seven are such that they do not waver, they do not change, nor do they harm one another, nor do they become merit, nor do they become sin, nor do they become both merit and sin, nor do they become pleasure, nor do they become pain, nor do they become both pleasure and pain. [S.10.b] Were one person to cut off the head of another person, even that would not influence the world nor would it cause the slightest harm to that which is still and solid, for the weapon would pass straight through the unbroken spaces in those seven bodies, leaving the life within them unharmed. There is absolutely no killing them, no making to kill them, no rousing them, no making to rouse them, no awareness of them, no making to be aware of them, no knowing them, and no making them known. Whether you be childish or wise, you are liberated from suffering after 8,400,000 eons; in the meantime, you are reborn in and cycle through 14,000 principal places of rebirth, 60,600 great eons, five types of actions, three types of actions, two types of actions, action, half-actions, sixty-two paths, sixty-two intermediate eons, thirty-six hells, one hundred and twenty senses, sixty-two constituent particles, 49,000 classes of nāga families, 49,000 classes of garuḍa, 49,000 classes of wandering mendicants, [F.26.b] 49,000 classes of Ājivika, 49,000 classes of Nirgrantha, seven realms with discerning awareness, seven realms lacking discerning awareness, seven Nirgrantha realms, seven demi-god realms, seven demonic realms, seven godly realms, seven human realms, seven great oceans, seven hundred lakes, seven great dreams, seven hundred dreams, seven states of great diminishment, seven hundred states of diminishment, seven states of great increase, seven hundred states of increase, seven states of great depletion, seven hundred states of depletion, seven great abysses, seven hundred abysses, six noble clans, ten high-status rebirths, and the eight grounds of a great person. Thus, just as a ball of thread thrown in the air unravels into a long thread as it falls, everyone, be they childish or wise, is liberated from suffering after having been through the cycle of rebirth for 8,400,000 eons. No ascetic or brahmin can say, ‘By observing ethics, a vow, asceticism, or celibacy, I shall bring to fruition those acts that have not borne fruit, and in facing those acts that have borne fruit, purify them.’ Our pleasures and pains are predestined. It is impossible to extend or reduce them. As this is how things are and not otherwise, the rounds of existence are thus to be counted.”

“Young brahmins,” replied Kakuda Kātyāyana, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: If someone comes to me and asks, ‘Is there an afterlife?’ I answer him by saying, ‘There is an afterlife.’ If he should ask, ‘Is there not an afterlife?’ I answer him by saying, ‘There is no afterlife.’ If he should ask, ‘Is there or is there not an afterlife?’ I answer him by saying, ‘There is and is not an afterlife.’ If he should ask, ‘Does an afterlife neither exist nor not exist?’ I answer him by saying, ‘An afterlife neither exists nor does it not exist.’ Likewise, if someone comes to me and asks, ‘Is the afterlife like or unlike this world?’ I answer him by saying, “The afterlife is like and unlike this world.’ If he should ask, ‘Is the afterlife different or not different?’ I answer by saying, ‘The afterlife is different and not different.’ [F.27.b] If he should ask, ‘Is the afterlife not different or not not different?’ I answer him by saying, ‘The afterlife is not different and not not different.’ If he should ask, ‘Is the afterlife like that or not like that?’ I answer him by saying, ‘The afterlife is like that and not like that.’ ”

“Young brahmins,” replied the Nirgrantha, “this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: No matter what a person individually experiences, it all comes from causes sown in the past. Old actions are purified through austerities, while new actions are averted by the dam of inactivity. In this way one avoids future defilement. In the absence of defilement, actions are exhausted. When actions are exhausted, suffering is exhausted. When suffering is exhausted, one is freed from suffering.”

Not long before, word had spread about a tīrthika named Sañjayin. The young brahmins Upatiṣya and Kolita went to where the teacher Sañjayin lived and asked, “Gentlemen, where is the teacher Sañjayin?” “He has withdrawn into seclusion.” “Oh! This is the first time we’ve heard the phrase ‘withdrawn into seclusion’ in such a long time!” They thought, “It would not be right to disturb the teacher’s withdrawal into seclusion. We will approach him once he has risen from this state.” And with that they sat off to one side.

The teacher Sañjayin emerged from seclusion. The states of absorption he had experienced had invigorated his senses. Upatiṣya and Kolita thought, “Whoever has such a face must have qualities to match.” They approached him and asked, “Sir Sañjayin, what is your approach to the Dharma? What instructions do you give to your students? What is the result of living the holy life? What are its benefits?”

yang dag rgyal ba can gyis smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u dag kho bo ni 'di ltar lta zhing 'di skad smra ste/ bden pa dang mi 'tshe ba ni chos so zhi ba dang / rga ba med pa dang / 'chi ba med pa dang / nyams pa med pa'i gnas de ni tshangs pa'o/ /
Sañjayin replied, “Young brahmins, this is how I see it and this is my philosophy: The Dharma is truth and non-violence. The peaceful, ageless, immortal, and unwaning [F.28.b] state is Brahman.”

de gnyis kyis smras pa/ mkhan po smras pa de'i don ci lags/ bden pa zhes bya ba ni bden pa'i bsam pas rab tu 'byung ba'o/ / mi 'tshe ba zhes bya ba ni chos thams cad mi 'tshe ba'i gzhi las byung ba'o/ / zhi ba dang / rga ba med pa dang / 'chi ba med pa dang /nyams pa med pa'i gnas zhes bya ba de dag ni mya ngan las 'das pa'i rnam grangs kyi tshig dag yin no/ / de ni tshangs pa'o zhes bya ba ni gal te re zhig tshe 'di nyid la mya ngan las 'das pa sgrub par byed na de lta na legs/ gal te sgrub par mi byed na yang tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du nye bar 'gro bar 'gyur te/ de lta na yang bram ze dag ni tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du gzhol ba dang / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du 'bab pa dang / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten du bab pa yin no/ / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten yang de lta bu yin zhing / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten yang de 'dra ba yin te/ tshangs pa'i 'jig rten dang skal ba mnyam par sgrub pa ni mya ngan las 'das pa la gzhol ba yin no/ /

The two replied, “Preceptor, what is the meaning of what you have said?” “As for truth, renunciation is born of true thoughts. As for non-violence, all dharmas spring from the ground of non-violence. The peaceful, ageless, immortal, and unwaning state are other names by which nirvāṇa may be known. That state is called Brahmā, for if some were to achieve nirvāṇa in this very life, all would be well. But even if they did not achieve it, they would still draw near to the world of Brahmā. Even so, brahmins will be reborn in the world of Brahmā, will alight into the world of Brahmā, will have alighted into the world of Brahmā. And how is the world of Brahmā? Gaining the fortune for the world of Brahmā is akin to entering nirvāṇa.”

mkhan po bdag cag rab tu 'byung bar gnang na bdag cag mkhan po'i spyan sngar tshangs par spyod pa spyad par bgyi'o/ / des de gnyis rab tu phyung ngo / / gang gi tshe ston pa yang dag rgyal ba can gyis bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis rab tu phyung ba de'i tshe na thams cad du ston pa yang dag rgyal ba can gyis bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis rab tu phyung ngo zhes sgra grags shing de la rnyed pa dang bkur sti mang po byung bar gyur to/ / des bsams pa/ sngon yang bdag shaN Di la'i rigs yin la da ltar yang bdag shaN Di la'i rigs yin na da ltar bdag la rnyed pa dang bkur sti mang po byung bar gyur pa'i sbyor ba gang yin snyam mo/ /

“Preceptor, allow us to go forth. We pledge to live the holy life under your guidance.” And with that the two became renunciants in Sañjayin’s order. After the teacher Sañjayin allowed Upatiṣya and Kolita’s going forth, the news of their acceptance spread everywhere and Sañjayin was lauded with many accolades and much praise. He thought, [S.11.b] “If I was a member of the Śāṇḍilya clan[92] before and am still a member now, what has caused such abundant accolades and praise to come to me now?”

des bsams pa/ 'di ni bdag gi mthu ma yin te/ 'di ltar bram ze'i khye'u 'di gnyis kyi mthu yin no snyam nas bram ze'i khye'u lnga brgya tsam bram ze'i gsang tshig dag klog tu 'jud pa na des gcig la nyis brgya lnga bcu gtad cing cig shos la yang nyis brgya lnga bcu gtad do/ /

Sañjayin thought, “It is not due to my own sway. Rather, it is the sway of these two young brahmins.” Thus when he accepted five hundred young brahmins for instruction in how to recite brahmanic mantras, he assigned two hundred and fifty to Upatiṣya and two hundred and fifty to Kolita. [F.29.a]

dus gzhan zhig na ston pa yang dag rgyal ba can na bar gyur nas nye rgyal gyis pang nas skyes la smras pa/ pang nas skyes ci khyod mkhan po'i g.yog byed dam 'on te sman tshol bar byed/ des bsams pa/ 'di ni shes rab can yin pas 'di nyid g.yog byed du bcug la bdag gis ni sman btsal bar bya'o snyam nas des smras pa/ khyod mkhan po'i g.yog byos shig dang kho bos sman btsal lo/ /

At one point, after the teacher Sañjayin had fallen ill, Upatiṣya asked Kolita, “Kolita, will you attend the preceptor or will you seek out medicine for him?” Kolita thought, “Upatiṣya is intelligent. I would have him attend the preceptor while I go in search of medicine,” and said, “Please attend the preceptor and I will seek medicine.”

nye rgyal gyis g.yog bya bar brtsams nas pang nas skyes sman tshol bar byed do/ / de la rtsa ba dang / sdong bu dang / 'dab ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu'i sman dag gis bsnyen bkur byas kyang nad de nye bar zhi bar ma gyur cing nyam dmas nas des 'dzum pa bstan pa dang bram ze'i khye'u nye rgyal gyis smras pa/ mkhan po khyod lta bu'i skyes bu gtso bo dag ni rgyu ma mchis rkyen ma mchis par 'dzum pa mi mdzad na/ mkhan po 'dzum pa mdzad pa'i rgyu ni gang lags/ rkyen ni gang lags/

Upatiṣya began to attend the preceptor and Kolita went off in search of medicine. Though Upatiṣya ministered to the preceptor with medicinal roots, stalks, leaves, flowers, and fruit, the illness would not subside. Though weak, the preceptor smiled, prompting Upatiṣya to ask, “Preceptor, given that great people like you do not smile for no reason, what causes you to smile? What prompts it?”

des smras pa/nye rgyal de de bzhin no/ / de de bzhin te/ kho bo lta bu skyes bu gtso bo dag ni rgyu med rkyen med par 'dzum pa mi ston te/ 'di ltar gser gling na rgyal po gser bdag ces bya ba dus la bab pa de'i chung ma me'i phung por mchongs pa na de la kho bo 'di snyam du sems te/ sems can 'di dag ni 'dod pa'i rgyu dang / 'dod pa'i gzhi dang /'dod pa'i gnas kyi rgyus 'di ltar sdug bsngal nyams su myong bar byed do snyam mo/ /

“Upatiṣya,” replied Sañjayin, “allow me to explain. Great beings like me do not smile without cause or condition. I was thinking about the wife of King Suvarṇapati of Suvarṇadvīpa. When her husband’s time had come, she leapt onto his funeral pyre. I was thinking how the impulse to desire, the very things desired, and the pursuit of desire are what cause these sentient beings to suffer.”
mkhan po dus gang gi tshe/ dus mang ge mo zhig gi tshe'o/ / zla ba gang la/ zla ba mang ge mo zhig la'o/ / nyi ma gang la/ nyi ma mang ge mo zhig la'o/ /
“When was this, preceptor?” “At such and such a time, a long time ago.” “In what month?” “In such and such a month long ago.” “On what day?” “On such and such a day long ago.”

des dris pa de glegs bu la bris te bzhag go/ / des smras pa/ mkhan po bdag cag cung zad rab tu phyung ba gang lags pa de dag thams cad bdud rtsi don du gnyer zhing bdud rtsi tshol ba lags na/ gal te mkhan pos bdud rtsi cung zad brnyes pa lta na/ kye ma mkhan pos bdag cag la yang bdud rtsi bgo bsha' mdzad du gsol/

Sañjayin recorded this conversation on a board and set it down. “Preceptor,” Upatiṣya urged, “if the whole of what little renunciation we have is for ambrosia and the search for ambrosia, and if you, preceptor, have found some small measure of that ambrosia then please share it with us!”

bu kho bo yang cung zad rab tu byung ba de thams cad bdud rtsi don du gnyer zhing bdud rtsi tshol ba yin na kho bos bdud rtsi cung zad kyang ma rnyed de/ 'di ltar 'di nyid kyi gso sbyong bcwa lnga pa la lha dag steng gi nam mkha' la rgyu ba rnams kyi sgra thos nas gangs kyi ngos dang nye ba chu klung skal ldan shing rta pa'i 'gram drang srong ser skya'i bsti gnas dang ha cang mi ring bar shAkya rnams kyi gzhon nu byung ste/ de bram ze ltas pa dang mtshan mkhan dag gis gzhon nu de pho brang gi nang na bzhugs par gyur na 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po mtha' bzhir rgyal ba/ chos kyi rgyal po chos dang ldan pa/ rin po che sna bdun dang ldan par 'gyur te/ de'i rin po che bdun po de dag ni 'di lta bur 'gyur te/ 'di lta ste 'khor lo rin po che dang / glang po rin po che dang / rta rin po che dang / nor bu rin po che dang / bud med rin po che dang / khyim bdag rin po che dang / dmag dpon rin po che nyid ni bdun pa yin no/ / 'di la bu dpa' ba/ rtul phod pa/ yan lag mchog gi gzugs dang ldan pa/ pha rol gyi sde rab tu 'joms pa stong tshang ba yod par 'gyur ro/ / de rgya mtsho la thug pa'i sa chen po ma lus pa gnod par sdo ba med cing 'tshe ba med pa 'di nyid chad pa med cing mtshon gyis bda' ba med la/ chos dang mthun zhing snyoms pas legs par phab ste gnas par 'gyur ro/ / gal te skra dang kha spu bregs te gos ngur smrig dag bgos nas yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu byung na ni de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'jig rten du rnam par grags pa'i sgra dang ldan par 'gyur ro zhes lung bstan to zhes zer ba'i sgra thos kyis/

“Son, [F.29.b] the whole of what little renunciation I have is for ambrosia and the search for ambrosia but neither have I discovered even a small measure of that ambrosia. Allow me to explain. On the fifteenth, a day of fast, I heard the gods, who were passing through the heavens above, say, ‘At the foot of the snow mountains, on the banks of the river Bhāgīrathī, not far from the sage Kapila’s hermitage, a youth from the Śākya clan has appeared. Brahmins skilled in interpreting omens and signs made this prophecy: ‘The youth installed in the palace will either become king of the world, with his reign extending over the four directions, or he will become a king of Dharma. He will be endowed with the Dharma or the seven precious emblems. The seven precious emblems he will possess are as follows: a precious wheel, a precious elephant, a precious horse, a precious jewel, a precious woman, a precious steward, and a precious general. He will have a full one thousand sons, heroic, brave, and of ideal build who will destroy enemy forces. Under him, the whole earth, from sea to sea, will be free from the threat of harm and violence, and will be a realm without punishment or armed expulsion, where rule is impartial and in harmony with the Dharma. But if he, with perfect faith, should cut his hair, shave his beard, don the saffron robes, and go forth from home into homelessness, then he shall become a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha, famed all over the world.’

khyed gnyis de'i bstan pa la rab tu byung la rigs smra bar mi bya/ rus smra bar mi bya/ bram ze'i khye'ur smra ba mi bya bar rgyags pa dang nga rgyal nges par bcom pa dag gis de'i spyan sngar tshangs par spyad pa spyod cig dang / de las khyed gnyis kyis bdud rtsi chen po thob par 'gyur ro zhes smras nas/

“ ‘You two should go forth into his teachings. Having gone forth, you should not proclaim your caste, you should not proclaim your clan, you should not proclaim your being a young brahmin. [S.12.a] Once you have overcome conceit and pride, you should live the holy life under his guidance and then you will receive a great ambrosia.” Then he said,
bsags pa kun gyi mtha' zad cing / mthon po rnams ni mtha' ltung 'gyur/ / phrad pa'i mtha' ni 'bral ba ste/ / gson pa'i mtha' ni 'chi ba yin/ /

zhes bya ba yin pas dus kyi chos dang ldan par gyur to/ / de de rnams kyi gos sngon po dang / ser po dang / dmar po dang / dkar po dag gi phyogs brgyan te dur khrod du bskyal nas bsregs te/ de'i 'og tu mya ngan bsang bdag byas nas 'khod do/ / gser gling nas bram ze'i khye'u ral pa gser 'dra zhes bya ba zhig mthar gyis rgyal po'i khab tu phyin nas de de rnams kyi 'dug gnas su zhugs pa dang nye rgyal gyis smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u khyod de bar ga las 'ongs/

On saying that, he went the way of all temporal phenomena. After decorating the sides of his bier with blue, yellow, red, and white cloth, they carried his corpse to the charnel ground and cremated him. In time, their grief subsided. In time, a young brahmin named Suvarṇajaṭa from Suvarṇadvīpa arrived in Rājagṛha. When he entered their dwelling, Upatiṣya asked, “Young brahmin, where have you come from?” “From Suvarṇadvīpa,” he replied.

des smras pa/ gser gling nas so/ / bram ze'i khye'u khyod kyis gser gling na ngo mtshar dang rmad du byung ba'i chos cung zad ci mthong / des smras pa/ bdag gis ngo mtshar dang rmad du byung ba'i chos chen po ma mthong ste/ 'di ltar bdag gis gser gling na ngo mtshar dang rmad du byung ba'i chos cung zad ci mthong ba de nyon cig /gser gling na rgyal po gser bdag ces bya ba dus la bab pa de'i chung ma me'i phung por mchongs so/ /

“Young brahmin, did you see anything at all amazing or remarkable in Suvarṇadvīpa?” “I didn’t see anything truly amazing or remarkable,” he replied, “but I did see something somewhat amazing and remarkable so listen as you please. The wife of King Suvarṇapati of Suvarṇadvīpa leapt onto his funeral pyre when her husband’s time had come.”
dus gang gi tshe/ dus mang ge mo zhig gi tshe'o/ /
“When was this?” “At such and such a time, a long time ago.”
zla ba gang la/ zla ba mang ge mo zhig la'o/ /
“In what month?” “In such and such a month long ago.”
nyi ma gang la/ nyi ma mang ge mo zhig la'o/ /
“On what day?” “On such and such a day long ago.”

des dris pa glegs bu la bris pa bltas na ji tsam na thams cad de kho na bzhin du mthong nas nye rgyal gyis pang nas skyes la smras pa/ mkhan pos slob dpon gyi dpe mkhyud byas te/ des shin tu bdud rtsi rnyed na bdag cag la bdud rtsi'i bgo bsha' ma byas te/ 'di ltar lha'i mig gis yul gzhan na 'dug pa'i gzugs dag mthong ba dang / lha'i rna bas sgra yid du 'ong ba dag thos pa las na/ des bdud rtsi ma rnyed do zhes bya ba ni chos med do/ /

When Upatiṣya looked at the conversation recorded on the board, he saw that everything was exactly as Sañjayin had said, at which point he said to Kolita, “Our preceptor Sañjayin concealed his learning from us. If he had found such rare ambrosia, he did not share it with us. For if he himself saw forms in other lands with the divine eye and heard pleasant sounds with the divine ear, then his claim to have found no ambrosia is not true.”

pang nas skyes kyis bsams pa/ nye rgyal 'di ni shes rab can yin pas 'dis kyang bdud rtsi rnyed na bdag la mi rjod pa gang yin pa de lta bu'i gnas yod par 'gyur ro snyam nas des smras pa/ nye rgyal tshur shog khrims su bya ba bcas/ bdag cag gnyis las gang gis dang por bdud rtsi rnyed pa des phan tshun bsnyad par bya'o zhes de gnyis kyis khrims su bya ba de lta bu bcas te ljongs rgyur dong ngo / /

Kolita thought, “Upatiṣya is intelligent. Were he to find such ambrosia he may not tell me and a situation such as this might happen again.” Then he said, “Upatiṣya, join me in a pledge. Whoever finds such ambrosia first, [F.30.b] he shall share it with the other.” They made the pledge and set out into the realm.
[rab tu byung ba]
Going Forth

gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das byang chub sems dpa' lo nyi shu rtsa dgu pa zhes kyang 'dod pa dag la ma rol te rgan po dang / na ba dang / shi ba gzigs pas thugs byung nas mtshan mo nam phyed na/ nags su gshegs nas lo drug tu dka' ba spyad de dka' ba byed pa ci yang med par rig nas ci bder dbugs rngub par mdzad/ ci bder dbugs 'byin par mdzad cing 'bras chan dang zan dron la sogs pa zhal zas rgya chen po dag kyang gsol bar mdzad/ zhun mar dang / 'bru mar dag gis sku dag kyang skud par mdzad/ chu dron pos kyang sku bsil bar mdzad cing grong sde 'dod du gshegs nas grong pa'i bu mo dga' mo dang / dga' stobs ma gnyis las lan bcu drug bzlas pa'i 'o ma sbrang rtsi dang bsres pa gsol te/ klu'i rgyal po nag pos mngon par bstod pa na rtswa bkra shis 'tshong ba las rtswa gser gyi mdog lta bu dag bzhes nas byang chub kyi gzhi ga la ba der gshegs te byon nas nyid kyis rtswa ma 'khrugs shing kun du ma 'khrugs pa'i gdan bshams nas skyil mo krung bcas te sku drang por bsrang nas dran pa phyogs par bzhag ste bzhugs nas/

When the blessed Bodhisattva reached the age of twenty-nine, he ceased to revel in desires, for the sight of the elderly, the sick, and the dead had moved him deeply. He stole out in the middle of the night and fled into the forest, where he spent six years practicing austerities. But he came to see that those austerities would amount to nothing. He then breathed freely, in and out, and partook again of solid foods such as rice and porridge. He rubbed ghee and oil into his skin and took refreshing baths in warm water. [S.12.b] When he came to the village of Senānī, the village headman’s daughters, Nandā and Nandabalā, gave him milk that had been churned sixteen times and mixed with honey to drink. He was lauded by the nāga king Kālika, and he accepted a bundle of auspicious golden-colored kūśa grass from a grassmonger. From there he went to what would be the site of his awakening. He arrived and settled cross-legged into an unshakable absorption on an unshakable bed of kuśa grass. Sitting straight and erect, he settled his mind and said:
ji srid zag med ma thob pa/ / de srid skyil krung gzhig mi bya/ /
“I shall not uncross my legs Until I have achieved the undefiled state.”
zhes thugs bskyed cing gsung brjod de/ de yis ji srid zag med pa/ / ma brnyes skyil krung 'jig mi mdzad/ /
His intention pledged, he said: “So long as I have not found an undefiled state, I shall not uncross my legs.”

ces bya ba dang / gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das kyis mtshan mo'i gung thun la bdud 'byung po dung phyur phrag gsum dang / bye ba phrag drug gi 'khor dang ldan pa byams pa'i stobs kyis mngon par btul te bla na med pa'i mkhyen pa thugs su chud nas tshangs pas gsol te bA rA Na sIr gshegs nas lan gsum du bzlas te rnam pa bcu gnyis su chos dang ldan pa chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba de'i tshe lnga pa dang / nye lnga dag dang / grong pa'i khye'u mtho ba mtho ba lnga bcu btul te rab tu byung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par mdzad do/ /

During the midnight hours, through the power of his loving kindness the Blessed One subdued Māra and his retinue of 360 million demonic spirits, and unsurpassed wisdom arose within him. At Brahmā’s request, he went to Vārāṇasī and turned the wheel of Dharma, revealing in three phases a teaching with twelve aspects.[93] During that time, he converted the group of five, the five friends,[94] and fifty high-born village brahmin youths, who then went forth and received full ordination. [F.31.a]

ras bal can gyi tshal gseb tu gshegs nas bzang sde'i tshogs drug bcu bden pa dag la bkod do/ / grong sde 'dong du gshegs nas grong pa'i bu mo dga' mo dang / dga' stobs ma gnyis bden pa dag la bkod do/ / lteng rgyas su gshegs nas ral pa can stong rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par mdzad do/ / ga yA mgo'i mchod rten du gshegs nas dge slong stong po de dag cho 'phrul gsum gyi gdams pa mdzad nas 'khor ba'i dgon pa las bsgral te shin tu mthar thug pa grub pa dang bde ba bla na med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa la bkod do/ / ltang brang gi tshal gseb tu gshegs nas ma ga d+hA'i rgyal po bzo sbyangs gzugs can snying po lha brgyad khri dang ma ga d+hA pa'i bram ze dang / khyim bdag 'bum phrag du ma dang lhan cig bden pa dag la bzhag go/ / rgyal po'i khab tu gshegs nas 'od ma'i tshal bzhes te/ de na sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rgyal po'i khab na 'od ma'i tshal ka lan da ka'i gnas na bzhugs so/ /

While passing through the Karpāsī forest, he convinced a noble band of sixty youths of the truths. While passing through the village of Senānī, he convinced the village headman’s daughters, Nandā and Nandabalā, of the truths. While passing through Uruvilvā, he inspired a group of one thousand dreadlocked ascetics to go forth, and ordained them. While passing by the Gayāśīrṣa stūpa, he instructed those one thousand monks by displaying three miracles, thereby freeing them from the wilds of saṃsāra and establishing them in the utterly final state of perfection and the unsurpassably blissful state of nirvāṇa. While passing through the Yaṣtī forest, he brought the King of Magadha, Bimbisāra of the Guilds, to the truths along with 80,000 gods and many hundreds of thousands of Magadhan brahmins and householders. While passing through Rājagṛha, he accepted the offering of a bamboo park. It was then that the Blessed Buddha took up residence at the Kalandakanivāpa in Rājagṛha’s Bamboo Park.

nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis kyang ljongs rgyu zhing dong ba na rgyal po'i khab tu phyin pa dang de na grong khyer rgyal po'i khab chem me chems se 'dug pa mthong nas/ de gnyis kyis bsams pa/ rgyu gnyis kyis grong khyer chen po 'di lta bu chem me chems ser gyur te/ pha rol gyi dmag tshogs kyis 'jigs pa dang / dge sbyong ngam bram ze bsod nams dang dbang che bar grags pa 'ga' zhig gnas pa las 'gyur ro snyam nas/

Having set out into the realm, Upatiṣya and Kolita also arrived in Rājagṛha. They saw that Rājagṛha was utterly still and thought, “One of only two things could have brought utter quiet to this town: either fear of neighboring armies, or the presence of several ascetics and brahmins famed for their merit and majesty.”
de gnyis kyi rgyu skar dag la blta bar brtsams nas de gnyis kyis bsams pa/ re zhig pha rol gyi dmag tshogs kyis 'jigs pa ni med pas sang shes par bya'o snyam mo/ /
As they began to examine the stars, they acknowledged, “As neighboring armies present no imminent danger, tomorrow we shall know more.”

de gnyis kyi kun du spyod pa ni gang gi tshe de gnyis 'phral ris gsum byas te spyod yul du 'dong ba de'i tshe na srog chags 'bum phrag du ma dag phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su 'brang bar 'gyur ba yin no/ / de gnyis phyi de nyin par 'phral ris gsum byas te/ spyod yul du dong ba dang de'i nyin par sems can gcig kyang phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su mi 'brang ngo / / de gnyis phyir byung ste bltas na/ ji tsam na sems can gcig kyang phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su mi 'brang bar mthong nas de gnyis kyis bsams pa/ bdag cag gnyis sngon chad spyod yul du 'dong ba de'i tshe na srog chags 'bum phrag du ma dag phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su 'brang bar gyur na/ da ltar sems can gcig kyang phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su mi 'brang ba 'di la rgyu gang yin snyam mo/ /

The two were in the habit of daubing three lines of ash across their foreheads and going out on their daily rounds. When they did so, many hundreds of thousands of creatures would always follow after them. The next day they daubed three lines of ash across their foreheads and went out on their daily rounds. However, on that day not a single being [F.31.b] followed after them. On returning they considered the matter. They saw that not a single being had followed after them and wondered, “In the past when we have gone out on rounds, many hundreds of thousands of creatures would follow after us. Why then has not a single being followed after us today?”

de'i skabs su sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams la ni mi mkhyen pa dang / ma gzigs pa dang / ma rig pa dang / rnam par mi mkhyen pa cung zad kyang mi mnga' bas/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'tsho zhing bzhugs la gson zhing gzhes pa thugs rje chen po dang ldan pa/ 'jig rten la phan par zhugs pa/ srung ba gcig pu pa/ nyag gcig dpa' ba/ gnyis pa med pa/ gnyis su mi gsung ba/ zhi gnas dang lhag mthong gis bzhugs pa/ rig pa gsum gsal bar mdzad pa/ bslab pa gsum la legs par bslabs pa/ dul ba'i gnas gsum gyi gzhi la mkhas pa/ chu bo bzhi las rgal ba rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhis spyod pa'i gzhi la legs par gnas pa/ bsdu ba'i dngos po bzhi la yun ring po nas yongs su sbyangs pa mdzad pa/ 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi ston pa/ mi 'jigs pa bzhis bsnyengs pa mi mnga' ba yan lag lnga spangs pa/ 'gro ba lnga las yang dag par 'das pa/ phung po lnga bdag med par ston pa/ yan lag drug dang ldan pa/ pha rol du phyin pa drug yongs su rdzogs pa/ rtag tu gnas pa drug gis gnas pa/ dbang po drug gi sgo bsdams pa/ yang dag par dga' bar bya ba'i chos drug la goms par mdzad pa/ byang chub kyi yan lag bdun gyi me tog gis phyug pa/ 'phags pa'i nor bdun ston pa/ 'jig rten gyi chos brgyad kyis ma gos pa/ kun nas mnar sems kyi dngos po dgu la mkhas pa/ lam gyi yan lag brgyad ston pa/ mthar gyis gnas pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dgu la mkhas pa/ stobs bcu'i stobs dang ldan pa/ phyogs bcur snyan pas yang dag par rgyas pa/ brgya phrag bcur dbang sgyur ba las khyad par du 'phags pa rnams kyi

There is nothing, even in the slightest, the blessed buddhas do not know, do not see, are not aware of, or do not notice. Thus the Blessed Buddha subsists, alive and well, endowed with great compassion, engaged in actions to help the world; is its sole protector, its lone champion, one of a kind; does not speak duplicitously; is sustained by calm abiding and insight; illuminates the three types of knowledge; is well-trained in the three trainings; is skilled in the three approaches to discipline; has crossed the four rivers; is well-grounded in his use of the four foundations of miraculous conduct, and is one who long ago perfected the four means of attraction; who teaches the four noble truths; who, being fearless in four ways, is never frightened; who has abandoned the five branches, has transcended the five rebirths, teaches the five aggregates to be selfless, is in possession of the six branches, and has perfected the six perfections; who always abides by the six spheres, who binds the six sense gates; who accustoms himself to the six dharmas that elicit perfect joy; who is rich with the flower of awakening’s seven branches; who displays the seven treasures of a noble being; who is unstained by the eight mundane concerns; who knows the nine things that inspire aggression; who teaches the eight branches of the path; who is skilled in the nine stages of meditative absorption;[95] [F.32.a] who possesses the strength of the ten strengths; whose good name has spread in the ten directions; and who surpasses those who rule over the thousandfold universe.

chos nyid ni nyin lan gsum mtshan lan gsum du sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis 'jig rten la rnam par gzigs nas/ gang na nyams par gyur/ gang ni 'phel bar gyur/ gang ni gnod par gyur/ gang na nyam nga bar gyur/ gang ni mi bde bar gyur/ gang ni gnod pa dang / nyam nga ba dang / mi bde bar gyur/ gang ni ngan song la gzhol/ gang ni ngan song la 'bab/ gang ni ngan song la bab/ ngas gang ni ngan song gi lam las bslong ste mtho ris dang / thar pa dang 'bras bu la gzhag par bya/ 'dod pa'i 'dam du bying ba gang gi lag nas ni drang bar bya/ 'phags pa'i nor gyi dbyig dang bral ba gang ni 'phags pa'i nor gyi dbang phyug la gzhag par bya/ gang gi sangs rgyas 'byung bas brgyan pa'i 'jig rten ni 'bras bu dang bcas par bya/ gang gi dge ba'i rtsa ba dag ma bskyed pa ni bskyed par bya/ gang gi dge ba'i rtsa ba dag bskyed pa ni yongs su smin par bya/ yongs su smin pa gang ni rnam par grol bar bya zhes mkhyen pa dang gzigs pa la 'jug go/ / smras pa/

As it is in the nature of such beings to watch over the world with their buddha eye during the three times of the day and night, they know and see who has fallen, who has flourished, who hurts, who wants, who is unhappy, who hurts, who wants, who is unhappy,[96] who is headed for a miserable rebirth, who will fall into a miserable rebirth; who will decide to rise from his path towards a miserable rebirth and land in a high-status rebirth, liberation, or the fruition; who will reach out his hand to those sinking in the mud of desire; who lacks the riches of a noble being’s treasures; who will come to the magnificent wealth of a noble being’s treasures; whose buddhahood, with its attendant fruits, will ornament the world; whose latent roots of virtue will bud; whose budding roots of virtue will blossom; and who, having blossomed, will be freed. It has been said:

chu srin gnas kyi dug can pa/ / dus las 'da' bar 'gyur srid kyi/ / sangs rgyas gdul la byams pa ni/ / dus las 'da' bar mi 'gyur ro/ / ji ltar ma ni bu sdug gcig pu la/ / rtog cing de srog srung bar byed pa ltar/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'ang gdul ba'i skye bo la/ / rtog par mdzad cing de srog srung bar mdzad/ / kun mkhyen rgyud la mnga' ba'i thugs rje yis/ / bzhon ma gdul ba'i be'u tshol mi skyo ste/ / srid dang ngan 'gros nyams la byams pa ni/ / rab nyams be'u la byams pa'i ba bzhin no/ /

The home of noxious water beasts May in time evaporate, But the love of buddhas For their disciples shall not. As a mother holds dear And protects her only child, Tathāgatas too hold dear And protect their disciples. An omniscient mind’s compassion never wanes In its quest for the young calves it nurses, So its love for those who fall to the miserable realms and saṃsāra Is like the cow’s love for its fallen calf.

de ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis 'jig rten la rnam par gzigs na kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis rgyud yongs su smin pa/ sngon gyi sangs rgyas rnams la bya ba lhag par byas pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba'i tshogs bsags pa yin te/ de gnyis gdul ba'i dus ni 'bras yongs su smin pa mtshon gyis brtol ba la sdod pa lta bu yin par gzigs nas/ bcom ldan 'das 'di snyam du dgongs te/ ci 'di gnyis re zhig ston pas gdul ba yin nam/ 'on te nyan thos kyis gdul ba yin snyam du dgongs na/ nyan thos kyis gdul ba yin par gzigs so/ /

Thus the Blessed One watches over the world with his buddha eye. With this eye, the Blessed One saw that the minds of the wandering mendicants Upatiṣya and Kolita had been ripened through their service to past buddhas and the stores of virtue they had amassed, [F.32.b] and thus he understood that the two wandering mendicants were like fruit ripe for the plucking. The time to train them had come. The Blessed One thought, “Will these two be captivated by the Teacher or by his disciples?” and saw they would be captivated by disciples.

sgo gang nas 'jug par 'gyur/ ci rdzu 'phrul gyis gdul ba yin nam/ 'on te spyod lam gyis gdul ba yin snyam du dgongs na/ spyod lam gyis gdul ba yin par gzigs so/ / bcom ldan 'das ni gang la spyod lam gyis gdul ba de la tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gtong bar mdzad de/ 'di ltar de'i spyod lam gyis ni lha dang mi'i yid sdud par byed pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa rta thul la bka' stsal pa/ rta thul khyod kyis kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis la soms shig /

He thought, “What will be their way into the renunciant order? Will they be drawn by miracles or by conduct?” Thinking that, he saw they would be drawn by conduct. The Blessed One summoned the venerable Aśvajit, whose conduct he saw would captivate them, for conduct like his captivated gods and men. Then the Blessed One instructed the venerable Aśvajit, “Aśvajit, consider the wandering mendicants Upatiṣya and Kolita.”

tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyis cang mi smra bas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa dang du blangs so/ / de nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' la lhag par bya ba byed pa yin pas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa la mngon par bstod pa dang rjes su yi rang ba byas nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/

Aśvajit’s silence indicated his assent to the Blessed One’s instruction. As Aśvajit was fully committed to acting on the Blessed One’s instruction, he praised and welcomed the Blessed One’s instruction. Bowing his head at the Blessed One’s feet, he said, “I go with the Blessed One’s guidance.”

bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas song ngo / / de nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul de nyid kyi mtshan mo 'das nas snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te/ 'gro ba dang / ldog pa dang / chung zad blta ba dang / rnam par blta ba dang / bskum pa dang / brkyang ba dang / snam sbyar dang /

Early the next morning, after the night had passed, the venerable Aśvajit put on his under robe and took up his begging bowl and robes. Clad in robes and bearing a begging bowl, he entered Rājagṛha to beg alms, radiant in his coming and going, his gazing ahead and his gazing to the side, the withdrawing and extending of his limbs.[97]

chos gos dang lhung bzed thogs pa mdzes pas rgyal po'i khab tu bsod snyoms la zhugs so/ / de'i tshe na kun du rgyu nye rgyal rgyal po'i khab tu bya ba zhig gi phyir spyod yul du zhugs pas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul 'gro ba dang / ldog pa dang / chung zad blta ba dang / rnam par blta ba dang / bskum pa dang / brkyang ba dang / snam sbyar dang / chos gos dang lhung bzed thogs pa mdzes pas rgyal po'i khab na bsod snyoms la rgyu ba thag ring po kho na nas mthong ngo / / mthong nas kyang 'di snyam du sems te/ rgyal po'i khab 'dir rab tu byung ba ji snyed cig lhags shing gnas pa dag las 'di lta ste/ rab tu byung ba 'di'i spyod lam lta bu ni bdag gis sngan chad 'ga' yang ma mthong bas bdag de'i gan du song ste/ dge slong khyod kyi ston pa ni gang yin/ gang gi phyir ni rab tu byung / su'i chos la ni dga' zhes dri'o snyam du rig nas

Meanwhile the wandering mendicant Upatiṣya was out and about in Rājagṛha on some errand when he saw from afar the venerable Aśvajit, clad in robes and bearing a begging bowl, he entered Rājagṛha to beg alms, [F.33.a] radiant in his coming and going, his gazing ahead and his gazing to the side, the withdrawing and extending of his limbs. On seeing him he thought, “So this is what the renunciants who come to live here in Rājagṛha are like. Never in my life have I seen anyone carry himself like this renunciant. I must approach him and ask, ‘Monk, who is your teacher? Why have you gone forth? Whose Dharma do you favor?’ ”

lam po che rub pa zhig na 'gro ba dang ldog pas shas cher sdod cing 'dug go/ / de nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul kun du rgyu nye rgyal ga la ba der song ngo / / de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal gyis tshe dang ldan pa rta thul la 'di skad ces smras so/ / dge slong khyod kyi ston pa ni gang yin/ gang gi phyir ni rab tu byung / su'i chos la ni dga'/

Knowing the monk was likely to pass by one of the main crossroads, Upatiṣya went there to wait. When the venerable Aśvajit reached the spot where Upatiṣya was, Upatiṣya asked this of Aśvajit: “Monk, who is your teacher? Why have you gone forth? Whose Dharma do you favor?”

tshe dang ldan pa shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong gau ta ma shAkya'i rigs las skra dang kha spu bregs nas gos ngur smrig dag bags te yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu byung ba zhig yod de/ de bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par sangs rgyas pas kho bo'i ston pa ni bcom ldan 'das de yin no/ / kho bo de'i phyir rab tu byung ngo / / kho bo de'i chos la dga'o/ /

“Gautama, the venerable monk and prince of the Śākyas, left the Śākya clan, shaved his head and beard, donned the saffron robes and, with perfect faith, went forth from home into homelessness. In his unsurpassed, perfect awakening, he has become a perfect buddha. My teacher is the Blessed One. It is because of him that I have gone forth. It is his Dharma that I favor.”

dge slong de'i phyir chos ston cig /tshe dang ldan pa kho bo ni na gzhon pa dang rab tu byung ba gsar pas de'i phyir kho bos bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas de'i bstan pa rgya cher yang dag par rab tu bstan par sla ba ma yin te/ 'di ltar de'i don bstan par bya'o/ /

“Monk, then you must share one of his teachings!” “Venerable, I am but young and a new renunciant so it would not be easy for me to fully and perfectly explain the teachings of the Blessed One, who is a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfect buddha. Thus I will share with you their import.”

dge slong kho bo la ni don dgos kyi tshig ni shin du mang pos kyang ci bya ste/ khyod kyis don mang yang rung nyung yang rung ston cig /de nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/
“Monk, the import is what I need. What good is a lengthy explanation? Please teach me the import, whatever its length.” The venerable Aśvajit spoke this verse:
chos rnams gang dag rgyu las byung ba dang / / de yi rgyu dang de 'gog gang yin pa'ang / / de bzhin gshegs pa nyid kyis bka' stsal te/ / de skad gsung ba'i tshul can dge sbyong che/ /
“Those phenomena that arise from causes, [F.33.b] The Tathāgata himself has taught That they have a cause and also a cessation. The Great Śramaṇa is the one who thus proclaims.”[98]

chos kyi rnam grangs 'di bshad pa na kun du rgyu nye rgyal chos rnams la chos kyi mig rdul med cing dri ma dang bral ba skyes so/ / de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal chos mthong ba dang / chos thos pa dang / chos rig pa dang / chos kyi gting sleb pa dang / som nyi las rgal ba dang / the tshom las rgal ba dang / gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog pa dang / gzhan gyis mi bkri ba dang / ston pa'i bstan pa'i chos rnams la mi 'jigs pa thob nas stan las langs te bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud de de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

Once he had explained this aspect of the Dharma, Upatiṣya came to see phenomena through the unclouded and pristine eyes of Dharma. Upatiṣya saw the Dharma, heard the Dharma, knew the Dharma, plumbed the depths of the Dharma, overcame his skepticism, transcended doubt, could not be swayed by others, and was not reliant on others. With his newfound fearless confidence in the Dharma taught by the Teacher, he stood up from his seat, pulled his shawl from one shoulder, bowed to the venerable Aśvajit with his palms pressed together, and spoke in verse:
skyob pa rnams kyi chos 'di yin/ / bskal mang bye ba khrag khrig tu/ / sngan chad ma mthong ma thos pa/ / 'chi med mya ngan med pa yi/ / go 'phang 'di la rjes su rtogs/ /
“This is the Dharma of saviors. For millions upon billions of eons I have neither seen it nor heard it. May I come to realize This immortal and peaceful state.”

tshe dang ldan pa bcom ldan 'das de da ltar ga la bzhugs/ tshe dang ldan pa rgyal po'i khab 'od ma'i tshal bya ka lan da ka'i gnas 'di nyid na'o/ / de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyis smras pa la mngon par bstod pa dang rjes su yi rang ba byas te/ tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyi rkang pa gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal nas/ tshe dang ldan pa rta thul la lan gsum bskor ba byas te song nas kun du rgyu pang nas skyes ga la ba der song ngo / /

“Venerable, where is the Blessed One now?” “Venerable, at the Kalandakanivāpa, in the Bamboo Park outside Rājagṛha.” Upatiṣya then praised and welcomed what Aśvajit had said. After prostrating at Aśvajit’s feet, he circumambulated him three times and went to see Kolita.

kun du rgyu pang nas skyes kyis kun du rgyu nye rgyal thag ring po kho na nas mthong ngo / / mthong nas kyang kun du rgyu nye rgyal la 'di skad ces smras so/ / tshe dang ldan pa khyod kyi dbang po rnams ni rnam par rang bzhin gyi mdog ni yongs su dag /pags pa'i mdog ni shin du dkar na khyod kyis bdud rtsi rnyed dam/

From a long way off, Kolita saw Upatiṣya approaching. On meeting him, he said to Upatiṣya, “Venerable, your faculties are clear and your complexion lustrous. If your skin is so radiant, does that mean you have found ambrosia?”
tshe dang ldan pa rnyed do/ / tshe dang ldan pa de'i phyir chos ston cig / de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal gyis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/
“I have found someone worth venerating.” “Share this venerable one’s teaching.” Upatiṣya then spoke in verse:
chos rnams gang dag rgyu las byung ba dang / / de yi rgyu dang de 'gog gang yin pa'ang / / de bzhin gshegs pa nyid kyis bka' stsal te/ / de skad gsung ba'i tshul can dge sbyong che/ /
“Those phenomena that arise from causes, [F.34.a] The Tathāgata himself has taught That they have a cause and also a cessation. The Great Śramaṇa is the one who thus proclaims.”
tshe dang ldan pa da dung yang lan gcig brjod cig / tshe dang ldan pa brjod par bya'o/ /
“Venerable, please repeat it one more time. Venerable, say it again.”
chos rnams gang dag rgyu las byung ba dang / / de yi rgyu dang de 'gog gang yin pa'ang / / de bzhin gshegs pa nyid kyis bka' stsal te/ / de skad gsung ba'i tshul can dge sbyong che/ /
“Those phenomena that arise from causes, The Tathāgata himself has taught That they have a cause and also a cessation. The Great Śramaṇa is the one who thus proclaims.”

chos kyi rnam grangs 'di bshad pa na kun du rgyu pang nas skyes chos rnams la chos kyi mig rdul med cing dri ma dang bral ba skyes so/ / de nas kun du rgyu pang nas skyes chos mthong ba dang / chos thos pa dang / chos rig pa dang / chos kyi gting sleb pa dang / som nyi las rgal ba dang / the tshom las rgal ba dang / gzhan gyi dring mi 'jog pa dang / gzhan gyis mi bkri ba dang / ston pa'i bstan pa'i chos rnams la mi 'jigs pa thob nas stan las langs te bla gos phrag pa gcig tu gzar nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud de/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

Once Upatiṣya had explained this aspect of the Dharma, Kolita too came to see phenomena through the unclouded and pristine eyes of Dharma. Kolita saw the Dharma, heard the Dharma, knew the Dharma, plumbed the depths of the Dharma, overcame his skepticism, transcended doubt, could not be swayed by others, and could not be led astray by others. Having gained a fearless confidence in the Dharma taught by the Teacher, he stood up from his seat, pulled his shawl from one shoulder, bowed to Upatiṣya with his palms pressed together, and spoke in verse:
skyob pa rnams kyi chos 'di yin/ / bskal mang bye ba khrag khrig tu/ / sngan chad ma mthong ma thos pa/ / 'chi med mya ngan med pa yi/ / go 'phang 'di la rjes su rtogs/ /
“This is the Dharma of saviors. For millions upon billions of eons I have neither seen it nor heard it. May I come to realize This immortal and peaceful state.”

tshe dang ldan pa bcom ldan 'das de da ltar ga la bzhugs/ tshe dang ldan pa rgyal po'i khab 'od ma'i tshal bya ka lan da ka'i gnas 'di nyid na'o/ / tshe dang ldan pa tshur shog /bcom ldan 'das de'i spyan sngar tshangs par spyod pa spyad par bya'o/ /
“Venerable, where is the Blessed One now?” “At the Kalandakanivāpa, in the Bamboo Park outside Rājagṛha.” “Come. We must live the holy life under the guidance of the Blessed One.”

tshe dang ldan pa de'i phyir je 'khor la blta bar bya ste/ bdag cag lta bu'i mi grags pa dang ldan pa shes par gyur pa dag gis 'khor la blta ba ni legs pa yin no/ / de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis kyis bram ze'i khye'u rnams la smras pa/ bram ze'i khye'u rnams shes par gyis shig /kho bo cag gnyis ni bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar tshangs par spyad pa spyod par byed na khyed cag ji ltar byed/

“But venerable, we must first see our followers; for it is only proper that knowledgeable and prominent people like us visit our followers.” So the wandering mendicants Upatiṣya and Kolita went to the young brahmins and said, “Young brahmins, listen. What will you do if we two go to live the holy life under the guidance of the Blessed One?”

mkhan po gnyis bdag cag cung zad ci 'tshal ba gang lags pa de dag thams cad mkhan po gnyis las brten nas 'tshal ba lags na/ gal te mkhan po gnyis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar tshangs par spyad pa spyod na bdag cag kyang mkhan po gnyis rab tu byung ba'i rjes su rab tu 'byung bar bgyi'o/ / bram ze'i khye'u rnams da de'i dus la bab par shes par gyis shig /

“Preceptors, [F.34.b] the little we seek, we seek because of you; so if you two preceptors go to live the holy life under the guidance of the Blessed One and go forth, we too will go forth.” “Young brahmins, then know that the time has come.”

de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis 'khor nyis brgya lnga bcu lnga bcu dang 'od ma'i tshal bya ka lan da ka'i gnas ga la ba der dong ngo / / de'i tshe na tshe dang ldan pa rta thul nyin mo spyod pa'i phyir shing ljon pa zhig gi drung na rten cing 'dug go/ / kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis kyis tshe dang ldan pa rta thul thag ring po kho na nas mthong ngo / / mthong nas kyang nye rgyal gyis pang nas skyes la smras pa/ pang nas skyes ci je bcom ldan 'das la bsnyen bkur bya'am/ 'on te gang las chos thos pa de la bya/

Upatiṣya and Kolita and their students, 250 apiece, then went to the Kalandakanivāpa in the Bamboo Park. At the time, the venerable Aśvajit was seated, taking shelter from the sun at the foot of a tree. The wandering mendicants Upatiṣya and Kolita saw the venerable Aśvajit from a long way off. On seeing him, Upatiṣya asked Kolita, “Kolita, do we first pay our respects to the Blessed One, or to the one from whom we have heard of his Dharma?”

des smras pa/ je gang las chos thos pa de la bsnyen bkur bya'o/ / de gnyis tshe dang ldan pa rta thul ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyi rkang pa gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te mtha' gcig tu 'khod do/ / de'i tshe na bram ze zla ba la dga' ba zhig zla ba la bsnyen bkur byed cing phyag 'tshal lo/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis byung ba 'di la tshigs su bcad pa bka' stsal pa/

“To the one from whom we have heard of his Dharma.” The two of them went to the venerable Aśvajit. Reaching him, they prostrated at his feet, before taking a seat off to one side. At that point, a brahmin who loved the Moon paid respect and homage. He then spoke a verse of the Blessed One’s:
rgan pa dang ni gzhon pa'ang rung / / gang las chos ni rnam shes pa/ / de la gus par phyag bya ste/ / zla ba tshes la ji bzhin no/ /
“Like a pure brahmin does to the Moon, Bow with respect to the one, Whether he be young or old, Who tells you of the Dharma.”
bram ze me la dga' ba zhig kyang me la bsnyen bkur byed cing phyag 'tshal lo/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis byung ba 'di la tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/
At that point, a brahmin who loved fire paid respect and homage. He then spoke a verse of the Blessed One’s:
rgan pa dang ni gzhon pa'ang rung / / gang las chos ni rnam shes pa/ / de la gus par phyag bya ste/ / me la bram ze gtsang ma bzhin// //
“Like a pure brahmin does to fire, Bow with respect to the one, Whether he be young or old, Who tells you of the Dharma.”
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po bzhi pa/
de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis tshe dang ldan pa rta thul gyi rkang pa gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te dong nas bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der dong ngo / /
When Upatiṣya and Kolita had prostrated at the feet of Aśvajit, they left and went to where the Blessed One was. [F.35.a]

de'i tshe na bcom ldan 'das dge slong gi 'khor brgya phrag du ma'i gung la chos ston cing bzhugs so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis thag ring po kho na nas gzigs so/ / gzigs nas kyang dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag khyed kyis grogs yongs su sdud pa/ tshogs yongs su 'dren pa/ tshogs kyi mdun nas 'ong ba 'di lta ste/ nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis mthong ngam/ btsun pa mthong ngo / / 'di gnyis ni nga'i nyan thos zung dang / zung gi mchog dang / zung bzang bor 'gyur te/ gcig ni rdzu 'phrul dang ldan pa rnams kyi mchog tu 'gyur la/ cig shos ni shes rab dang ldan pa rnams kyi mchog tu 'gyur ro/ / de nas dge slong zhig gis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

At the time, the Blessed One was seated, teaching Dharma amidst many hundreds of monk followers. The Blessed One saw Upatiṣya and Kolita from a long way off. When he saw them, he said to the monks, “Monks, embrace your friends, bring them to the head of the assembly, let them come before you. Do you see Upatiṣya and Kolita, or do you see venerable ones? These two will become my disciples, my foremost and noblest pair, for one shall become the greatest of miracle workers, and the other shall become the wisest of the wise.” A monk then spoke a verse:

ston pa dgongs yul mtha' yas pa/ / skyes bu'i dbang po mkhyen mthar byon/ / bcom ldan srid pa'i mthar mdzad pas/ / grogs po nye rgyal pang nas skyes/ / 'od ma'i tshal du ma phyin par/ / de ltar mchi ba gzigs gyur nas/ / tshogs mchog dbus su de gnyis ni/ / 'di gnyis nga yi nyan thos kyi/ / zung mchog 'gyur zhes nges bstan te/ / gcig ni rdzu 'phrul ldan pa'i mchog / cig shos shes rab ldan pa yi/ / mchog tu 'gyur bar lung bstan mdzad/ /

“To what the Teacher knows there is no end, His mind the perfection of human capacity. The Blessed One has reached saṃsāra’s end, So before our friends Upatiṣya and Kolita Arrived in the Bamboo Park He foresaw their coming And said with certainty among this gathering: ‘These two will become The foremost among all my disciples. One will be the greatest Of miracle workers; The other will be The wisest of the wise.’ ”

de nas kun du rgyu nye rgyal dang pang nas skyes gnyis bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/ bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa bdag cag legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po gnang na/ bdag cag bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar tshangs par spyod pa spyad par bgyi'o/ /

Upatiṣya and Kolita then approached the Blessed One, prostrated at his feet, and made the following request: “If we are permitted, reverend, we would receive the going forth, ordination, and monkhood in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya. We would live the holy life in the Blessed One’s presence.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis de gnyis la dge slong tshur shog ces bya bas rab tu phyung zhing dge slong dag tshur shog tshangs par spyad pa spyod cig ces bka' stsal pa dang / de dag bcom ldan 'das kyi bka'i mjug kho nar skra byi ba dang snam sbyar gyon par gyur te/ skra dang kha spu zhag bdun skyes pa tsam dang / lag pa na lhung bzed dang / bya ma bum thogs pa dang / dge slong bsnyen par rdzogs nas lo brgya lon pa'i spyod lam lta bur gnas par gyur to/ / yang smras pa/

The Blessed One allowed goings forth by saying the phrase, “Come, monk,” and so as soon as he said, “Come, monks, live the holy life,” their hair fell out and they were clad in robes, [F.35.b] with but a week’s growth of hair and beard, begging bowls and water jars in hand, settled, with the composure of monks who had been ordained for one hundred years. Again it is said:
de bzhin gshegs pas tshur shog bka' stsal pas/ / skra byi snam sbyar gyon pa'i lus ldan zhing / / mod la dbang po rab zhir gnas gyur te/ / sangs rgyas dgongs pas lus gzugs bkab par gyur/ /
Hair tonsured and body clad in robes By the Tathāgata’s call to come forth, That moment, their senses were perfectly stilled For then will your body be swathed in the Buddha’s mind.

de nas dge slong rab tu mang po dag snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te/ rgyal po'i khab tu bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / de na rgyal po'i khab kyi mi gang dag yang dag rgyal ba can gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs nas ring po ma lon pas yi ma rangs shing mngon par mi dga' ba de dag gis dge slong de dang de dag mthong nas co 'dri zhing tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

Early the next morning, a great many monks put on their under robes, took up their begging bowls and robes and entered Rājagṛha to beg for alms. When the people of Rājagṛha saw that members of Sañjayin’s tīrthika community had renounced it and joined the Buddha’s renunciant order, they quickly became disappointed[99] and visibly upset. Vilifying the monks, they spoke in verse:

sangs rgyas ma ga d+hA dag gi/ / grong mchog rgyal po'i khab gshegs pas/ / yang dag rgyal ba'i kun khrid na/ / phyin chad ci zhig bkri bar bya/ / des dge slong rnams spa gong zhing mi dga' ba dang mi 'jigs pa med par gyur to/ /

“The Buddha has come to Rājagṛha, Magadha’s premier city, And led away all Sañjayin’s students Only when there was naught else to lead away.”[100] The monks were crestfallen, upset, and lost their fearlessness.

de nas dge slong rab tu mang po dag rgyal po'i khab tu bsod snyoms kyi phyir brgyus nas zas kyi bya ba byas te phyi dro bsod snyoms mi len pas lhung bzed dang chos gos mkhos su phab nas rkang pa gnyis bkrus te sdug bsngal zhing mi bde bas bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der dong nas phyin pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te phyogs gcig tu 'khod do/ / phyogs gcig tu 'khod nas bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rab tu mang po dag gis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa 'di na bdag cag dge slong rab tu mang po dag snga dro sham thabs 'tshal/ lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te rgyal po'i khab tu bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / de na rgyal po'i khab kyi mi gang dag yang dag rgyal ba can gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs nas ring po ma lags pas yi ma rangs shing mngon par mi dga' ba de dag gis dge slong de dang de dag mthong nas co 'dri zhing tshigs su bcad pa/

Having gone to collect alms in Rājagṛha, the great many monks ate what they had been given and, as alms are not sought after noon, packed their begging bowls and robes, washed their feet, and went, hurting and upset, to see the Blessed One. As they arrived, the great many monks prostrated at the Blessed One’s feet, sat off to one side, and told the Blessed One, “Reverend, early this morning a great many of us monks put on our robes, picked up our begging bowls and robes, and went to Rājagṛha to collect alms. There, when the people of Rājagṛha saw that members of Sañjayin’s tīrthika community had renounced it and joined the Buddha’s renunciant order, they quickly became disappointed and visibly upset. [F.36.a] Vilifying us, they spoke in verse:

sangs rgyas ma ga d+hA dag gi/ / grong mchog rgyal po'i khab gshegs pas/ / yang dag rgyal ba'i kun khrid na/ / phyin chad ci zhig bkri bar bya/ / zhes mchi nas des bdag cag rnams spa gong zhing mi dga' ba dang / mi 'jigs pa ma mchis par gyur to/ /

“The Buddha has come to Rājagṛha, Magadha’s premier city, and And led away all Sañjayin’s students Only when there was naught else to lead away.” “With this, we became crestfallen, upset, and lost our fearlessness.”
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag rgyal po'i khab kyi mi de skad zer ba rnams la 'di skad ces/
“Monks,” instructed the Blessed One, “say this to the people of Rājagṛha who say such things:

'di la dpa' chen bde gshegs dag / dam pa'i chos kyis khrid mdzad de/ / de dag chos kyis khrid mdzad la/ / mkhas pa su zhig mi bzod byed/ / ces brjod na rgyal po'i khab kyi mi de skad zer ba rnams kyi rlom pa tsam mam spobs pa tsam gang yin pa de thams cad kyi thams cad du med par 'gyur ro/ /

“ ‘Here the mighty sugatas Lead with the sublime Dharma. What wise man could reject Such noble leadership?’ “That will dispel all the vanity and self-assurance of the people of Rājagṛha who speak like that.”

de nas dge slong rab tu mang po dag snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te rgyal po'i khab tu bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / de na rgyal po'i khab kyi mi gang dag yang dag rgyal ba can gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs nas ring po ma lon pas yi ma rangs shing mngon par mi dga' ba de dag gis dge slong de dang de dag mthong nas co 'dri zhing tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

Early the next morning, a great many monks put on their robes, took up their begging bowls and robes, and entered Rājagṛha to beg for alms. When the people of Rājagṛha saw that members of Sañjayin’s tīrthika community had renounced it and joined the Buddha’s renunciant order, they soon become disappointed and visibly upset. Vilifying the monks, they again spoke the same verse:
sangs rgyas ma ga d+hA dag gi/ / grong mchog rgyal po'i khab gshegs pas/ / yang dag rgyal ba'i kun khrid na/ / phyin chad ci zhig bkri bar bya/ /
“The Buddha has come to Rājagṛha, Magadha’s premier city, And led away all Sañjayin’s students Only when there was naught else to lead away.”

de nas dge slong zhig gis de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/ 'di na dpa' chen bde gshegs dag / dam pa'i chos kyis khrid mdzad de/ / de dag chos kyis khrid mdzad la/ / mkhas pa su zhig bzod mi byed/ /
One monk then replied: “Here the mighty sugatas Lead with the sublime Dharma. What wise man could reject Such noble leadership?”
de skad ces smras pa dang / rgyal po'i khab kyi mi de skad zer ba rnams kyi rlom pa tsam mam spobs pa tsam gang yin pa de thams cad kyi thams cad du med par gyur to/ /
With that statement he dispelled all the vanity and self-assurance of the people of Rājagṛha who spoke like that.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na bram ze gnas len gyi bu dus la bab cing de'i chung ma yang dus la bab/ bram ze skar rgyal yang dus la bab/ shA ri kA yang dus la bab bo/ / bram ze'i bu khye'u stod rings kyang lho phyogs nas 'jig rten rgyang 'phen bzung nas grong na la dar phyin pa dang / de sgo bas bzhin gyi gzugs las ngo shes nas smras pa/ shes ldan khyod stod rings yin nam/

Some time later, the brahmin Māṭhara’s time came, as did his wife’s. The brahmin Tiṣya’s time came, as did Śārikā’s. Tiṣya’s son, Koṣṭhila, returned to the village of Nālada from the South where he had taken up with the Lokāyata ascetics. [F.36.b] The village gatekeeper recognized him and asked, “Sir, are you Koṣṭhila?”
kho bo skye bo dag gis de ltar shes so/ /bram ze gnas len gyi bu de ga re/ dus la bab bo/ / de'i chung ma de ga re/ de yang dus la bab bo/ /
“People know me thus. What has become of the brahmin Māṭhara?” “His time came.” “What has become of his wife?” “Her time came.”
bram ze skar rgyal ga re/ de yang dus la bab bo/ / shA ri kA ga re/ de yang dus la bab bo/ /
“What has become of the brahmin Tiṣya?” “His time came too.” “What has become of Śārikā?” “Her time came too.”

shA ri'i bu de ga re/ rgyal po'i khab tu ston pa yang dag rgyal ba can zhes bya ba byung nas ring po ma lon pa de'i gan du rab tu byung ngo / / 'di lta ste re zhig rab tu 'byung bar bya ba de ni bram zes bya ba yin no/ /
“What has become of Śāriputra?” “Shortly after a teacher named Sañjayin appeared in Rājagṛha, he went forth and joined his renunciant order. Lately it has become common for brahmins to go forth.”
de mthar gyis rgyal po'i khab tu phyin nas de der song ste dris pa/ ston pa yang dag rgyal ba can ga re/ dus la bab bo/ /
Koṣṭhila then made his way to Rājagṛha, and when he arrived there he asked, “What has become of the teacher Sañjayin?” “His time came.”
de'i mu stegs kyi gnas ga re/ thams cad dge sbyong gau ta ma'i drung du rab tu byung ngo / /
“What has become of his tīrthika community?” “They have all gone forth and joined the renunciant order around the ascetic Gautama.”
dge sbyong gau ta ma ni 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal por lung bstan pas de yang de'i mdun na 'don du 'gyur bas legs so/ /
“It would have been good had the ascetic Gautama, who was prophesied to become king of the world, become royal priest.”

de nas kun du rgyu sen rings bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das dang thabs cig phan tshun mngon du yang dag par dga' bar 'gyur ba dang / yang dag par mgu bar 'gyur ba'i gtam sna tshogs byas te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / phyogs gcig tu 'dug nas bcom ldan 'das la kun du rgyu sen rings kyis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / kye gau ta ma bdag ni thams cad mi bzod do/ /

Koṣṭhila, who had taken the name Dīrghanakha when he became a wandering mendicant,[101] went to see the Blessed One. When he arrived, he and the Blessed One were clearly overjoyed to see one another and exchanged warm words of goodwill before Dīrghanakha sat off to one side. As he sat there off to one side, Dīrghanakha said to the Blessed One, “O Gautama, no self endures.”[102]
mer 'jug gi bu khyod kyis bdag thams cad mi bzod par lta ba gang yin pa'i lta ba de yang mi bzod do/ / kye gau ta ma bdag ni thams cad mi bzod par lta ba gang yin pa'i lta ba de yang mi bzod do/ /

“Son of a self-immolator,[103] even that view you hold, which views all forms of self as unable to endure, does not itself endure.” “Agreed, O Gautama,” replied Dīrghanakha, “even that view which views all forms of self as unable to endure does not itself endure.”

mer 'jug gi bu 'o na khyod kyis de ltar shes shing de ltar mthong na lta ba de yang spong ba dang / 'dor ba dang / med par 'gyur la/ lta ba gzhan yang mtshams mi sbyor ba dang / nye bar mi len pa dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ / kye gau ta ma bdag gis de ltar shes shing de ltar mthong na lta ba de yang spong ba dang / 'dor ba dang / med par 'gyur la/ lta ba gzhan yang mtshams mi sbyor ba dang / nye bar mi len pa dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, then know this: if you see it like that, that view too will be abandoned, discarded, and cease to be. Other views too will not be entertained, embraced, or arise.” “O Gautama, I know this, that if it is seen like that, that view too will be abandoned, discarded, and cease to be. Other views too will not be entertained, embraced, or arise.”

mer 'jug gi bu khyod ni skye bo phal po che dang lhan cig mtshungs shing 'dra bar 'gyur te/ skye bo phal po che yang de ltar lta zhing de skad smra bas khyod kyang de dang 'dra ba kho nar 'gyur ro/ / mer 'jug gi bu 'jig rten na dge sbyong ngam bram ze gang la la dag lta ba 'di yang 'dor zhing lta ba gzhan yang nye bar mi len pa'i dge sbyong ngam bram ze de dag ni nyung ba bas kyang ches nyung ba zhes bya'o/ /

The Blessed One replied at length, “Son of a self-immolator, you are like and akin to most people, [F.37.a] for most people also view things thus and say such things, and in that you are just like them. Son of a self-immolator, in this world those ascetics and brahmins who discard this view, and those ascetics and brahmins who do not embrace other views, are said to be the fewest of the few.

mer 'jug gi bu gsum po 'di dag ni lta ba'i gnas yin te/ gsum gang zhe na/ mer 'jug gi bu 'di la la la bdag ni thams cad bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba dang / gzhan yang 'di la la la bdag ni thams cad mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba dang / gzhan yang 'di la la la bdag ni kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba'o/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, there are three positions regarding the view. What are those three positions? Son of a self-immolator, regarding this point, some hold the view and argue that all selves endure. Others hold the view and argue that no self endures, while still others hold the view and argue that some selves endure and other selves do not endure.[104]

mer 'jug gi bu de la bdag ni thams cad bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni kun du 'dod chags par 'gyur gyi/ kun du 'dod chags pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du zhe sdang bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du zhe sdang ba med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du gti mug par 'gyur gyi/ kun du gti mug pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du stsogs par 'gyur gyi/ kun du stsogs pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du sbyor bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du sbyor ba dang bral bar mi 'gyur ba dang / kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur gyi/ rnam par byang bar mi 'gyur ba dang / bdag ni thams cad bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni mngon par dga' ba dang / nye bar len pa dang lhag par chags par 'gyur ba yin no/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, in holding that all selves endure, attachment will arise and attachment will not disappear; aversion will arise and aversion will not disappear; confusion will arise and confusion will not disappear; accumulation will occur and accumulation will not disappear; fetters will occur and fetters will not disappear; and defilement will arise and purification will not occur. With this view that holds that all selves endure, eager anticipation, pursuit, and excessive attachment will arise.

mer 'jug gi bu de la bdag ni thams cad mi bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni kun du 'dod chags pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du 'dod chags par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du zhe sdang ba med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du zhe sdang bar mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du gti mug pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du gti mug par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du stsogs pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du stsogs par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du sbyor ba dang bral bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du sbyor bar mi 'gyur ba dang / rnam par byang bar 'gyur gyi/ kun nas nyon mongs par mi 'gyur ba dang / bdag ni thams cad mi bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni mngon par mi dga' ba dang / nye bar len pa med pa dang / lhag par chags pa med par 'gyur ba yin no/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, in holding that no self endures, attachment will disappear and attachment will not arise; aversion will disappear and aversion will not arise; confusion will disappear and confusion will not arise; accumulation will disappear and accumulation will not occur; one will be free of fetters and fetters will not occur; and purification will occur and defilement will disappear. [F.37.b] With this view that holds that no self endures, there will be no eager anticipation, no pursuit, and excessive attachment will disappear.

mer 'jug gi bu de la bdag ni kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di la ni re zhig bdag ni kha cig bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni kun du 'dod chags par 'gyur gyi/ kun du 'dod chags pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du zhe sdang bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du zhe sdang ba med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du gti mug par 'gyur gyi/ kun du gti mug pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du stsogs par 'gyur gyi/ kun du stsogs pa med par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du sbyor bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du sbyor ba dang bral bar mi 'gyur ba dang / kun nas nyon mongs par 'gyur gyi/ rnam par byang bar mi 'gyur ba dang / bdag ni kha cig bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni mngon par dga' ba dang / nye bar len pa dang / lhag par chags par 'gyur ba yin no/ / bdag ni kha cig mi bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni kun du 'dod chags pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du 'dod chags par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du zhe sdang ba med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du zhe sdang bar mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du gti mug pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du gti mug par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du stsogs pa med par 'gyur gyi/ kun du stsogs par mi 'gyur ba dang / kun du sbyor ba dang bral bar 'gyur gyi/ kun du sbyor bar mi 'gyur ba dang / rnam par byang bar 'gyur gyi/ kun nas nyon mongs par mi 'gyur ba dang / bdag ni kha cig mi bzod do zhes lta ba'i lta ba gang yin pa 'di ni mngon par mi dga' ba dang / nye bar len pa med pa dang / lhag par chags pa med par 'gyur ba yin no/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, regarding the view that some selves endure and other selves do not endure, in holding that some selves do endure, attachment will arise and attachment will not disappear; aversion will arise and aversion will not disappear; confusion will arise and confusion will not disappear; accumulation will occur and accumulation will not disappear; fetters will occur and fetters will not disappear; and defilement will arise and purification will not occur. With this view that holds that some selves endure, eager anticipation, pursuit, and excessive attachment will arise. At the same time, in holding that some selves do not endure, attachment will disappear and attachment will not arise; aversion will disappear and aversion will not arise; confusion will disappear and confusion will not arise; accumulation will disappear and accumulation will not occur; one will be free of fetters and fetters will not occur; and purification will occur and defilement will disappear. With this view that holds that some selves do not endure, there will be no eager anticipation, no pursuit, and excessive attachment will disappear.

de la 'phags pa nyan thos thos pa dang ldan pa ni 'di ltar so sor rtog par byed de/ gal te bdag thams cad bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra na bdag ni thams cad mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa dang / bdag ni kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa gnyis dang bdag lhan cig rtsod par 'gyur/ 'gyed par 'gyur te/ rtsod na 'gyed par 'gyur/ 'gyed na rnam par 'tshe bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Learned noble disciples scrutinize the first position in this way: if one holds the view and argues that all selves endure, then the view and argument that no self endures [F.38.a] and the view and argument that some selves endure while other selves do not endure would counter and undermine the self; if it counters, it would undermine, and if it undermines, it would debunk the self.

de ltar rtsod pa dang / 'gyed pa dang / rnam par 'tshe ba yang dag par mthong nas lta ba 'di'ang dor zhing lta ba gzhan nye bar mi blang ste/ de ltar na bdag la lta ba de yang spong ba dang / 'dor ba dang / med par 'gyur la/ lta ba gzhan yang mtshams mi sbyor ba dang / nye bar mi len pa dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro snyam mo/ /

“In correctly seeing the countering, the undermining, and the debunking thus done, that view too would be abandoned and other views would not be embraced. Thus that view of self too would be abandoned, discarded, and cease to be, while other views too would not be entertained, embraced, or arise.

de la 'phags pa nyan thos thos pa dang ldan pa ni 'di ltar so sor rtog par byed de/ gal te bdag thams cad mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra na de bdag ni thams cad bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa dang / bdag ni kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa gnyis dang bdag lhan cig rtsod par 'gyur/ 'gyed par 'gyur te/ rtsod na 'gyed par 'gyur/ 'gyed na rnam par 'tshe bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Learned noble disciples scrutinize the second position in this way: if one holds the view and argues that no self endures, then the view and argument that all selves endure and the view and argument that some selves endure while other selves do not endure would counter and undermine the self; if it counters, it would undermine, and if it undermines, it would debunk the self.

de ltar rtsod pa dang / 'gyed pa dang / rnam par 'tshe ba yang dag par mthong nas lta ba 'di yang dor zhing lta ba gzhan nye bar mi blang ste/ de ltar na bdag la lta ba de yang spong ba dang / 'dor ba dang / med par 'gyur la/ lta ba gzhan yang mtshams mi sbyor ba dang / nye bar mi len pa dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro snyam mo/ /

“In correctly seeing the countering, the undermining, and the debunking thus done, that view too would be abandoned and other views would not be embraced. Thus that view of self too would be abandoned, discarded, and cease to be, while other views too would not be entertained, embraced, or arise.

de la 'phags pa nyan thos thos pa dang ldan pa ni 'di ltar so sor rtog par byed de gal te bdag kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra na bdag ni thams cad bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa dang / bdag ni kha cig bzod la kha cig mi bzod do zhes de ltar lta zhing de skad smra ba gang yin pa gnyis dang bdag lhan cig rtsod par 'gyur/ 'gyed par 'gyur te/ rtsod na 'gyed par 'gyur/ 'gyed na rnam par 'tshe bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Learned noble disciples scrutinize the third position in this way: if one holds the view and argues that some selves endure while other selves do not endure, the view and argument that all selves endure and the view and argument that no selves endure[105] would counter and undermine the self; if it counters, it would undermine, and if it undermines, it would debunk the self.

de ltar rtsod pa dang / 'gyed pa dang / rnam par 'tshe ba yang dag par mthong nas lta ba 'di yang dor zhing lta ba gzhan yang nye bar mi blang ste/ de ltar na bdag la lta ba de yang spong ba dang / 'dor ba dang / med par 'gyur la/ lta ba gzhan yang mtshams mi sbyor ba dang / nye bar mi len pa dang / mi 'byung bar 'gyur ro snyam mo/ /

“In correctly seeing the countering, the undermining, and the debunking thus done, that view too would be abandoned and other views would not be embraced. Thus that view of self too would be abandoned, discarded, and cease to be, while other views [F.38.b] too would not be entertained, embraced, or arise.

mer 'jug gi bu lus 'di ni gzugs can rags pa 'byung ba chen po bzhi las gyur pa yin te/de la 'phags pa'i nyan thos kyis yang dang yang du 'byung ba dang 'jig pa rjes su blta zhing gnas par bya'o/ / de la 'phags pa'i nyan thos yang dang yang du 'byung ba dang 'jig par rjes su lta zhing gnas na/ de la lus la 'dun pa dang / lus la chags pa dang / lus la dga' ba dang / lus la zhen pa dang / lus la chums pa dang / lus la lhag par chags pa 'byung ba gang yin pa des de'i sems yongs su gtugs te mi gnas so/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, as this body is composed of gross form and arises from the four great elements, noble disciples observe and dwell on its repeated arising and destruction. If noble disciples observe and dwell on its repeated arising and destruction, whatever aspirations, attachment, craving, obsessions, preoccupations, or excessive attachment may arise towards the body will be confronted and will not remain.

mer 'jug gi bu gsum po 'di dag ni tshor ba yin te/ gsum gang zhe na/ bde ba dang / sdug bsngal dang / sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'o/ / mer 'jug gi bu gang gi tshe 'phags pa'i nyan thos bde ba'i tshor ba myong bar byed pa de'i tshe na de la sdug bsngal dang / sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba gnyis 'gag par 'gyur te/ de'i tshe na 'phags pa'i nyan thos bde ba'i tshor ba 'ba' zhig myong bar byed de/ bde ba'i tshor ba yang mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / 'gog pa'i chos can yin no/ /

“Son of a self-immolator, there are three feelings. What are these three? Pleasure, pain, and that which is neither pleasant nor painful. Son of a self-immolator, when noble disciples experience feelings of pleasure, then feelings of pain and feelings which are neither pleasant nor painful come to a halt. At that time noble disciples experience only feelings of pleasure yet feelings of pleasure too are subject to impermanence, suffering, and cessation.

gang gi tshe 'phags pa'i nyan thos sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba myong bar byed pa de'i tshe na de la bde ba dang / sdug bsngal ba yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba gnyis 'gag par 'gyur te/ de'i tshe na 'phags pa'i nyan thos sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba 'ba' zhig myong bar byed de/ sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba yang mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / 'gog pa'i chos can yin no/ /

“When noble disciples experience feelings of pain, then feelings of pleasure and feelings which are neither pleasant nor painful come to a halt. At that time, noble disciples experience only feelings of pain yet feelings of pain too are subject to impermanence, suffering, and cessation.

gang gi tshe 'phags pa'i nyan thos sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba myong bar byed pa de'i tshe na de la bde ba dang sdug bsngal gyi tshor ba gnyis 'gag par 'gyur te/ de'i tshe na 'phags pa'i nyan thos sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba 'ba' zhig myong bar byed de/ sdug bsngal yang ma yin bde ba yang ma yin pa'i tshor ba yang mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / 'gog pa'i chos can no/ /
