d.crumb: How to give the layperson’s vows

f.d: How to give the layperson’s vows

'di ltar sbyin par bya ste/ dang por ston pa la phyag 'tshal du gzhug go/ / de'i 'og tu slob dpon la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

This is how to give the layperson’s vows. First, the postulant should prostrate to the Teacher.[119] Then, once he has been made to prostrate, have him kneel before the instructor, join his palms together, and say:

btsun pa dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba dus 'di nas bzung ste/ ji srid 'tsho'i bar du rkang gnyis rnams kyi mchog sangs rgyas la skyabs su mchi'o / / 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams kyi mchog chos la skyabs su mchi'o/ / tshogs rnams kyi mchog dge 'dun la skyabs su mchi'o / / bdag ji srid 'tsho'i bar du dge bsnyen du btsun pas gzung du gsol/

“Reverend, heed me. I, [postulant’s name], will henceforth, for as long as I live, seek refuge in the Buddha, supreme among men; I will seek refuge in the Dharma, supreme among all that is free from attachment; I will seek refuge in the Saṅgha, supreme among communities. For as long as I live, I ask that you, reverend, accept me as a lay brother.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ tshig gsum pa la slob dpon gyis zhes brjod par bya'o/ / slob dpon gyis thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant repeats this a second and a third time, but in the third recitation, should say “instructor.”[120] The instructor then says: “This is the method.”
dge bsnyen gyis legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the lay devotee says: “It is excellent.”
de ni dge bsnyen gyi sdom pa sbyin pa'o/ /
That is the giving of the layperson’s vows.

d.crumb: bslab pa brjod pa khas blang ba'i tshul

f.d: [bslab pa brjod pa khas blang ba'i tshul]
Pledging to keep the precepts

de'i 'og tu bslab pa brjod pa khas blang ba'i tshul gyis bya'o/ / 'di ltar bya ste/ slob dpon dgongs su gsol/ ji ltar 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du srog gcod pa spangs te srog gcod pa las slar log pa de bzhin du/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi bas kyang dus 'di nas bzung ste/ ji srid 'tsho'i bar du srog gcod pa spangs te/ srog gcod pa las slar ldog par bgyi'o/ / yan lag dang po 'dis bdag 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gi bslab pa la rjes su slob bo/ / rjes su bsgrub bo/ / rjes su bgyid do/ / gzhan yang ji ltar 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ma byin par len pa dang / 'dod pas log par g.yem pa dang / brdzun du smra ba dang / 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas spangs te/ 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas las slar log pa de bzhin du/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi bas kyang dus 'di nas bzung ste/ ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ma byin par len pa dang / 'dod pa la log par g.yem pa dang / brdzun du smra ba dang / 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas spangs te/ 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas las slar ldog par bgyi'o/ / yan lag lnga pa 'dis bdag 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gi bslab pa la rjes su slob bo/ / rjes su sgrub bo/ / rjes su bgyid do/ /

The postulant then expresses his commitment to the precepts with the following words: “Instructor, heed me. Just as noble arhats renounced killing and swore to refrain from killing for as long as they lived, so do I, [F.49.b] [postulant’s name], henceforth, for as long as I live, renounce killing and swear to refrain from killing. With this first branch, I pledge to train in, practice, and act upon the precepts of those noble arhats. Furthermore, noble arhats renounced and swore to refrain from stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and intoxicating substances like grain alcohol and its by-products, which leave one uninhibited. Just so do I, [postulant’s name], too, for as long as I live, renounce and swear to refrain from stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and intoxicating substances like grain alcohol and its by-products, which leave one uninhibited. With this, the fifth branch, I pledge to train in, practice, and act upon the precepts of those noble arhats.”
slob dpon gyis thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The instructor then says: “This is the method.”
dge bsnyen gyis legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the lay devotee says: “It is excellent.”
dge bsnyen nyid du nye bar sgrub pa'i cho ga rdzogs s+ho// //
This completes the layperson’s induction rite.
[rab tu 'byung ba]
Going forth
['dod pa zhu ba]

d.crumb: Informing the saṅgha of the wish to go forth

f.d: Informing the saṅgha of the wish to go forth

de'i 'og tu gang gis de zhu bar byed pa'i dge slong la gtad par bya'o/ / zhu ba'i dge slong gis mkhan po la khyod kyis bar chad kyi chos rnams dris sam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par zhu bar byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The postulant should then be directed to the monk petitioner. The monk petitioner asks the preceptor: “Have you inquired into the private matters?” A breach occurs if he makes a petition without inquiring.

de'i 'og tu zhu ba'i dge slong gis zhu bar bya'o/ / 'di ltar zhu bar bya ste/ gnas mal bsham pa byas nas gaN DI brdungs te dris pa'i tshig gis dge slong rnams la yang dag par bsgo nas dge 'dun thams cad 'dug cing mthun par gyur pa la'ang rung / gnas khang so so na 'khod pa la'ang rung ste/ rgan rims la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas zhu bar byed pas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

The monk petitioner then petitions the saṅgha in the following way. Having laid out sitting mats, he strikes the gaṇḍī beam. Once he has informed the monks with a response to their queries, the entire saṅgha sits; either together in consensus or each in his own dwelling. The postulant is then made to prostrate to the seniormost in the saṅgha before taking his place in a kneeling position, [F.50.a] with palms pressed together. The monk petitioner then addresses the saṅgha with these words:

dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi ba las rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal te/ khyim pa gos dkar po can skra dang kha spu ma bregs pa las legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal te/ ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal zhing skra dang kha spu bregs nas gos ngur smrig bgos te/ yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi ba las rab tu 'byung ste/ de yang bar chad kyi chos rnams yongs su dag go zhes kho na nyid mchi na/ ci de rab tu dbyung ngam

“I ask you, reverend saṅgha, to listen. The postulant [postulant’s name] has asked the preceptor [preceptor’s name] to allow his going forth. He wants to leave the householder’s life, with its white clothes and unshaven head and face, and go forth in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya. [Postulant’s name] wants to go forth and, having shaven head and face, to don the saffron robes. He wants to go forth from home into homelessness under the guidance of this preceptor [preceptor’s name] so that he may rely solely on what is right. And if indeed he too is without impediments, should he be allowed to go forth?”
de dag thams cad kyis gal te yongs su dag na'o zhes brjod par bya'o/ / gal te de skad brjod na de lta na legs/ gal te mi brjod na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /
The whole saṅgha should reply: “If he is without impediment, he should be allowed.” If they say that, then all is well. A breach occurs if they do not.
de ni rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa zhu ba'o// //
That is how one informs the saṅgha of the wish to go forth.
[mkhan por gsol ba]
Requesting the preceptor

de'i 'og tu mkhan por gsol ba'o/ / 'di ltar gsol bar bya ste/ mkhan po la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ slob dpon dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba slob dpon la mkhan por gsol gyis/ slob dpon bdag gi mkhan po mdzad du gsol/ slob dpon mkhan pos rab tu dbyung bar bgyi'o/ /

Next, a request is made to the preceptor. The request should be made in the following way. The postulant is made to prostrate to and then kneel before the preceptor. With palms pressed together, he should say: “Instructor, heed me. I, [postulant’s name], ask you, instructor, to serve as preceptor. Instructor, please act as my preceptor. Instructor, as preceptor, please allow my going forth.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ tshig gsum pa la mkhan po zhes brjod par bya'o/ / mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ / rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

He repeats this a second and a third time, but the third time he should say “preceptor” in place of “instructor.” The preceptor then says: “This is the method.” To which the person wishing to go forth says: “It is excellent.”
de ni mkhan por gsol ba'o/ /
That is the request to the preceptor.

de'i 'og tu gang gis de'i skra dang kha spu dag 'breg par byed pa'i dge slong la bcol bar bya'o/ / des thams cad 'breg par byed nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ thams cad breg par mi bya bar 'di ltar gtsug phud gzhag par bya zhing de'i 'og tu ci gtsug phud breg gam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / gal te mi breg go zhes zer na 'o na song shig ces brjod par bya'o/ / gal te bregs shig ces zer na breg par bya'o/ /

The postulant should then be entrusted to a monk who will shave the postulant’s hair and beard. The Blessed One decreed, “Do not shave off all of his hair but rather leave a tuft of hair at his crown.” So, after shaving off nearly all the postulant’s hair, the monk should ask the postulant: “Shall I cut this tuft?” [F.50.b] If he answers “No, do not cut it,” then tell him to go. But if he answers “Yes, I am happy for you to do so,” then cut it.
de'i 'og tu khrus byed du gzhug ste/ gal te re zhig grang ba'i dus yin na ni chu dron pos khrus byed du gzhug go/ / gal te tsha ba'i dus yin na ni chu grang mos khrus byed du gzhug go/ /
The postulant is then made to bathe. If the weather is cold, he may bathe with warm water. If the weather is warm, he should bathe with cold water.

de'i 'og tu mkhan pos lhung bzed dang gos ngur smrig dag sbyin par bya zhing des kyang rkang pa gnyis la gtugs nas blang bar bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu mkhan pos bskon par bya zhing mtshan med pa'am/ mtshan gnyis pa'am/ gle 'dams pa ma yin nam zhes brtag par bya'o/ /

The preceptor should then give him a begging bowl and saffron robes, which he accepts after bowing at the preceptor’s feet. The preceptor should then dress the postulant, checking to ensure he is not a person without genitalia, a person with two sets of genitalia, or a person with a fistula.[121]

bcom ldan 'das kyis brtag par bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas dge slong dag de sgren mor phyung ste rtog par byed pa na de ngo tsha nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ sgren mor phyung ste brtag par mi bya bar sham thabs bskon pa nyid kyi tshe ma tshor bar brtag par bya'o/ /

The Blessed One decreed that postulants should be examined, but the embarrassment that the monks’ examination caused to the naked and exposed postulants prompted the Blessed One to decree, “Do not examine him while naked. Examine him without his knowing, while he is putting on the under robe.”
de ni dus dang por bya ba'o// //
That is how the first part of the ceremony should be performed.

d.crumb: rab tu byung ba nye bar sgrub pa

f.d: [rab tu byung ba nye bar sgrub pa]
Allowing the postulant’s going forth

de'i 'og tu skyabs su 'gro ba rtsom pas rab tu 'byung ba nye bar bsgrub par bya'o/ / 'di ltar nye bar bsgrub par bya ste/ dang por ston pa la phyag 'tshal du gzhug go/ / de'i 'og tu mkhan po la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du tsog tsog pur 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

Then the postulant should be inducted as a renunciant by first going for refuge. This is how he should be inducted. The postulant is first made to prostrate to the Teacher. Then he is made to prostrate to the preceptor and kneel before him. Having pressed his palms together, he should say:

mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba dus 'di nas bzung ste ji srid 'tsho'i bar du rkang gnyis rnams kyi mchog sangs rgyas la skyabs su mchi'o/ / 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams kyi mchog chos la skyabs su mchi'o/ / tshogs rnams kyi mchog dge 'dun la skyabs su mchi'o/ / bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas shAkya thub pa/ shAkya'i seng ge /shAkya'i rgyal po gtso bo de rab tu byung ba'i rjes su rab tu 'byung ste khyim pa'i rtags spong ngo / / rab tu byung ba'i rtags yang dag par len to/ /

“Preceptor, heed me. I, [postulant’s name], will henceforth, for as long as I live, seek refuge in the Buddha, supreme among men; I will seek refuge in the Dharma, supreme among all that is free from attachment; I will seek refuge in the Saṅgha, supreme among communities. Following the example of going forth set by the Blessed One, the tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly complete Buddha Śākyamuni, the lion of the Śākyas, the king of the Śākyas, I, in going forth, renounce the tokens of the householder life and embrace the tokens of the renunciant life.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ / rab tu byung bas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
He repeats this a second and a third time. The preceptor then says: “This is the method.” [F.51.a] At which point the renunciant says: “It is excellent.”
de ni rab tu byung ba nye bar sgrub pa'o// //
That is the induction as a renunciant.

d.crumb: dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub pa'i cho ga

f.d: [dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub pa'i cho ga]
Becoming a novice

d.crumb: nye bar sgrub par byed pa

f.d: [nye bar sgrub par byed pa]

d.crumb: Inducting the postulant into the novitiate

f.d: Inducting the postulant into the novitiate

de'i 'og tu dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub par byed pa'i dge slong la gtad par bya'o/ / des kyang mkhan po la ci yongs su dag gam zhes dris nas yongs su dag na skyabs su 'gro ba dang / dge tshul nyid du khas blang bas dge tshul nyid du nye bar bsgrub par bya'o/ /

The postulant is then directed to the monk who will induct him into the novitiate. He again asks the preceptor whether the postulant is without impediments, and if, upon asking, he is, he should be inducted into the novitiate by going for refuge and promising to live as a novice.

'di ltar nye bar bsgrub par bya ste/ dang por ston pa la phyag 'tshal du gzhug go/ / de'i 'og tu slob dpon la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

The postulant should be inducted into the novitiate in the following way. The postulant is first made to prostrate to the Teacher. Then he is made to prostrate to and kneel before the instructor. Then, with his palms pressed together, he should say :

btsun pa dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba dus 'di nas bzung ste/ ji srid 'tsho'i bar du rkang gnyis rnams kyi mchog sangs rgyas la skyabs su mchi'o/ / 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams kyi mchog chos la skyabs su mchi'o/ / tshogs rnams kyi mchog dge 'dun la skyabs su mchi'o/ / bdag ji srid 'tsho'i bar du dge tshul du btsun pas gzung du gsol/ de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ tshig gsum pa la slob dpon gyis zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Reverend, heed me. I, [postulant’s name], will henceforth, for as long as I live, seek refuge in the Buddha, supreme among men; I will seek refuge in the Dharma, supreme among pure doctrines; I will seek refuge in the Saṅgha, supreme among communities. I ask that you, reverend, accept me as a novice for as long as I live.” The postulant repeats this a second and a third time, but the third time he says “instructor” in place of “reverend.” The instructor then says:
slob dpon gyis thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ / dge tshul gyis legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
“This is the method.” At which point the novice says: “It is excellent.”
de ni dge tshul gyi sdom pa sbyin pa'o// //
That is the giving of the novice vow.
[grib tshod gzhal ba]
Marking the time
de'i 'og tu slob dpon ma yin pa dge slong gzhan gang yang rung ba gcig gis grib tshod gzhal bar bya zhing skyes bu dang / rtsa ba dang / nyin mtshan gyi cha dang / dus tshod kyang brjod par bya'o/ /
Then, any monk other than the instructor should consult the sundial and announce the gnomon, the root, the time of day or night, and the season.
[rjes su thabs legs]
The novice investiture

de'i 'og tu bslab pa brjod pa khas blang ba'i tshul gyis bya'o/ / 'di ltar bya ste/ slob dpon dgongs su gsol/ ji ltar 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du srog gcod pa spangs te/ srog gcod pa las slar log pa de bzhin du bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi bas kyang dus 'di nas bzung ste/ ji srid 'tsho'i bar du srog gcod pa spangs te/ srog gcod pa las slar ldog par bgyi'o/ / yan lag dang po 'dis bdag 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gi bslab pa la rjes su slob bo/ / rjes su sgrub bo/ / rjes su bgyid do/ / gzhan yang ji ltar 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gis ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ma byin par len pa dang / mi tshangs par spyod pa dang / brdzun du smra ba dang / 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas dang / glu dang / gar dang / rol mo'i sgra dang / phreng ba dang / spos nyug pa dang / rgyan dang kha dog 'chang ba dang / khri stan mthon po dang / khri stan chen po dang / dus ma yin pa'i zas dang / gser dngul len pa spangs te/ gser dngul len pa las slar log pa de bzhin du/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi bas kyang dus 'di nas bzung ste ji srid 'tsho'i bar du ma byin par len pa dang / mi tshangs par spyod pa dang / brdzun du smra ba dang / 'bru'i chang dang bcos pa'i chang myos par 'gyur ba bag med pa'i gnas dang / glu gar dang / rol mo'i sgra dang / phreng ba dang / spos nyug pa dang / rgyan dang kha dog 'chang ba dang / khri stan mthon po dang / khri stan chen po dang / dus ma yin pa'i zas dang / gser dngul len pa spangs te/ gser dngul len pa las slar ldog par bgyi'o/ / yan lag bcu pa 'dis bdag 'phags pa dgra bcom pa de dag gi bslab pa la rjes su slob bo/ / rjes su sgrub bo/ / rjes su bgyid do/ /

The novice should then promises to keep the precepts by reciting them. This should be done in the following way: “Instructor, heed me. Just as noble arhats renounced and swore off killing for as long as they lived, so do I, [novice’s name], henceforth, for as long as I live, renounce and swear to refrain from killing. [F.51.b] With this first branch, I pledge to train in, practice, and act upon the precepts of those noble arhats. Furthermore, noble arhats renounced stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, intoxicating substances like grain alcohol and its by-products which leave one uninhibited, singing, dancing, music, garlands, perfumes, jewelry, cosmetics, tall seating, grand seating, untimely eating, and accepting gold and silver, and thus ceased accepting gold and silver. Just so, henceforth, for as long as I live, so too do I, [novice’s name], renounce stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, intoxicating substances like grain alcohol and its by-products which leave one uninhibited, singing, dancing, music, garlands, perfumes, jewelry, cosmetics, tall seating, grand seating, untimely eating, and accepting gold and silver; thus will I cease to accept gold and silver. With these ten branches, I too pledge to train in, practice, and act upon the precepts of those noble arhats.”
slob dpon gyis thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The instructor then says: “This is the method.”
dge tshul gyis legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the novice says: “It is excellent.”
dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub pa'i cho ga rdzogs s+ho// //
That marks the end of the rite of induction into the novitiate.

d.crumb: bsnyen par rdzogs pa nye bar sgrub pa

f.d: [bsnyen par rdzogs pa nye bar sgrub pa]
Granting ordination
[dus dang por bya ba]
The opening occasion

de'i 'og tu gal te de lo nyi shu tshang na mkhan pos de'i lhung bzed dang chos gos dag btsal bar bya zhing las byed pa'i dge slong la gsol ba gdab par bya/ gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba gdab par bya/ gang dag de'i las kyi gnas su 'jug par 'gyur ba'i dge slong dag la yang gsol ba gdab par bya'o/ /

Then, if the novice has reached the age of twenty, the preceptor should give him his begging bowl and robes and request the presence of a monk officiant. The preceptor should also request the presence of the monk who will serve as privy advisor, and that of any other monk who will enter the ceremony site.

dge slong gang dag de'i las kyi gnas su 'jug par 'gyur ba de dag gis kyang der 'du bar 'gyur ba'i tshe zla ba phyed 'das pa'i nyes pa bsdam par bya ba dang / bshags par bya ba dang / byin gyis brlab par bya ba dag la so sor brtag par bya zhing nyes pa shes pa bsdam pa'am/ bshags pa'am/ byin gyis brlabs pas phyir bcos te 'dug par bya'o/ /

When the monks have gathered there, they should each examine whether they have incurred any offenses in the past half a month that should be refrained from, confessed, [F.52.a] and formally excused.[122] Those who recognize such offenses should make reparations by reining them in, confessing them, or having them formally excused before taking their places.

de'i 'og tu dge 'dun thams cad 'dug cing mthun par gyur pa'am/ dkyil 'khor ba yang rung ste/ yul dbus su dge slong bcu la sogs pa'i tshogs sam/ mtha' 'khob dag tu gzhan med na 'dul ba 'dzin pa dang lnga la sogs pa'i tshogs la yang rung ste/ dang por ston pa la phyag 'tshal du gzhug go/ / de'i 'og tu dge slong re re la phyag gsum gsum 'tshal du gzhug go/ / phyag ni gnyis te/ yan lag lngas phyag 'tshal ba dang / sgyid pa nas 'khyud pa ste 'dir gang yang rung ngo / /

All of the saṅgha then take their places in concord or in an inner circle.[123] In the Middle Country, a quorum of ten monks is needed. In outlying areas, if there are no other monks, then a Vinaya master and a quorum of five will suffice. The ordinand should first prostrate to the Teacher, then prostate three times to each monk. Either of the two types of prostration‍—bowing prostrate with all four limbs and head, or a kneeling bow‍—is permissible.
'di ni dus dang por bya ba'o// //
This is how the opening occasion is conducted.
[mkhan por gsol ba]
Requesting the preceptor

de'i 'og tu mkhan por gsol ba bya'o/ / 'di ltar gsol bar bya ste/ mkhan po la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du pha gu'i steng du rtswa bting ba la rting pa gnyis kyis mnan nas tsog tsog par 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas gal te mkhan po yin na mkhan po zhes brjod par bya/ slob dpon yin na slob dpon zhes brjod par bya/ btsun pa yin na btsun pa zhes ci rigs par brjod par bya'o zhes bstan nas/ des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

Then, a request should be made to the preceptor. The request is made in the following way. The ordinand should be made to prostrate to the preceptor and then squat before him, with his two heels pressed to a grass mat on bricks so as to relieve pressure on the nerves. Pressing his palms together, he should say, employing whichever address is appropriate‍—“Preceptor” if addressing the preceptor, “Instructor” if addressing the instructor, or “Reverend” if addressing a monk:

btsun pa dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba btsun pa la mkhan por gsol gyis/ btsun pa bdag gi mkhan po mdzad du gsol/ btsun pa mkhan pos bsnyen par rdzogs par bgyi'o/ / de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ tshig gsum pa la mkhan po zhes brjod par bya'o/ / mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Reverend, heed me. I, [ordinand’s name], ask you, reverend, to serve as preceptor. Reverend, please act as my preceptor. Reverend, please grant me ordination.” This is repeated a second and a third time, but the third time he says “preceptor” in place of “instructor” or “reverend.” The preceptor then says: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the ordinand says: “It is excellent.”
de ni mkhan por gsol ba'o// //
That is the request to the preceptor.

f.d: Taking possession of robes that have already been cut and sewn

de'i 'og tu mkhan po rang gis de la chos gos gsum byin gyis brlab par bya'o/ / gal te re zhig chos gos dras shing drubs pa dag yod na de lta na legs te/ 'di ltar byin gyis brlab par bya ste/ chos gos gsum po so sor bltab ste slob ma'i phrag pa g.yon par bkal nas gnyis ka 'greng ste/ lag pas chos gos snam sbyar bzung nas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos bgyis lags pa rung ba spyad par 'os pa 'di chos gos snam sbyar du byin gyis brlab bo/ /

The preceptor himself should then take possession of the three robes for the ordinand. It is best if the ordinand has a set of robes already cut and sewn, in which case they are sanctioned as follows. Each of the three robes are folded and laid over the ordinand’s left shoulder, after which both preceptor and ordinand rise. [F.52.b] They both take the robe called the “mantle” in their hands, and the novice says: “Preceptor, heed me. This is my, [ordinand’s name]’s, robe, woven, good, right, and fit to wear. I take possession of this robe as a mantle.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand repeats this a second and a third time. The preceptor should then say: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the ordinand says: “It is excellent.”

de'i 'og tu chos gos bla gos bzung nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ / bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos bgyis lags pa rung ba spyad par 'os pa 'di chos gos bla gos su byin gyis brlab bo/ /

After that, he takes the upper robe in his hands and says: “Preceptor, heed me. This is my, [ordinand’s name]’s, robe, woven, good, right, and fit to wear. I take possession of this robe as an upper robe.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor should then say: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the ordinand says: “It is excellent.”

de'i 'og tu chos gos mthang gos bzung nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos bgyis lags pa rung ba spyad par 'os pa 'di chos gos mthang gos su byin gyis brlab bo/ /
Next, he takes the lower robe in his hands and says: “Preceptor, heed me. This is my, [ordinand’s name]’s, robe, woven, good, right, and fit to wear. I take possession of this robe as a lower robe.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor should then: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the student says: “It is excellent.”

de'i 'og tu chos gos dag bskon par bya zhing des kyang snam sbyar dang bcas pa nyid yin na bsnyen par rdzogs pa'i phyir 'dus pa'i dge 'dun la phyag bya'o/ / de ni chos gos dras shing drubs pa gsum byin gyis brlab pa'o// //

After that, the ordinand should put the robes on, along with the mantle if there is one, and prostrate to the saṅgha that has assembled to ordain him. That is how the ordinand should take possession of robes that have already been cut and sewn.

f.d: Taking possession of robes that have not already been cut and sewn

gal te re zhig chos gos dras shing drubs pa dag med na rgyu la byin gyis brlab par bya'o/ / 'di ltar byin gyis brlab par bya ste/ chos gos gsum gyi rgyu so sor bltab ste slob ma'i phrag pa g.yon par bkal nas gnyi ga 'greng ste lag pas chos gos snam sbyar rgyu bzung nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

If the ordinand’s robes have not already been cut and sewn, the ordinand should take possession of the materials in the following way. The materials for the three robes should be folded separately and laid on the student’s left shoulder, after which the ordinand and the preceptor both rise. They both take the material for the robe called the mantle in their hands, and the ordinand should say:

mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos 'di snam sbyar du byin gyis brlab bo/ / 'tshal na snam phran dgu pa la sogs par bgyis te/ glegs bu phyed dang gsum pa la sogs par bgyi'o/ / bar chad ma byung na bkru'o/ / brkyang ngo / / dra'o / / bsdeb bo/ / gzungs gdab bo/ / drub bo/ / kha bsgyur ro/ / yang na 'di la lhan thabs su glan no/ / rkyen ji lta ba bzhin du bgyis te/ chos gos 'di rung ba spyad par 'os pa'o/ /

“Preceptor, heed me. I take possession of this, my, [ordinand’s name]’s, Dharma robe, as a mantle. If you wish, I will divide it into nine or more patches and those into sections of two and a half and more. [F.53.a] If not prevented from doing so, I will wash them, lay them out, cut them, piece them together, stitch them, sew them together, and dye them. Or, I will patch additional pieces onto this. As circumstances allow, this robe will be right and fit to wear.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor should then say: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the student says: “It is excellent.”

de'i 'og tu chos gos bla gos rgyu bzung nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos 'di bla gos su byin gyis brlab bo/ / 'tshal na snam phran bdun par bgyis te/ glegs bu phyed dang gsum par bgyi'o/ / bar chad ma byung na bkru'o/ / brkyang ngo / / dra'o/ / bsdeb bo/ / gzungs gdab bo/ / drub bo/ / kha bsgyur ro/ / yang na 'di la lhan thabs su glan no/ / rkyen ji lta ba bzhin du bgyis te/ chos gos 'di rung ba spyad par 'os pa'o/ /

After that, they both take the material for the upper robe in their hands, and the ordinand should say: “Preceptor, heed me. I take possession of this, my, [ordinand’s name]’s, robe, as an upper robe. If you please, I will divide it into seven patches and those into sections of two and a half. If not prevented from doing so, I will wash them, lay them out, cut them, piece them together, stitch them, sew them together, and dye them. Or, I will patch additional pieces onto this. As circumstance allows, this robe will be right and fit to wear.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor should then say: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the student says: “It is excellent.”

de'i 'og tu chos gos mthang gos rgyu bzung nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i chos gos 'di mthang gos su byin gyis brlab bo/ / 'tshal na snam phran lnga par bgyis te/ glegs bu phyed dang gnyis par bgyi'o/ / bar chad ma byung na bkru'o/ / brkyang ngo / / dra'o/ / bsdeb bo/ / gzungs gdab bo/ / drub bo/ / kha bsgyur ro/ / yang na 'di la lhan thabs su glan no/ / rkyen ji lta ba bzhin du bgyis te/ chos gos 'di rung ba spyad par 'os pa'o/ /

Next, they both take the material for the lower robe in their hands, and the ordinand should say: “Preceptor, heed me. I take possession of this, my, [ordinand’s name]’s, robe, as a lower robe. If you please, I will divide it into five patches and those into sections of two and a half. If not prevented from doing so, I will wash them, lay them out, cut them, piece them together, stitch them, sew them together, and dye them. Or, I will patch additional pieces onto this. As circumstances allow, this Dharma robe will be right and fit to wear.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor should then say: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the student says: “It is excellent.”
de ni chos gos ma dras shing ma drubs pa gsum byin gyis brlab pa'o// //
That is the taking possession of robes that have not already been cut and sewn.
[lhung bzed bstan pa]
Displaying the begging bowl

de'i 'og tu de'i lhung bzed bstan par bya'o/ / 'di ltar bstan par bya ste/ dge slong gcig gis lhung bzed lag pa g.yon par bzhag ste/ lag pa g.yas pas bkab nas rgan pa'i mtha' logs nas dge slong re re'i mdun du 'greng ste 'dud pa dang bcas pas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ btsun pa'am tshe dang ldan pa dgongs su gsol/ tshe dang ldan pa ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i lhung bzed 'di mi chung ngam/ mi che 'am/ mi skya 'am/

Then the begging bowl should be shown. It should be shown in the following way. One monk [F.53.b] places the begging bowl in his left hand and covers it with his right hand, then bows to each of the monks, starting with the seniormost, and as he stands before them, he should ask the following question: “Reverend or venerable, heed me. Venerable [monk’s name], is this begging bowl too small, too large, or too pale?”

dge slong thams cad kyis kyang lhung bzed de lta bu nyid ma yin na re re nas lhung bzed bzang ngo zhes brjod par bya'o/ / gal te de skad brjod na de lta na legs/ gal te mi brjod na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /
If all the monks agree the begging bowl is none of those, they should each say: “The begging bowl is fine.” If they should say that, then all is well. A breach occurs if they do not say that.
de ni lhung bzed bstan pa'o// //
That is the showing of the begging bowl.

f.d: Taking possession of the begging bowl

de'i 'og tu mkhan po rang gis de la lhung bzed byin gyis brlab par bya'o/ / 'di ltar byin gyis brlab par bya ste/ gnyi ga 'greng ste lag pa g.yon par lhung bzed bzhag la lag pa g.yas pas bkab nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/ mkhan po dgongs su gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba'i lhung bzed zas la spyad par 'os pa drang srong gi snod 'di bslang ba'i snod du byin gyis brlab bo/ /

Then, the preceptor himself should take possession of the begging bowl for the ordinand. He should do so in the following way. Both rise, and the ordinand places the begging bowl in his left hand while he covers it with his right hand and says the following: “Preceptor, heed me. This is my, [ordinand’s name]’s, begging bowl, fit to eat from. I take possession of this sage’s bowl as a container for alms begged.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ mkhan pos thabs yin no zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
This is repeated a second and a third time. The preceptor then says: “This is the method.”
slob mas legs so zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
At which point the student says: “It is excellent.”
de ni lhung bzed byin gyis brlab pa'o/ /

de'i 'og tu dge slong las byed pas gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong la/ mkhan po ming 'di zhes bya bas ming 'di zhes bya ba'i gsang ste ston par gsol ba btab pa gang yin zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
The monk officiant should then ask the monk who will serve as privy advisor: “Who has the preceptor [preceptor’s name] asked to serve as privy advisor to this ordinand [ordinand’s name]?”
gsang ste ston pa gang yin pa des bdag ming 'di zhes bya ba'o zhes brjod par bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu dge slong las byed pas gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong la

The monk officiant next [F.54.a] makes an act of motion alone so that the monk who will serve as privy advisor may question the student about impediments.

'di ltar bya ste/ 'dug la 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ dge slong ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la gsang ste ston par spro na/ gal te dge 'dun gyi dus la bab cing bzod na dge 'dun gyis gnang bar mdzod cig dang / dge slong ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la gsang ste ston to/ /

This is how that is done. While seated, he should say the following: “Reverend saṅgha, please listen. This monk, [privy advisor’s name], is willing to serve as privy advisor to the ordinand [ordinand’s name], at the behest of the preceptor [preceptor’s name]. If that is so, and the time is right and the saṅgha can accept it, I ask that the saṅgha grant their permission. This monk, [privy advisor’s name], shall act as privy advisor to the ordinand [ordinand’s name] at the behest of the preceptor [preceptor’s name].”

This is the motion. That is the act that moves to appoint the privy advisor.
[gsang ste bstan pa]
The inquiry into private matters

de'i 'og tu gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong gis dkyil 'khor ba'i phyi rol du song ste bsnyen par rdzogs par bya ba de bdag la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/
The monk who is serving as privy advisor then leaves the inner circle. The ordinand is made to prostrate to and kneel before him. When he has joined his palms, the privy advisor should say:

tshe dang ldan pa khyod nyon cig 'di ni khyod kyi bden pa'i dus/ 'di ni 'byung ba'i dus te/ kho bos khyod la chung zad cig dris/ khyod ma 'dzem par byos la yin pa la yin zhes smros shig /ma yin pa la yang ma yin zhes lan thob shig /khyod skyes pa yin nam/

“Listen, venerable. It is time for you to be truthful. It is time for you to be forthcoming. I shall ask you a few questions. Do not be apprehensive. Answer simply by saying what is so is so, and what is not is not. Are you a male?”
des skyes pa lags zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant responds: “I am a male.”
skyes pa'i dbang po dang ldan nam/
The privy advisor asks: “Do you have male organs?”
des ldan zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant responds: “I do.”
lo nyi shu lon nam/
The privy advisor asks: “Have you reached the age of twenty?”
des lon zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant responds: “I have reached that age.”
khyod kyi chos gos gsum dang lhung bzed tshang ngam/
The privy advisor asks: “Do you have all three robes and a begging bowl?”
des tshang zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant responds: “I have them all.”
khyod kyi pha ma gson nam/
The privy advisor asks: “Are your parents still living?”
gal te gson zhes zer na/ khyod pha mas gnang ngam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
If the ordinand says his parents are still living, he is then asked: “Have your parents given you leave?”
des gnang zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “They have given me leave.”

gal te shi zer na/ khyod bran ma yin nam/ brkus pa ma yin nam/ rnyed btson ma yin nam/ rtsod pa can ma yin nam/ btsongs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal pos bkrabs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal po la sdigs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal po la gnod pa'i las byed pa ma yin nam/ khyod rgyal po la gnod pa'i las byas sam/ byed du bcug pa ma yin nam/ chom rkun par grags pa ma yin nam/ za ma ma yin nam/ ma ning ma yin nam/ dge slong ma sun phyung ba ma yin nam/ rku thabs su gnas pa ma yin nam/ tha dad du gnas pa ma yin nam/ gnas par mi bya ba ma yin nam/ mu stegs can ma yin nam/ mu stegs can zhugs pa ma yin nam/ pha bsad pa ma yin nam/ ma bsad pa ma yin nam/ dgra bcom pa bsad pa ma yin nam/ dge 'dun dbyen byas pa ma yin nam/ de bzhin gshegs pa la ngan sems kyis khrag phyung ba ma yin nam/ sprul pa ma yin nam/ dud 'gro ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /

If the ordinand says his parents are deceased, he is asked: “Are you a bondsman? Are you a captive? Are you a pledge? Are you a pawn? Are you an indentured servant? Are you an officer of the king? Are you a threat to the king? Have you worked to harm the king? Have you worked to harm the king or enlisted others to do so? Are you a known bandit or thief? Are you a person who has undergone castration? [F.54.b] Are you a person labeled a paṇḍaka? Have you violated a nun? Are you an impostor? Are you duplicitous? Have you been ousted? Are you a tīrthika? Are you a convert to a tīrthika order? Are you a patricide? Are you a matricide? Have you killed an arhat? Have you caused a schism in the saṅgha? Have you maliciously drawn blood from a tathāgata? Are you a shape shifter? Are you an animal?”
des ma lags zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “No.”
khyod la la la'i bu lon mang yang rung nyung yang rung cung zad chags pa med dam/
If the ordinand responds that he is not these things, the privy advisor asks him: “Have you incurred some debts, be they large or small?”
gal te bu lon chags so zhes zer na/ khyod bsnyen par rdzogs nas 'jal nus sam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “I have incurred some,” the privy advisor asks: “Are you able to repay them once you have been ordained?”
gal te mi nus zhes zer na/ 'o na song shig ces brjod par bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “No, I am unable,” the privy advisor tells him: “In that case, I ask you to leave.”
gal te bsnyen par rdzogs nas 'jal nus zhes zer na/ khyod sngon rab tu byung ba ma yin nam zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “I am able to repay them after I have been ordained, the privy advisor asks him: “Have you gone forth before?”
gal te rab tu byung ngo zhes zer na khyod la pham par 'gyur ba bzhi las ltung ba gang yang rung ba zhig byung ba ma yin nam/ khyod 'babs pa na bslab pa legs par phul lam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /

If the ordinand responds “I have gone forth before,” the privy advisor asks him: “Did you not transgress and incur one of the four defeats? Did you properly offer back your precepts when you stepped down?”
gal te ltung ba byung ngo zhes zer na/ 'o na song shig ces brjod par bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “An offense occurred,” the privy advisor tells him: “In that case, I ask you to leave.”
gal te ma byung ngo zhes zer na/ ji ltar khyod da ltar rab tu byung ba yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “No offense occurred,” the privy advisor asks him: “Have you now gone forth?”[124]
gal te bdag rab tu byung ba yin zhes zer na/ khyod kyis tshangs par spyod pa legs par spyad dam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “I have gone forth,” the privy advisor asks him: “Have you properly lived the holy life?”
des legs par spyad ces brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “I have lived it properly.”
khyod kyi ming ci/ khyod kyi mkhan po'i ming ci/
If the ordinand says he has lived the holy life properly, the privy advisor asks him: “What is your name? What is your preceptor’s name?”
des bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi/ don gyi slad du mtshan nas smos te bdag gi mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “My name is [ordinand’s name] and my preceptor’s name, who will speak on my behalf, is [preceptor’s name].”

tshe dang ldan pa khyod nyon cig /mi rnams kyi lus la lus kyi nad kyi rnam pa 'di lta bu 'di dag 'byung ba 'di lta ste/ mdze dang / 'bras dang / phol mig dang / 'brum phran dang / sha bkra dang / khyi rngo dang / g.ya' ba dang / glog pa dang / rkang shu dang / skem nad dang / skem pa dang / brjed byed dang / bkres ngab dang / skya rbab dang / rkang bam dang / mtshan bar rdol ba dang / rims dang / rims drag po dang / nyin gcig pa dang / nyin gnyis pa dang / nyin gsum pa dang / nyin bzhi pa dang / 'dus pa dang / rims nyin re ba dang / rtag pa'i rims dang / rims ldang dub pa dang / shu ba dang / gsud pa dang / skyigs bu dang / lud pa dang / dbugs mi bde ba dang / lhog pa dang / yan lag tu zug pa dang / skran dang / khrag nad dang / mkhris nad dang / gzhang 'brum dang / skyug bro ba dang / chus bgags pa dang / ngal ba dang / lus tsha ba dang / rtsib logs tsha ba dang / rus pa la zug pa ste/ lus kyi nad 'di lta bu 'di dag las gang yang rung ba dang / 'di lta bu gzhan dag kyang khyod kyi lus la med dam/

The privy advisor asks him: “Venerable, please listen. Human bodies are subject to diseases that manifest on the body in these ways: as oozing pustules, large pustules, small pustules, exanthema, leprosy, oozing rashes, dry rashes, welts, scabs, consumption, pulmonary consumption, fits, [F.55.a] anal fistula, fluid retention, elephantiasis, urethral fistula, a latent or raging fever, fevers which last a day, two day fevers, tertian fevers, quartan fevers, complexes, daily fevers, chronic fevers, dissipation, abscesses, vomiting and diarrhea, hiccoughs, coughs, asthma, carbuncles, pain in the extremities, tumors, blood disorders, jaundice, hemorrhoids, nausea, urinary retention, fatigue, pyrexia, arthritis, and bone pain.[125] Do any of these physical conditions or others like them afflict your body?”
des ma mchis zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “They do not.”

tshe dang ldan pa khyod nyon cig /khyod la da ltar ngas gang dris pa de nyid dge 'dun gyi dbus su yang tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa mkhas pa rnams khyod la 'dri bas der yang khyod kyis ma 'dzem par byos la yin pa la yang yin zhes smros shig /ma yin pa la yang ma yin zhes lan thob cig /khyod ma bos kyi bar du ma 'ong bar sdod cig /

The privy advisor says to him: “Venerable, listen. The learned fellow brahmacārin will ask the same questions I have just now asked you but in front of the saṅgha community. Once there, do not be apprehensive. Answer simply by saying what is so is so, and what is not is not. Stay here until you are called.”
de ni gsang ste bstan pa'o// //
['ong ba zhu ba]
Reporting the findings
de'i 'og tu gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong gis rgan pa'i mtha' logs su 'greng ste/ 'dud pa dang bcas pas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/
The monk who inquired into private matters then stands before the senior monks, bows, and says the following:

dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ / bdag gis mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la bar chad kyi chos rnams gsang ste rjes su bstan na/ de yang bar chad kyi chos rnams yongs su dag go zhes kho na nyid mchi na/ ci mchi zhig gam/ thams cad kyis gal te yongs su dag na'o zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Venerable saṅgha, please listen. If the preceptor [preceptor’s name] were to again ask the ordinand [ordinand’s name] about the private matters regarding impediments I have inquired into, he too will find that the ordinand is utterly free of impediments. If that is indeed the case, and the ordinand is asked, ‘Which of these do you have?’ he will respond, ‘I have none at all.’ ”
gal te de skad brjod na de lta na legs/ gal te mi brjod na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /
If he says that, then all is well. A breach occurs if he does not say that.
de ni 'ong ba zhu ba'o/ /

d.crumb: bsnyen par rdzogs par gsol ba

f.d: [bsnyen par rdzogs par gsol ba]
The ordinand’s request for ordination
de'i 'og tu bsnyen par rdzogs par bya ba de dkyil 'khor bar bkug nas rgan pa'i mtha' logs su phyag 'tshal du bcug ste/ dge slong las byed pas bsnyen par rdzogs pa gsol du gzhug par bya'o/ /
The ordinand is then brought into the inner circle and prostrates before the seniormost of those gathered. [F.55.b] The monk officiant then prompts him to ask for ordination.

'di ltar gsol du gzhug par bya ste/ dang por ston pa la phyag 'tshal du gzhug go/ / de'i 'og tu rgan pa'i mtha' logs su phyag 'tshal du bcug ste/ pha gu'i steng du rtswa bting ba la rting pa gnyis kyis mnan nas tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas des 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

The ordinand first prostrates to the Teacher, then before the seniormost monk. He then squats with his two heels pressed to a grass mat on bricks so as to relieve pressure on the nerves. Joining his palms, he says:

dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi ba don gyi slad du mtshan nas smos te mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas dge 'dun las bsnyen par rdzogs par 'tshal te/ bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi bas don gyi slad du mtshan nas smos te/ mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas dge 'dun las bsnyen par rdzogs par gsol na/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis bdag bsnyen par rdzogs par mdzad du gsol/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis bdag drang bar gsol/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis bdag rjes su gzung du gsol/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis bdag la rjes su bstan du gsol/ thugs brtse ba can dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis thugs brtse ba'i slad du bdag la thugs brtse bar mdzad du gsol/

“Venerable saṅgha, please listen. The preceptor, [preceptor’s name], speaking on my, [ordinand’s name], behalf, seeks consent from the saṅgha for ordination. If the saṅgha allows the motion of the preceptor [preceptor’s name], who speaks on my, [ordinand’s name], behalf, I ask that the venerable saṅgha grant me ordination. I ask that the venerable saṅgha guide me. I ask that the venerable saṅgha accept charge of me. I ask that the venerable saṅgha show me the way. I ask that the venerable and compassionate saṅgha, in their compassion, extend their compassion to me.”
de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/
That is repeated a second and a third time.
de ni bsnyen par rdzogs par gsol ba'o/ /

d.crumb: nang du bar chad dri ba gsol ba'i las

f.d: [nang du bar chad dri ba gsol ba'i las]

d.crumb: The motion to ask about impediments before the saṅgha

f.d: The motion to ask about impediments before the saṅgha
de'i 'og tu dge slong las byed pas dge 'dun gyi nang du bar chad dri ba'i phyir gsol ba 'ba' zhig gi las bya'o/ / 'di ltar bya ste 'dug la 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ /
The monk officiant makes an act of motion alone so that the ordinand can be asked before the saṅgha about impediments. While seated, the monk officiant says:

dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas dge 'dun las bsnyen par rdzogs par 'tshal te/ ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas dge 'dun las bsnyen par rdzogs par gsol na/ gal te dge 'dun gyi dus la bab cing bzod na dge 'dun gyis gnang bar mdzod cig dang / bdag gis dge 'dun gyi nang du mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi bas ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la bar chad kyi chos rnams dri bar bgyi'o/ /

“Venerable saṅgha, please listen. The ordinand [ordinand’s name] seeks consent from the saṅgha to receive ordination from the preceptor [preceptor’s name]. If he has asked the saṅgha to give consent to the preceptor [preceptor’s name] to grant ordination to the ordinand, and if the time is right and the saṅgha can accept it, I ask that the saṅgha grant their consent. Before the saṅgha, I shall ask about the impediments faced by the ordinand [ordinand’s name] who is to be ordained by the preceptor [preceptor’s name].” [F.56.a]
'di ni gsol ba'o/ /de ni nang du bar chad dri ba gsol ba'i las so// //

d.crumb: Inquiring into impediments before the Saṅgha

f.d: Inquiring into impediments before the Saṅgha

de'i 'og tu dge slong las byed pas dge 'dun gyi nang du bar chad dri bar bya'o/ / 'di ltar dri bar bya ste/ las byed pa la phyag 'tshal du bcug nas mdun du pha gu'i steng du rtswa bting ba la rting pa gnyis kyis mnan nas tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyor du bcug nas 'di skad ces brjod par bya ste/

The monk officiant then inquires into impediments before the saṅgha. The ordinand prostrates to the officiant and then squats with his two heels pressed to a grass mat on bricks so as to relieve pressure on the nerves. The ordinand then joins his palms as the monk officiant inquires into impediments.

tshe dang ldan pa khyod nyon cig /'di ni khyod kyi bden pa'i dus/ 'di ni 'byung ba'i dus te/ kho bos khyod la cung zad cig dris/ khyod ma 'dzem par byos la yin pa la yang yin zhes smros shig /ma yin pa la yang ma yin zhes lan thob cig /khyod skyes pa yin nam/

“Listen, venerable. It is time for you to be truthful. It is time to come forth. I shall ask you a few questions. Do not be apprehensive. Answer simply by saying what is so is so, and what is not is not. Are you a male?”
des skyes pa lags zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The postulant responds: “I am a male.” The privy advisor asks:
skyes pa'i dbang po dang ldan nam/ des ldan zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
“Do you have male organs?” The postulant responds: “I do.”
lo nyi shu lon nam/ des lon zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The privy advisor asks: “Have you reached the age of twenty?” The postulant responds: “I have reached that age.”
khyod kyi chos gos gsum dang lhung bzed tshang ngam/ des tshang zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The privy advisor asks: “Do you have all three robes and a begging bowl?” The postulant responds: “I have them all.”
khyod kyi pha ma gson nam/ gal te gson zhes zer na/ khyod pha mas gnang ngam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
The privy advisor asks: “Are your parents still living?” If the ordinand says his parents are still living, he is then asked: “Have your parents given you leave?” The ordinand responds:

des gnang zhes brjod par bya'o/ / gal te shi zhes zer na/ khyod bran ma yin nam/ brkus pa ma yin nam/ rnyed btson ma yin nam/ rtsod pa can ma yin nam/ btsongs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal pos bkrabs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal po la sdigs pa ma yin nam/ rgyal po la gnod pa'i las byed pa ma yin nam/ khyod rgyal po la gnod pa'i las byas sam byed du bcug pa ma yin nam/ chom rkun par grags pa ma yin nam/ za ma ma yin nam/ ma ning ma yin nam/ dge slong ma sun phyung ba ma yin nam/ rku thabs su gnas pa ma yin nam/ tha dad du gnas pa ma yin nam/ gnas par mi bya ba ma yin nam/ mu stegs can ma yin nam/ mu stegs can zhugs pa ma yin nam/ pha bsad pa ma yin nam/ ma bsad pa ma yin nam/ dgra bcom pa bsad pa ma yin nam/ dge 'dun gyi dbyen byas pa ma yin nam/ de bzhin gshegs pa la ngan sems kyis khrag phyung ba ma yin nam/ sprul pa ma yin nam/ dud 'gro ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /

“They have given me leave.” If the ordinand says his parents are deceased, he is asked: “Are you a bondsman? Are you a captive? Are you a pledge? Are you a pawn? Are you an indentured servant? Are you an officer of the king? Are you a threat to the king? Have you worked to harm the king? Have you worked to harm the king or enlisted others to do so? Are you a known bandit or thief? Are you a person who has undergone castration? Are you a person labeled a paṇḍaka? Have you violated a nun? Are you an impostor? Are you duplicitous? Have you been ousted? Are you a tīrthika? Are you a convert to a tīrthika order? Are you a patricide? Are you a matricide? Have you killed an arhat? Have you caused a schism in the saṅgha? Have you maliciously drawn blood from a tathāgata? [F.56.b] Are you a shape shifter? Are you an animal?”
des ma lags zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “No.”
khyod la la la'i bu lon mang yang rung nyung yang rung cung zad chags pa med dam/
If the ordinand responds that he is not these things, the privy advisor should ask him: “Have you incurred some debts, be they large or small?”
gal te bu lon chags so zhes zer na/ khyod bsnyen par rdzogs nas 'jal nus sam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / gal te mi nus zhes zer na/ 'o na song shig ces brjod par bya'o/ /

If the ordinand responds “I have incurred some,” the privy advisor should ask him: “Are you able to repay them once you have been ordained?” If the ordinand responds “No, I am unable,” the privy advisor should tell him: “In that case, I ask you to leave.”

gal te bsnyen par rdzogs nas 'jal nus zhes zer na/ khyod sngon rab tu byung ba ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / gal te rab tu byung ngo zhes zer na khyod la pham par 'gyur ba bzhi las ltung ba gang yang rung ba zhig byung ba ma yin nam/ khyod 'babs pa na bslab pa legs par phul lam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /

If the ordinand responds “I am able to repay them after I have been ordained, the privy advisor should ask him: “Have you gone forth before?” If the ordinand responds “I have gone forth before,” he privy advisor should ask him: “Have you incurred an offense of one of the four defeats? Did you properly offer back your precepts when you stepped down?”
gal te ltung ba byung ngo zhes zer na/ 'o na song shig ces brjod par bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “An offense occurred,” the privy advisor should tell him: “In that case, I ask you to leave.”
gal te ma byung ngo zhes zer na/ ji ltar khyod da ltar rab tu byung ba yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “No offense occurred,” the privy advisor should ask him: “Have you now gone forth?”[126]
gal te bdag rab tu byung ba yin zhes zer na/ khyod kyis tshangs par spyod pa legs par spyad dam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / des legs par spyad ces brjod par bya'o/ /
If the ordinand responds “I have gone forth,” the privy advisor should ask him: “Have you properly lived the holy life?” The ordinand responds: “I have lived it properly.”
khyod kyi ming ci/ khyod kyi mkhan po'i ming ci/ des bdag ming 'di zhes bgyi don gyi slad du mtshan nas smos te bdag gi mkhan po ming 'di zhes bgyi zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

If the ordinand says he has lived the holy life properly, the privy advisor should ask him: “What is your name? What is your preceptor’s name?” The ordinand responds: “My name is [ordinand’s name] and my preceptor’s name, who will speak on my behalf, is [preceptor’s name].”

tshe dang ldan pa khyod nyon cig /mi rnams kyi lus la lus kyi nad kyi rnam pa 'di lta bu 'di dag 'byung ba 'di lta ste/ mdze dang / 'bras dang / phol mig dang / 'brum phran dang / sha bkra dang / khyi rngo dang / g.ya' ba dang / glog pa dang / rkang shu dang / skem nad dang / skem pa dang / brjed byed dang / bkres ngab dang / skya rbab dang / rkang bam dang / mtshan par rdol ba dang / rims dang / rims drag po dang / nyin gcig pa dang / nyin gnyis pa dang / nyin gsum pa dang / nyin bzhi pa dang / 'dus pa dang / rims nyin re ba dang / rtag pa'i rims dang / rims ldang dub pa dang / shu ba dang / gsud pa dang / skyigs bu dang / lud pa dang / dbugs mi bde ba dang / lhog pa dang / yan lag tu zug pa dang / skran dang / khrag nad dang / mkhris nad dang / gzhang 'brum dang / skyug bro ba dang / chus bgags pa dang / ngal ba dang / lus tsha ba dang / rtsib logs tsha ba dang / rus pa la zug pa ste/ lus kyi nad 'di lta bu 'di dag las gang yang rung ba dang / 'di lta bu gzhan dag kyang khyod kyi lus la med dam/

The privy advisor should ask him: “Venerable, please listen. Human bodies are subject to diseases that manifest on the body in these ways: as oozing pustules, large pustules, small pustules, exanthema, leprosy, oozing rashes, dry rashes, welts, scabs, consumption, pulmonary consumption, fits, anal fistula, fluid retention, elephantiasis, urethral fistula, a latent or raging fever, fevers which last a day, two day fevers, tertian fevers, quartan fevers, complexes, daily fevers, chronic fevers, dissipation, abscesses, vomiting and diarrhea, hiccoughs, coughs, asthma, carbuncles, [F.57.a] pain in the extremities, tumors, blood disorders, jaundice, hemorrhoids, nausea, urinary retention, fatigue, pyrexia, arthritis, and bone pain.[127] Do any of these physical conditions or others like them afflict your body?”
des ma mchis zhes brjod par bya'o/ /
The ordinand responds: “They do not.”
de ni nang du bar chad dri ba'o// //
This was the inquiry into impediments in the inner circle.
