Tīrthikas
sdom la/ mu stegs can dang nyi shu dang / / dge tshul bcwa lnga ma lon pa'o/ /
A summary: Tīrthikas, twenty years, and Novices not yet fifteen.
[mu stegs can]
Tīrthikas

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / de'i tshe na rgan zhugs byis pa/ rmongs pa/ mi gsal ba/ mi mkhas pa zhig gis gzhan mu stegs can zhig rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas pa na dge slong rnams dang lhan cig rtsod pa 'ga' zhig byung nas bslab pa phul te sngon gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas de nyid du song ba'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol ba dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag ji ltar mi gti mug can de legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba gya nom pa 'di lta bu spangs nas sngon gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas de nyid du song ba la ltos/ dge slong dag 'di lta ste dper na khyi bkres pa'i nyam chung bas yongs su gzir ba ni bza' ba dang bca' ba gya nom pa spangs nas bshang ba bza' bar bya'o snyam du sems so/ / dge slong dag de bzhin du mi gti mug can des kyang legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba gya nom pa 'di lta bu spangs nas sngon gyi mu stegs can gyi gnas de nyid du song ngo / /

[F.72.a] The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when an elder who was immature, dense, dim-witted, and unskilled allowed a follower of another tīrthika tradition to go forth. The elder granted the tīrthika ordination, sparking a number of disputes between monks. After the tīrthika had offered back his training and returned to his community of tīrthikas, the monks asked the Blessed One about it. This is how he responded: “Monks, look at how that benighted man has turned his back on such a fine and well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya and returned to his community of tīrthikas. Monks, it seems to me he is behaving like a dog, wracked by hunger, but refusing fine food and fare and eating excrement instead. Monks, this is how a benighted man acts who turns his back on such a fine and well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya and returns to his former community of tīrthikas.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag de lta bas na nye du shAkya dang me ba ral ba can ma gtogs pa sems mgu bar ma gyur pa'i mu stegs can rab tu dbyung bar mi bya zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o/ / gal te nye du shAkya mu stegs can gyi rgyal mtshan gyis 'ongs shing gal te legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'dod na/ dge slong dag de rab tu dbyung bar bya zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dge slong dag nga ni nye du rnams la nye du'i yongs su spang ba sbyin par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te gzhan mu stegs can kun du rgyu 'ongs shing gal te legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'dod na/ dge slong dag de zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa sbyin par bya ba shes par gyis shig / dge slong dag gzhan mu stegs can gnas pa spyad nas sems mgu bar gyur na rab tu dbyung bar bya/ bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ /

Then the Blessed One declared, “Monks, apart from our Śākya kin and dreadlocked fire-worshippers,[156] the going forth of tīrthikas who do not have a sense of reverence should not be allowed nor should they be ordained. If perchance a Śākya kin should come under a tīrthika banner, and if perchance he should want monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, then, monks, his going forth should be allowed and he should be ordained. Why is that? Because, monks, I give kin exceptions to kin. If perchance a wandering mendicant from another tīrthika order should come, and he should want monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, then, monks, understand that he should be allowed to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months. [F.72.b] Monks, if, after having submitted to his station, the follower of another tīrthika order has a sense of reverence, his going forth should be allowed and he should be ordained.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis gzhan mu stegs can zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa sbyin par bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas/ dge slong rnams kyis ji ltar sbyin par bya ba mi shes nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag 'ga' zhig gi gan du gzhan mu stegs can rab tu dbyung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la bar chad kyi chos rnams dris nas gzung bar bya'o/ / bzung nas gsum la skyabs su 'gro ba dang / dge bsnyen nyid du khas blang bas dge bsnyen gyi sdom pa sbyin par bya'o/ / de'i 'og tu dge 'dun thams cad 'dug cing mthun par gyur pa la rgan rims kyis phyag 'tshal du bcug nas tsog tsog por 'dug tu bcug ste/ thal mo sbyar du bcug nas 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ bdag mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba ming 'di zhes bgyi ba las rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal te/ bdag mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas par dge 'dun la gsol na/ thugs brtse ba can dge 'dun btsun pa rnams kyis thugs brtse ba'i slad du bdag mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas par bgyi ba stsal du gsol/

When the Blessed One said that followers of other tīrthika orders should be allowed to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months, the monks were in a quandary, not knowing how such robes should be given. “Monks,” instructed the Blessed One, “if a follower of another tīrthika order wishing to go forth approaches any one of you, you should ascertain through questioning him whether he has any impediments. Once you have ascertained this, have him take the threefold refuge and, after he commits himself to living as a lay devotee, give him the lay devotee vows. Then, as the entire saṅgha sits in concord, have him prostrate to them in order of seniority before sitting in a squatting position. Pressing his palms together, he should say, ‘Reverend saṅgha, please heed me. I, the tīrthika [tīrthika’s name], wish to renounce this identity and go forth. I, the tīrthika [tīrthika’s name], petition the saṅgha to allow me to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months. I, the tīrthika [tīrthika’s name], ask that the reverend and compassionate saṅgha, out of your compassion, might allow me to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months.’

de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ de'i 'og tu dge slong gcig gis gsol ba byas te las bya'o/ / 'di ltar bya ste/'dug la 'di skad ces brjod par bya'o/ / dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di ming 'di zhes bgyi ba las rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal te/ mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas par dge 'dun la gsol na/ gal te dge 'dun gyi dus la bab cing bzod na/ dge 'dun gyis gnang bar mdzod cig dang / dge 'dun gyis mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bya ba la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa gsol to/ /

“This should be repeated a second and a third time, after which a monk moves the motion be acted upon. This is how the request is made: while seated, the monk says, ‘Reverend saṅgha, please heed me. This tīrthika [tīrthika’s name] wishes to renounce this identity and go forth. This tīrthika has asked the saṅgha to allow him to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months. If the reverend saṅgha can accept it, I ask the saṅgha to give its consent and [F.73.a] allow this tīrthika to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months.’
'di ni gsol ba'o/ /

las ni 'di ltar bya ste/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di ming 'di zhes bgyi ba las rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal nas/ mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba 'di zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas par dge 'dun la gsol te/ de'i slad du dge 'dun gyis mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa stsol na/ tshe dang ldan pa gang dag mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas bstsal bar bzod pa de dag ni cang ma gsung shig /gang dag mi bzod pa de dag ni gsung shig /

“The motion is acted upon thus: ‘Reverend saṅgha, please heed me. This tīrthika [tīrthika’s name] wishes to renounce this identity and go forth. Therefore, I ask the saṅgha that you allow him to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months. If the saṅgha were to permit this action, I would ask the venerables who can accept it to please remain silent. Those who cannot accept it, please speak up.’

'di ni las brjod pa dang po ste/ de bzhin du lan gnyis lan gsum du bzlas/ dge 'dun gyis bzod cing gnang nas dge 'dun gyis mu stegs can ming 'di zhes bgyi ba la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa stsal lags te/ 'di ltar cang mi gsung bas de de bzhin du 'dzin to/ /

“That is the first motion to act. This should be repeated a second and a third time. The saṅgha, by remaining silent, acknowledges its acceptance and gives its consent for the tīrthika [tīrthika’s name] to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months.

dge 'dun gyis gzhan mu stegs can gang la zla ba bzhi'i bar du mkhan pos sbyar ba'i gos dag gis gnas pa byin pa de'i zan ni dge 'dun las so/ / gos ni mkhan po las so/ / las ni dge tshul gyi gral rims bzhin bya'o/ /

“For any tīrthika to whom the saṅgha gives its permission to live in robes provided by a preceptor for four months, his food is the saṅgha’s responsibility. His robes are the preceptor’s responsibility. His duties are akin to those in the novice ranks.”

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyis gzhan mu stegs can gnas pa spyad nas sems mgu bar gyur na rab tu dbyung bar bya/ bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o zhes bka' stsal na/ btsun pa ji tsam gyis na gzhan mu stegs can sems mgu bar gyur pa zhes brjod par bgyi/

Upāli asked the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, the Blessed One has said, ‘If, after having submitted to his station, the follower of another tīrthika order has a sense of reverence, his going forth should be allowed and he should be ordained.’ If so, then reverend, by what measure may we say that a follower of another tīrthika order has a sense of reverence?”

nye ba 'khor gzhan mu stegs can gyi mdun du sangs rgyas kyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod par bya/ chos dang dge 'dun gyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod par bya zhing mu stegs can rnams kyi bsngags pa ma yin pa yang dag pa brjod par bya'o/ / nye ba 'khor gal te gzhan mu stegs can sangs rgyas kyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod/ chos dang dge 'dun gyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod cing mu stegs can rnams kyi bsngags pa ma yin pa yang dag pa brjod pa na nang bar byed/ 'khrug par byed/ khro bar byed cing yul yul por 'dug par byed/ khro ba skyed par byed na gzhan mu stegs can sems mgu bar ma gyur pa zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“Upāli, in the presence of the follower of another tīrthika order, speak the Buddha’s praises perfectly. Speak too the praises of the Dharma and the Saṅgha, and speak them perfectly. [F.73.b] Speak perfectly of the tīrthikas’ unworthiness. Upāli, when you speak of these things perfectly, if the follower of this other order becomes upset, disturbed, or angry, or if he sits withdrawn or seethes with anger, it can be said that the follower does not have a sense of reverence.

nye ba 'khor gal te gzhan mu stegs can sangs rgyas kyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod/ chos dang dge 'dun gyi bsngags pa yang dag pa brjod cing / mu stegs can rnams kyi bsngags pa ma yin pa yang dag pa brjod pa na nang bar mi byed/ 'khrug par mi byed/ khro bar mi byed cing yul yul por 'dug par mi byed/ khro ba skyed par mi byed na/ nye ba 'khor de tsam gyis na gzhan mu stegs can sems mgu ba zhes brjod par bya'o/ /

“But, Upāli, when you speak perfectly the praises of the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha, and also speak perfectly of the tīrthikas’ unworthiness, if the follower of this other tīrthika order does not become upset, disturbed, or angry, if he does not sit withdrawn or seethe with anger, then, Upāli, by that measure we may say the tīrthika has a sense of reverence.

dge slong dag me ba ral pa can dag rab tu dbyung bar bya zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dge slong dag me ba ral pa can dag ni las smra ba dang / me ba ral pa can dag ni bya ba smra ba dang / rgyu smra ba dang / brtson 'grus smra ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / dge slong dag de lta bas na 'di ltar bslab par bya ste/ las smra bar 'gyur ba dang / bya ba smra ba dang / rgyu smra ba dang / brtson 'grus smra bar 'gyur bar bya ste/ dge slong dag khyed kyis de ltar bslab par bya'o// //

“Monks, the going forth of dreadlocked fire-worshippers should be allowed and they should be ordained. Why? It is because, monks, they argue for karma, they argue for action, they argue for causes, and they argue for diligence. Therefore, monks, you too should train so that you come to argue for karma, for actions, for causes, and for diligence. Monks, that is how you should train.”
[nyi shu]
Twenty Years

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / gang gi tshe tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos nye ba 'khor la sogs pa sar pa skyes phran gzhon nu bcu bdun sde'i tshogs dag rab tu phyung bsnyen par rdzogs par byas pa de'i tshe na de dag mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe bkres pa'i nyam chung bas yongs su gzir nas ngu'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe kun dga' ra ba'i nang na byis pa khye'u rab tu mang po dag ngu ba'i sgra gsan to/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when Mahāmaudgalyāyana allowed the going forth of Upāli and a band of seventeen healthy new youths, and ordained them. Come twilight, reduced and wracked by hunger as they were, they would cry out and the Blessed One would hear these great many cries from within the monastery’s grounds. [F.74.a]

gsan nas kyang sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni mkhyen bzhin du rmed par mdzad pa ste/ mkhyen bzhin du rmed pa/ mkhyen kyang mi rmed pa/ dus su rmed pa/ dus las yol bar mi rmed pa/ don dang ldan pa rmed pa/ don dang mi ldan pa mi rmed pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni don dang mi ldan pa rmed pa la chu lon gyis zlog par mdzad pa yin no/ /

Though they hear, blessed buddhas may inquire about what they already know. Though they already know, they may inquire‍—or, even though they know, they may not inquire. They inquire when the time is right, not when the time has passed. Their inquiries are meaningful, not meaningless. In this way blessed buddhas dam the flow of meaningless inquiries.

de la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni don dang ldan pa rmed pa la dus mkhyen pa yin pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo la rmas pa/ kun dga' bo mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe kun dga' ra ba'i nang na byis pa khye'u rab tu mang po ngu ba 'di dag su/
As blessed buddhas know the time for a meaningful inquiry, the Blessed Buddha asked the venerable Ānanda, “Who are these great many young boys who cry within the monastery’s grounds at twilight?”

btsun pa 'di dag ni tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos nye ba 'khor la sogs pa sar pa skyes phran gzhon nu bcu bdun sde'i tshogs dag rab tu byung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par bgyis pa de dag mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe bkres pa'i nyam chung bas yongs su gzir te ngu ba lags so/ /
“Reverend, it is Upāli and a band of seventeen healthy new youths whom Mahāmaudgalyāyana allowed to go forth, and has ordained. At twilight it is they who, reduced and wracked by hunger, cry out.”
kun dga' bo dge slong dag gang zag lo nyi shu ma lon pa dge slong gi dngos por bsnyen par rdzogs par byed dam/ btsun pa bgyid do/ /
“Ānanda, do monks grant ordination into the monkhood to persons who have not yet reached twenty years?” “Reverend, they do.”

kun dga' bo bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o/ / de ci'i phyir zhe na/ kun dga' bo gang zag lo nyi shu ma lon pas ni grang ba dang / tsha ba dang / bkres pa dang / skom pa dang / sha sbrang dang / sbrang bu mchu rings dang / rlung dang / nyi ma dang / sdig sbrul dag gi reg pa dag dang / gzhan las tshig gi lam ngan pa smras pa dang / ngan pa 'ongs pa dag dang / lus kyi tshor ba sdug bsngal mi bzad pa rtsub pa tsha ba yid du mi 'ong ba srog 'phrog par byed pa byung ngo cog dag mi bzod cing zag pa dag la ji mi snyam par bya ba yang ma bzod cing dang du len mi nus pa'i rang bzhin can yin pa'i phyir dang /

“Ānanda, ones so young should not be ordained. Persons who are not yet twenty years of age cannot accept all they may be subjected to‍—the cold, the heat, the hunger, the thirst, the blowflies, the gadflies, the gnats, the wind, the sun, the snakes, the abuse hurled at them, the bad that befalls them, or the physical pains that are intolerable, oppressive, intense, dreadful, and life-threatening. Their nature is such that they cannot abide or withstand their longing for defilements.

gang zag lo nyi shu lon pa ni grang ba dang / tsha ba dang / bkres pa dang / skom pa dang / sha sbrang dang / sbrang bu mchu rings dang / rlung dang / nyi ma dang / sdig sbrul gyi reg pa dag dang / gzhan las tshig gi lam ngan pa smras pa dang / ngan pa 'ongs pa dag dang / lus kyi tshor ba sdug bsngal mi bzad pa rtsub pa tsha ba yid du mi 'ong ba srog 'phrog par byed pa byung ngo cog bzod cing zag pa dag la ji mi snyam par bya ba yang bzod cing dang du len nus pa'i rang bzhin can yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

“Persons who have reached twenty years of age, on the other hand, can accept all they may be subjected to‍—the cold, the heat, the hunger, the thirst, the blowflies, the gadflies, the gnats, the wind, the sun, the snakes, the abuse hurled at them, [F.74.b] the bad that befalls them, or the physical pains that are intolerable, oppressive, intense, dreadful, and life-threatening. Their nature is such that they can abide and withstand their longing for defilements.”
bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag gang zag lo nyi shu ma lon pa dge slong gi dngos por bsnyen par rdzogs par byed pa las gyur pa yin snyam nas
The Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks granting ordination into the monkhood to persons who have not yet reached twenty years.”

bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis gang zag lo nyi shu ma lon pa dge slong gi dngos por bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du bsnyen par rdzogs par 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la lo nyi shu lon nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par bsnyen par rdzogs par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

Then he decreed, “In light of this, monks should not grant ordination into the monkhood to persons who have not yet reached twenty years. If someone wishing to be ordained approaches any of you, ask him if he has reached twenty years. If you grant ordination without asking this, a breach occurs.”

Novices Not Yet Fifteen

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal bu rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas/ de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod pa de'i bu byung nas bsrings shing bskyed de chen por gyur to/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one other. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself gave birth to a son who was nurtured and grew until he was big.

de nas dus gzhan zhig na khyim bdag de nye du zad par gyur cing nor zad pa dang / longs spyod zad par gyur nas des bsams pa/ bdag gis rgas pa'i gnas skabs su nor bsgrub par mi nus kyis rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas

At a certain point, the householder’s kin had dwindled, his riches had dwindled, and his possessions had dwindled, prompting the thought, “As I am grown old and cannot gain more riches, I shall go forth.”

des bu de la smras pa/ bu kho bo rgas pa'i gnas skabs su nor bsgrub par mi nus kyis/ kho bo rab tu 'byung du 'gro'o/ / des smras pa/ yab gal te khyod rab tu 'byung na bdag kyang rab tu 'byung ngo / / bu de bzhin gyis shig ces
He then said this to his son, who replied, “Father, if you are to go forth, then I too shall go forth.” “Son, let us do just that!” said the householder.
des de khrid nas rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste/ dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
He took his son and went to Jetavana, where they approached a monk and he said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”
des smras pa/ khyod kyi khye'u 'di su yin/ bu lags so/ / 'di yang rab tu 'byung ngam/ 'phags pa rab tu 'byung ngo / /
The monk replied, “Who is this lad with you?” “He is my son.” “Is he to go forth as well?” “Yes, noble one, he is.” [F.75.a]

des de la chags pas gnyi ga yang rab tu phyung nas de'i 'og tu nyi ma gnyis sam gsum du kun du spyad pa'i chos dag slob tu bcug nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs dag ri dgas kyis ri dgas mi sos/ mnyan yod rgya che la rang gi spyod yul dang yab kyi yul yin gyis bsod snyoms sgrubs la 'tsho bar gyis shig /

As the monk had taken a liking to them, he allowed their going forth. For the next two or three days he trained them in their regular duties, and then said, “Gentlemen, game does not eat other game. The whole of Śrāvastī is your field and fatherland, so seek out alms and live on them.”

de snga dro sham thabs bgos chos gos dang lhung bzed thogs te/ dge tshul de nyid dang lhan cig mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs so/ / dge tshul des srang zhig na khur ba sreg pa mthong nas des smras pa/ yab bdag la khur ba sbyin du chug shig /

Early the next morning, the father put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and went to beg alms in Śrāvastī with his novice son. Seeing a burnt piece of bread in the market, the novice said, “Father, ask the shopkeeper to give me the bread.”

des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs dge tshul 'di la khur ba byin cig / des smras pa/ 'phags pa rin ma mchis par mi gsol gyi/ 'di ltar kAr ShA pa Na dag gi slad du gsol lo/ / bzhin bzangs kho bo cag ni rab tu byung ba yin pas kho bo cag la kAr ShA pa Na dag ga la yod/

“Sir, please give this novice bread,” said the father. The shopkeeper replied, “Noble one, no one eats for free. So I would ask a few coins in return.” “Sir, we are renunciants. How could we have a few coins?”
des smras pa/ 'phags pa ci lags dge tshul 'di khyod rab tu byung bas bskyed dam/ 'on te khyim pas bskyed/ des smras pa/ khyim pas so/ / de lta na bsags pa de dag stsol cig /
“Noble one, did you raise this novice while a renunciant or householder?” “A householder.” “Then give him what you earned while a householder.”
des smras pa/ dge tshul 'di bgrang ba mang po dag slong bar byed kyis tshur shog 'dong ngo zhes des de sor mo dag nas bzung ste 'phags pa dang / de gan rgyal du 'gyel nas ngu bar brtsams so/ /
“This novice is but one of many who beg. Come! Let us go!” Saying this, the father grabbed out for his son’s hand, but his son jumped back, fell down and began to cry.
de gnyis skye bo phal po che'i tshogs kyis mthong nas de dag gis smras pa/ shes ldan dag 'di'i dge tshul 'di su zhig yin/ bu yin no/ / de dag khrag gi thigs pa 'di rab tu phyung bas ci zhig bya zhes
A great crowd of people saw the two and asked, “Gentlemen, to whom does this novice belong?” “He is my son,” his father said. “Why did you make the fruit of your loins go forth?” they asked.

smod par byed/ phyar ka gtong bar byed/ kha zer bar byed pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag gang zag lo bcwa lnga ma lon par rab tu 'byin par byed pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas

Since the bystanders denounced, disparaged, and insulted him, the monks asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing persons who have not yet reached fifteen years to go forth.”

bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis gang zag lo bcwa lnga ma lon pa rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la lo bcwa lnga lon nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

Then he decreed, “That being the case, monks should not allow persons under fifteen years old to go forth. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, [F.75.b] ask him if he has reached fifteen years. If you allow going forth without so asking, a breach occurs.”
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po bdun pa/

The Two Novices
sdom la/ dge tshul gnyis dang bran dang ni/ / bu lon chags dang ma gnang dang / / zhu ba dang ni nad pa dang / / shAkya'i sde tshan bsdus pa yin/ /
A summary: The chapters are of two novices, Those in servitude, debtors, Those without consent, Without consultation, ill persons, and the Śākyas.
[dge tshul gnyis]
Two Novices

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / tshe dang ldan pa nye dga'i dge tshul tsher ma dang chen po pa gnyis gcig la gcig gzhogs stegs dang phyar g.yeng dang / lus la rdeg par byed cing 'di lta ste dper na bud med skyes pa dang lhan cig byed pa dang / skyes pa bud med dang lhan cig byed pa ltar byed pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag dge tshul gnyis nye bar 'jog pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when two of Upananda’s novices, Kaṇṭaka and Mahaka, flirted with, groped, and tickled one another. They acted as a man does with a woman, or as a woman does with a man. Once, when they were behaving like this, the monks asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks placing two novices together.”
bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis dge tshul gnyis nye bar gzhag par mi bya'o/ /nye bar 'jog na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /
He then decreed, “In light of this, monks should not place two novices together. If you do so, a breach occurs.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong gis dge tshul gnyis nye bar gzhag par mi bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas/ gzhan spun gnyis shig 'ongs te/ bdag cag gnyis cig car lhan cig tu rab tu 'byung bar bya'o zhes nges par byas te lhags pa na/ dge slong dag de gnyis rab tu 'byin par mi byed pas de gnyis rab tu 'byung ba ma thob par dong ste/

After the Blessed One had so decreed, sure enough, two brothers turned up, saying, “We two shall go forth together, at the same time.” When that occurred, the monks did not allow their going forth so the two of them left without going forth.

de nyid tshe dang ldan pa de gnyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po'i bar chad du gyur pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ gal te spun gnyis shig 'ongs te bdag cag gnyis cig car lhan cig tu rab tu 'byung bar bya'o zhes nges par byas te lhags na rab tu dbyung bar bya'o/ / rab tu phyung nas gal te lo nyi shu lon na bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ / gal te gcig lo nyi shu lon na de bsnyen par rdzogs par bya zhing cig shos dge tshul du nye bar gzhag par bya'o/ / gal te gnyi ga lo nyi shu ma lon na gcig bdag nyid kyis nye bar gzhag par bya zhing / cig shos dge slong grogs po 'ga' la gtad par bya'o/ /

When that proved to be an impediment to monkhood‍—the state of having gone forth and been ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya‍—the monks asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One decreed, “If two brothers turn up as they are sure to, saying, ‘We two shall go forth together, at the same time,’ their going forth should be allowed. Once they have gone forth, they should be ordained if they have reached twenty years. If one should have reached twenty years, then he [F.76.a] should be ordained while the other should be left a novice. If neither has reached twenty years, then you should take charge of one while entrusting the other to a monk friend of yours.”

gang la gtad pa de nyid kyis bsnyen par rdzogs par byed nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de gang gi yin pa des bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ / des mi ster nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ mi ster ba las mthus dgug par bya'o// //

The one he is entrusted to shall ordain him, for the Blessed One decreed, “Whoever that may be, it is he that should grant ordination.” If ordination was not given, the Blessed One decreed, “Induce him to grant what was not given.”
[bran]
Those in Servitude

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa de la bran mkhas pa/ le lo med pa/ sgrub phod pa/ 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la sngon du 'gro ba zhig yod do/ / dus gzhan zhig na des bran de spyos pa dang bran des bsams pa/ khyim bdag 'di mgu dka' bar gyur pas bdag gis 'di'i sems srung bar byed mi nus kyis 'bros su 'gro snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ yul gtong ba ni dka' ba byed pa yin gyis shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong 'di dag gis rgyal po las gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba thob pas 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas/

While the Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, there was a householder living in Śrāvastī with a clever servant who was industrious, assured in his work, and the first to any task, no matter how small. At a certain point the householder insulted his servant, prompting the servant to think, “This householder is hard to please and I cannot guard my mind against his abuse. I ought to run away. But leaving one’s own land behind is hard, so instead I shall go forth among the ascetic sons of the Śākya, for they have secured from the king the liberty of a prince.”
de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste/ dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
With that he went to Jetavana, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas te/ gdams ngag byin nas des brtson pa dang / 'bad pa dang / brtsal ba byas pas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas te/ dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan dang ste'ur mnyam pa lta bu/ rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing / rig pa dang mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang / bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur to/ /

After allowing his going forth and ordaining him, the monk gave him instructions. To these, the former servant applied himself with diligence, energy, and exertion so that he abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship, becoming an arhat free of attachment to the three realms, for whom filth was equal to gold, for whom space was equal to the palm of his hand,[157] whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood,[158] and whose knowledge had rent open the shell. He attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. He turned his back on worldly gain, desires, [F.76.b] and esteem, and was venerated, honored, and saluted by Indra and the gods who attend him.

khyim bdag de 'gyod pa skyes nas des bsams pa/ de bdag gi 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la sngon du 'gro ba yin na/ bdag gis ci'i phyir spyos snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ gal te da mthong na bzod pa gsol lo snyam nas des mnyan yod kyi sgor bsdad do/ /

The householder, meanwhile, was feeling regret: “If my servant was first to all of my tasks, no matter how small, why did I insult him? If I see him now, I will beg his forgiveness.” With that he sat down at the gates to Śrāvastī.

dge slong de yang snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te/ mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang khyim bdag des de mthong nas des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod rab tu byung na kho bo'i rim gro sus byed par 'gyur/ tshur shog 'dong zhes des lag pa brkyang ste de'i lag pa gnyis nas gzung bar brtsams pa dang / des ngang pa'i rgyal po 'dab ma brkyang ba ltar steng gi nam mkha' la mngon par 'phags nas 'bar ba dang / gsal ba dang / char 'bebs pa dang / glog 'byin pa'i cho 'phrul dag bya bar brtsams so/ /

The next morning, the monk put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and was preparing to beg alms in Śrāvastī when the householder saw him and said, “Sir, if you have gone forth, who will attend me? Come back!” As the householder reached out to grab at him, the monk, like a kingly swan taken to wing, flew up into the sky above, blazing and brilliant, as a miraculous show of rain and thunder began.

so so'i skye bo ni rdzu 'phrul la myur du sems gtod par byed pa yin pas khyim bdag de shing ljon pa rtsa ba nas bcad pa bzhin du dge slong de'i rkang pa gnyis la gtugs nas smras pa/ 'phags pa khyod kyis yon tan gyi tshogs 'di lta bu brnyes sam/ thob bo/ /
Because ordinary beings are quick to heed a miracle, the householder dropped like a felled tree at the monk’s feet and asked, “Noble one, have you found such a store of qualities?” “I have.”

des de la yo byad thams cad kyis bstabs pa dang / thams cad du khyim bdag che ge mo zhig gi bran rab tu byung nas yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes sgra grags so/ / ko sa la'i rgyal po gsal rgyal gyis khyim bdag che ge mo'i bran rab tu phyung nas yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes thos nas des blon po rnams la bsgo ba/ shes ldan dag nga ni rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba bya ba thams cad kyi mnga' bdag yin pas deng phyin chad 'ga' zhig gi bran rab tu 'byung bar 'dod na des mi bzlog par bya'o/ /

The householder provided the monk with all the provisions he would need, and word spread everywhere that the servant of this householder had gone forth and attained a store of qualities. When Prasenajit, the King of Kosala, heard that this servant had gone forth and attained a store of qualities, he summoned his ministers and said, “Gentlemen, as the ruler of all anointed kṣatriya kings, I declare that henceforth any servant who should wish to go forth shall not be prevented from doing so.”

mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa de la bran mkhas pa/ le lo med pa/ sgrub phod pa/ 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la sngon du 'gro ba zhig yod do/ / dus gzhan zhig na des bran de spyos pa dang bran des bsams pa/ khyim bdag 'di mgu dka' bar gyur pas bdag gis 'di'i sems srung bar byed mi nus kyis 'bros su 'gro'o snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ yul gtong ba ni dka' ba byed pa yin gyis shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong 'di dag ni rgyal po las gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba thob pas 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas

In Śrāvastī there lived a different householder with a clever servant who was industrious, assured in his work, and first to any task, no matter how small. [F.77.a] At a certain point the householder insulted his servant, prompting the servant to think, “This householder is hard to please and I cannot guard my mind against his abuse. I ought to run away. But leaving one’s own land behind is hard, so instead I shall go forth among the ascetic sons of the Śākya, for they have secured from the king the liberty of a prince.”

de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste/ dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ / des de rab tu dbyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas de'i 'og tu nyi ma gnyis sam gsum du kun du spyad pa'i chos dag slob tu bcug nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ri dgas kyis ri dgas mi sos/ mnyan yod rgya che la rang gi spyod yul dang yab kyi yul yin gyis bsod snyoms sgrubs la 'tsho bar gyis shig

With that he went to Jetavana, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.” After allowing his going forth and ordaining him, the monk trained him for the next two or three days in his regular duties, and then said, “Sir, game does not eat other game. The whole of Śrāvastī is your field and fatherland, so seek out alms and live on them.”

/khyim bdag de 'gyod pa skyes nas des bsams pa/ de bdag gi 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la sngon du 'gro ba yin na/ bdag gis ci'i phyir spyos snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ gal te da mthong na bzod pa gsol lo snyam nas des mnyan yod kyi sgor bsdad do/ /

The householder, meanwhile, was feeling regret: “If he was first to all of my tasks, no matter how small, why did I insult him? If I see him now, I will beg his forgiveness.” With that he sat down at the gates to Śrāvastī.

dge slong de yang snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / khyim bdag des de mthong nas des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod rab tu byung na kho bo'i rim gro sus byed par 'gyur/ tshur shog 'dong zhes des lag pa brkyang ste de'i lag pa gnyis nas gzung bar brtsams pa dang / des smras pa/ kho bo cag la rgyal pos gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba byin nas gal te reg par byed na khyod kyi lag pa mkhrig ma nas gcod du gzhug go/ /

The next morning, the monk put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and was preparing to beg alms in Śrāvastī when the householder saw him and said, “Sir, if you have gone forth, who will attend me? Come back!” As the householder reached out to grab at him, the monk said, “The king has given us a prince’s liberty. If you touch me, I shall cut your hand off at the wrist!”

de shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong rnams kyi dge sbyong gi tshul ni tshig pa yin no/ / bram ze'i tshul ni tshig pa yin te/ 'di ltar bran yang rab tu 'byin par byed do zhes smod par byed/ phyar ka gtong bar byed/ kha zer bar byed pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag bran rab tu 'byin pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas bka' stsal pa/

As such words put to flame the virtuous ways of the ascetic sons of the Śākya, and put to flame the ways of brahmins, the allowing of this servant’s going forth was denounced, disparaged, and criticized. The monks then asked the Blessed One about it, [F.77.b] and he thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing the going forth of servants.”

de lta bas na dge slong gis bran rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la bran ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

Then he decreed, “That being the case, monks should not allow the going forth of servants. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You are not a servant, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[bu lon chags]
Debtors

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa de la bu lon chags pa zhig gis dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed 'jal bar byed do/ /
While the Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, a debtor was repaying the principle and interest of a debt in timely fashion to a householder living in Śrāvastī.

dus gzhan zhig na khyim bdag des bu lon chags pa de ma tshor ba kho nar bzung nas smras pa/ dngos dang skyed cig car phul cig ces des de dus cung zad cig tu bzung ste btang ba dang des bsams pa/ khyim bdag 'di mgu dka' bar gyur pas bdag gis dngos dang skyed cig car 'jal mi nus kyis 'bros su 'gro'o snyam mo/ / des bsams pa yul gtong ba ni dka' ba byed pa yin gyis shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong 'di dag gis rgyal po las gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba thob pas 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas/

At a certain point, the householder unexpectedly accosted the debtor, saying, “I demand you repay the principle and interest in their entirety all at once.” After agreeing to a short window for repayment, he released the debtor, who thought, “This householder is hard to please and I cannot repay the principle and interest all at once. I ought to run away. But leaving one’s own land behind is hard, so instead I shall go forth among the ascetic sons of the Śākya, for they have secured from the king the liberty of a prince.”
de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
With that he went to Jetavana, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas te gdams ngag byin nas/ des brtson pa dang / 'bad pa dang / brtsal bar byas pas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas te/ dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan zhag lon par bzhag pa lta bu rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing rig pa dang / mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang / bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur to/ /

After allowing the debtor’s going forth and ordaining him, the monk gave him instructions. To these, he applied himself with diligence, energy, and exertion so that he abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship, becoming an arhat free of attachment to the three realms, for whom filth was equal to gold, for whom space was equal to the palm of his hand, whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood, and whose knowledge had rent open the shell. He attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. He turned his back on worldly gain, desires, and esteem, and was venerated, honored, and saulted by Indra and [F.78.a] the gods who attend him.

khyim bdag de 'gyod pa skyes nas des bsams pa/ de bdag la dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed 'bul ba yin na bdag gis ci'i phyir bzung snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ gal te da mthong na bzod pa gsol lo snyam nas des mnyan yod kyi sgor bsdad do/ /

The householder, meanwhile, was feeling regret: “If he was giving me the principle and interest in a timely fashion, why did I accost him? If I see him now, I will beg his forgiveness.” With that he sat down at the gates to Śrāvastī.

dge slong de yang snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / khyim bdag des de mthong nas des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod rab tu byung na kho bo la dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed sus 'bul bar 'gyur/ tshur shog 'dong zhes des lag pa brkyang ste de'i lag pa gnyis nas gzung bar brtsams pa dang / des ngang pa'i rgyal po 'dab ma brkyang ba ltar steng gi nam mkha' la mngon par 'phags nas 'bar ba dang / gsal ba dang / char 'bebs pa dang / glog 'byin pa'i cho 'phrul dag bya bar brtsams so/ /

The next morning, the monk put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and was preparing to beg alms in Śrāvastī when the householder saw him and said, “Sir, if you have gone forth, who will repay the principle and interest in a timely fashion? Come back!” As the householder reached out to grab at him, the monk, like a kingly swan taken to wing, flew up into the sky above, blazing and brilliant, as a miraculous show of rain and thunder began.

so so'i skye bo ni rdzu 'phrul la myur du sems gtod par byed pa yin pas khyim bdag de shing ljon pa rtsa ba nas bcad pa bzhin du dge slong de'i rkang pa gnyis la gtugs nas smras pa/ 'phags pa khyod kyis yon tan gyi tshogs 'di lta bu brnyes sam/ thob bo/ /
As ordinary beings are quick to heed a miracle, the householder dropped like a felled tree at the monk’s feet and asked, “Noble one, have you found such a store of qualities?” “I have attained them.”

des de la yo byad thams cad kyis bstabs pa dang / thams cad du khyim bdag che ge mo zhig gi bu lon chags pa rab tu byung nas yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes sgra grags so/ / ko sa la'i rgyal po gsal rgyal gyis khyim bdag che ge mo zhig gi bu lon chags pa rab tu byung nas yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes thos nas/ des blon po rnams la bsgo ba shes ldan dag nga ni rgyal po rgyal rigs spyi bor dbang bskur ba bya ba thams cad kyi mnga' bdag yin pas deng phyin chad 'ga' zhig gi bu lon chags pa rab tu 'byung bar 'dod na des de mi bzlog par bya'o// //

The householder provided the monk with all the provisions he would need, and word spread everywhere that the debtor of this householder had gone forth and attained a store of qualities. When Prasenajit, the King of Kosala, heard this debtor had gone forth and attained a store of qualities, he summoned his ministers and said, “Gentlemen, as the ruler of all anointed kṣatriya kings, I declare that henceforth any debtor who should wish to go forth shall not be prevented from doing so.”

mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa de la bu lon chags pa zhig gis dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed 'jal bar byed do/ / dus gzhan zhig na khyim bdag des bu lon chags pa de ma tshor ba kho nar bzung nas smras pa/ dngos dang skyed cig car phul cig ces des de dus cung zad cig bzung nas btang ba dang / des bsams pa/ khyim bdag 'di mgu dka' bar gyur pas bdag gis dngos dang skyed cig car 'jal mi nus kyis 'bros su 'gro'o snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ yul gtong ba ni dka' ba byed pa yin gyis shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong 'di dag gis rgyal po las gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba thob pas 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas/

In Śrāvastī, a different debtor was repaying the principle and interest of a debt in timely fashion to a householder. [F.78.b] At a certain point, the householder unexpectedly accosted the debtor, saying, “I demand you repay the principle and interest in their entirety all at once.” After agreeing to a short window for repayment, he released the debtor, who thought, “As this householder is hard to please and I cannot repay the principle and interest all at once, I ought to run away. But leaving one’s own land behind is hard, so instead I shall go forth among the ascetic sons of the Śākya, for they have secured from the king the liberty of a prince.”
de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
With that he went to Jetavana, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas de'i 'og tu nyi ma gnyis sam gsum du kun du spyad pa'i chos dag slob tu bcug nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ri dgas kyis ri dgas mi sos/ mnyan yod rgya che la rang gi spyod yul dang yab kyi yul yin gyis bsod snyoms sgrubs la 'tsho bar gyis shig /

After allowing his going forth and ordaining him, for the next two or three days he trained him in his regular duties, and then said, “Sir, game does not eat other game. The whole of Śrāvastī is your field and fatherland, so seek out alms and live on them.”

khyim bdag de 'gyod pa skyes nas des bsams pa/ de bdag la dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed 'bul ba yin na/ bdag gis ci'i phyir gzung snyam mo des bsams pa/ gal te da mthong na bzod pa gsol lo snyam nas des mnyan yod kyi sgor bsdad do/ /

Meanwhile, the householder was feeling regret and thought, “If he was repaying the principle and interest in timely fashion, why did I accost him?” If I see him now, I will beg his forgiveness.” With that he sat down at the gates to Śrāvastī.

dge slong de yang snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang / khyim bdag des de mthong nas des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod rab tu byung na kho bo la dus dang dus su dngos dang skyed su 'bul bar 'gyur/ tshur shog 'dong zhes des lag pa brkyang ste/ de'i lag pa gnyis nas gzung bar brtsams pa dang des smras pa/ kho bo cag la rgyal pos gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba byin pas gal te reg par byed na khyod kyi lag pa mkhrig ma nas gcod du gzhug go/ /

The next morning, the monk put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and was preparing to beg alms in Śrāvastī when the householder saw him and said, “Sir, if you have gone forth, who will repay the principle and interest in timely fashion? Come back!” As the householder reached out to grab at him, the monk said, “The king has given us a prince’s liberty. If you touch me, I shall cut your hand off at the wrist!”

de shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong rnams kyi dge sbyong gi tshul ni tshig pa yin no/ / bram ze'i tshul ni tshig pa yin te/ 'di ltar bu lon chags pa yang rab tu 'byin par byed do zhes smod par byed/ phyar ka gtong bar byed/ kha zer bar byed pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag bu lon chags pa rab tu 'byin pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas

As such words put to flame the virtuous ways of the ascetic sons of the Śākya, and put to flame the ways of brahmins, the allowing of this debtor’s going forth was denounced, [F.79.a] disparaged, and criticized. The monks asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing the debtors’s going forth.”

bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis bu lon chags pa rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la bu lon chags pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

Then the Blessed One decreed, “In light of this, monks should not allow debtors’ going forth. If someone wishing to be allowed to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You aren’t a debtor, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[ma gnang]
Those Without Consent

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas/ de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod pa de'i bu byung nas bsrings shing bskyed de chen por gyur to/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself then gave birth to a son who was nurtured and grew until he was big.

dus gzhan zhig na des bu de spyos pa dang / bu des bsams pa/ pha 'di mgu dka' bar gyur pas bdag gis 'di'i sems srung bar byed mi nus kyis 'bros su 'gro'o snyam mo/ / des bsams pa/ yul gtong ba ni dka' ba byed pa yin gyis shAkya'i sras kyi dge sbyong 'di dag ni rgyal po las gzhon nu'i yongs su spang ba thob pas 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas/

At a certain point, the householder insulted his son, prompting his son to think, “This father of mine is hard to please and I cannot guard my mind against his abuse. I ought to run away. But leaving one’s own land behind is hard, so instead I shall go forth among the ascetic sons of the Śākya, for they have secured from the king the liberty of a prince.”
de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ste dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ / 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
With that he went to Jetavana, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag byin nas gang gis de zhu bar byed pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab/ gang gis de'i skra dang kha spu dag 'breg par byed pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab gang gis de'i khrus byed pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab/ gang gis de dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub par byed pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab ste/ de rab tu phyung nas gang gis de'i las byed pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab/ gang gis de la gsang ste ston pa'i dge slong la yang gsol ba btab/

After the monk gave him refuge and the precepts, the son requested him to serve as his monk petitioner, as the monk who cuts his hair and beard, as the monk who oversees bathing, and as the monk who inducts him into the novitiate. Then, after his going forth was allowed, [F.79.b] he again requested him, this time to serve as the monk officiant. His final request to him was to serve as the monk privy advisor.

gang dag de'i las kyi gnas su 'jug par 'gyur ba'i dge slong dag la yang gsol ba btab nas de bsnyen par rdzogs par byed pa na/ khyim bdag de 'ongs nas dris pa/ 'phags pa khye'u 'di 'dra ba zhig mchis pa gzigs sam/

After the son had appealed to the monk to serve in all of these capacities, the householder who was the ordinand’s father arrived during the ordination ceremony, and asked the monk, “Noble one, have you seen a lad fitting the description of my son?”[159]
des smras pa/ de zhu bar byed/ de skra dang kha spu dag 'breg par byed/ de khrus byed de/ dge tshul nyid du nye bar sgrub par byed/ de bsnyen par rdzogs par byed do zhes
The monk replied, “I asked on his behalf, I cut his hair and beard, I oversaw his bath, I inducted him into the novitiate, and I ordained him.”

de dag gis de bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas grib tshod gzhal zhing nyin mtshan gyi cha dang / dus tshigs brjod de/ gnas rnams dang / ltung bar 'gyur ba'i chos rnams dang / dge sbyong byed pa'i chos rnams dang / mchog tu 'dod par bya ba yang dag pa nyid kyis rdzogs pa nyid dang / tshul khrims kyis mnyam par gyur pa nyid bsgrub pa la nges par sbyar bar bya ba dang / tshul dang 'brel ba'i gzugs brnyan la nges par sbyar bar bya ba dang / dul bar gnas pa nyid la nges par sbyar bar bya ba dang / dgos pa rjes su bsgrub pa la nges par sbyar bar bya ba dang / ma brjod pa yang dag par blangs pa yongs su shes pa'i bsgrub par 'gyur ba nyid dang / gus pa la nges par sbyar ba/

After the son was ordained, they measured the shadows and noted the time of day and the hour. They made sure he knew the foundations, what things brought about offenses, what constituted spiritual practice, how to attain perfect fulfillment of his greatest desire, and how to practice the equally applicable ethical code. They enjoined him to bond with his role model in the renunciant life, to dwell in tranquility, to carry out his obligations, to do what he must do to fully understand his unspoken commitments, to heed what he reveres, and told him:

shes rab mchog gi bstan pa la/ / khyod ni bsnyen par rdzogs par gyur/ / dal dang 'byor pa rnyed dka' bas/ / 'di dag ji lta bzhin du sgrubs/ / mdzes pa rab tu dbyung ba dang / / yongs su dag pa bsnyen rdzogs par/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis rab mkhyen te/ / bden pa'i mtshan gyis bka' stsal to/ / zhes bya ba dang / bsgrub par bya ba thabs brjod pa dang bcas pa la nges par sbyar bar byas te/

“You have been ordained Into the teachings of the most wise. To find leisure and opportunity is rare, So heed them perfectly. Knowing all, the Perfectly Awakened One, Whose name denotes truth, proclaimed That going forth is for the beautiful And ordination for the pure.” And they enjoined him in what he must practice and how.

dge slong de dag langs pa dang khyim bdag de 'ongs te smras pa/ 'phags pa dag ci khyed cag spu gri thogs pa 'ba' zhig gis sdod dam/ gal te bdag la dad pa ma mchis par gyur du lags na 'di'i tshangs par spyod pa'i bar chad du 'gyur ro/ / kye ma khyod kyis zhag bdun nam brgyad cig bsrel na ci nongs zhes zer ba'i skabs de

As the newly ordained monk committed to these things, his father the householder arrived and asked, “Noble one, why are you just sitting there with a razor in your hand? If he has lost faith in me, that will be an impediment to his living the holy life. Goodness! Where is the harm in waiting seven or eight days?” [F.80.a]

bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa pha mas ma gnang ba zhag bdun mi bsrel ba las gyur pa yin no snyam nas bka' stsal pa/

The monks then asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks not waiting seven or eight days for consent from the parents of one wishing to go forth.”
de lta bas na 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa pha ma gson zhing de gnyis kyis ma gnang bar 'ongs na zhag bdun nam brgyad bsrel bar bya'o/ /
Then he decreed, “In the light of this, if someone approaches any of you, wishing to go forth, who has parents who are alive but have not granted him consent, wait seven or eight days.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na zhag bdun nam brgyad bsrel bar bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas/ rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa pha mas gnang ba gzhan dag 'ongs shing yul thag ring ba pha mas gtam yang mi thos pa dag kyang 'ongs pa na/ dge slong rnams kyis de dag kyang zhag bdun nam brgyad srel bar byed pas de dag rab tu byung ba ma thob par dong ste/

But later, after the Blessed One had said, “If someone approaches you, wishing to go forth, wait seven or eight days,” others arrived, wishing to go forth, whose parents had granted them consent, as did others coming from afar whose parents could not be consulted. When this occurred, the monks made them, too, wait seven or eight days, and so some left without having been allowed to go forth.

de nyid tshe dang ldan pa de dag legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po'i bar chad du gyur pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ pha mas gnang ba gang dag 'ongs pa dang / yul thag ring po pha mas gtam yang mi thos pa gang dag 'ongs pa de dag ni rab tu dbyung bar bya ste/ 'di la 'gyod par mi bya'o// //

When that proved to be an impediment to monkhood, the state of having gone forth and been ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, the monks asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One decreed, “Whoever comes with his parents’ consent, and whoever comes from so far away that his parents cannot be consulted, their going forth should be allowed. This you need not regret.”
[zhu ba]
Without Consultation

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i bu byung nas des chung ma la smras pa/ bzang mo yu bu cag gi bu lon 'jal bar byed pa dang / nor spyod pa skyes kyis/ kho bo zong thogs te yul gzhan du 'gro'o/ / rje'i sras de bzhin mdzod cig /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself then gave birth to a son, upon which occasion the householder said, “Mistress, as we must repay our debts and build our wealth, I shall go to trade in another land.” “Son of a lord, do as you wish.”

de zong thogs te yul gzhan du song ba dang / de de nyid du tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur to/ / mas khye'u de nye du'i mthu dang lag mthus bsnyod cing gsos te bskyed nas/ des khye'u de yig dpon la bcol ba dang / khye'u de'i na zla rnams kyis ni yig 'bru'i yi ge dag lobs nas phyi rol gyi bstan bcos dag bklag par brtsams so/ / de ni yig 'bru'i yi ge de dag nyid la slob par byed pa dang / de'i ma yig dpon gyi gan du song ste phyin nas smras pa/ jo bo khye'u 'di'i na zla khye'u dag gis khyod la ci 'bul ba de bdag kyang khyod la 'bul na/ khye'u 'di'i na zla khye'u dag gis ni yi ge'i yig 'bru dag lobs nas phyi rol gyi bstan bcos dag bklag par brtsams na/ khye'u 'di ni da dung yig 'bru'i yi ge dag slob par bgyid do/ /

With that, he set out for another land to trade, [F.80.b] and in this land he suffered misfortune. His wife gave guardianship of their son to relatives while supporting and providing for him through her own industry. Once he had grown, she placed him under the tutelage of a court scribe. While other boys of the lad’s age had already learned their letters and had begun to study the grammar treatises, he was still struggling to learn his letters. His mother went to the court scribe and said, “Lord, whatever the other boys of the lad’s age may offer you, I too will give you. Those boys have already learned their letters and have begun to study the grammar treatises, while this lad is still learning his letters.”

des smras pa/ rgyu gnyis kyis rig pa lobs par 'gyur te/ gang la bdag nyid las byung ba'i ngo tsha shes pa yod pa dang / gang la phyi rol las byung ba'i khrel yod pa yod pas so/ / khye'u 'di la ni ngo tsha shes pa yang med la/ khrel yod pa yang med do/ / 'di ltar khyod la yang nyes pa yod de/ kho bos 'di gzhus pa na khyod kyis shed bskyed do/ / des smras pa/ de de bzhin no/ / bdag la nongs pa de mchis te/ khyod kyis gzhus pa bdag gis shed bskyed do/ /

The court scribe replied, “There are two factors in honing one’s intelligence. The first is a sense of modesty, which pertains to oneself; another is a sense of propriety, which pertains to others. This lad has no modesty nor does he have any sense of propriety. For this, you too are at fault, for you object when I strike him.” “I am guilty of that, as you say,” she responded, “and I do object to your striking him.”

dus gzhan zhig na des de gzhus pa dang / de ngu zhing ma'i gan du song ngo / / mas de la smras pa/ bu khyod ci'i phyir ngu/ ma bdag yig dpon gyis gzhus so/ / mas kyang de gzhus pa dang khye'u des bsams pa/ gnyi gar nyes dmigs byung ste/ sngon ni bdag gnas gcig tu gzhus na/ da ni gnas gnyi gar gzhus pas bdag gis gnas gnyi gar gnod pa mi bzod pas 'bros so snyam nas

Another time, the court scribe struck him and the lad went off crying to his mother. His mother asked him, “Son, why are you crying?” “Mother, the court scribe struck me.” His mother then struck him too, prompting the lad to think, “Both are at fault. Before I was only struck in one place. Now I am struck in both. I cannot bear being hurt in both places so I will run away.”

de rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ba dang / de na dge tshul zhig me tog thu ba de des mthong nas khye'u des smras pa/ 'phags pa khyod re bde/ ci'i phyir/ gang gi phyir khyod rab tu byung bas so/ / khyod ci'i phyir rab tu mi 'byung / 'phags pa bdag sus rab tu 'byin par 'gyur/ des smras pa/ tshur shog mkhan po'i gan du 'dong zhes des de khrid de mkhan po'i gan du song nas smras pa/ mkhan po rigs kyi bu 'di rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal gyis 'di rab tu dbyung du gsol/ des de rab tu phyung ngo / /

With that, he set out for Jetavana, where he saw a novice picking flowers and said, “Noble one, you look so happy. Why?” “It is because I have gone forth. Why don’t you go forth?” “Noble one, who can allow my going forth?” The novice said, “Come, [F.81.a] let us go before a preceptor,” and led him away. When they arrived before a preceptor, the novice said, “Preceptor, this son of noble family wants to go forth. I ask that you allow his going forth.” And with that, the preceptor allowed his going forth.

de'i ma yig dpon gyi gan du song ste smras pa/ khye'u de da gar mchis/ de de ring kho bos gzhus so/ / des kyang smras pa/ bdag gis kyang de de ring gzhus so/ / yig dpon gyis smras pa/ de bros kyis tshol du song shig /

His mother went to the court scribe, who asked, “Where is the lad? Today I struck him.” “I too struck him today,” she replied. “He has run away,” the court scribe said. “You should go and look for him.”

des dka' thub kyi tshal dang mu stegs kyi gnas de dang de dag tu bu 'dri zhing song ste dris na de'i gtam thos pa yang su yang med do/ / de mnyan yod du song ste sgor bsdad pa dang / dge tshul de yang snga dro sham thabs bgos lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te/ phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong dge tshul de nyid dang mnyan yod du bsod snyoms la zhugs pa dang des de mthong nas des brang brdungs te smras pa/ bu dka' thub kyi tshal dang mu stegs kyi gnas de dang de dag tu kho mos khyod kyi phyir ma btsal ba de dag gang yod de/ khyod kyi gtam thos pa yang su yang med na/ khyod shAkya'i bu'i rkun ma rnams kyi nang du ci'i phyir rab tu 'byung / tshur shog 'dong zhes

She went searching for the boy, asking for word from the ascetics in the forest, among the tīrthika communities, and in other places; but wherever she asked, no one had heard any word of him. She went to Śrāvastī and waited at the gate. In the morning, the novice put on his under robe, picked up his begging bowl and robes, and was preparing to beg alms in Śrāvastī with the ascetic follower novice in tow. When she saw her son, she beat her fists on his chest and cried, “Son! I went searching for you among the ascetics in the forest, among the tīrthika communities, and in other places but everywhere I looked, no one had heard any word of you. Why have you gone forth among these thieving sons of the Śākya? Come back!”

des de'i lag pa gnyis nas bzung nas khyim du khrid do/ / de nyid tshe dang ldan pa de legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po'i bar chad du gyur pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang /

Grabbing him with both hands, she dragged him home. When that proved to be an impediment to monkhood, the state of having gone forth and been ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, the monks appealed to the Blessed One.

bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag dge 'dun la ma zhus par rab tu 'byin pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis dge 'dun la ma zhus par rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de dge 'dun la zhur gzhug par bya'o/ / ma zhus par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

The Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing going forth without consulting the saṅgha. That being the case, monks should not allow going forth without consulting the saṅgha. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, have him ask the saṅgha. If you allow going forth without consulting them, a breach occurs.”
[nad pa]
Ill persons

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rgyal po'i khab na 'od ma'i tshal ka lan da ka'i gnas na bzhugs so/ / rgyal po'i khab na bram ze zhig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed /dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i bu byung nas bsrings shing bskyed de chen por gyur to/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at the Kalandakanivāpa in the Bamboo Park near Rājagṛha [F.81.b] when a brahmin living in Rājagṛha took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself later gave birth to a son who was nurtured and grew until he was big.

de dus gzhan zhig na na bar gyur nas sman pa thams cad kyis bor ba dang mas de la smras pa/ bu 'tsho byed gzhon nus gsos 'di ni sman pa'i rgyal po bla na med pa yin gyis 'di'i gan du song shig / de 'tsho byed kyi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'tsho byed bdag la gsos mdzod cig /

At a certain point, he fell ill, and when every doctor had given up hope, his mother said to him, “Son, the physician Kumārabhṛta is the unsurpassed king of doctors. To him you must go.” He went before the physician and pleaded, “Physician, please cure me.”

des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod ni gso dka' la 'di ltar kho bo yang gzhan su'i gsos kyang mi byed de/ kho bo ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das nyan thos kyi dge 'dun dang bcas pa dang / rgyal po btsun mo'i 'khor dang bcas pa gnyis kyi gsos byed do/ /

“Sir,” replied the physician, “your condition is hard to cure. Neither I nor anyone else can cure you, and I am physician to the Blessed Buddha and his community of disciples as well as to the king, the queen, and their court.”

de ma'i gan du song ba dang mas smras pa/ bu khyod 'tsho byed kyi gan du son tam/ ma bdag gis 'tsho byed kyi gan du son na de na re khyod ni gso dka' la/ 'di ltar kho bo yang gzhan su'i gsos kyang mi byed de/ kho bo ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das nyan thos kyi dge 'dun dang bcas pa dang / rgyal po btsun mo'i 'khor dang bcas pa gnyis kyi gsos byed do zhes zer ro/ /

He went to his mother, who asked, “Son, did you go to the physician?” “Mother, I went to the physician, who told me my condition is hard to cure. He said neither he nor anyone else could cure me, and that he is physician to the Blessed Buddha and his community of disciples as well as to the king, the queen, and their court.”

bu gal te de lta na rab tu byung shig /ma bdag rigs kyi mchog tu gyur nas ji ltar shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong rigs sna tshogs can rnams kyi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya/ des smras pa/ bu khyod kyi klad par rtswa ka sha dang ku sha skye bar 'gyur ram ci babs so cog /de 'od ma'i tshal du song ste dge slong gi gan du song nas smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /

“In that case, son, go forth.” “Mother, as I am of the highest caste, how could I go forth into the mixed caste order of the ascetic sons of the Śākya?” “Son, has your brain turned to hay? Or are you just babbling?” He went to the Bamboo Park, where he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des de rab tu phyung ba dang de 'khun zhing 'dug go/ / des smras pa/ ci'i phyir 'khun cing 'dug /mkhan po bdag bro 'tshal to/ / des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ci khyod rab tu byung nas 'di ltar na bar gyur tam/ mkhan po bdag rab tu byung nas 'di ltar bro 'tshal bar ma gyur gyi/ bdag bro 'tshal bzhin du rab tu byung ngo / /

As soon as the monk allowed his going forth, he sat down, moaning. The monk asked him, “Why do you sit and moan?” “Preceptor, I am unwell.” “Sir, why have you fallen ill upon going forth?” he asked. “Preceptor, I have not fallen ill upon going forth. I was already unwell [F.82.a] when I went forth.”

ci'i phyir khyod kyis kho bo la ma smras/ des smras pa/ mkhan po khyod kyis bdag la smras sam ci/ de mi dga' bar gyur cing 'dug pa dang / de'i lhan cig gnas pa dang nye gnas rnams lhags te smras pa/ mkhan po khyod ci'i slad du mi dgyes shing bzhugs/ bu dag rigs kyi bu 'di na bzhin du rab tu phyung bas kho bos nad brang nye bar gzhag go/ /

“Why did you not tell me?” “Preceptor,” he replied, “what would you have said to me?” The preceptor was seated, unhappy, when his monk appretinces and monk journeymen happened by and asked, “Preceptor, why do you sit here thus, so unhappy?” “Boys, I have allowed the going forth of an ill son of noble family, so I will have to place him in the infirmary.”

de dag gis smras pa/ mkhan po bcom ldan 'das kyis skyes bu dam pa ni gnyis te/ khur ma blangs pa len par mi byed pa dang / gang khur blangs pa mthar phyin par byed pa'o zhes bka' stsal pas khur blangs pa 'di mthar phyin par mdzod cig /

“Preceptor,” they replied, “the Blessed One has said there are two types of saints, those who do not assume burdens they do not bear and those who carry through to the end those burdens they bear. You must carry through to the end this burden you bear.”

de dag phan tshun smra zhing 'khod pa na 'tsho byed kyang phyogs der 'ongs nas de dag gis de la smras pa/ 'tsho byed gzhon nu 'di'i nad ci yin ltos shig /des smras pa/ bro lci ste/ 'di ltar rgyal pos 'di'i yo byad thams cad sbyar cing bdag gis 'di'i gsos bgyis la/ 'phags pa dag gis bro g.yog mdzad na ring po mi thogs pa kho nar sos par 'gyur ro zhes

As they stood discussing the matter among themselves, the physician passed by and they inquired of him, “Physician Kumārabhṛta! What illness is this? Please have a look.” “It is a grave illness,” he replied. “Have the king provide all that is required and I shall try to cure him. But he will only recover quickly if you noble ones nurse him.”

des de'i gsos byas pa dang de sos par gyur to/ / des smras pa/ mkhan po bdag gang gi don du rab tu 'byung ba'i don de bdag gis thob kyis mchi'o/ / des smras pa/ bu khyod kyis dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas sam/ mkhan po ma bgyis so/ /

The physician then treated the ill person and he was cured. The newly cured monk said, “Preceptor, I have achieved the aim I had in going forth.” “Son, have you actualized arhatship?” he asked. “No, preceptor, I have not.”

'o na ci khyod kyis phyir mi 'ong ba'i 'bras bu'am/ lan gcig phyir 'ong ba'i 'bras bu'am/ rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu mngon du byas sam/ mkhan po ma bgyis te/ bdag bro 'tshal bas rab tu byung na da bdag sos par gyur to/ / des smras pa/ bu gang du 'gro/ mkhan po sdum par 'chi'o/ /

“Well then, have you actualized a non-returner’s fruition? A once-returner’s fruition? A stream enterer’s fruition?” “No, preceptor, I have not. But I was unwell. Then I went forth and now am cured.” He asked, “Son, where will you go?” “I will return home, preceptor.”

des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs gang gi phyir khyod kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu byung nas dge sbyong gi 'bras bu bzhi po dag las dge sbyong gi 'bras bu gang yang rung ba thob par bya ba yin na/ khyod dad pas sbyin par bya ba chud gzan nas tshul bzhin ma yin pas sdug bsngal skyed par byed dam/

“Sir,” the preceptor said, “having gone forth in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, you have not attained any of the four fruitions of spiritual practice for which it was taught. Do you want to squander the offerings of the faithful and invite misfortune?”
des de'i tshig tshig ma yin par byas te song nas/ de byas pa shes pas 'tsho byed la lo ma dag dang / me tog dag dang / 'bras bu dag dang / so shing dag stobs par byed do/ /
Dismissing his preceptor’s words, [F.82.b] the monk departed. Knowing what had been done for him, he gave the physician sprigs, flowers, fruits, and sticks of neem.

'tsho byed kyis smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod kho bo las ci zhig 'dod/ des smras pa ci yang mi 'tshal te/ 'di ltar bdag bgyis pa 'tshal bas khyod la lo ma dag dang / me tog dag dang / 'bras bu dag dang / so shing dag stobs par bgyid do/ / des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod la kho bos ci zhig byas/ bdag bro 'tshal ba la khyod kyis gsos bgyis so/ /

“Sir, what would you like from me?” asked the physician. He replied, “I want nothing in return. I have sought you out in order to give you these offerings.” “Sir, what did I do for you?” he asked. “You cured me when I was unwell.”

des smras pa/ kho bos mi dran no/ / bdag gis khyod dgongs par bgyi'o zhes des de dran par byas pa dang 'tsho byed kyis smras pa/ bzhin bzangs gang gi phyir khyod kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu byung nas dge sbyong gi 'bras bu bzhi po dag las dge sbyong gi 'bras bu gang yang rung ba thob par bya ba yin na/ khyod dad pas sbyin par bya ba chud gzan nas tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal skyed par gyur tam/

“I don’t recall that,” replied the physician. “I will refresh your memory,” he said, and reminded him. At this point the physician said, “Sir, having gone forth in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, you have not attained any of the four fruitions of spiritual practice for which it was taught. Do you want to squander the offerings of the faithful and invite misfortune?”
'tsho byed kyis bsams pa/ 'di ni bdag gi bya ba kho na yin gyis/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'gro snyam mo/ /
Then physician thought to himself, “This is my responsibility and my responsibility alone, so I must go see the Blessed One.”

de nas 'tsho byed gzhon nus gsos bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te mtha' gcig tu 'dug go/ / mtha' gcig tu 'dug nas bcom ldan 'das la 'tsho byed gzhon nus gsos kyis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa 'phags pa 'di dag rigs kyi bu bro 'tshal ba rab tu 'byin par bgyid/ bsnyen par rdzogs par bgyid pas btsun pa re zhig rgyal po'i mdzod dang bang ba dag kyang bsrabs pa dang / yongs su bas pa dang / yongs su gtugs par 'gyur la/ bdag gi lus kyang dal zhing 'phags pa dag gi dge ba'i phyogs kyang yongs su nyams par 'gyur bas/ kye ma bcom ldan 'das kyis thugs brtse ba'i slad du gang gis 'phags pa dag rigs kyi bu bro 'tshal ba rab tu 'byin pa dang / bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bgyid pa dran par bgyi ba cung zhig bca' ba mdzad na legs so/ /

The physician Kumārabhṛta went to see the Blessed One and on arriving, bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet before taking a seat off to one side. As he sat off to one side, the physician requested the Blessed One, “Reverend, the noble monks’ allowing the going forth of ill sons of noble families and their ordination will, at some point, cause even the king’s treasury and stores to dwindle, diminish, and come to an end. It will cause even my body to flag, and the virtuous endeavors of noble beings to wane. O Blessed One! It would be good if you, in your compassion, would give some consideration to prohibiting the noble ones from allowing the going forth of ill sons of noble families and ordaining them.” [F.83.a]

bcom ldan 'das kyis 'tsho byed gzhon nus gsos la cang mi gsung bas gnang ngo / / de nas 'tsho byed gzhon nus gsos kyis bcom ldan 'das kyis cang mi gsung bas gnang bar rig nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas song ngo / /

By keeping silent, the Blessed One assented to the physician’s request. Understanding the Blessed One’s silence to be assent, the physician bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet and took his leave.

bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag nad pa rab tu 'byin par byed pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis nad pa rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la nad pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

The Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing the going forth of ill persons.” Then he decreed, “That being the case, monks should not allow the going forth of ill persons. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You are not an ill person, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[shAkya]
Śākyas

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das ser skya'i gnas na n+ya gro d+ha'i kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das kyis ser skya'i gnas kyi shAkya rnams kyi khyim dag nas re re rab tu phyung ba de'i tshe na de dag gi gan du nye du dag lhags nas/ de dag nye du lhags pa de dag la chos ston par byed do/ / de dag chos thos nas de nyid du rab tu phyung ba na shAkya mo la la'i ni pha rab tu phyung / la la'i ni ming po/ / la la'i ni khyim thab/ la la'i ni skud po/ / la la'i ni bu rab tu byung ba dang de dag mya ngan gyis non nas mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe snying rje rje skad du ngu'o/ /

While the Blessed Buddha was staying at the Banyan Park near Kapilavastu, he allowed the going forth of members from each Śākya family in Kapilavastu. Their relatives came to see the newly ordained, who taught the Dharma to their assembled family members, and they in turn, upon hearing the Dharma, sought to go forth on the spot.
