Among those who, upon hearing the Dharma, were allowed to go forth on the spot were the fathers of some Śākya women, their brothers-in-law, their husbands, brothers, and sons. Overwhelmed by grief, the Śākya women cried out in misery in the twilight.

rgyal po zas gtsang gis mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe na shAkya mo rab tu mang po dag snying rje rje skad du ngu ba'i sgra thos so/ / thos nas kyang shAkya rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag ci'i phyir mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe shAkya mo rab tu mang po dag snying rje rje skad du ngu/

In the twilight, King Śuddhodana heard the sound of a great many Śākya women crying out in misery. Hearing their cries, he asked the Śākyas, “Gentlemen, why do so many Śākya women cry out in misery in the twilight?”

de dag gis smras pa/ lha 'phags pa 'di dag gis rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu 'byin par bgyid/ bsnyen par rdzogs par bgyid de/ shAkya mo la la'i ni pha rab tu phyung / la la'i ni ming po/ la la'i ni khyim thab/ la la'i ni skud po/ la la'i ni bu rab tu byung ba dang de dag mya ngan gyis non nas mtshan mo'i tho rangs kyi dus kyi tshe snying rje rje skad du ngu'o/ /

“Your Majesty,” they replied, “the going forth of certain noble ones and sons of noble families has been allowed, and they have been ordained without the consent of their parents. The going forth of the fathers, brothers-in-law, husbands, brothers, and sons of some Śākya women has also been allowed. Thus, overwhelmed by grief, [F.83.b] the Śākya women cry out in misery in the twilight.”

rgyal po zas gtsang gis bsams pa/ 'di ni bdag gi bya ba kho na yin gyis/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'gro'o snyam mo/ / de nas rgyal po zas gtsang bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / phyogs gcig tu 'dug nas bcom ldan 'das la rgyal po zas gtsang gis 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das bdag la dam pa 'os so/ / bde bar gshegs pa bdag la dam pa 'os so/ /

“This is my responsibility and my responsibility alone,” thought King Śuddhodana, “so I must go to see the Blessed One.” King Śuddhodana went to see the Blessed One and on arriving, bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet before taking a seat off to one side. The king then said to the Blessed One, “Blessed One, I have a worthy suit. Tathāgata, I have a worthy suit.”

rgyal po chen po de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams ni dam pa las 'das pa kho na yin na/ khyod la dam pa ci zhig sbyin smros shig /'phags pa rnams kyis brnyes sla ba gang lags pa'o/ / gal te rnyed sla ba yin na sbyin no/ /

“Great king, if you insist on passing up the boons of the tathāgatas, arhats, and perfectly complete buddhas, tell me, what favor could I grant you?” “One that noble beings would find easy.” “If I find it easy, I shall grant it.”

btsun pa gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das 'khrungs pa de'i tshe na bcom ldan 'das 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal por 'gyur la/ bdag kyang nam mkha'i ngos la rgyu zhing gling bzhi dag tu rjes su mchi'o snyam pas bde ba dang yid bde ba mi chung ba dang ldan pa las/

“Reverend, when the Blessed One was born, the Blessed One was destined to become king of the world. I even thought I would soar through the sky and see the four continents, my delight and pleasure being not inconsiderable.

btsun pa gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das rab tu byung ba de'i tshe na bdag gi 'khor los sgyur bar re ba gang lags pa de ma mchis par gyur to/ / gzhan yang gzhon nu mdzes dga' 'di stobs kyis 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal por 'gyur ro snyam du re ba tsam du gyur pa las gang gi tshe gzhon nu mdzes dga' rab tu byung ba de'i tshe na bdag gi stobs kyi 'khor los sgyur bar re ba gang lags pa de yang ma mchis par gyur to/ / gzhan yang gzhon nu sgra can zin bzang po 'di dngos btsan pa'i rgyal por 'gyur ro snyam du re ba tsam du gyur pa las/ gang gi tshe gzhon nu sgra can zin bzang po rab tu byung ba de'i tshe na bdag gi rgyal po dngos btsan par re ba gang lags pa de yang thams cad kyi thams cad du ma mchis par gyur to/ /

“Reverend, when the Blessed One became a renunciant, what hopes I had for you to become king of the world were dashed. So instead, I went on to think that the prince Sundarananda would conquer and become king of the world. When those hopes were shown to be just that, and the prince Sundarananda became a renunciant, the hopes I had for conquering and for becoming king of the world were dashed too. So instead, I then went on to think that the prince Rāhulabhadra would become a king of real command. When those hopes were shown to be just that, and the prince Rāhulabhadra became a renunciant, what hopes I had for becoming a king of real command were completely and utterly dashed too.

btsun pa gzhan yang pha ma dag ni bu la bag dro bar gyur pa lags na/ btsun pa 'phags pa 'di dag rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu 'byin par bgyid/ bsnyen par rdzogs par bgyid pas/ kye ma bcom ldan 'das kyis thugs brtse ba'i slad du gang gis 'phags pa dag rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu 'byin pa dang bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bgyid par dran par bgyi ba cung zhig bca' ba mdzad na legs so/ /

“Reverend, if only it were otherwise and your parents could have found satisfaction in you! Reverend, [F.84.a] these noble monks are allowing the going forth of sons of noble families and ordaining them without their parents’ consent. O Blessed One! It would be good if, in your compassion, you were to give some consideration to prohibiting the noble ones from allowing the going forth of sons of noble families and their ordination without their parents’ consent.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis rgyal po zas gtsang la cang mi gsung bas gnang ngo / / de nas rgyal po zas gtsang gis bcom ldan 'das kyis cang mi gsung bas gnang bar rig nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas song ngo / /
By keeping silent, the Blessed One assented to King Śuddhodana. Understanding the Blessed One’s silence to be assent, King Śuddhodana bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet and took his leave.

bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu 'byin par byed/ bsnyen par rdzogs par byed pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na dge slong gis rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu dbyung bar mi bya/ bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na des de la pha mas gnang ngam/ zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from monks allowing the going forth of sons of noble families and their ordination without their parents’ consent.” He then decreed, “In light of this, monks should not allow the going forth of sons of noble families or ordain them without their parents’ consent. If someone approaches any of you wishing to go forth, ask him, ‘Have your parents given their consent?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong gis rigs kyi bu pha mas ma gnang ba rab tu dbyung bar mi bya/ bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas/ pha mas ma gnang ba yul thag ring ba pha mas gtam yang mi thos pa gzhan dag 'ongs na/ dge slong rnams kyis de dag kyang rab tu 'byin par mi byed pas de dag rab tu 'byung ba ma thob par dong ste/

After the Blessed One had decreed, “A monk should not allow the going forth of sons of noble families or ordain them without their parents’ consent,” the monks did not allow others to go forth who came, without their parents’ consent, from faraway lands where their parents could not be consulted. Thus, their going forth not allowed, the hopefuls turned back.

de nyid tshe dang ldan pa de dag legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang / bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po'i bar chad du gyur pa'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ pha mas ma gnang ba yul thag ring po pha mas gtam yang mi thos pa gang dag 'ongs na de dag ni rab tu dbyung bar bya ste/ 'di la 'gyod par mi bya'o// //

When that proved to be an impediment to monkhood, the state of having gone forth and been ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, the monks asked the Blessed One about it, and he decreed, “Those who come without their parents’ consent from faraway lands where their parents cannot be consulted should be allowed to go forth. [F.84.b] This you need not regret.”
[bya rog skrod]
Scaring Away a Crow
sdom la/ bya rog skrod dang sun phyung dang / / rku thabs gnas dang ma ning dang / / dud 'gro dang ni mu stegs can/ / ma bsad pa dang pha bsad pa'o/ /
A summary: Scaring away a crow, violators, Impostors, person labeled a paṇḍaka, Creatures, tīrthikas, Matricides, and patricides.
[bya rog skrod]
Scaring Away a Crow

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / gang gi tshe 'phags skyes po mi gti mug can gyis ser skya'i gnas na gnas pa'i shAkya khon med pa dang / mi 'gran pa dang / mi 'khu ba dag bsad pa de'i tshe na tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis shig pha mas bor nas/ de dang de na 'khyam pa las mnyan yod kyi tshong pa dag zong thogs te ser skya'i gnas su dong ba dang / de dag gis de gnyis bzhin gzugs las ngo shes nas smras pa/ khye'u gnyis khyod kyi pha ma gnyis gang na/ de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags skyes po mi gti mug can gyis bsad do/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when the ignorant Virūḍhaka had slaughtered the Śākya inhabitants of Kapilavastu, although they had not been aggressive, antagonistic, or thieving. The two sons of the venerable Ānanda’s younger sister were left orphaned, and were wandering aimlessly when traders from Śrāvastī on their way to Kapilavastu on business recognized the two good-looking lads and asked, “Boys, where are your parents?” “They were killed by the ignorant Virūḍhaka,” they replied.

mnyan yod na khyed gnyis kyi zhang po btsun pa kun dga' bo zhes bya ba dge slong rab tu grags pa 'dug na ci'i phyir der mi 'dong / des gnyis kyis smras pa/ kho bo cag su zhig gis der khrid par 'gyur/ kho bo cag gis bkri'o/ /
“If your uncle, the famous monk known as reverend Ānanda, is staying in Śrāvastī, why don’t you go there?” They replied, “Who would take us there?” “We will take you.”

de dag gi zong sgyur nas rin blangs te khye'u de gnyis khrid nas mnyan yod du dong ste/ de dag gis khye'u de gnyis rgyal byed kyi tshal gyi sgor bor ba dang / tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos de gnyis bzhin gzugs las ngo shes nas des smras pa/ khye'u gnyis khyed gnyis kyi pha ma gnyis gang na/ de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags skyes po mi gti mug can gyis bsad do/ /

After they traded their goods and made a profit, the traders set out for Śrāvastī with the two boys in tow. They left the boys at the gate of Jetavana, where the venerable Ānanda recognized them and asked, “Boys, where are your parents?” “They were killed by the ignorant Virūḍhaka.”

tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo nye du la mnyes gshin pa yin pas des nye du dang bral ba thos nas mchi mas brnangs te 'dug go/ / dge slong rnams kyis de la smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo khyod kyi khye'u 'di gnyis su dag cig yin/ sring mo'i bu dag go/ /
Because Ānanda cared for his kin, on hearing of their death he became choked with tears. The monks asked him, “Venerable Ānanda, who are these two lads?” “They are my sister’s boys.”

khyod ci'i phyir 'di gnyis sdud par mi byed/ des smras pa/ kho bo ni lto 'grangs tsam gyi bsod snyoms blangs nas phyir 'byung na kho bos 'di gnyis la gang nas sbyin/ de dag gis smras pa/ khye'u 'di gnyis kyis dge slong dag la lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu dag 'bul na/ dge slong dag kyang 'di gnyis la lhung bzed kyi lhag ma sbyin par 'gyur ro/ /

“Why don’t you take them in?” “I barely get enough from begging to fill my own stomach,” he replied. “Where out there can I get enough to provide for them?” “If these two boys offer the monks herbs, [F.85.a] flowers, and fruits, in return the monks will give them the leftovers from their begging bowls.”

des de gnyis bsdus nas dge slong dag la lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu dag 'bul du gzhug par brtsams pa dang / dge slong dag kyang de gnyis la lhung bzed kyi lhag ma sbyin par byed do/ / de dag gis de gnyis la zhag nyung shas shig byin nas yang mi sbyin par brtsams pa dang / tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo lto 'grangs tsam gyi bsod snyoms blangs nas phyir 'byung bar byed cing de phyed ni bdag nyid za bar byed/ phyed ni de gnyis la sbyin par byed pa na skya bo bseng bseng po rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang / skam pa dang / lus ma thob par gyur to/ /

After being taken in, the boys began to offer the monks herbs, flowers, and fruits, and in return the monks gave them the leftovers from their begging bowls. After a few days of giving the two their leftovers, they stopped. So Ānanda went out and about begging alms, but received only just enough to fill his own stomach. Eating half himself and giving the other half to the two boys, he became pallid, emaciated, feeble, withered, thin, and weak.

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni mkhyen bzhin du rmed par mdzad pa ste/ mkhyen bzhin du rmed pa/ mkhyen kyang mi rmed pa/ dus su rmed pa/ dus las yol bar mi rmed pa/ don dang ldan pa rmed pa/ don dang mi ldan pa mi rmed pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni don dang mi ldan pa rmed pa la chu lon gyis zlog par mdzad pa yin no/ /

Although they know, blessed buddhas may inquire about what they already know. Though they already know, they may inquire‍—or, even though they know, they may not inquire. They inquire when the time is right, not when the time has passed. Their inquiries are meaningful, not meaningless. In this way blessed buddhas dam the flow of meaningless inquiries.

de la sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams ni don dang ldan pa rmed pa la dus mkhyen pa yin pas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la rmas pa/ dge slong dag ci'i phyir dge slong kun dga' bo skya bo bseng bseng po rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang / skam pa dang / lus ma thob par gyur/
As blessed buddhas know the time for a meaningful inquiry, the Blessed Buddha asked the monks, “Monks, why has the monk Ānanda become pallid, emaciated, feeble, withered, thin, and weak?”

de dag gis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis shig pha mas bor nas tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo g.yar bltam gyi bsod snyoms blangs nas slar 'byung zhing de phyed ni bdag nyid 'tshal bar bgyid/ phyed ni de gnyis la stsol bas des na tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo 'di skya bo bseng bseng po rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang / skam pa dang / lus ma thob par gyur to/ /

“Blessed One,” they replied, “since the two sons of the venerable Ānanda’s younger sister were orphaned, he has gone out receiving only enough alms to fill his own mouth,[160] half of which he takes for himself while the other half he gives to them. This has reduced the venerable Ānanda to such a state.”
de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo la bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo khye'u de gnyis rab tu mi 'byin tam/ bcom ldan 'das rab tu 'byin to/ /
The Blessed One then asked the venerable Ānanda, “Will you not allow these two boys’ going forth?” [F.85.b] “Blessed One, I will allow their going forth.”
bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de lta bas na rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa dge 'dun gyi zan sbyin par rjes su gnang ngo / /
The Blessed One decreed, “In light of that, I give permission for food given to the saṅgha to be given to those wishing to go forth.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa dge 'dun gyis zan sbyin par bya'o zhes bka' stsal nas/ dge slong dag gis zhag nyung shas shig byin nas smod par brtsams so/ /de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo la yang lan gnyis su bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo khye'u de gnyis rab tu mi 'byin tam/ btsun pa de gnyis kyis dgung lo bcwa lnga ma lags so/ /

After the Blessed One gave permission for food that has been given to the saṅgha to be given to those wishing to go forth, the monks gave them food for a few days and then began to complain. The Blessed One then asked Ānanda a second time, “Did you refuse to allow these two boys’ going forth?” “Reverend, the two of them are not yet fifteen.”

khye'u de gnyis kyis dge 'dun gyi skos mal nas bya rog skrod nus sam/ btsun pa rdo thog go/ / kun dga' bo de lta bas na lo bdun lon pa bya rog skrod nus pa yongs su spang bas rab tu dbyung bar rjes su gnang ngo / / tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos de gnyis rab tu phyung ngo / /

“Can the two boys scare crows away from the saṅgha’s sleeping quarters?” “Reverend, they can throw stones.” “In that case, Ānanda, I give my permission to allow freely the going forth of those as young as seven years old, provided they can scare away crows.” Ānanda then allowed the two to go forth.

rab tu phyung nas klog tu gzhug par brtsams pa dang / de gnyis kyis zhag nyung shas shig bklags nas mi nyan par brtsams pa dang / tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo la smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo dge tshul 'di gnyis ci'i phyir klog tu mi gzhug /des smras pa/ gnas brtan bdag la mnyan par mi bya bar sems na bdag gis ji ltar bya/ bdag gis 'di gnyis klog tu gzhug go/ /

After Ānanda’s nephews went forth, Ānanda began to teach them to read, but after a few days of study they began to misbehave. The venerable Mahāmaudgalyāyana asked Ānanda, “Why do you not make these two novices study?” “Elder,” replied Ānanda, “they do not listen to me. I do not know what to do, but I must compel these two novices to study.”

des smras pa/ gnas brtan de bzhin gyis shig / des de gnyis klog tu gzhug par brtsams so/ / de gnyis kyis de la yang zhag nyung shas shig bklags nas de la yang mi nyan par brtsams pa dang / tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos smras pa/ gnas brtan dge tshul 'di gnyis ci'i phyir klog tu mi gzhug / des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo 'di gnyis kyis bdag la yang mi mnyan par brtsams so/ / tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos smras pa/ gnas brtan dge tshul 'di gnyis re zhig yid byung bar gyis shig /

Mahāmaudgalyāyana replied, “Elder, do as you say.” So Ānanda began to make the two novices study. But again, after a few days, the two of them began to misbehave, and Ānanda asked Mahāmaudgalyāyana, “Elder, why can I not make these two novices study?” “Ānanda, these two will not yet listen to me either.” “Elder, the two novices must be given a little scare.”
tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos de gnyis la smras pa/ dge tshul gnyis nyin mo spyod du 'dong ngo / / de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags pa bzhud do/ / stan khyer cig /
The venerable Mahāmaudgalyāyana said to the two, “Novices, [F.86.a] let’s do our daily practice.” “Yes, noble one.” “Bring something to sit on.”

tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos dge tshul de gnyis khrid nas nyin mo spyod du song ngo / / de na tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos phyogs gcig tu sems can dmyal ba dag tu sprul te/ de na gcod pa dang / 'tsheg pa dang / rdung ba dang / 'dral ba la sogs pa'i sgra dag grag go/ / de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags pa 'di ci lags/ des smras pa/ deng la ltos shig /

Mahāmaudgalyāyana then took the two novices for their daily practice. On the way, Mahāmaudgalyāyana conjured up an apparition of beings in the hell realms, who cried out from being cut, sliced, crushed, and hacked to pieces. The two boys exclaimed, “Noble one, what is this?” “Have a closer look,” he replied.

de gnyis der dong ba dang ji tsam na gcod pa dang / 'tsheg pa dang / rdung ba dang / 'dral ba la sogs pa'i las dag byed cing / de na kha cig ni sog le dag gis 'tsheg par byed/ kha cig ni rang thag dag gis 'thag par byed/ kha cig ni zangs po che khol ba dag gi nang du 'jud par byed de/ de na lcags kyi zangs po che gnyis shig khol zhing 'dug pa mthong nas de gnyis kyis smras pa/ shes ldan dag 'di gnyis su su yang mi gzhug gam/

The two of them approached and found what was being done there‍—the cutting, the slicing, the crushing, and the hacking to pieces. Some were being sliced apart by saws, some were being ground in mills, and some were being melted down in boiling vats. When they saw two boiling iron vats standing there empty, they asked, “Gentlemen, will no one be put into these two?”

de dag gis smras pa/ su yang mi gzhug ste/ 'di ltar 'phags pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis rab tu byung nas le los 'da' bar byed pa de gnyis shi zhing dus la bab na 'dir skye bar 'gyur bas de gnyis kyi don du bzhag go/ / de gnyis shin tu skrag nas gal te shes na deng nyid du bcug par 'ong ngo snyam nas phyogs bzhir rnam par blta bar brtsams nas/ de gnyis tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen po'i gan du dong ba dang / tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos smras pa/ khyed kyis mthong ngam/ 'phags pa mthong ngo / /

“No,” they replied. “For the two sons of noble Ānanda’s sister have gone forth and yet lazily pass their time. When their time has come and they die, they will be reborn here, so these two vats have been reserved for them.” Terrified, they thought, “If we’re recognized, they’ll put us in those vats this very day,” and began to look all about them. They went to Mahāmaudgalyāyana, who asked, “Did you see something?” “Noble one, we did.”
de na ci yod/ sems can dmyal ba dag mchis so/ / de na ci byed/
“What?” “Beings in the hell realms.” “What were they doing there?”

de gnyis kyis smras pa/ gcod pa dang / 'tsheg pa dang / rdung ba dang / 'dral ba la sogs pa'i las dag bgyid cing de na kha cig ni sog le dag gis 'tsheg par bgyid/ kha cig ni rang thag dag gis 'thag par bgyid/ kha cig ni zangs po che khol ba dag gi nang du stsol bar bgyid de/ de na lcags kyi zangs po che gnyis shig khol zhing mchis pa mthong nas bdag cag gis shes ldan dag 'di gnyis su su yang mi gzhug gam zhes bgyis na/ de dag gi mchid nas su yang mi gzhug ste/ 'di ltar 'phags pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis rab tu byung nas le los 'da' bar byed pa de gnyis shi zhing dus la bab na 'dir skye bar 'gyur bas de gnyis kyi don du bzhag go zhes mchi'o/ /

“They were doing all sorts of things‍—cutting, slicing, crushing, hacking to pieces,” they replied. “There, some were being sliced apart by saws, some were being ground in mills, and some were being melted down in boiling vats. [F.86.b] When we saw two boiling iron vats standing empty, we asked, ‘Gentlemen, will no one be put into these two?’ And they replied, ‘No. For the two sons of noble Ānanda’s sister have gone forth and yet lazily pass their time. When their time has come and they die, they’ll be reborn here, so these two have been reserved for them.’ ”
dge tshul gnyis de ltar na nyes dmigs 'di dag dang / gzhan dag kyang le los 'byung bar 'gyur bas brtson 'grus gyis shig /
Then Mahāmaudgalyāyana advised, “Thus, novices, knowing that disadvantages such as these, and others too, accrue from laziness, apply yourselves diligently.”

de gnyis brtson 'grus rtsom pa bklag par bya bar brtsams shing / gal te snga dro sems can dmyal ba dran na ni zan za bar yang mi byed la/ gal te phyi dro dran na ni zas de skyug par 'gyur bas de gnyis skya bo bseng bseng po rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang / skam pa dang / lus ma thob par gyur nas

The two nephews began to apply themselves to their studies with diligence. If they thought of the beings in the hell realms in the morning, they would not even eat; if they thought of them in the afternoon, they would vomit up what they had eaten. Thus it was that the two of them became pallid, emaciated, feeble, withered, thin, and weak.

des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bo de gnyis yid byung bar byas zin to/ / gnas brtan da ni gzengs stod cig / tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos de gnyis la smras pa/ dge tshul gnyis nyin mo spyod du 'dong ngo / / de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags pa bzhud de/ phyogs gzhan du bzhud kyi der ni mi bzhud do/ / stan khyer cig /

Mahāmaudgalyāyana said, “Ānanda, the two have become dispirited.” “Elder, now they must be inspired.” Mahāmaudgalyāyana said to the two, “Novices, let’s go for our daily practice.” “Noble one,” they replied, “we will go, but we will not return to that one place.” “Bring something to sit on.”

de nas tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos de gnyis khrid nas nyin mo spyod du song ngo / / de na tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos phyogs gcig cig tu lha dag sprul te/ de na pi bang dang / 'od ma dang / bal la ri dang / ma ha ti dang / su g+ho Sha ka dag gi sgra dag grag go/ /

Mahāmaudgalyāyana then took the two novices for their daily practice. On the way, Mahāmaudgalyāyana conjured up an apparition of the gods, along with the sounds of the vīṇā, ektara, balari, mahāti, and the sughoṣak.[161]

de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags pa 'di ci lags/ des smras pa/ deng la ltos shig /de gnyis der dong ba dang / ji tsam na pi bang dang / 'od ma dang / bal la ri dang / ma ha ti dang / su g+ho Sha ka dag gi sgra dag sgrogs shing de na gzhal med khang mal cha dang stan bshams pa lha'i bu mo dag gis yongs su gang ba gnyis shig yod de/ de gnyis na lha'i bu su yang mi 'dug pa mthong nas de gnyis kyis smras pa/ shes ldan dag ci'i phyir gzhal med khang 'di gnyis na lha'i bu su yang mi 'dug / de dag gis smras pa/ su yang mi 'dug go/ /

The two boys exclaimed, “Noble one, what is this?” “Have a closer look,” he replied. The two of them approached and followed the sounds of the vīṇā, ektara, balari, mahāti, and the sughoṣak to where there stood two palaces strewn with beds and divans replete with goddesses. Seeing no gods in either palace, they inquired, “Mistresses, [F.87.a] are there no gods in either of these palaces?” “No, there are none.”

ci'i phyir/ de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis rab tu byung nas brtson 'grus brtsams shing spyod pa de gnyis shi zhing dus la bab na 'dir skye bar 'gyur bas de gnyis kyi don du bzhag go/ /

“Why is that?” “The two sons of noble Ānanda’s sister have gone forth, and since they act and apply themselves diligently, when their time has come and they die, they will be reborn here, so these two have been reserved for them.”

de gnyis yongs su dga' nas tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen po'i gan du dong ba dang / tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos de gnyis la smras pa/ khyed kyis mthong ngam/ 'phags pa mthong ngo / / de na ci yod/ lha dag mchis so/ /
Overjoyed, they went to Mahāmaudgalyāyana, who again asked, “Did you see something?” “Noble one, we did.” “What?” “Gods.”

de na ci byed/ de gnyis kyis smras pa/ pi bang dang / 'od ma dang / bal la ri dang / ma ha ti dang / su g+ho Sha ka dag gi sgra dag sgrogs shing de na gzhal med khang mal cha dang stan bshams pa lha'i bu mo dag gis yongs su gang ba gnyis shig mchis te/ de gnyis na lha'i bu su yang ma mchis pa mthong nas/ bdag cag gnyis kyis shes ldan dag ci'i phyir gzhal med khang 'di gnyis na lha'i bu su yang mi 'dug ces bgyis na/ de dag gi mchid nas su yang mi 'dug go/ / ci'i phyir zhes bgyis na de dag gi mchid nas/ 'phags pa kun dga' bo'i sring mo'i bu gnyis rab tu byung nas brtson 'grus brtsams shing spyod pa de gnyis shi zhing dus la bab na 'dir skye bar 'gyur bas de gnyis kyi don du bzhag go zhes mchi'o/ /

“What were they doing?” “We could hear the sounds of the vīṇā, ektara, balari, mahāti, and the sughoṣak, and found two palaces strewn with beds and divans replete with goddesses, who said, ‘The two sons of noble Ānanda’s sister have gone forth, and since they act and apply themselves diligently, when their time has come and they die, they will be reborn here, so these two have been reserved for them.’ ”
dge tshul gnyis de lta na phan yon 'di dag dang / gzhan dag kyang brtson 'grus brtsams pa las 'byung bar 'gyur bas brtson 'grus gyis shig/ //
Then Mahāmaudgalyāyana advised, “Thus, novices, knowing that advantages such as these, and others too, accrue from diligence, apply yourselves.”
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po brgyad pa/
de gnyis brtson 'grus rtsom pas bklag par bya bar brtsams te lung nod pa dang / ji tsam na gleng gzhi dang / yang dag par ldan pa'i rgyud du gtogs pa las/
The two of them began to apply themselves to their studies and receive instructions. After a time, they came across the following passage in the Nidānasaṃyukta:[162]

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyi phyag gi sen mo'i rtse mos rdul dag bzhes nas dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag ji snyam du sems/ ngas sen mo'i rtse mos rdul dag blangs pa gang dag yin pa dang / sa la gnas pa'i rdul gang dag yin pa de dag gang mang snyam/

Then, taking dirt from the tip of his fingernail, the Blessed One asked the monks, “Monks, what do you think? Which is more, the dirt I take from the tip of my fingernail or the dirt that is upon this earth?” [F.87.b]

btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyi phyag gi sen mo'i rtse mos rdul dag bzhes pa gang dag lags pa de dag ni nyung ba dang / nyung ngu dang / nyung shas dang / nyung zad lags te/ de dag dogs la gnas pa'i rdul dag dang bskrun na brgya'i char yang nye bar mi mchi/ stong gi cha dang / brgya stong gi cha dang / grangs dang / cha dang / bgrang ba dang / dpe dang / rgyur yang nye bar mi mchi'o/ /

“Reverend, the dirt the Blessed One takes from the tip of his fingernail is less, much less, a great deal less, entirely less. Upon reciting this chapter, called “Repeating Like a Wheel,” the two boys asked Mahāmaudgalyāyana, “Noble one, will we too die among gods and humans only to be reborn among hell realm beings, animals, and spirits?”

des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs gnyis 'gro ba lnga pa'i 'khor bar ji srid du nyon mongs pa rnams rgyun chad par ma gyur pa de srid du zo chun rgyud mo'i tshul gyis yongs su 'khor bar bya dgos so/ / de gnyis yid byung nas tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/
“Gentlemen, so long as the continuum of disturbing emotions remains uninterrupted, you must spin like a waterwheel through the cycle of five migrations.” Disheartened, they spoke this verse:
gang phyir mi gnas lha rnams mi bzang ste/ / 'tsho ba thung ba'i mi rnams mi bzang ngo / / gang na zhi med srid pa mi bzang ste/ / mya ngan 'das pa mchog ces bde gshegs gsung / /

“Being a god, who cannot stay a god, is no good. Being a human, whose life is short, is no good. Being in saṃsāra, where there is no peace, is no good. That is why, said the Sugata, nirvāṇa is supreme.
'phags pa ci nas kyang bdag cag 'khor bar 'khor ba na slan chad nyon mongs pa de lta bu dag kun du spyod par mi 'gyur ba de ltar bdag cag la chos bstan du gsol/
“Noble one, henceforth, come what may, as we cycle through saṃsāra we must avoid engaging with such disturbing emotions, so please, we ask that you teach us the Dharma.”

tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen pos de gnyis kyi bsam pa dang / bag la nyal ba dang / khams dang / rang bzhin khong du chud nas gang thos nas de gnyis kyis nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas te/ dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan dang ste'ur mnyam pa/ rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing / rig pa dang / mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang / bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur pa de lta bu'i chos bstan pa byas so/ /

Mahāmaudgalyāyana knew their thoughts, their tendencies, their characters, and their natures. Drawing on all he had heard, he taught them the Dharma so that they abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship, becoming arhats free of attachment to the three realms, for whom filth was equal to gold, who knew space like the palm of their hands, whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood, whose knowledge had rent open the shell. They attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. They turned their backs on worldly gain, desires, and esteem and were venerated, honored, and saluted by Indra and the gods who attend him. [F.90.a]

When the monks saw the two novices miraculously flying through the air, picking flowers, they asked one another, “Venerables, who are those two?” One said, “They are the two novices, kin to Ānanda.”

de dag gis smras pa/ bdag cag lhung bzed nag por zos nas so dag lhung zhing mgo skya bor gyur kyang bdag cag gis sems rtse gcig pa yang ma thob na/ tshe dang ldan pa 'di gnyis dang po lo bdun kho na lon te rab tu byung na nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas pas bcom ldan 'das kyis kun dga' bo brtson 'grus kyis byang chub 'thob bo zhes bka' stsal pa de ni legs par gsungs pa yin no/ /

“Our begging bowls are black with wear. Our teeth are falling out and our hair turns grey, and yet we have not achieved even stillness of mind. Venerable, if these two were but seven years old when they went forth and yet abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship, then the Blessed One spoke well when he said, ‘Ānanda, awakening is attained through diligence.’ ”

dge slong rnams the tshom skyes nas the tshom thams cad gcod pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la zhus pa/ btsun pa dge tshul 'di gnyis kyis las ci zhig bgyis na las de'i rnam par smin pas lo bdun kho na lags na rab tu byung ste/ bcom ldan 'das kyis 'dul ba la nyan thos rnams kyi bslab pa'i gzhi bca' ba mdzad pa gang lags pa de 'di gnyis kho na la brten nas bag yangs su mdzad cing nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du bgyis/

In doubt, the monks went to he who severs all doubts, the Blessed Buddha, and asked, “Reverend, what actions have these two novices done that the fruition of such an act should lead them to go forth at the mere age of seven, and that the Blessed One exempted them alone from the vinaya guidelines he laid down for his disciples, allowing them to abandon all disturbing emotions and actualize arhatship?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag 'di gnyis nyid kyis las tshogs rnyed pa/ rkyen yongs su bsgyur ba/ 'od pa bzhin du nye bar gnas pa/ gdon mi za bar 'byung bar 'gyur ba dag byas shing bsags pas 'di gnyis nyid kyis las byas shing bsags pa dag gzhan su zhig gis so sor myong bar 'gyur/ dge slong dag las byas shing bsags pa dag ni phyi rol gyi sa'i khams la rnam par smin par mi 'gyur/ chu'i khams la mi 'gyur/ me'i khams la mi 'gyur/ rlung gi khams la mi 'gyur gyi/ 'di ltar las dge ba dang mi dge ba byas shing bsags pa dag ni zin pa'i phung po dang khams dang / skye mched dag la rnam par smin par 'gyur te/

The Blessed One responded, “Monks, these two themselves performed the actions‍—which have accrued a heap of karma, whose results have matured, which follow their course like an irrigation channel, which inevitably come to be‍—so who else will experience the actions they themselves have performed and accrued? Monks, actions which have been performed and accrued do not ripen upon the external elements. They do not ripen upon the element of water, upon the element of fire, nor upon the element of wind. Likewise, virtuous and non-virtuous actions which have been performed and accrued come to fruition upon the aggregates, elements, and seats of the senses of the one who performed them, for:
las rnams bskal pa brgyar yang ni/ / chud mi za ba'ang tshogs dang dus/ / rnyed na lus can rnams la ni/ / 'bras bu dag tu 'gyur ba nyid/ /
“Actions never waste away, Not even after one hundred eons. When the time [F.90.b] and the conditions Are right, they alight upon embodied beings.

“Monks, earlier in this fortunate eon, when the lifespan of beings lasted twenty thousand years, there appeared in the world a teacher, a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha, a knowledgeable and venerable one, a sugata, one who knew the world, an unsurpassed guide who tamed beings, a teacher to gods and men, the Blessed Buddha Kāśyapa.
