“With his following of twenty thousand monks, he lived and stayed in the Deer Park of Ṛṣipatana near Vārāṇasī. In Vārāṇasī there lived two householders and friends, who had wished to go forth in their youth, but had not received leave to go forth from their relatives. At a certain point, after their youth had faded, they abdicated in favor of their relatives and went forth into the teachings of the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. As was natural given their junior status, they were always expected to perform errands, and so the monks would order them about, saying, ‘You two old-timers! Go do this!’ and ‘You two old-timers! Bring me that!’

de na gcig ni spro ring ba'i rang bzhin can yin/ cig shos ni spro thung ba'i rang bzhin can yin pas de khro bar byed pa dang cig shos kyis smras pa/ rgan zhugs gzhon pa'i gnas skabs su rab tu ma byung na da ci'i phyir khro/
“One of them had a placid nature but the other was quick-tempered. Thus when the one became angry, the other would say, ‘Old-timer, if you couldn’t go forth when you were young, why get angry now?’

de na 'di gnyis kyi tshe ji srid bar tshangs par spyod pa spyad na yon tan gyi tshogs 'ga' yang ma thob nas de'i 'og tu 'chi ba'i tshe smon lam 'di skad ces/ bdag cag gis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas yon gnas bla na med pa 'od srung la tshe ji srid bar tshangs par spyod pa spyad na yon tan gyi tshogs 'ga' yang ma thob ste/ bdag cag gis tshe ji srid bar tshangs par spyod pa spyad pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gis bram ze'i khye'u bla ma la bram ze'i khye'u khyod ma 'ongs pa'i dus na skye dgu'i tshe lo brgya thub pa na de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas/ rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa zhes bya bar 'gyur ro zhes lung bstan pa de'i bstan pa la bdag cag lo bdun kho na lon nas rab tu byung ste/ bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas mkhyen cing gzigs pa des 'dul ba la nyan thos rnams kyi bslab pa'i gzhi bca' ba mdzad pa gang yin pa de bdag cag gnyis kho na la brten nas bag yangs su mdzad cing nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du gyur cig ces gdab par brtsams so/ /

“Though they lived the holy life for the remainder of their lives, they did not achieve any of the host of qualities. So later, as they died, they said this prayer: ‘We have lived the holy life for what remained of our lives under the Blessed One, the tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly awakened Buddha, the hallowed and unsurpassed Kāśyapa, but we have achieved none of the host of qualities. Therefore, may the roots of virtue from having lived the holy life for what remained of our lives ensure that at the mere age of seven we go forth into the teachings of the Blessed Buddha Śākyamuni, whose coming has been foretold in a prophecy that the blessed tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa gave to a wonderful brahmin boy: “In the future, when the lifespans of beings last one hundred years, you brahmin boy [F.91.a] will become the tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly awakened Buddha, the knowledgeable and venerable one, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the unsurpassed guide who tames beings, the teacher to gods and men, the Blessed Buddha Śākyamuni.” And further, may the Blessed One exempt us alone from the vinaya guidelines he laid down for his disciples, allowing us to abandon all disturbing emotions and actualize arhatship.’

dge slong dag de la de'i tshe de'i dus na khyim bdag gnyis gang dag yin pa de dag ni dge tshul 'di gnyis yin te/ de gnyis kyis der smon lam btab pa gang yin pa des da ltar lo bdun kho na lon nas rab tu byung ste/ ngas 'dul ba la nyan thos rnams kyi bslab pa'i gzhi bcas pa gang yin pa 'di gnyis kho na la brten nas bag yangs su byas shing nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas so/ /

“Monks, the two householders of that time are now these two novices. And due to the prayer that they made, they have gone forth at the mere age of seven, and I have exempted them alone from the vinaya guidelines I laid down for my disciples, allowing them to abandon all disturbing emotions and actualize arhatship.”
[sun phyung]
Violators

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das yul ka shi dag tu ljongs rgyu zhing gshegs pa na phyogs gcig cig tu byon pa dang 'dzum pa mdzad do/ / chos nyid kyis na gang gi tshe/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams 'dzum pa mdzad pa de'i tshe na zhal nas 'od zer sngon po dang / ser po dang / dmar po dang / dkar po dang / btsod ka dang / shel dang / dngul gyi kha dog lta bu dag byung nas kha cig ni 'og logs su 'dong / kha cig ni steng logs su 'dong bas

While the Blessed Buddha was journeying and passing through Kāśī, he arrived at a place and smiled. As is natural, when blessed buddhas smile, blue, yellow, red, white, maroon, crystalline, and silvery rays of light emerge from their mouths, some streaming downwards and some streaming upwards.

gang dag 'og logs su 'dong ba de dag ni sems can dmyal ba yang sos dang / thig nag dang / bsdus gzhom dang / ngu 'bod dang / ngu 'bod chen po dang / tsha ba dang / rab tu tsha ba dang / mnar med pa dang / chu bur can dang / chu bur rdol ba dang / so thams thams dang / kyi hud zer dang / a chu zer dang / ut+pal ltar gas pa dang / pad ma ltar gas pa dang / pad ma ltar gas pa chen por dong ste/ sems can dmyal ba tsha ba gang dag yin pa de dag tu bsil bar gyur te 'bab par byed la/ sems can dmyal ba grang ba gang dag yin pa de dag tu ni dro bar gyur te 'bab par byed do/ / des sems can dmyal ba de dag gi gnod pa'i bye brag dag rgyun gcod par byed cing de dag 'di snyam du shes ldan dag ci bdag cag 'di nas shi 'phos sam/ 'on te gzhan du skyes snyam du sems so/ /

Those that streamed downwards proceeded to the hell realms of Sañjīva, Kālasūtra, Saṅghāta, Raurava, Mahāraurava, Tapana, Pratāpana, Avīci, Arbuda, [F.91.b] Nirarbuda, Aṭaṭa, Hahava, Huhuva, Utpala, Padma, and Mahāpadma. Alighting on and cooling those in the hot hells and alighting on and warming those in the cold hells, these rays of light interrupted the various harms inflicted on those hell realm beings, prompting the denizens of hell to think, “Gentlemen, what is this? Have we died, moved on, and taken birth elsewhere?”

de dag dad pa bskyed par bya ba'i phyir bcom ldan 'das kyis sprul pa gtong bar mdzad de/ de dag gis sprul pa mthong nas 'di snyam du shes ldan dag bdag cag 'di nas shi 'phos pa yang ma yin la/ gzhan du skyes pa yang ma yin te/ 'di ltar sems can sngon ma mthong ba 'di'i mthus bdag cag gi gnod pa'i bye brag dag rgyun chad par gyur to snyam du sems so/ /

To engender faith in them, the Blessed One sent an emanation which, when they saw it, prompted them to think, “Gentlemen, we have not died and moved on, nor have we been born elsewhere. Rather, the various harms inflicted on us have been interrupted by a being we have never seen before.”

de dag sprul pa la sems mngon par dad par gyur nas sems can dmyal ba myong bar 'gyur ba'i las de zad par byas nas gang du bden pa dag gi snod du gyur par 'gyur ba'i lha dang mi rnams kyi nang du nying mtshams sbyor ba len par byed do/ /

Through the faith they felt in the emanation, the karma that led them to experience the hell realms was exhausted and they took rebirth as gods or humans, forms in which they became fit vessels for the truth.

gang dag steng logs su 'dong ba de dag ni rgyal po chen po bzhi dang / sum bcu rtsa gsum dang / 'thab bral dang / dga' ldan dang / 'phrul dga' dang / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed dang / tshangs ris dang / tshangs pa'i mdun na 'don dang / tshangs chen dang / 'od chung dang / tshad med 'od dang / 'od gsal dang / dge chung dang / tshad med dge dang / dge rgyas dang / sprin med dang / bsod nams skyes dang / 'bras bu che dang / mi che dang / mi gdung dang / gya nom snang dang / shin tu mthong dang / 'og min gyi lha rnams kyi nang du dong nas mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / stong pa dang / bdag med pa zhes bya ba'i sgra sgrogs par byed cing tshigs su bcad pa gnyis po/

Those rays of light that streamed upwards reached the gods of Cāturmahārājika, Trāyastriṃśa, Yāma, Tuṣita Nirmāṇarati, Paranirmitavaśavartina, Brahmakāyikā, Brahmapurohita, Mahābrahman, Parīttābha Apramāṇābha Ābhāsvara, Parīttaśubha Apramāṇaśubha, Śubhakṛtsna, Anabhraka, Puṇyaprasava, Bṛhatphala, Abṛha, Atapa, Sudṛśa, Sudarśana, and Akaniṣṭha. Resonating with the words “impermanence,” “subject to suffering,” “empty,” and “selfless,” the rays of light proclaimed these two verses: [F.92.a]

brtsam par bya zhing 'byung bar bya/ / sangs rgyas bstan la 'jug par bya/ / 'dam bu'i khyim la glang chen bzhin/ / 'chi bdag sde ni gzhom par bya/ / gang zhig rab tu bag yod par/ / chos 'dul 'di la spyod 'gyur ba/ / skye ba'i 'khor ba rab spangs nas/ / sdug bsngal tha mar byed par 'gyur/ / zhes bya ba yang smras so/ /

“Take action! Go forth! Apply yourself to the Buddha’s teachings! As an elephant does a mud hovel, Destroy Yama’s minions! He who with great care Trains in the Dharma and Vinaya Abandons the cycle of rebirth And ends suffering once and for all!”

de nas 'od zer de dag gis stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams byul nas bcom ldan 'das nyid kyi slad bzhin slad bzhin du rjes su 'dong ste/ de la bcom ldan 'das 'das pa'i las lung ston par bzhed na ni bcom ldan 'das kyi snam logs su nub par 'gyur ro/ /

The rays of light then unfurled through the worlds of the great billionfold universe, so that they would, in the future, be drawn into the Blessed One’s sphere. If the Blessed One was about to foretell actions of the past, the rays of light would fade into the space behind the Blessed One.

ma 'ongs pa'i las lung ston par bzhed na ni mdun logs su nub par 'gyur/ sems can dmyal bar skye bar lung ston par bzhed na ni zhabs kyi mthil du nub par 'gyur/ dud 'gror skye bar lung ston par bzhed na ni long bur nub par 'gyur/ yi dgas su skye bar lung ston par bzhed na ni zhabs kyi mthe bor nub par 'gyur/ mir skye bar lung ston par bzhed na ni pus mor nub par 'gyur/ stobs kyi 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal srid lung ston par bzhed na ni phyag mthil g.yon par nub par 'gyur/ 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal srid lung ston par bzhed na ni phyag mthil g.yas par nub par 'gyur/ lhar skye bar lung ston par bzhed na ni lte bar nub par 'gyur/ nyan thos kyi byang chub lung ston par bzhed na ni zhal du nub par 'gyur/ rang sangs rgyas kyi byang chub lung ston par bzhed na ni mdzod spur nub par 'gyur/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub lung ston par bzhed na ni gtsug tor du nub par 'gyur ro/ /

If the Blessed One was about to foretell actions of the future, the rays of light would fade into the space before the Blessed One. If the Blessed One was about to foretell rebirth as a hell realm being, the rays of light would fade into the soles of his feet. If the Blessed One was about to foretell rebirth as an animal, the rays of light would fade into his ankle. If the Blessed One was about to foretell rebirth as a spirit, the rays of light would fade into his big toe. If the Blessed One was about to foretell rebirth as a human, the rays of light would fade into his knee. If the Blessed One was about to foretell a reign as a powerful king of the world, the rays of light would fade into the palm of his left hand. If the Blessed One was about to foretell a reign as a king of the world, the rays of light would fade into the palm of his right hand. If the Blessed One was about to foretell rebirth as a god, the rays of light would fade into his navel. If the Blessed One was about to foretell a śrāvaka’s awakening, the rays of light would fade into his mouth. If the Blessed One was about to foretell a pratyekabuddha’s awakening, the rays of light would fade into the tuft of hair at his brow. If the Blessed One was about to foretell unsurpassed, complete and perfect awakening, the rays of light would fade into the uṣṇīṣa at his crown.

de nas 'od zer de dag gis bcom ldan 'das la lan gsum bskor ba byas te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs kyi mthil du nub bo/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa kun dga' bos thal mo sbyar te zhus pa/ btsun pa de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams ni rgyu ma mchis rkyen ma mchis par 'dzum pa mi mdzad na/ btsun pa 'dzum pa mdzad pa'i rgyu ni gang lags/ rkyen ni gang lags/ tshigs su bcad pa yang gsol pa/

The rays of light then circled the Blessed One three times and faded into the soles of his feet. The venerable Ānanda then pressed his palms together and said to the Blessed One, “Reverend, not without cause or condition do tathāgatas, arhats, perfectly awakened buddhas [F.92.b] smile. If so, reverend, what then has caused you to smile? What condition has occasioned it?” And then he asked again in verse:

kha dog sna tshogs stong gis bkra ba yi/ / tshogs rnams zhal gyi sgros nas byung gyur te/ / de yis phyogs rnams thams cad snang bgyis pa/ / nyi gdugs bdal bar gyur pa ji bzhin no/ / rgod bral zhum dang rgyags pa rab spangs la/ / sangs rgyas 'gro ba mchog gi rgyur gyur pa/ / rgyal ba dgra thul byed rgyu ma mchis par/ / rtsa ba dung ltar dkar 'dzum ston mi mdzad/ / de slad brtan pa rang blo dus mkhyen nas/ / thub pa khyu mchog dge sbyong skye dbang po/ / nyan pa'i skye bo som nyi ldan rnams la/ / the tshom skyes pa gsung tshig brtan pa dang / / dam pa dge ba dag gis bsal du gsol/ / tshwa chu ri rgyal lta bur brtan pa yi/ / sangs rgyas mgon rnams glo bur 'dzum mi ston/ / brtan pa ji slad 'dzum pa ston mdzad pa/ / skye bo'i tshogs rnams de ni nyan par 'tshal/ /

“A mass made brilliant by a thousand colors Emerged from your mouth,[163] Illuminating every direction, So why bother with a parasol? Not brazen, nor dejected, nor self-satisfied, You have become a buddha, the best of beings, A victorious tamer of enemies. Not without cause Do you flash a smile white like a conch or lotus root. Your mind thus knows when the time is right to proclaim.[164] Leader among sages! Sovereign among ascetics! For your disciples who doubt, Dispel their uncertainty with words Reliable, sublime, and virtuous. Steady as a mountain or the salty sea, Lord buddhas do not smile accidentally. Steady as you are, this group is eager to hear The reason for your smile.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ kun dga' bo de de bzhin no/ / de de bzhin te/ kun dga' bo de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams ni rgyu med rkyen med par 'dzum pa mi mdzad de/ kun dga' bo phyogs 'di nyid du g.yon can rab tu mang po dag gis dge slong ma rab tu mang po dag lus bskyod pas sun phyung ste/ de dag 'di nas shi 'phos nas sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang du skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

The Blessed One replied, “Ānanda, it is like this. Not without cause or condition do tathāgatas, arhats, perfectly awakened buddhas smile. Ānanda, a great many sinister men here have violated a great many nuns by bodily forcing themselves upon them. For this, when they die, they will pass from this life to be reborn among the denizens of hell.”

de nas dge slong zhig gis bcom ldan 'das ga la ba de logs su thal mo sbyar ba btud nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa g.yon can rab tu mang po dag gis dge slong ma rab tu mang po dag lus bskyod pas sun phyung ba gang dag lags pa de dag gi nang nas gcig bdag lags so/ / mi gti mug can khyod kyis kyang dge slong ma rab tu mang po dag lus bskyod pas sun phyung ngam/ btsun pa bdag gis kyang dge slong ma rab tu mang po dag lus bskyod pas sun phyung ngo / /

A monk then went to where the Blessed One was, pressed his palms together and bowed, appealing to him in these words: “Reverend, I am one of the many sinister men who have bodily and forcibly violated nuns.” “Fool, have you really committed this act?” “Reverend, indeed I have.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag dge slong ma sun phyung ba ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag dge slong ma sun phyung ba chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la dge slong ma sun phyung ba ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

The Blessed One then [F.93.a] decreed to the monks, “Monks, a person who has violated a nun will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya.[165] Therefore, monks, you must banish from this Dharma and the Vinaya those persons who have violated a nun. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You have not violated a nun, have you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[rku thabs gnas]
Impostors
sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig rgyal byed kyi tshal du 'ongs so/ /
The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder of Śrāvastī came to Jetavana.

dge slong dag 'dod chags dang bral ba med pa na dge 'dun lhag ma'i ltung ba 'byin par byed de/ kha cig gzhon nu'i gnas skabs su ltung ba byung nas rgan por gyur/ kha cig ni rgan po'i gnas skabs na ltung ba 'byin par byed do/ / de dag gis gang gi tshe dge slong mdo sde 'dzin pa dang / 'dul ba 'dzin pa dang / ma mo 'dzin pa rnams las thos pa de'i tshe na chos bzhin du sgrub par byed de/ de dag yongs su spo ba dang mgu bar bya bar spyod pa na dge 'dun la rim gro byed cing de na kha cig ni btung ba 'drim par byed/ kha cig ni bsil yab thogs te g.yob par byed do/ /

When monks are not free from desire, it leads to saṅgha stigmata offenses. Some incur offenses in their youth and then grow old, and others incur offenses in their maturity. When such an offense occurs, the monks who retain the sūtras, retain the vinaya, and retain the mātṛkā impose, in accordance with the Dharma, a sentence[166] on the offender. The offender must serve the saṅgha while undergoing his full probation and penance. According to some, this service includes providing the saṅgha with drinks. According to others, it includes fanning them.

ji tsam na khyim bdag des de na gnas mal bzang po dag bshams shing kha zas bsod pa'i spyi bungs bshams pa mthong nas des bsams pa/ 'di dag gi chos ni bzang na 'di ltar 'di dag la skyon yang yod de/ 'di dag la rjes dang gus pa med de/ rgan pa rgan pa dag las byed du 'jug go snyam nas

At a certain point, the householder from Śrāvastī saw a spread of fine shelters with choice food laid out for the community and thought, “Though there is some good to their teaching, there are flaws too‍—they lack honor and respect for those elders they put to work.”
de skad smras pa dang / drug sde dag gis thos nas de dag gis smras pa/ khyim bdag ci zer/ 'phags pa khyed cag gi chos ni bzang na 'di ltar khyed cag la skyon yang mchis so/ /
When the group of six [167] heard him say this, they asked, “What did you say, householder?” “Noble ones, though there is some good to your teaching, you too have flaws.”
khyim bdag kho bo cag la skyon ci yod/ des smras pa/ 'phags pa dag khyed cag la rjes dang gus pa ma mchis te/ rgan pa rgan pa dag las bgyid du stsol to/ /
“Householder, what are our flaws?” “Noble ones,” he replied, “you lack honor and respect for the elders by putting them to work.”

rgan pa dag la yang las byed du gzhug dgos pa yod do/ / 'phags pa dag khyed kyi nang du nga rab tu phyung na yang las bgyid du stsol tam/ de dag gis smras pa/ khyod pas gang ches khyad par du 'phags pa rab tu phyung na yang de yang nged kyis las byed du gzhug na khyod lta ci smos/ des bsams pa/ gal te bdag 'di dag gi nang du rab tu byung na bdag kyang 'di dag gis las byed du bcug par 'gyur gyis/ thabs kyi rnam pa zhig bya'o snyam mo/ /

“There is a reason we put even elders to work.” [F.93.b] “Noble ones, if I were to go forth, would you put me to work too?” They replied, “What would you say if someone much more distinguished than you were to go forth and we put even him to work?” The householder thought, “If I were to go forth, they would also put me to work. I must find some way around it.”

khyim bdag de mkhas pa'i rang bzhin can yin pas des dge slong dag gi gan nas kun du spyod pa'i chos dag bslabs so/ / bslabs nas mtha' 'khob cig tu song ste skra dang kha spu bregs nas gos ngur smrig dag bgos te 'dug pa dang /

As the householder was possessed of a natural intelligence, while in the monks’ company he learned how to conduct himself. Having learned that, he set off for a remote land, where he shaved off his hair and beard, donned saffron robes, and settled down.

ji tsam na dge slong mchod rten la phyag 'tshal ba dag phyogs de nas 'ong zhing 'gro bar byed pa de dag gis de mthong nas smras pa/ gnas brtan mnyan yod na chos kyi rje mngon sum du bzhugs shing de na dus dang dus su lha'i gzugs dag kyang snang / snang ba rgya chen po dag kyang 'byung / lha'i sgra dag kyang grag /kun shes pa brda sprod pa dag kyang grag /longs spyod gnyis po zang zing gi longs spyod dang / chos kyi longs spyod kyang yod na ci'i phyir mnyan yod du mi 'gro/ des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag 'di nyid du 'dug par bya'o/ /

After a time, monks who were paying homage to stūpas passed by. When the pilgrims saw him they said, “Elder, in Śrāvastī there resides one who is verily a lord of Dharma. Around him, gods are always appearing in the flesh. Vast lights also appear, divine sounds are heard, as are the auguries of all-knowing beings, and the two forms of wealth‍—material wealth and the wealth of Dharma‍—are to be had. Why then do you not go to Śrāvastī?” “Venerables, I shall remain right here.”

de dag gis de la yang dang yang du smras pa/ gnas brtan mnyan yod na chos kyi rje mngon sum du bzhugs shing de na dus dang dus su lha'i gzugs dag kyang snang / snang ba chen po dag kyang 'byung / lha'i sgra dag kyang grag /kun shes pa brda sprod pa dag kyang grag /longs spyod gnyis po zang zing gi longs spyod dang / chos kyi longs spyod dag kyang yod na ci'i phyir mnyan yod du mi 'gro/

They implored him again and again, “Elder, in Śrāvastī there verily resides a lord of Dharma. Around him always are gods appearing in the flesh. Vast lights also appear, divine sounds are heard, as are the auguries of all-knowing beings, and the two forms of wealth‍—material wealth and the wealth of Dharma‍—are to be had. Why then do you not go to Śrāvastī?”

de tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa dag gis dus bskyed pa na mnyan yod du song ngo / / ji tsam na des de na gnas mal bzang po bshams shing kha zas bsod pa'i spyi bungs bshams pa mthong nas des bsams pa/ gal te bdag gral gyi dang por 'dug na ni yon bshad pa bya dgos par 'gyur ro snyam nas des stan gcig bor nas stan gnyis pa la 'dug go/ /

At the urging of his fellow brahmacārin, he set off for Śrāvastī. In time, he saw the spread of fine shelters with choice food laid out for the community there and thought, “If I sit in the front row, I’ll be called upon to demonstrate my knowledge.” Passing by the first seat, he sat down on the second. [F.94.a]

tshe dang ldan pa kun shes kauN+Di n+ya 'ongs nas des bsams pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag snam sbyar gyi rgyal mtshan 'chang ba rnams kyi mchog tu bstan na 'di su zhig yin snyam mo/ / ji tsam na bsams pa dang rku thabs su gnas pa zhig yin par mthong nas des de se gol gyi sgras bskrad do/ / tshe dang ldan pa rta thul dang / bzang ldan dang / rlangs pa dang / ming chen dang / grags pa dang / gang po dang / dri med dang / ba lang bdag dang / lag bzangs dang / tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu dang / tshe dang ldan pa maud gal gyi bu chen po dang / dge slong gnas brtan gnas brtan thams cad kyis kyang se gol gyi sgras bskrad do/ /

When the all-knowing Kauṇḍinya arrived, he thought, “If the Blessed One declared that I am first among those who wear the monk’s mantle standard, then who is this?” On thinking it over, Kauṇḍinya saw that he was an impostor and dismissed him with a snap of his fingers. The venerable Aśvajit, Bhadrika, Vāṣpa, Mahānāman, Yaśas, Pūrṇa, Vimala, Gavāmpati, Subāhu, the venerable Śāriputra, the venerable Mahāmaudgalyāyana, and all the eldest of elder monks then also dismissed him with the snap of their fingers.
ji tsam na drug sde dag gi gan du song ba dang de dag gis de la smras pa/ gnas brtan khyod lo du lon/ des na tshod kyi dbang du byas te kho bo lo drug bcu lon no zhes smras pa dang /
Some time later he approached the group of six, and they asked him, “Elder, how many years have you passed?” “If you’re asking my age, I have seen sixty years,” he replied.

de dag gis smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das nyid kyis kyang lo drug bcu ma bzhes na 'dis ga la lon/ de dag gis de la smras pa/ rgan zhugs khyod kyi mkhan po gang yin/ des smras pa/ dge sbyong gau ta ma'i mkhan po gang yin/
They asked, “If the Blessed One himself has not passed sixty years, how could you?” And they asked him, “Old-timer, who is your preceptor?” He replied, “Who is the ascetic Gautama’s preceptor?”

de dag gis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag rgan zhugs 'di ni rang gis rtags blangs pa yin no zhes de dag gis de lag pa dang rkang pa dag nas bzung ste rgan pa'i mthar khrid nas smras pa/ dge 'dun btsun pa rnams gsan du gsol/ 'jig rten na rang byung gcig ni bcom ldan 'das lags na gnyis pa ni rgan zhugs 'di lags so/ / 'di ni gsol ba'o zhes smras nas rgan pa'i mtha' nas bskrad do/ /

They exclaimed, “Venerables, this old-timer claims he has taken up these signifiers on his own.”[168] With this, they grabbed him by his arms and legs, dragged him before the senior monks and said, “Reverend saṅgha, please listen! If the Blessed One was the first self-ordained one in this world, this old-timer is the second. Or so he claims.” And with that they led him away.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag rku thabs su gnas pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas/ dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag rku thabs su gnas pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la rku thabs su gnas pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The Blessed One then addressed the monks: “Monks, this impostor will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya; therefore, you must banish impostors from this Dharma and Vinaya. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You are not an impostor, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.” [F.94.b]

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyis gang zag rku thabs su gnas pa bsnyil bar bya'o zhes bka' stsal na/ btsun pa ji tsam gyis na gang zag rku thabs su gnas pa lags/ nye ba 'khor gang tshun chad nas dge slong rang bzhin du gnas pa dag dang lhan cig gso sbyong gi las dag lan gnyis sam gsum du nyams su myong bar gyur na de tsam gyis na gang zag rku thabs su gnas pa yin no// //

Venerable Upāli asked the Blessed One, “Reverend, if the Blessed One says an impostor should be excluded, then reverend, what constitutes an impostor?” “Upāli, were he to later participate in the purification two or three times with monks of good standing, he would thereby be an imposter.”[169]
[ma ning]
Person labeled a paṇḍaka

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na bram ze zhig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i chung ma la sems can zhugs par gyur to/ / de zla ba brgyad dam dgu 'das te btsas pa las ma ning skyes pa 'dra ba bud med kyang ma yin skyes pa yang ma yin pa zhig byung nas bsrings shing bskyed de che bar gyur to/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a brahmin living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself soon conceived a child. After eight or nine months, a paṇḍaka child was born who, though resembling a boy, was neither female nor male. Still, they nurtured and raised the child until it grew up.
de khye'u dag dang lhan cig rtse bar byed pa na de de dag la mtshan ma ston par byed nas de dag gis de la smras pa/ khyod ci yin/ des smras pa/ bdag ma ning ngo / /
While the child was playing with a group of children, he showed them his sex organs, at which point they asked him, “What are you?” He replied, “I’m a person labeled a paṇḍaka.”[170]

de dag gis smras pa/ khyod ni bram ze yin pas khyod kyi khyim du mi snyan pa grags par gyur na mi rung gis de lta ma byed cig / de dag gis de'i pha ma la smras pa/ khyod kyis ma ning 'di 'di lta 'di lta byed kyis zlog shig /

“You’re a brahmin,” they said. “It’s not right to bring ill repute upon your family, so do not behave like this.” They said to his parents, “You must stop this person labeled a paṇḍaka of yours from behaving like this.”
de dag gis de la smras pa/ ma ning bdag cag ni bram ze yin pas bdag cag gi khyim du mi snyan par grags par gyur na mi rung gis de lta ma byed cig /
His parents then said to him, “Person labeled a paṇḍaka, we are brahmins. It is not right to bring ill repute upon our family. Do not behave so.”

de de dag gis bzlog kyang mi 'dug go/ / de dus gzhan zhig na rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ba dang / ji tsam na des dge slong gzhon nu gzhon nu dag mthong nas des bsams pa/ bdag 'di dag gi nang du rab tu byung na 'di dag bdag la skyes pa'i bya ba byed par 'gyur zhing bdag kyang 'di dag la bud med kyi bya ba byed par 'gyur ro snyam nas/ de dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /

Though this put a stop to that, the person labeled a paṇḍaka did not linger. He went to Jetavana and, after some time, he saw a group of young monks and thought, “If I were to go forth, they could play the role of a male for me while I could play the role of a female for them.” [F.95.a] He then approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”
des de la smras pa/ khyod pha mas gnang ngam/ des smras pa/ ma gnang ngo / /
“Have your parents given you their permission?” asked the monk. “They have not.”
song la pha ma la gsol cig / de pha ma'i gan du song ste smras pa/ yab yum bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
“Go and ask your parents.” He went to his parents and said, “Father, Mother, I want to go forth.”

de gnyis des yongs su gdungs pas bsams pa/ bdag cag 'di dang bral bar byas rab tu 'byung la rag go snyam nas/ de gnyis kyis de la smras pa/ ma ning gnang ngo / / de dge slong gi nang du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag pha mas gnang gis rab tu dbyung du gsol/

Depressed, the two of them thought, “His going forth will require our parting with him.” Then they said to him, “Person labeled a paṇḍaka, we give you our permission.” He went to the monk and said, “Noble one, my parents have given me permission, so please allow my going forth.”

des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas pa dang / dge slong rnams kyi mdun du mtshan ma ston par byed nas/ de dag gis de la smras pa/ khyod ma ning yin nam ci/ des smras pa/ yin no zhes zer ba'i skabs
After his going forth was allowed and he was granted ordination, he exposed his sex organs in the presence of monks, whereupon they asked him, “What are you? A person labeled a paṇḍaka?”

de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / de na bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag ma ning ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas/ dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag ma ning chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la ma ning ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

When he acknowledged that he was, the monks appealed to the Blessed One, and the Blessed One said to the monks, “A person labeled a paṇḍaka will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya; therefore, you must banish people labeled paṇḍakas from this Dharma and Vinaya. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You are not a person labeled a paṇḍaka, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

dge slong dag ma ning ni lnga po 'di dag yin te/ lnga gang zhe na/ skyes nas ma ning dang / zla ba phyed pa'i ma ning dang / 'khyud nas ldang ba'i ma ning dang / phrag dog can gyi ma ning dang / nyams pa'i ma ning ngo / / de la skyes nas ma ning gang zhe na/ gang skyes nas bud med kyang ma yin skyes pa yang ma yin pa'o/ / zla ba phyed pa'i ma ning gang zhe na/ gang zla ba phyed ni bud med zla ba phyed ni skyes par 'gyur ba'o/ / 'khyud nas ldang ba'i ma ning gang zhe na/ gang la gzhan dag gis 'khyud na dbang po 'byung bar 'gyur ba'o/ / phrag dog can gyi ma ning gang zhe na/ gang la gzhan dag rtsol ba mthong na dbang po 'byung bar 'gyur ba'o/ / nyams pa'i ma ning gang zhe na/ gang gi dbang po nad kyis nyams pa'am mtshon gyis bcad pa'o/ /

“Monks, there are five kinds of persons labeled paṇḍakas. What are they? They are intersex persons, rhythmic-consecutive persons, sexually submissive persons, persons with a voyeuristic fetish, and persons with a sexual disability. What is a intersex person? One who is born neither a female nor a male. What is a rhythmic-consecutive person? Someone who is female for half the month yet becomes male during the other half. What is a sexually submissive person? One who becomes erect if embraced by another. What is a person with a voyeuristic fetish? One who becomes erect at the sight of others’ exertion. [F.95.b] What is a person with a sexual disability? A person whose sexual organs have been disabled by disease, or removed with some instrument.

de la ma ning snga ma bzhi po skyes nas ma ning dang / zla ba phyed pa'i ma ning dang / 'khyud nas ldang ba'i ma ning dang / phrag dog can gyi ma ning gang dag yin pa de dag ni rab tu ma byung na ni rab tu dbyung bar mi bya la/ rab tu byung na ni bsnyil bar bya'o/ / de la nyams pa'i ma ning gang yin pa de ni rab tu ma byung na ni rab tu dbyung bar mi bya la/ rab tu byung na ni gal te 'gyur ba mi sten na btang snyoms su bya'o/ / gal te 'gyur ba bsten na bsnyil bar bya'o// //

“If the first four types of persons labeled paṇḍakas‍—intersex persons, rhythmic-consecutive person, sexually submissive persons, and persons with a voyeuristic fetish‍—have not gone forth, you should not allow their going forth. If they have gone forth, they should be banished. As for a person with a sexual disability, if they have not gone forth, you should not allow their going forth. If they have gone forth, they should be left as they are, provided they do not show an inclination to change.[171] If they show an inclination to change, they should be banished.”
[dud 'gro]
Creatures
[dge 'dun 'tsho dang klu sprul pa]
Saṅgharakṣita and the Shape-Shifting Nāga
[dad ldan sprul pa]

d.crumb: The shape-shifting nāga who finds faith in the Dharma

f.d: The shape-shifting nāga who finds faith in the Dharma

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / klu rnams kyi kun du spyod pa ni lus la nyin mo bye ma me'i mdog lta bu lan gsum 'bab cing des de dag rus pa'i keng rus tsam zhig lus par byed do/ / klu gzhon nu skyes nas ring po ma lon pa zhig gi lus la nyin mo bye ma me'i mdog lta bu lan gsum 'bab cing des de rus pa'i keng rus tsam zhig lus par byas pa dang des ma la smras pa/ ma bdag gis yun ji srid cig tu sdug bsngal 'di lta bu mnag par bgyi 'tshal/ bu ji srid du ris mthun pa yod kyi bar du'o/ /

While the Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, the nāgas thrice felt fiery sand fall from the heavens upon them, reducing their bodies to mere skeletons. After fiery sand thrice fell from the heavens upon a young nāga, reducing his body to that of a mere skeleton, he asked his mother, “Mother, how long must I endure such suffering?” “Son, for as long as you are in this life.”

de na klu rdzu 'phrul che ba dang mthu che ba gzhan gang dag yin pa de dag gi lus la bye ma me'i mdog lta bu mi 'bab nas des smras pa/ ma 'di dag la ci'i phyir mi 'bab/ mas smras pa/ 'di dag ni rdzu 'phrul che ba/ mthu che ba/ bskal par gnas pa/ sa 'dzin pa/ 'dab chags kyi rgyal po 'dab bzangs kyis dbyung bar mi nus pa yin pas de'i phyir 'di dag la mi 'bab bo/ /

Through all of this, fiery sand had not fallen on other nāgas who possessed miraculous powers and great might, prompting him to ask, “Mother, why did it not fall upon them?” His mother replied, “It did not fall upon them because they possess miraculous powers and great might; they live for eons and they sustain the earth. Even the garuḍa Suparṇi could not dislodge them.”

de na klu phra mo gzhan gang dag yin pa de dag gi lus la bye ma me'i mdog lta bu mi 'bab nas des smras pa/ ma 'di dag la ni rigs na 'di dag la ci'i phyir mi 'bab/ mas smras pa/ 'di dag gis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag blangs pas de'i phyir 'di dag la mi 'bab bo/ / des smras pa/ gal te de lta na bdag gis kyang bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag blang ngo / /

Through all of this, fiery sand had not fallen on a number of scrawny nāgas either, prompting him to ask, “Mother, why did it not fall upon those of their type?” “It did not fall upon them because they took refuge and adopted the precepts in the presence of the Blessed One.” “If that is so, [F.96.a] then I too shall take refuge and adopt the precepts in the presence of the Blessed One.”

mas smras pa/ bu tshe gcig gi sdug bsngal ni bla'i tshe rabs mang po'i ni ma yin te/ gal te khyod kyis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan snga nas skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag blangs nas yang dag par ma bsrungs na yun ring por sems can dmyal bar sdug bsngal mnag par bya dgos so/ /

“Son, a single life’s suffering is easy to bear, that of many lifetimes is not. If you take refuge and adopt the precepts in the presence of the Blessed One, but then do not properly heed them, you will have to endure suffering as a denizen in the hell realms for a long time to come.”

des bsams pa/ sdug bsngal 'di bas ches sdug bsngal bar 'gyur ba ci zhig yod kyis/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag len du 'gro'o snyam nas/ de bram ze'i cha lugs su mngon par sprul nas rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ba dang / ji tsam na des dge slong dag bsam gtan dang / klog pa dang / rnal 'byor dang / yid la byed pa la brtson zhing gnas pa mthong ngo / / mthong nas kyang dad pa skyes te/ des bsams pa/ ji je dang por skyabs su 'gro ba dang bslab pa'i gzhi dag blang ngam/ 'on te rab tu 'byung bar bya snyam mo/ /

The young nāga thought, “What suffering could be worse than my present suffering? I shall take refuge and adopt the precepts in the presence of the Blessed One.” Conjuring up the appearance of a brahmin, he set off for Jetavana, where he saw monks applying themselves to and abiding in meditation, recitation, yoga, and concentration. Upon seeing them, he felt faith and thought, “Oh my! Should I first take refuge and adopt the precepts or go forth?”

des yang bsams pa/ rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas de dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ / des smras pa/ kho bo ni gsar bu yin pas gnas brtan gzhan 'ga' zhig gi drung du song shig /des smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag gis gzhan ngo 'tshal ba ma mchis te/ 'di ltar bdag thog mar kho nar 'phags pa'i gan du mchis pas khyod nyid kyis bdag dge slong 'ga' zhig la gtad par gsol/

On thinking it over, he decided, “I shall go forth,” and with that he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.” “As I am new, you should go to someone else, an elder.” “Noble one, I do not know anyone else. This is my first time in the presence of a noble being, so I ask you, please, introduce me to a monk.”

dge slong de'i mkhan po dgon pa pa zhig dgon pa na 'dug pas des de khrid de de'i gan du song nas smras pa/ mkhan po rigs kyi bu 'di rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal gyis rab tu dbyung du gsol/ des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong dag gshan pa byed du bcug pa ni bla'i rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas yal bar bor ba ni mi rung ngo zhes bka' stsal pas/ 'di yang sems can dmyal bar 'gro bar 'gyur la/ kho bo yang ltung ba dang bcas par 'gyur bas kho bo 'di rab tu mi 'byin to/ /

As the new monk’s preceptor was a hermit living in the forest, the monk took the nāga disguised as a brahmin to see him and said, “Preceptor, as this noble son wants to go forth, I ask that you allow him to go forth.” The preceptor replied, “My dear sir, the Blessed One said, ‘Monks, one could accept being pressed into work as a butcher, but it is not right to leave the life once you have gone forth and been ordained.’ This brahmin would go to the hells [F.96.b] and I too would fall, so I will not ordain him.”

des smras pa/ mkhan pos rab tu dbyung ba 'ba' zhig mdzod cig dang / bdag gis 'di bslab par bgyi zhing klog tu stsal bar bgyi'o/ / des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs 'di nyid khyod kyi mkhan po gcig pa yin/ 'di nyid slob dpon yin gyis khyod kyis 'di nyid la dri bar bya/ khyod kyis 'di nyid la bklag par bya'o/ / khyod kyis 'di nyid la bslab par bya'o/ /

“Please, preceptor,” the monk replied, “all you need do is allow his going forth and I shall undertake to train and instruct him.” After the preceptor had allowed the nāga’s going forth and ordained him, the preceptor said to the monk, “My dear sir, you and he now share a preceptor. As his instructor, you must quiz him, you must instruct him, and you must train him.”

des gcig las 'phros pa'i lung bklags pas des de gcig las 'phros pa'i lung klog tu gzhug par brtsams pa dang / des shin tu brtson 'grus brtsams pas kha ton du lhogs nas dge slong slob dpon de shin tu mig gang ste des de la smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ci lhan cig tu bsod snyoms la 'jug par bya'am/ 'on te so sor/

The monk recited the Ekottarikāgama [172] and then had the nāga repeat it. As he did so with great vigor, it took on the cadence of a prayer. The monk instructor’s eyes lit up with joy and the monk said to the nāga disguised as a brahmin, “My dear sir, shall we seek alms together or on our own?”

des bsams pa/ bdag gis mi'i zas kyis 'tsho bar mi nus kyis/ bdag klu'i gnas su song la bdud rtsi zos shing zos shing phyir 'ong bar bya'o snyam nas/ des smras pa/ slob dpon so sor 'jug par bya'o/ / des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs de ltar gyis shig /

The nāga disguised as a brahmin thought, “I cannot live on the things humans eat; I had better return to the land of nāgas, where I can imbibe ambrosia, and return once I’ve eaten.” “Instructor, let us seek them on our own.” “Very well, my dear sir,” replied the monk.

de klu'i gnas su lha'i bdud rtsi zos nas phyir 'ong ngo / / klu rnams ni gnyid che ba yin pas de gang gi tshe gnyid log nas langs pa de'i tshe na dge slong de bsod snyoms blangs nas phyir 'ong ngo / /

The nāga would drink the ambrosia of the gods in the land of nāgas and then return. As nāgas require a lot of sleep, he would soon fall into slumber. The monk would return later from his alms round as the nāga was rising from his nap.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na dge slong des bsod snyoms glo bur ba rnyed nas des de blangs te phyir 'ongs pa dang / ji tsam na gnas khang na mgar ba'i sbud pa 'bud pa lta bu'i sgra thos nas des gtan pa'i bu ga nas bltas na/ gnas khang de thams cad klu'i lus bskyil bas gang ba mthong nas des sprul pa sprul pa zhes sgra phyung ba dang /

One day, the monk received alms right away, took them, and headed home. As he drew near, he heard a sound, like a smith pumping his bellows, coming from his hut. Looking through the keyhole, he saw the entire hut filled with the coiled up body of a nāga and cried out, “A shape shifter! A shape shifter!”

de sgra la mkhas pas myur ba myur ba kho nar sad nas rang bzhin gyi cha lugs mi snang bar byas te de sprul pa'i cha lugs su 'dug go/ / dge slong dag lhags nas de dag gis de la smras pa/ 'di ci yin/ des smras pa/ sprul pa yin no/ /

Understanding well what such words meant, the nāga hastily transformed, cloaking his natural appearance and reverting to his conjured look. Monks gathered around and asked him, “What is the matter?” “He’s a shape shifter,” the monk replied.

de dag gis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa brtson 'grus brtsams pas rtag tu kha ton la brtson pa yin na ci khyod 'di la ser sna byed dam/ des smras pa/ kho bo ni 'di la cung zad kyang ser sna mi byed de/ 'di ltar 'di ni sprul pa yin no/ /

They said, [F.97.a] “This venerable applies himself diligently, always making an effort in his recitations. Why do you begrudge him?” “I do not begrudge him in the least. It is just that he’s a shape shifter.”
de dag phan tshun smra ba na bcom ldan 'das kyang phyogs der gshegs nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ 'di ci yin/ dge slong dag gis gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das sprul pa lags so/ /
While they were conferring, the Blessed One passed by and inquired, “What is the matter?” “Blessed One, he’s a shape shifter.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag sprul pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas/ dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag sprul pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la sprul pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The Blessed One replied, “A shape shifter will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya; therefore, you must banish shape shifters from this Dharma and Vinaya. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, ask him, ‘You are not a shape shifter, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.

dge slong dag klu'i rang bzhin lnga po 'di dag yin la lhag ma ni sprul pa yin no/ / lnga gang zhe na/ rang bzhin gyis skye ba dang / rang bzhin gyis 'chi ba dang / rang bzhin gyis nyal ba dang / rang bzhin gyis za ba dang / rang bzhin gyis mi tshangs par spyod pa 'khrig pa'i chos sten par byed pa'o/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis de la bka' stsal pa/ bzhin bzangs khyod kyis phung po 'di dag gis yon tan gyi tshogs 'ga' yang thob par mi nus kyis/ dge slong rnams la ma 'tshe bar song shig /

“Monks, a nāga’s nature is characterized by five things; the rest are emanations. What are these five? Nāgas are born a natural birth, they die a natural death, they sleep a natural sleep, they are nourished naturally, and they procreate naturally‍—these are the qualities they exhibit.” The Blessed One said to the nāga, “My dear sir, with this body of yours you cannot attain any of a host of qualities, so leave and do no harm to the monks.”

des bsams pa/ 'babs par ga la bya snyam nas des sA la'i dgon pa zhig tu song nas gtsug lag khang rta babs mthon po dang ldan pa/ mthongs khung dang / skar khung dra ba can dang / lan kan gyis brgyan pa/ snying dang mig 'phrog par byed pa/ mtho ris kyi them skas su gyur pa/ khri dang / khri'u dang / yo byad phun sum tshogs pa zhig sprul te/ dge slong glo bur du 'ongs pa dang / 'gro bar chas pa rnams la yo byad thams cad kyis stobs par byed do/ /

The nāga, not knowing where he might wind up, eventually came upon a forest of śāla trees, where he conjured up a monastery with a high gate, skylights, and latticed windows. It was adorned with balustrades, beguiling to the heart and beautiful to the eye, with a staircase to the upper level, and perfectly outfitted with beds, seats, and supplies. To arriving monks and departing monks, he provided all the supplies they needed.[173]

“Noble ones,” he replied, “are you merely displeased or utterly disappointed?” “We are not just ‘merely displeased,’ for our fellow brahmacārin would denounce us if it were said, ‘The group of six passed the rainy season at that very monastery and yet they know nothing of its income and know nothing of its allocations.’ ”

When the group of six saw this they said, “Nanda and Upananda, investigate this old-timer and after seven days, evict him along with his partisans.” After seven days had passed, the old-timer made the monastery vanish as the group of six slept, and fled to the seashore. The Blessed One then decreed, “A monk should not be forced to account for income and allocations with no obvious source and recipients. The debarred nāga, now disguised as a monk preacher, saw the six approaching from off in the distance, and thought, “Ah! Those rogues have arrived. What would they do if I refused to demurely acquiesce to them?”

They said to the nāga, disguised as the monk preacher, “What do you know, old-timer?” “The Ekottarikāgama .” “You teach the Dharma using this out-of-date Ekottarikāgama while these monks here are all versed in the Three Piṭakas, are teachers of Dharma in their own right, and possessed of intelligence and untrammeled confidence. Why do you not request teachings from them?”

“What? Nobles ones, do I stop them? Why do you not teach the Dharma?” “Nanda and Upananda, this old-timer is at odds with us. On waking on the sandy beach, the group of six said, “Nanda and Upananda, get up and erect a lion throne from which we shall teach the Dharma.” When they noticed they had slept on a sandy beach, they said, “We opposed one who trusted in the Blessed One and served the Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, causing him to flee and make his monastery disappear.”

The Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from the monks’ teaching without being requested to do so.” With that he said, “A monk should not teach without first having been asked to do so. If a monk teaches without first having been asked to do so, a breach occurs. If he is invited to do so, then no offense ensues.”
