Buddharakṣita, a wealthy householder with much riches and goods who lived in Śrāvastī, took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. Looking to guide them, the venerable Śāriputra went to their house and enjoined the householder and his wife to seek refuge and pledge to uphold the precepts. Some time afterwards, the householder’s wife conceived a child.

tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bus sems can de nges par skal ba dang ldan pa nyid du shes nas phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong med par de'i khyim du song ba dang khyim bdag des rkang pa la phyag 'tshal te smras pa/ ci 'phags pa la slad bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong ma mchis sam/ des smras pa/ khyim bdag ci kho bo'i phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong rtswa ka sha'i byings sam/ ku sha'i byings nas 'byung bar 'gyur ram/ 'di ltar khyod lta bu dag las thob pa gang dag yin pa de dag kho bo'i phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong du 'gyur ro/ /

Knowing this being was certain to become one of the fortunate, the venerable Śāriputra visited the family without any ascetic followers in his wake. Prostrating at his feet, the householder asked, “Does the noble one have no ascetic followers?” “Householder,” he replied, “do you think my ascetic followers simply sprout up like weeds? It’s those who issue from people like you who become my ascetic followers.”

khyim bdag sangs rgyas 'tshos smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag gi mchis 'brang 'di la sems can zhig zhugs par gyur gyis/ gal te bu pho zhig btsas par gyur na de bdag gis 'phags pa'i slad bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong du 'bul lo/ / des smras pa/ khyim bdag thabs yin no/ /
“Noble one, my spouse has conceived a child. If she should give birth to a boy, I will offer him as an ascetic follower to the noble one.” “Householder, I accept.”

de zla ba brgyad dam dgu 'das pa dang khye'u gzugs bzang ba/ blta na sdug pa/ mdzes pa/ gsal ba/ gser gyi mdog 'dra ba/ mgo gdugs lta bu dang ldan pa/ lag pa ring ba/ dpral ba'i dbyes che ba/ smin ma 'jar ba/ sna'i gzangs mtho ba zhig btsas so/ / btsas nas de'i nye du dag 'dus shing lhags nas de nyi ma bdun gsum nyi shu gcig tu btsas pa'i btsas ston rgya cher byas nas khye'u ming cir gdags zhes ming 'dogs par byed do/ / gzhan dag gis smras pa/ khye'u 'di sangs rgyas 'tsho'i bu yin pas khye'u 'i ming dge 'dun 'tshor gdags so zhes de'i ming dge 'dun 'tsho zhes bya bar btags so/ /

After eight or nine months had passed a boy was born, well proportioned, pleasing to the eye, [F.101.a] handsome, radiant, with a golden complexion, a head shaped well like a parasol, long arms, a broad forehead, eyebrows that meet, and a prominent nose. Three weeks, or twenty-one days, after the birth, relatives came and gathered to celebrate his birth in grand style, during which time they discussed what name should be chosen for the boy. Some said, “Since the boy is Buddharakṣita’s son, the boy should be named Saṅgharakṣita,” and thus he was named Saṅgharakṣita.

de dag gis khye'u dge 'dun 'tsho 'o ma dang / zho dang / mar dang / zhun mar dang / mar gyi snying gu dang / gzhan yang yo byad kyi bye brag gtso bo gtso bo dag gis sring bar byed/ skyed par byed cing rdzing na gnas pa'i pad ma bzhin du myur du skyed par byed do/ / gang kho na'i nyin mo dge 'dun 'tsho btsas pa de kho na'i nyin mo tshong pa lnga brgya dag gi bu dag kyang btsas te/ de dag kyang rigs dang mthun pa'i ming dag btags so/ /

Fortified with milk, curd, butter, ghee, cream, and other nourishing foods, the boy Saṅgharakṣita grew quickly, shooting up like a lotus in a pond. On the very day Saṅgharakṣita was born, that same day sons were also born to five hundred merchants, each of whom was given a name appropriate to his patrilineage.

gang gi tshe khye'u dge 'dun 'tsho chen por gyur pa de'i tshe na tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bus de rab tu dbyung ba'i dus shes nas gdul ba la ltos pas phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong med par gcig pu de'i khyim du song ba dang khyim bdag sangs rgyas 'tshos rkang pa la phyag 'tshal te stan bting ba dang tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu 'dug go/ / 'dug nas kyang khyim bdag sangs rgyas 'tsho la brda bya bar brtsams so/ / de nas khyim bdag sangs rgyas 'tshos dge 'dun 'tsho la smras pa/ bu kho bos khyod ma'i rum na 'dug cing ma btsas pa nyid nas 'phags pa shA ri'i bu la phyi bzhin 'brang ba'i dge sbyong du phul gyis khyod song la 'di la bsnyen bkur gyis shig /

In time the boy Saṅgharakṣita grew up and the venerable Śāriputra knew it was time to allow his going forth. So, looking to guide them, he went alone without any ascetic followers in his wake to the boy’s house. After prostrating at Śāriputra’s feet, the householder Buddharakṣita laid out a seat and invited the venerable Śāriputra to sit. As he sat, Śāriputra signaled to prompt the householder Buddharakṣita. The householder Buddharakṣita then said to Saṅgharakṣita, “Son, when you were in your mother’s womb, before you were even born, I offered you as an ascetic follower to the noble Śāriputra. Go and serve him.”

de sems can srid pa tha ma pa yin pas 'dzum sngon du btang ste/ 'jigs pa med cing bzhin nyams pa med pa dang / dman pa med pas de ltar bgyi'o zhes khas blangs nas de tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu'i phyi bzhin phyi bzhin rjes su 'brang ngo / / de nas tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bus de rab tu byung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas kun du spyod pa'i chos dag bslabs te lung bzhi klog tu bcug go/ /

As this was to be Saṅgharakṣita’s last life as a sentient being, a smile had already spread across his face and, without apprehension, neither crestfallen nor gloomy, he pledged to do as he was told. With that he became the venerable Śāriputra’s attendant apprentice and follower. [F.101.b] After the venerable Śāriputra had allowed his going forth and given him ordination, he taught Saṅgharakṣita how Dharma practitioners conduct themselves and made him recite the Four Āgamas.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na/ tshong pa lnga brgya po dag gi bu lnga brgya po de dag gis phan tshun gros byas te rgya mtsho chen por 'dong ba'i zong sta gon byas nas rgya mtsho chen por 'phags pa dang / de dag 'di snyam sems te/ shes ldan dag rgya mtsho chen po ni 'jigs pa du mas kun du gang ba yin pas bdag cag gis gang bdag cag rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du dong ba rnams la chos ston par 'gyur ba'i 'phags pa 'ga' zhig gshegs su gsol na/ des bdag cag bde legs su 'gyur snyam nas/

Some time later, after assembling merchandise to bring on their journey across the ocean, the five hundred sons of the five hundred merchants conferred and decided to bring, along with their goods, a noble monk across the ocean. “Gentlemen, the ocean is full of many terrors. So those of us that journey across the ocean would do well to ask for the company of a noble one who might teach us the Dharma.”

de dag gis dpyad par brtsams te smras pa/ su gshegs su gsol/ gzhan dag gis smras pa/ shes ldan dag 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'di bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pas rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba yin pas bdag cag gis 'di la gsol ba gdab par bya'o/ /
Beginning their search, they asked, “Who shall we ask to come?” Some answered, “Gentlemen, we should ask our peer, the noble Saṅgharakṣita, for we grew up together playing in the dirt with him.”

de nas de dag de'i gan du song ste rkang pa la phyag 'tshal nas smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pa sa rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba lags te/ bdag cag ni rgya mtsho chen por 'phags na rgya mtsho chen po ni 'jigs pa du mas kun du gang ba lags pas 'phags pas bdag cag rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du mchis pa rnams la chos bstan na des bdag cag bde legs su 'gyur ba lags kyis/ de'i slad du 'phags pa bdag cag dang thabs cig rgya mtsho chen por gshegs par gsol/ des smras pa/ shes ldan dag kho bo la rang dbang med kyis deng la mkhan po la zhus shig /

They went to him, prostrated at his feet, and said, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, we grew up together playing in the dirt with you, our peer, so if we set out upon the ocean, an ocean full of many terrors, we would do well were the noble one to teach Dharma to those of us crossing the ocean. Therefore, noble one, we ask that you come with us across the ocean.” “Gentlemen,” he replied, “as I am not at liberty to do as I please, you should put your request to my preceptor.”

de dag tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu ga la ba der song ste phyin nas tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu'i rkang pa gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/ tshe dang ldan pa shA ri'i bu la 'di skad ces smras so/ / 'phags pa shA ri'i bu mkhyen par mdzod cig /'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'di bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pa sa rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba lags te/ bdag cag ni rgya mtsho chen por 'phags na rgya mtsho chen po ni 'jigs pa du mas kun du gang ba lags pas 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tshos bdag cag rgya mtsho chen po'i nang du mchis pa rnams la chos bstan na des bdag cag bde legs su 'gyur lags kyis/ de'i slad du 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag dang thabs cig rgya mtsho chen por gtang bar gsol/ des smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das nyid la zhus shig dang kho bos zlog par mi byed do/ /

They went to the venerable Śāriputra, bowed their heads at his feet, and said, “Noble Śāriputra, please give us your attention. We grew up together playing in the dirt with our peer, the noble Saṅgharakṣita. So if we set out upon the ocean, [F.102.a] an ocean full of many terrors, we would do well were the noble one to teach Dharma to those of us crossing the ocean. For that reason, we ask that you send the noble Saṅgharakṣita with us across the ocean.” “Ask the Blessed One himself and I will not object.”

de dag bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der dong ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te/bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das mkhyen par mdzad du gsol/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'di bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pa sa rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba lags te/ bdag cag ni rgya mtsho chen por 'phags na rgya mtsho chen po ni 'jigs pa du mas kun du gang ba lags pas 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tshos bdag cag rgya mtsho chen por mchis pa rnams la chos bstan na des bdag cag bde legs su 'gyur ba lags kyis/ de'i slad du 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag dang thabs cig rgya mtsho chen por gtang bar gsol/

They went to the Blessed One, bowed their heads at his feet, and said, “Blessed One, please give us your attention. We grew up together playing in the dirt with our peer, the noble Saṅgharakṣita. So if we set out upon the ocean, an ocean full of many terrors, we would do well were the noble one to teach Dharma to those of us crossing the ocean. For that reason, we ask that you send the noble Saṅgharakṣita with us across the ocean.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ ci tshong pa 'di dag la dge ba'i rtsa ba cung zad yod dam/'on te med snyam na yod par gzigs so/ / su la rag lus snyam nas dge slong dge 'dun 'tsho la rag lus par gzigs nas/ de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho la bka' stsal pa/ dge 'dun 'tsho khyod rgya mtsho chen por 'jug tu song la khyod kyis 'jigs pa dang 'jigs su rung ba dag bzod par gyis shig /

The Blessed One considered whether or not these merchants had any meager roots of virtue and saw that they did. Considering who their awakening hinged on, he saw that it hinged on the monk Saṅgharakṣita. The Blessed One then said to the venerable Saṅgharakṣita, “Saṅgharakṣita, you shall go on this journey across the ocean and face your fears along with what provokes them.”

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos bcom ldan 'das la cang mi smra bar dang du blangs so/ / de nas tshong pa lnga brgya po de dag tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho dang lhan cig dge mtshan dang / bkra shis dang / bde legs su 'gyur ba dag byas te/ shing rta dag dang / khur dag dang / spyad dag dang / gle ba dag dang / rnga mo dag dang / ba lang dag dang / bong bu dag gis rgya mtsho chen por 'dong ba'i zong khyer te/ rgya mtsho chen por 'phags nas mthar gyis grong dang / grong rdal dang / yul 'khor dang / rgyal po'i pho brang dang / tshong rdal dag tu rnam par rgyu ba na rgya mtsho chen po'i 'gram du phyin nas de dag gis lam gis dub pa bsal te/ zong rnying pa lnga brgyas gru bo che sbyar nas zho shas 'tsho ba lnga brgya po stobs par byed pa dang / sel bar byed pa dang / rkyal chen dang / gru pa dang / rlung yor thogs pa dag khrid de/ lan gsum dril bsgrags nas nor bsgrub pa'i phyir rgya mtsho chen por zhugs so/ /

With his silence, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita assented to the Blessed One. After performing rites for protection, good luck, and success, the five hundred merchants together with the venerable Saṅgharakṣita carried their goods to the ocean in carts, on poles, in baskets and hampers, and on camels, bullocks, [F.102.b] and donkeys. Setting out for the ocean, they passed in stages through villages, towns, countryside, kingdoms, and markets until they reached the ocean shore, where they paused to recover from the weariness of the road. For five hundred denarii they obtained a ship and hired five hundred crew members to serve as stewards, cleaning staff, divers, deck hands, and riggers. After calling out three times,[176] they set out upon the ocean in pursuit of riches.

ji tsam na de dag rgya mtsho chen por dong ba dag gi gru bo che de klu rnams kyis bzung nas de dag zhi ba dang / chu lha dang / lus ngan dang / brgya byin dang / tshangs pa la sogs pa lha rnams la rgya mtsho chen po 'di na lha'am/ klu'am/ gnod sbyin nam/ dri za'am/ gang gnas pa de bdag cag la ci 'dod pa smra bar gyur cig ces gsol ba gdab par brtsams pa dang / de nas rgya mtsho chen po nas 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho nged la byin cig ces sgra phyung ngo / / de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho ni bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pa sa rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba/ bcom ldan 'das dang btsun pa shA ri'i bus bdag cag la gnang ba yin pas bdag cag 'di dang lhan cig 'chi ba dang dus byed pa ni bla'i/ 'di yongs su gtang bar ni mi bya'o/ /

Part of the way into their voyage, they and their seafaring ship were held up by nāgas. The merchants began to implore Śiva, Varuṇa, Kubera, Śakra, Brahmā, and other gods, “Whoever it is that dwells here, be they gods, nāgas, yakṣas, or gandharvas, may they tell us what they desire!” From the ocean there came a voice, saying, “Give us the noble Saṅgharakṣita!” “The noble Saṅgharakṣita is our peer. We grew up together playing in the dirt with him. The Blessed One and the venerable Śāriputra have entrusted him to us, so we would sooner die and face our death with him than turn him over.”

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos de dag la smras pa/ shes ldan dag ci zer/ de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa rgya mtsho chen po nas 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho nged la byin cig ces sgra byung ngo / / des smras pa/ ci'i phyir mi sbyin/

The venerable Saṅgharakṣita said to them, “What are you talking about, gentlemen?” “Noble one,” they replied, “a voice from the ocean has said, ‘Give us the noble Saṅgharakṣita!’ ” “Why do you not give me over?”

de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa khyod ni bdag cag gi ne'u ldangs lhan cig skyes pa sa rdul la lhan cig rtse rtse ba/ bcom ldan 'das dang / btsun pa shA ri'i bus bdag cag la gnang ba lags pas bdag cag khyod dang thabs cig 'gum pa dang dus bgyid pa ni bla'i/ khyod yongs su gtang bar ni mi bgyi'o/ / tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos bsams pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag la dge 'dun 'tsho khyod rgya mtsho chen por 'jug tu song la khyod kyis 'jigs pa dang 'jigs su rung ba dag bzod par gyis shig ces bka' stsal pa gang yin pa de ni 'di yin no snyam nas/

“Noble one, you are our peer. We grew up together playing in the dirt with you. The Blessed One and the venerable Śāriputra have entrusted you to us, so we would sooner die and face our death with you than turn you over.” [F.103.a] The venerable Saṅgharakṣita thought, “This must be what the Blessed One meant when he said to me, ‘Saṅgharakṣita, you shall go on this journey across the ocean and face your fears along with what provokes them.’ ”

des lhung bzed dang chos gos thogs te bdag nyid rgya mtsho chen por mchong bar brtsams pa dang / de nas tshong pa de dag gis des de ltar brtsams pa mthong nas smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho ci mdzad ci mdzad/ de de dag de ltar bzlog bzhin du rgya mtsho chen por mchongs pa dang / de ma thag kho nar klu rnams kyis gru bo che de btang ngo / / tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho yang klu rnams kyis khrid de klu'i gnas su zhugs so/ /

Taking up his begging bowl and robe, he prepared to jump into the sea. Seeing him prepare to jump, the merchants shouted, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita! What are you doing? What are you doing?” As they tried to stop him, Saṅgharakṣita jumped into the sea and at the very moment he did so, the nāgas released the ship. Taking the venerable Saṅgharakṣita, the nāgas returned to the land of the nāgas.

de nas klu de rnams klu'i bu mo rnams dang lhan cig 'dzum pa sngon du btang ste ya mtshan skyes nas mig tshugs su lta zhing tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho mchod rten de dag la phyag 'tshal du gzhug par brtsams te smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'di ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnam par gzigs kyi dri gtsang khang lags so/ / 'di ni gtsug tor can dang / thams cad skyob dang / 'khor ba 'jig dang / gser thub dang / 'od srung gi dri gtsang khang lags so/ / 'di ni bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa'i dri gtsang khang lags so/ /

Smiling at one another, the nāgas and their nāga women watched in amazement as they invited the venerable Saṅgharakṣita to pay homage to a set of shrines, saying, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, this shall be the sanctuary of the perfectly awakened Buddha Vipaśyin, while these shall be the sanctuaries of the perfectly awakened Buddhas Śikhin, Viśvabhū, Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, and Kāśyapa. This shall be the sanctuary of the Blessed One Śākyamuni.”[177]

des de dag dang lhan cig mchod rten dag la phyag 'tshal nas klu'i tshogs kyi gung la stan bshams pa nyid la 'dug go/ / de nas klu de rnams kyis thal mo sbyar nas gsol ba btab pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho lha dang mi rnams la ni bcom ldan 'das kyi mdo sde dang / ma mo rab tu gnas na/ bdag cag klu rnams ni mi khom par skyes/ log par ltung ba'i lus dang ldan pas/ kye ma 'phags pas bdag cag la mdo sde'i mtha' rab tu gnas par mdzad du gsol/ des de ltar bya'o zhes khas blangs so/ /

After prostrating to the shrines with them, Saṅgharakṣita sat on the seat they had arranged at the center of the assembled nāgas. The nāgas joined their palms and supplicated him: “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, though the Blessed One’s sūtras and mātṛkā have taken root among gods and humans, we nāgas were born into this cursed state with fallen forms! O noble one, please see that the ultimate sūtras take root among us!” Saṅgharakṣita assented with the words, “I shall do just that.”

de nas sprul pa des klu gzhon nu gsum spro ba bskyed nas gcig la smras pa/ re zhig khyod kyis ni yang dag par ldan pa lhogs shig /gnyis pa la smras pa/ khyod kyis ni bar ma lhogs shig /gsum pa la smras pa/ khyod kyis ni ring po lhogs shig / kho bos kyang gcig las 'phros pa'i lung brjod pa'i skabs de dag nyid la gsal bar bya'o/ /

The shape shifter who had fled his seaside monastery for the land of the nāgas after being confronted by the group of six then chose three nāga youths and said to the first, “You shall memorize [F.103.b] the Saṃyuktāgama.” To the second he said, “You shall memorize the Madhyamāgama.” To the third he said, “You shall memorize the Dīrghāgama. The nāgas can learn how to recite the Ekottarikāgama by listening to me recite it.”[178]
de dag gis bklag par brtsams nas de na gcig ni mig btsums te lung nod par byed do/ / gnyis pa ni rgyab kyis phyogs te lung nod par byed do/ / gsum pa ni thag ring por 'dug ste lung nod par byed do/ /

When the young nāgas began to recite, the first closed his eyes as he sought to memorize the Saṃyuktāgama, the second turned his back as he sought to memorize the Madhyamāgama, while the third sat off in the distance as he sought to memorize the Dīrghāgama.

de dag gi nang nas sprul pa de nyid ni sngon gyi bag chags kyi khyad par gyis gus pa dang bcas pa dang / zhe sa dang bcas pa dang / 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la thog mar 'gro ba yin pas de nang bar sngar langs te/ 'phags pa bzhengs la tshems shing 'or cig /bcom ldan 'das kyi dkyil 'khor dang mchod rten la phyag mdzod cig /bshos gsol cig /gzims mal shoms shig ces smra bar byed do/ /

Because the shape shifter had greater exposure to Buddhist customs than the others, he was respectful, deferential, and came first to all of their chores. He would rise early and say, “Noble ones, get up and brush your teeth. Pay homage to the gathering of blessed ones and their shrines. Eat and make the bed.”

ji tsam na de thams cad kyis rim gyis lung rnams bklags pa dang / sprul pa des smras pa/ 'phags pa 'di dag gis lung rnams bklags na ci 'dzin tam 'on te mi 'dzin/ des smras pa/ 'di dag dran pa dang ldan pas 'dzin par ni 'gyur na 'di ltar 'di dag la nyes pa yod do/ /

Once, as they were all reciting their respective Āgamas, the shape shifter said, “Noble one, if nāga youths recite the Āgamas, will they remember them or not?” Saṅgharakṣita replied, “Even if with their good memories they remember them, they still have certain flaws.”

des smras pa/ 'phags pa nongs pa ci mchis/ 'di dag thams cad gus pa med pa dang zhe sa med pa yin te/ re zhig gcig ni mig btsums te lung nod par byed/ gnyis pa ni rgyab kyis phyogs te lung nod par byed/ gsum pa ni thag ring por 'dug ste lung nod par byed do/ / khyod 'ba' zhig gus pa dang bcas pa dang / zhe sa dang bcas pa dang 'phral gyi bya ba thams cad la thog mar 'gro ba yin no/ /

“Noble one,” the shape shifter asked, “what are their failings?” “They lack respect and deference. The first closes his eyes as he seeks to memorize the Saṃyuktāgama, the second turns his back as he seeks to memorize the Madhyamāgama, while the third sits off in the distance as he seeks to memorize the Dīrghāgama. You alone are respectful, deferential, and come first to all of your chores.”

des smras pa/ 'phags pa de dag ni gus pa ma mchis pa dang / zhe sa ma mchis pa ma lags te/ re zhig mig btsums te lung nod pa gang lags pa ni mig gdug pa lags so/ / rgyab kyis phyogs te lung nod pa gang lags pa ni dbugs gdug pa lags so/ / thag ring por mchis te lung nod pa gang lags pa de ni reg pa gdug pa lags so/ / bdag gcig pu ni mche ba gdug pa lags so/ /

“Noble one,” the shape shifter replied, “it is not that they lack respect and deference. The one who closes his eyes as he seeks to memorize the Saṃyuktāgama has noxious eyes that burn; the one who turns his back as he seeks to memorize the Madhyamāgama has noxious breath; and the one who sits off in the distance as he seeks to memorize the Dīrghāgama [F.104.a] has a noxious touch. I myself have noxious fangs.”

de nas tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho skrag nas bsams pa/ bdag kho bo dgra bo rnams kyi nang na 'dug pa lta snyam nas/ de skya bo bseng bseng po/ rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang skam pa dang lus ma thob par gyur to/ / klu sprul pas smras pa/ 'phags pa khyod ci'i slad du skya bo bseng bseng po/ / rid pa dang / nyam chung ba dang / rke ba dang / skam pa dang / lus ma thob par gyur/ des smras pa/ kho bo ni dgra bo rnams kyi nang na 'dug ste gang gi tshe khyed cag las gang yang rung ba zhig 'khrugs par gyur pa de'i tshe na kho bo ming tsam zhig lus par 'gyur ro/ /

Frightened, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita thought, “Look! I am living among my mortal enemies,” and he grew pallid, emaciated, feeble, withered, thin, and weak. The shape-shifting nāga asked, “Noble one, why have you become pallid, emaciated, feeble, withered, thin, and weak?” “I am among enemies so the moment I do anything to upset you, I shall be reduced to naught but a memory.”

des smras pa/ bdag cag 'phags pa la gnod pa mi bgyid de/ 'di ltar 'phags pa slar 'dzam bu'i gling du gshegs bzhed dam ci/ des smras pa/ bzhin bzangs kho bo 'di na dga' ba med pas 'gro 'dod do/ / de nas klu de rnams kyis phan tshun gros byas te/ gang gi tshe gru bo che de phyogs der 'ongs pa de'i tshe na 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bteg ste gru bo che'i nang du bzhag go/ /

“We do not intend to harm the noble one. However, given the situation, does the noble one wish to return to Jambudvīpa?” “My dear sir, I do. I do not care for this place.” The nāgas discussed the matter among themselves and when the noble Saṅgharakṣita’s ship passed by on its return journey, they raised him from the waters and placed him on board the ship.

de nas tshong pa de dag 'dzum pa sngon du btang ste ya mtshan skyes nas mig tshugs su lta zhing smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho byon pa legs so/ / byon pa legs so des smras pa/ shes ldan dag kho bos ni klu'i gnas su klu rnams la lung bzhi po dag rab tu gnas par byas kyis rjes su yi rang bar gyis shig /de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa 'di lta ste/ gzhan la phan 'dogs pa 'di ni ston pa'i bstan pa la rab tu byung bas bgyi ba lags te rjes su yi rang ngo / /

Smiles broke out upon the merchants’ faces as they stared in amazement and cried out, “Welcome back, noble Saṅgharakṣita, welcome back!” Saṅgharakṣita said, “Gentlemen! Rejoice, for I have seen to it that the Four Āgamas have taken root in the land of nāgas!” “Noble one, we do! We rejoice in this good you have done for others, for this is the job of those who go forth.”

de nas tshong pa de dag tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho dang lhan cig tshogs shing kun dga' bzhin du mthar gyis rgya mtsho'i 'gram du phyin to/ / ji tsam na thams cad ngal zhing dub pas gnyid log pa na tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho yang rgya mtsho chen po la blta bar brtsams so/ /

Reunited and happy, the merchants and the venerable Saṅgharakṣita completed the journey back to shore. On arriving, all were tired and weary. As his companions slept, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita turned his gaze to the ocean. [F.104.b]

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong dag lnga po 'di dag ni blta bas chog mi shes shing mthong na mi mthun pa med pa yin te/ lnga gang zhe na/ dge slong dag glang po che cang shes gzhon sha can dang / 'khor los sgyur ba'i rgyal po dang / rgya mtsho dug can pa dang / ri'i rgyal rgyal po ri rab dang / de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ni blta bas chog mi shes shing mthong na mi mthun pa med pa yin no zhes gsungs pas/

The Blessed One has said, “Monks, there are five things one never tires of looking at and which are in no way displeasing to the eye. What are the five? One never tires of looking at a clever and youthful elephant; a king of the world; the ocean with its monsters; Sumeru, the king of mountains; and a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha‍—these five things are in no way displeasing to the eye.”

de yun ring du rgya mtsho chen po la lta ba na dub pas tho rangs gnyid stug pos non to/ / de nas tshong pa de dag khal dag bkal te 'phags nas mtshan mo nam nangs pa na tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho mi snang nas/ de dag brtad cing shes ldan dag 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho ga re zhes phan tshun du blta bar brtsams pa dang /

Saṅgharakṣita gazed long at the ocean until just before dawn when, fatigued, he was overcome by a deep sleep. Not long after, the merchants loaded the pack animals and set out. But because it was in the wee hours of the morning, they could not see the venerable Saṅgharakṣita and they began to look and ask one another, “Gentlemen, what has happened to the noble Saṅgharakṣita?”

de na kha cig na re mdun du song ngo zhes zer ro/ / kha cig na re phyi bzhin 'ong ngo zhes zer ro/ / kha cig na re dbus nas 'gro'o zhes zer ro/ / de dag rnam pa thams cad du kun du tshol ba na yi chad par gyur cing ma mthong ngo / / de nas de dag bzhin nyams shing dman par gyur te smras pa/ shes ldan dag bdag cag gis 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bor ba ma legs pa byas kyis phyir ldog par bya'o/ /

Some suggested he had gone ahead while others said he was still coming from behind and still others said he was traveling in the middle of the caravan. After searching everywhere to no avail, they gave up. Dispirited and downcast, they said, “Gentlemen, it is not good that we have left the noble Saṅgharakṣita behind. We must turn around.”

yang bsams pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho ni rdzu 'phrul che ba mthu che ba yin pas 'di ltar rgya mtsho chen por yang dus la ma bab na de da lta skam la phyin na dus la bab par ga la 'gyur/ de ni rdzu 'phrul che ba mthu che ba yin pas de ches sngon du song ba gang yin pa de lta bu'i gnas yod do snyam nas

But then, on reflection, it occurred to them, “The noble Saṅgharakṣita possesses miraculous powers and great might. If he did not meet his end in the ocean, how could he meet his end while traveling on dry land? With his miraculous powers and great might, he must have gone far ahead of us and be waiting there now.”
smras pa/ shes ldan dag tshur sheg 'dong zhes de dag 'phags so/ /
With the call, “Gentlemen, come, let us go!” they set out.
[rnam smin mngon sum]

d.crumb: Saṅgharakṣita sees the effects of actions with his own eyes

f.d: Saṅgharakṣita sees the effects of actions with his own eyes

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho yang bye ma'i thang stong pa la nyi ma 'char ba'i dus kyi tshe nyi ma'i 'od zer dag gis phog nas sad pa dang / ji tsam na ci yang mi snang nas des bsams pa/ tshong pa de dag ni dong na da ji ltar bya/ gar bab bab tu 'gro'o snyam mo/ /

When the sun rose, its rays struck the venerable Saṅgharakṣita as he lay asleep on the empty, sandy beach, waking him from his slumber. Seeing no one around, he thought, “What will I do if the merchants have left? They might have gone in any direction!”

tshe dang ldan pa de snying stobs che bas song ba dang lam mi snang nas des phan tshun btsal nas lam srang zhig mthong nas de der zhugs pa dang / ji tsam na sa la'i dgon pa zhig na gtsug lag khang rta babs mthon po dang ldan pa/ mthongs khung dang / skar khung dra ba can dang / lan kan gyis brgyan pa/ snying dang mig 'phrog par byed pa/ mtho ris kyi them skas su gyur pa/ khri dang khri'u dang yo byad phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa/ shing ljon pa sna tshogs kyis bskor ba/ rdzing bu dang mtshe'us nye bar mdzes par byas pa/ ngang pa dang / khrung khrung dang / rma bya dang / ne tsho dang / ri skegs dang / khu byug mngon par sgra 'byin pa/ lha'i gnas ltar dpal gyis 'bar ba zhig dang / de na dge slong legs par bgos shing legs par sbyangs pa/ spyod lam zhi bas gnas pa dag mthong nas gus pa dang bcas pas de dag gi gan du song ngo / /

With great courage, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita set out but he could see no trail. [F.105.a] After searching about, he spied a narrow path and set off upon it. After a time, he saw, in a forest of śāla trees, a monastery with a high gate, skylights, and latticed windows. It was adorned with balustrades, beguiling to the heart and beautiful to the eye, with a staircase to the upper level and perfectly outfitted with beds, seats, and supplies. It was surrounded by a variety of trees, and graced with pools and ponds, ringing with the sounds of swans, cranes, peacocks, parrots, mynahs, and cuckoos. When he saw the monks, finely dressed and well trained, living peacefully in this glorious and heavenly abode, he respectfully approached them.

de nas de dag gus par sgrim pa dang bcas pas de la smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho byon pa legs so byon pa legs so khyod da gzod ga las byon/ des ji ltar gyur pa thams cad brjod pa dang / de nas de dag gis ngal sor bcug ste/ lam gyi dub pa bsal nas gtsug lag khang du khrid do/ / ji tsam na stan bzang po bshams pa dang / kha zas bsod pa'i spyi bungs bshams pa mthong nas de dag gis de la smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho mi skyems sam/ mi sbrebs sam/

With a show of respect, they said to him, “Welcome, reverend Saṅgharakṣita, welcome. From where have you come just now?” After he explained everything that had happened, they let him rest and once he recovered from the fatigue of the road, they led him into the monastery. [S.43.a] Once there, he saw that fine seats had been arranged and choice foods laid out. They asked him, “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, are you not thirsty? Are you not hungry?”

des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag skom mo/ /bkres so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho gsol cig / des smras pa/ dge 'dun gyi nang du bza'o/ / de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho khyod shul gyis dub pa lags kyis da gsol cig /slad kyis 'dir nyes dmigs 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Venerables,” he replied, “I am thirsty and I am hungry.” “Then partake, reverend Saṅgharakṣita.” “I will eat with the saṅgha.” “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, you are tired from your travels, so eat now. Later the food will have spoiled.”

des nyes dmigs mthong bas zos nas mtha' gcig tu song ste 'dug go/ / ji tsam na de dag dro la bab ste/ gaN+DI brdungs pa na rang rang gi lhung bzed thogs te gral rims bzhin 'khod do/ / de dag 'khod pa dang gtsug lag khang de yang mi snang bar gyur cing de dag gi rang rang gi lhung bzed kyang lcags kyi tho ba rnam pa sna tshogs su gyur to/ / de nas de dag ji srid du dro ma yol gyi bar du lcags kyi tho ba de dag gis phan tshun glad pa bcom nas de dag glad pa zhom zhing sdug bsngal gyi tshor bas nyen nas nyam thag pa'i skad 'byin to/ /

Seeing the drawback in waiting, Saṅgharakṣita ate and then took a seat off to one side. Some time later, the meal was laid out and when the gaṇḍī beam was struck, the monks filed in, each carrying his own begging bowl, and sat down in order of seniority. As soon as they sat down, the monastery vanished [F.105.b] and each of their begging bowls turned into iron clubs of different sorts. For the remainder of the meal, they bludgeoned each other over the head with their iron clubs, cracking their skulls open and inflicting unbearable pain that caused them to cry out pitifully.

ji tsam na dro yol ba dang gtsug lag khang de yang de kho na bzhin du phyir byung zhing dge slong de dag kyang de kho na bzhin du spyod lam zhi bas gnas so/ / de nas tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho de dag gi gan du song ste dris pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag khyed su yin/ las gang gis 'dir skyes/ de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'dzam bu'i gling pa'i mi rnams ni yid ches par dka' bas khyed yid ches par mi 'gyur ro/ / des smras pa/ kho bos mngon sum kho nar mthong na ci'i phyir yid ches par mi 'gyur/

As soon as the mealtime ended, the monastery reappeared as before while the monks also resumed their peaceful demeanors. The venerable Saṅgharakṣita approached them and asked, “Who are you, venerables? What karma has led you to this?” “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita,” they replied, “the people of Jambudvīpa are skeptical, so you will not believe us.” “Why would I not believe what I have seen with my own eyes?”

de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gi nyan thos su gyur te/ ji tsam na bdag cag gis zan gyi gral du 'thab mo bgyis pas las de'i rnam par smin pas bdag cag nyi tshe ba'i sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang du skyes te/ bdag cag 'di nas shi 'phos pa dag sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang du skye bar 'gyur ba gang lags pa de lta bu'i gnas kyang mchis par 'gyur ro/ / btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho de'i slad du 'dzam bu'i gling du gshegs nas tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams la tshe dang ldan pa dag 'di lta ste/ dper na 'od srung gi dge slong dag ltar zan gyi gral du thab mo ma byed cig /sdug bsngal gyi tshogs de lta bu'i skal ba can du 'gyur bar ma byed cig ces don 'di rgya cher brjod na legs so/ /

“Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, we were disciples of the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. While in the meal queue, we fought and, as the fruition of that karma, have been born as denizens of an ephemeral hell. As soon as we die and pass from this life, we will be reborn among the denizens of hell and will have to live there in such straits. Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, once you have returned to Jambudvīpa, say to your fellow brahmacārin, ‘Venerables, do not fight in the food queue like Kāśyapa’s monks. Do not act so as to accrue the fortune for that mass of suffering.’ It would be good if you were you to explain our plight at length.”

des de ltar bya'o zhes khas blangs te song ngo / / ji tsam na de kho na bzhin du sa la'i dgon pa zhig na gtsug lag khang gnyis pa rta babs mthon po dang ldan pa/ mthongs khung dang / skar khung dra ba can dang / lan kan gyis brgyan pa/ snying dang mig 'phrog par byed pa/ mtho ris kyi them skas su gyur pa/ khri dang khri'u dang yo byad phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa/ shing ljon pa sna tshogs kyis bskor ba/ rdzing bu dang mtshe'us nye bar mdzes par byas pa/ ngang pa dang / khrung khrung dang / rma bya dang / ne tso dang / ri skegs dang / khu byug dag mngon par sgra 'byin pa/ lha'i gnas ltar dpal gyis 'bar ba zhig dang / de na dge slong legs par bgos shing legs par sbyangs pa/ spyod lam zhi bas gnas pa dag mthong nas gus pa dang bcas pas de dag gi gan du song ngo / /

After agreeing to do just that, Saṅgharakṣita departed. After some time, he saw again as before, in a forest of śāla trees, a second monastery with a high gate, skylights, and latticed windows. It was adorned with balustrades, beguiling to the heart and beautiful to the eye, with a staircase to the upper level, and perfectly outfitted [F.106.a] with beds, seats, and supplies. It was surrounded by a variety of trees, and graced with pools and ponds, ringing with the sounds of swans, cranes, peacocks, parrots, mynahs, and cuckoos. When he saw the monks, finely dressed and well trained, living peacefully in this glorious and heavenly abode, he respectfully approached them.

From where have you come just now?” After he explained everything that had happened, they let him rest and once he recovered from the fatigue of the road, they led him into the monastery. Once there, he saw that fine seats had been arranged and choice foods laid out. They asked him, “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, are you not thirsty? Are you not hungry?”

“Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, we were disciples of the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. Once the saṅgha had received a supply of rich food and when a group of arriving monks turned up, those of us overcome by greed thought and even said, ‘We should not serve the food until the arriving monks have left.’ For seven days, an unseasonable rain fell, spoiling the food and drink, leaving it unsuitable for consumption. Thus we wasted what had been given in faith and, as the fruition of that karma, have been born as denizens of an ephemeral hell. As soon as we die and pass from this life, we will be reborn among the denizens of a great hell and will have to live there in such straits. Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, once you have returned to Jambudvīpa, say to your fellow brahmacārin, ‘Venerables, do not waste what has been given in faith like Kāśyapa’s monks. Do not act so as to accrue the fortune for that mass of suffering.’ It would be well were you to explain our plight at length.”

des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag skom mo/ /bkres so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho gsol cig /des smras pa/ dge 'dun gyi nang du bza'o/ / de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho khyod shul gyis mnyel ba lags kyis da gsol cig /slad kyis 'dir nyes dmigs 'byung bar 'gyur ro/ /

“Venerables, I am thirsty and I am hungry.” “Then partake, reverend Saṅgharakṣita.” “I will eat with the saṅgha.” “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, you are fatigued from your travels, so eat now. Later the food will have spoiled.”

des nyes dmigs mthong bas zos nas mtha' gcig tu song ste 'dug go/ / ji tsam na de dag dro la bab ste gaN+DI brdungs na rang rang gi lhung bzed thogs te gral rims bzhin du 'khod do/ / de dag 'khod pa dang de dag gi gtsug lag khang de 'bar rab tu 'bar kun du rab tu 'bar zhing me lce gcig tu gyur nas sreg par brtsams so/ / de nas de dag ji srid du dro ma yol gyi bar du me lce des bsregs nas de dag lus tshig cing sdug bsngal gyi tshor bas nyen nas nyam thag pa'i skad 'byin to/ /

Seeing the drawback in waiting, he ate and then took a seat off to one side. Some time later, the meal was laid out and when the gaṇḍī beam was struck, the monks filed in, each carrying his own begging bowl, and sat down in order of seniority. As soon as they sat down, the monastery caught alight, burst into flames, and was engulfed in a fire that began to burn as a single, giant inferno. [S.44.a] For the remainder of the meal, the fire raged, burning their bodies and inflicting unbearable pain that caused them to cry out pitifully.

ji tsam na dro yol ba dang gtsug lag khang de yang de kho na bzhin du phyir byung zhing dge slong de dag kyang de kho na bzhin du spyod lam zhi bas gnas so/ / de nas tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho de dag gi gan du song ste dris pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag khyed su yin/ las gang gis 'dir skyes/ de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho 'dzam bu'i gling pa'i mi rnams ni yid ches par dka' bas khyed yid ches par mi 'gyur ro/ / des smras pa/ kho bos mngon sum kho nar mthong na ci'i phyir yid ches par mi 'gyur/

As soon as the mealtime ended, the monastery reappeared as before while the monks [F.107.b] also resumed their peaceful demeanors. The venerable Saṅgharakṣita approached them and asked, “Who are you, venerables? What karma has led you to this?” “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita,” they replied, “the people of Jambudvīpa are skeptical, so you will not believe us.” “Why would I not believe what I have seen with my own eyes?”

de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gi nyan thos su gyur te/ ji tsam na bdag cag tshul khrims 'chal ba dang sdig pa'i chos can du gyur nas/ dge slong tshul khrims dang ldan pa rnams kyis bdag cag gtsug lag khang nas bskrad pa dang bdag cag gtsug lag khang stong pa zhig tu 'khod do/ / ji tsam na dge slong tshul khrims dang ldan pa gcig cig rgyu ba na der phyin pa dang / de nas bdag cag la blo skyes pa/ 'di gcig pus bdag cag gi yon sbyong bar 'gyur gyis 'dug la rag go snyam pa dang / de de nyid du 'dug go/ / ji tsam na de'i zhar gyis yang dge slong tshul khrims dang ldan pa mang po dag lhags nas de dag gis bdag cag de nas bskrad do/ / de nas bdag cag mi bzod pa skyes pa dag gis shing dang / rtswa dang / lci ba skam po dag bcer te gtsug lag khang la me btang nas der dge slong bslab pa 'dod pa mang po dag bsregs pas las de'i rnam par smin pas bdag cag nyi tshe ba'i sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang du skyes te/ bdag cag 'di nas shi 'phos pa dang sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang du skye bar 'gyur ba gang lags pa de lta bu'i gnas kyang mchis par 'gyur ro/ / btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho de'i slad du 'dzam bu'i gling du gshegs nas tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams la tshe dang ldan pa dag 'di lta ste/ dper na 'od srung gi dge sbyong ltar tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa dag la sdang ba'i sems ma skyed cig /sdug bsngal gyi tshogs de lta bu'i skal ba can du 'gyur bar ma byed cig ces don 'di rgya cher brjod na legs so/ /

“Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, we were disciples of the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. In time, our ethics became lax and we became dissolute. When the ethical monks evicted us from the monastery, we took up in an empty monastery. After a while, an ethical monk happened by, which gave us an idea. We thought, ‘He alone can purify patronage.[179] We must get him to stay,’ and so he stayed. And in time, as a result of that, many ethical monks gathered there, who then proceeded to evict us. Those of us who could not bear this piled wood, straw, and dried dung and set fire to the monastery, burning many of the monks intent on training there. As the fruition of that karma, we have been born as denizens of an ephemeral hell. As soon as we die and pass from this life, we will be reborn among the denizens of hell and will have to live there in such straits. Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, once you have returned to Jambudvīpa, say to your fellow brahmacārin, ‘Venerables, do not nurse hatred for your fellow brahmacārin as Kāśyapa’s monks did. Do not act so as to accrue the fortune for that mass of suffering.’ It would be well were you to explain our plight at length.” [F.108.a]

des de ltar bya'o zhes khas blangs te song ngo / / ji tsam na sems can rtsig pa 'dra ba dag dang / ka ba 'dra ba dag dang / shing ljon pa 'dra ba dag dang / lo ma 'dra ba dag dang / me tog 'dra ba dag dang / 'bras bu 'dra ba dag dang / thag pa 'dra ba dag dang / phyags ma 'dra ba dag dang / phor pa 'dra ba dag dang / gtun 'dra ba dag dang / phru ba 'dra ba dag dang / rked pa chad pa chu rgyus kyis bzung ba dag 'dong ba yang mthong ngo / /

After agreeing to do just that, Saṅgharakṣita departed. On his journey, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita saw beings shaped like walls, pillars, trees, leaves, flowers, fruit, rope, brooms, bowls, mortars and pestles, pots, and even beings cut at the waist, their bodies held together by tendons.[180]
[drang srong lnga brgya]

d.crumb: Saṅgharakṣita’s sermon leads five hundred seers to the truth

f.d: Saṅgharakṣita’s sermon leads five hundred seers to the truth

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho yang mthar gyis ljongs su song ba dang / ji tsam na bsti gnas shig na drang srong lnga brgya tsam 'khod de/ de dag gis tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho thag ring po kho na nas 'ong ba mthong ngo / / de nas de dag gis gros bya bar brtsams pa shes ldan dag nyon cig /shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong 'di dag ni smra ba mang ba yin pas 'di la sus kyang tshig sbyin par mi bya'o zhes

Eventually, the venerable Saṅgharakṣita reached a settlement with an ashram where there lived five hundred seers. The seers saw the venerable Saṅgharakṣita approaching from off in the distance and began to confer with one another: “Listen, gentlemen. These ascetic sons of the Śākya tend to preach a great deal. Let none of us offer a single word in response.”

de dag gis khrims su bya ba bcas te 'khod do/ / tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho yang spyod lam zhi bas de dag gi gan du song ste bsti gnas brnya bar brtsams pa na 'gas kyang tshig ma ster to/ / de na drang srong bsod nams 'dod pa gcig cig gis smras pa/ khyod la ci'i phyir bsti gnas mi brnyan te 'di ltar khyed la nyes pa yod do/ / khyed ni smra ba mang ba yin no/ / de lta mod kyi dam tshig gis brnya bar bya ste/ gal te cung zad kyang mi smra na brnyan no/ /

Having made this pact, they remained where they were. With a peaceful demeanor, Saṅgharakṣita approached them, but when he requested a place to stay, they gave not a word in response. A single seer, intent on merit, said, “Why do we not give you a place to stay? It is because you have a fault. You tend to preach a lot. You must therefore swear an oath: I will give you a place if you refrain from giving even the slightest sermon.”

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos smras pa/ drang srong de bzhin du byas mi smra'o/ / de na drang srong gcig cig ljongs rgyur song ba de'i spyil bu stong par 'dug pa de tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho la 'dir nyol cig ces brnyan no/ / tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos spyil bu de chag chag btab/ phyag dar byas/ ba lang gi lci ba sar pas byug pa byas so/ / de dag gis de mthong nas de dag gis smras pa/ shes ldan dag shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong 'di dag ni gtsang sbra byed pa yin no/ /

“Seer, as you instruct, I shall not preach,” replied Saṅgharakṣita. The seer took Saṅgharakṣita to an unoccupied thatched hut in the settlement and told him he could sleep there. Saṅgharakṣita sprinkled water on, swept, and applied fresh cow dung to the dirt floor of the thatched hut.[181] On seeing this, the seers said, “Gentlemen, these ascetic sons of the Śākya are sanitary.” [S.44.b]

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos spyil bu'i phyi rol du rkang pa gnyis bkrus te spyil bur zhugs nas skyil mo krung bcas te lus drang por bsrang nas dran pa phyogs par bzhag ste 'dug go/ / de nas bsti gnas de na lha mo zhig 'dug pa gang yin pa de mtshan mo thun dang po la tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho ga la ba der song ste phyin nas des smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho chos bstan du gsol/

Saṅgharakṣita washed his feet outside the thatched hut before going back inside. Sitting down, he crossed his legs, held his body erect, [F.108.b] and rested in mindfulness. A goddess living in the ashram went to the venerable Saṅgharakṣita during the evening watch and said, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, please teach the Dharma.”

des smras pa/ lha mo khyod bde bar gyur cig /kho bos khrims su bya bas bsti gnas rnyed pa khyod kyis ma mthong ngam/ ci kho bo bskrad par 'dod dam/ des bsams pa/ rab tu byung ba 'di ngal gyis 'di ltar gung thun la 'ong bar bya'o snyam nas de gung thun la 'ongs te smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho chos bstan du gsol/ des smras pa/ sring mo khyod kha rog mi sdod pas kho bo nges par bskrad par 'dod dam/

“Goddess, I wish you well but did you not see I received this resting place by making a pact? Would you like me to be kicked out?” The goddess thought, “This renunciant is tired, so I shall return during the night watch.” She returned during the night watch and said, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, please teach the Dharma.” “Sister, you just can’t leave it be! You must want me to be kicked out!”

des bsams pa/ rab tu byung ba 'di da dung gnyid kyis myos kyis thun tha ma la 'ong bar bya'o snyam nas de thun tha ma la 'ongs te smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho ci'i slad du gzims/ mtshan mo'i dgung sangs kyis bzhengs la chos bstan du gsol/ des smras pa/ sring mo khyod kyis kho bo rnam pa thams cad du bskrad do/ /

She thought, “This renunciant is still groggy from sleep. I shall return during the final watch.” She returned during the final watch and said, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, why do you sleep? I woke you in the middle of the night and asked you to teach the Dharma.” “Sister, you are trying by every means to get me kicked out!”

des smras pa/ 'phags pa mtshan mo'i dgung sangs pas gal te bskrad na yang cir 'gyur bzhud do 'tshal/ 'di ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis 'jigs pa dang 'jigs su rung ba bzod par bya'o zhes bka' ma stsal tam/ tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos bsams pa/ sring mo 'di zer ba ni bden te/ gal te kho bo bskrad na 'gro la rag gis 'di ltar 'di dag ni bram ze yin pas bram ze dang yang dag par ldan pa'i tshigs su bcad pa brjod par bya'o snyam nas/ des bram ze'i sde tshan 'di skad ces/

“Noble one, the darkness of night has passed. Even if you were kicked out, why would it matter? You’d be seeking to leave soon anyway. Did the Blessed One not say you must face your fears along with what provokes them?” “Sister, what you say is true. I must get going regardless of whether I am kicked out. Since these people are brahmins, I should recite a verse the brahmins themselves take to be true.” Saṅgharakṣita then began to recite the Brāhmaṇavarga:[182]

som nyi ma rgal gcer bu'i spyod pa dang / / ral pa rdzab dang sna tshogs zas dang ni/ / thang la nyal dang rdul dang dri ma dang / / tsog bu'i spong bas mi dag 'byung mi 'gyur/ / 'byung po kun la 'tshe ba rnam spangs te/ / chos spyod zhi dul yang dag sdom pa dang / / tshangs spyod ldan pa rgyan gyis brgyan gyur kyang / / de nyid bram ze dge sbyong dge slong yin/ / zhes kha ton bya bar brtsams so/ /

de dag gis de thos nas de dag gis bsams pa/ bram ze dang yang dag par ldan pa'i tshigs su bcad pa zer ro snyam nas gcig nye bar 'ongs so/ / de bzhin du gnyis pa dang / gsum pa nas de dag thams cad kyi bar du nye bar lhags pa dang / lha mo des ci nas kyang de dag gcig gis gcig mi mthong ba de ltar byin gyis brlabs so/ / de'i 'og tu tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos grong khyer lta bu'i mdo gdon par brtsams so/ /

On hearing this verse, the seers thought, “This monk’s verses express the real meaning of ‘brahmin.’ ” One seer drew near, then a second and a third, until they all surrounded him, at which point the goddess charmed them so they could not see one another. After that Saṅgharakṣita began to recite the Nagaropama Sūtra:[184]

'di skad bdag gis thos pa dus gcig na/ bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal bu rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag sngon nga rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par rdzogs par sangs ma rgyas pa'i tshe gcig pu dben par song ste nang du yang dag bzhag pa na sems la sems kyi yongs su rtog pa 'di lta bu byung ste/ kye ma 'jig rten 'di sdug bsngal bar gyur te/ 'di lta ste skye bar 'gyur/ rga bar 'gyur 'chi bar 'gyur/ nyams par 'gyur/ 'byung bar 'gyur yang 'on kyang sems can 'di dag gis rga shi bas bla ma yod bzhin du nges par 'byung ba yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin rab tu mi shes so snyam nas

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī. The Blessed One said to the monks, “Monks, before I achieved perfect awakening and became a perfect buddha, I went alone into the wild. While inwardly absorbed, this perfect thought arose in my mind: ‘Ah! This world is prone to suffering, for we are born, we age, we die, we deteriorate, and then it all happens again. And though a higher state exists, beings who age and die know nothing of the perfect remedies that exist.’

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na rga shi 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis rga shi 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar skye ba yod na rga shi 'byung zhing skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na skye ba 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis skye ba 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar srid pa yod na skye ba 'byung zhing srid pa'i rkyen gyis skye ba 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for birth to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of birth. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is becoming, there will be birth, and becoming contributes to the occurrence of birth.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na srid pa 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis srid pa 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar len pa yod na srid pa 'byung zhing len pa'i rkyen gyis srid pa 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for becoming to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of becoming. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: [S.45.a] if there is grasping, there will be becoming, and grasping contributes to the occurrence of becoming. [F.109.b]

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na len pa 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis len pa 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar sred pa yod na len pa 'byung zhing sred pa'i rkyen gyis len pa 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for grasping to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of grasping. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is craving, there will be grasping, and craving contributes to the occurrence of grasping.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na sred pa 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis sred pa 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar tshor ba yod na srid pa 'byung zhing tshor ba'i rkyen gyis srid pa 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for craving to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of craving. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is sensation, there will be craving, and sensation contributes to the occurrence of craving.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na tshor ba 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis tshor ba 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar reg pa yod na tshor ba 'byung zhing reg pa'i rkyen gyis tshor ba 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for sensation to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of sensation. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is contact, there will be sensation, and contact contributes to the occurrence of sensation.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na reg pa 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis reg pa 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar skye mched drug yod na reg pa 'byung zhing skye mched drug gi rkyen gyis reg pa 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for contact to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of contact. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there are seats for the six senses, there will be contact, and seats for the six senses contribute to the occurrence of contact.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na skye mched drug 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis skye mched drug 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar ming dang gzugs yod na skye mched drug 'byung zhing ming dang gzugs kyi rkyen gyis skye mched drug 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for the seats of the six senses to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of the seats of the six senses. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there are name and form, there will be seats for the six senses, and name and form contribute to the occurrence of seats for the six senses.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na ming dang gzugs 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis ming dang gzugs 'byung snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar rnam par shes pa yod na ming dang gzugs 'byung zhing rnam par shes pa'i rkyen gyis ming dang gzugs 'byung ngo snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what was needed for name and form to occur and what conditions contribute to the occurrence of name and form. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is consciousness, there will be name and form, and consciousness contributes to the occurrence of name and form.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang yod na rnam par shes pa 'byung zhing rkyen gang gis rnam par shes pa 'byung snyam pa las/ nga'i yid rnam par shes pa nas phyir log cing de phan chad du 'jug par mi byed de/

“I then pondered what was needed for consciousness to occur and [F.110.a] what conditions contribute to the occurrence of consciousness. By reversing the conception of ‘I,’ one will not incite what follows from that.

'di lta ste/ rnam par shes pa'i rkyen gyis ming dang gzugs/ ming dang gzugs kyi rkyen gyis skye mched drug /skye mched drug gi rkyen gyis reg pa/ reg pa'i rkyen gyis tshor ba/ tshor ba'i rkyen gyis sred pa/ sred pa'i rkyen gyis len pa/ len pa'i rkyen gyis srid pa/ srid pa'i rkyen gyis skye ba/ skye ba'i rkyen gyis rga shi dang / mya ngan dang / smre sngags 'don pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / yid mi bde ba dang / 'khrug pa rnams 'byung ste/ de ltar na sdug bsngal gyi phung po chen po 'ba' zhig pa 'di 'byung bar 'gyur ro snyam mo/ /

“Thus consciousness contributes to name and form, name and form contribute to the seats of the six senses, the seats of the six senses contribute to contact, contact contributes to sensation, sensation contributes to craving, craving contributes to grasping, grasping contributes to becoming, becoming contributes to birth, birth contributes to aging and death, and the occurrence of sorrow, lamentation, suffering, unhappiness, and strife. And that is how, I thought, this whole huge mass of suffering comes to be.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na rga shi mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas rga shi 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar skye ba med na rga shi mi 'byung zhing / skye ba 'gags pas rga shi 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for aging and death not to occur and what must cease for aging and death to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no birth, no aging and death will occur, and the cessation of birth arrests aging and death.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na skye ba mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas skye ba 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar srid pa med na skye ba mi 'byung zhing / srid pa 'gags pas skye ba 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for birth not to occur and what must cease for birth to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no becoming, no birth will occur, and the cessation of becoming arrests birth.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na srid pa mi 'byung zhing / gang 'gags pas srid pa/ 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar len pa med na srid pa mi 'byung zhing len pa 'gags pas srid pa 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for becoming not to occur and what must cease for becoming to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no grasping, [S.45.b] no becoming will occur, and the cessation of grasping arrests becoming.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na len pa mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas len pa 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar sred pa med na len pa mi 'byung zhing sred pa 'gags pas len pa 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for grasping not to occur and what must cease for grasping to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no craving, no grasping will occur, and the cessation of craving arrests grasping.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na sred pa mi 'byung zhing / gang 'gags pas sred pa 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar tshor ba med na sred pa mi 'byung zhing tshor ba 'gags pas sred pa 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for craving not [F.110.b] to occur and what must cease for craving to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no sensation, no craving will occur, and the cessation of sensation arrests craving.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na tshor ba mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas tshor ba 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar reg pa med na tshor ba mi 'byung zhing reg pa 'gags pas tshor ba 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for sensation not to occur and what must cease for sensation to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no contact, no sensation will occur, and the cessation of contact arrests sensation.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na reg pa mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas reg pa 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar skye mched drug med na reg pa mi 'byung zhing skye mched drug 'gags pas reg pa 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for contact not to occur and what must cease for contact to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there are no seats for the six senses, no contact will occur, and the cessation of the seats for the six senses arrests contact.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na skye mched drug mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas skye mched drug 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar ming dang gzugs med na skye mched drug mi 'byung zhing ming dang gzugs 'gags pas skye mched drug 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for the seats of the six senses not to occur and what must cease for the seats of the six senses to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there are no name and form, no seats of the six senses will occur, and the cessation of name and form arrests the seats of the six senses.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na ming dang gzugs mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas ming dang gzugs 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar rnam par shes pa med na ming dang gzugs mi 'byung zhing rnam par shes pa 'gags pas ming dang gzugs 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for name and form not to occur and what must cease for name and form to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no consciousness, no name and form will occur, and the cessation of consciousness arrests name and form.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na rnam par shes pa mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas rnam par shes pa 'gag go snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar 'du byed rnams med na rnam par shes pa mi 'byung zhing 'du byed rnams 'gags pas rnam par shes pa 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for consciousness not to occur and what must cease for consciousness to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no conditioning, no consciousness will occur, and the cessation of conditioning arrests consciousness.

nga 'di snyam du sems te/ gang med na 'du byed rnams mi 'byung zhing gang 'gags pas 'du byed rnams 'gag snyam du nga tshul bzhin yid la byed pa na/ 'di ltar ma rig pa med na 'du byed rnams mi 'byung zhing ma rig pa 'gags pas 'du byed rnams 'gag go snyam du yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin mngon par rtogs par gyur to/ /

“I then pondered what must be absent for conditioning [F.111.a] not to occur and what must cease for conditioning to cease. On proper reflection, I realized this perfectly and as it is: if there is no ignorance, no conditioning will occur, and the cessation of ignorance arrests conditioning.

'di lta ste ma rig pa 'gags pas 'du byed rnams 'gag 'du byed rnams 'gags pas rnam par shes pa 'gag /rnam par shes pa 'gags pas ming dang gzugs 'gag /ming dang gzugs 'gags pas skye mched drug 'gag /skye mched drug 'gags pas reg pa 'gag /reg pa 'gags pas tshor ba 'gag /tshor ba 'gags pas sred pa 'gag /sred pa 'gags pas len pa 'gag /len pa 'gags pas srid pa 'gag /srid pa 'gags pas skye ba 'gag /skye ba 'gags pas rga shi dang / mya ngan dang / smre sngags 'don pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / yid mi bde ba dang / 'khrug pa rnams 'gag ste/ de ltar na sdug bsngal gyi phung po 'ba' zhig pa 'di 'gag par 'gyur ro snyam mo// //

“Thus the cessation of ignorance arrests conditioning, the cessation of conditioning arrests consciousness, the cessation of consciousness arrests name and form, the cessation of name and form arrests the seats of the six senses, the cessation of the seats of the six senses arrests contact, the cessation of contact arrests sensation, the cessation of sensation arrests craving, the cessation of craving arrests grasping, the cessation of grasping arrests becoming, the cessation of becoming arrests birth, the cessation of birth arrests aging and death, and sorrow, lamentation, suffering, unhappiness, and strife. And that is how, I thought, this whole huge mass of suffering comes to cease.
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po bcu pa/

dge slong dag nga 'di snyam du sems te ngas sngon gyi lam dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi lam srol sngon gyi drang srong rnams gshegs shing rjes su 'dong ba rnyed do snyam mo/ / 'di lta ste dper na mi zhig dgon pa nags mchog tu 'khyam zhing 'gro ba na sngon gyi lam dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi lam srol sngon gyi mi rnams dong zhing rjes su 'dong ba zhig rnyed nas de de'i rjes su song ba dang / sngon gyi grong khyer dang / sngon gyi rgyal po'i pho brang kun dga' ra ba phun sum tshogs pa/ tshal phun sum tshogs pa/ rdzing bu phun sum tshogs pa/ bzang ba nags dang ldan pa/ dga' bar 'gyur ba zhig mthong zhing mthong nas kyang de 'di snyam du sems te/ bdag rgyal po'i gan du song ste brjod par bya'o snyam nas/ de rgyal po'i gan du song ste lha mkhyen par mdzod cig /'di na bdag dgon pa nags mchog cig tu 'khyam zhing mchi ba na sngon gyi shul dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi shul srol sngon gyi mi rnams mchis shing rjes su mchi ba zhig rnyed nas bdag de'i rjes su mchis pa dang / sngon gyi grong khyer dang / sngon gyi rgyal po'i pho brang kun dga' ra ba phun sum tshogs pa/ tshal phun sum tshogs pa/ rdzing bu phun sum tshogs pa/ bzang ba nags dang ldan pa/ dga' bar 'gyur ba zhig mthong ste lhas de grong khyer bgyid du gsol la/ de rgyal po'i pho brang bgyid du stsol cig dang / dus gzhan na de rgyal po'i pho brang 'byor pa/ rgyas pa/ bde ba/ lo legs pa/ skye bo dang mi mang pos bltam par 'gyur ro zhes zer ba

“Monks, I thought of this as an old path I had found, an old [S.46.a] route, an old trail which seers of old have traveled and traversed. It is analogous to this: Say that a person wanders, passing through a great forest, and discovers an old path, an old route, an old trail which people of old have traveled and traversed and he follows it until he sees an old city and a king’s delightful old palace, with its resplendent gardens, resplendent parks, resplendent pools, and fine hedges. On seeing it, he thinks, “I shall go and speak to the king!” He goes to the king and says, “Your majesty, please grant me your attention. I was wandering, passing through a great forest, [F.111.b] when I discovered an old path, an old route, an old trail which people of old have traveled and traversed and I followed it until I saw an old city and the king’s delightful old palace, with its resplendent gardens, resplendent parks, resplendent pools, and fine hedges. Your Majesty, allow me to restore the city, allow me to restore the king’s palace.” In time, the king’s palace prospers and thrives, crops are bountiful and the land teems with animals and people.

de bzhin du dge slong dag ngas kyang sngon gyi lam dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi lam srol sngon gyi drang srong rnams gshegs shing rjes su 'dong ba rnyed do/ / dge slong dag sngon gyi lam dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi lam srol sngon drang srong rnams gshegs shing rjes su 'dong ba de gang zhe na/ 'di lta ste/ 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa 'di lta ste/ yang dag pa'i lta ba dang / yang dag pa'i rtog pa dang / yang dag pa'i ngag dang / yang dag pa'i las kyi mtha' dang / yang dag pa'i 'tsho ba dang / yang dag pa'i rtsol ba dang / yang dag pa'i dran pa dang / yang dag pa'i ting nge 'dzin te/

“Just so, monks, I too have found an old path, an old route, an old trail which seers of old have traveled and traversed. Monks, what is this old path, this old route, this old trail which seers of old have traveled and traversed? It is this, the Noble Ones’ Eightfold Path, which consists of right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right recollection, and right concentration.

dge slong dag 'di ni sngon gyi lam dang / sngon gyi bgrod pa dang / sngon gyi lam srol sngon gyi drang srong rnams gshegs shing rjes su 'dong ba yin no/ / ngas der son cing der son pa na rga shi mthong / rga shi kun 'byung ba dang / rga shi 'gog pa dang / rga shi 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam mthong ste/ skye ba dang / srid pa dang / len pa dang / sred pa dang / tshor ba dang / reg pa dang / skye mched drug dang / ming dang gzugs dang / rnam par shes pa dang / 'du byed rnams mthong zhing 'du byed rnams kun 'byung ba dang / 'du byed rnams 'gog pa dang / 'du byed rnams 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam mthong ste/ ngas rang gi mngon par shes pas mngon par rdzogs par byang chub nas dge slong rnams dang / dge slong ma rnams dang / dge bsnyen rnams dang / dge bsnyen ma rnams dang / gzhan mu stegs can dang / dge sbyong dang / bram ze dang spyod pa can dang / kun du rgyu sna tshogs dag la brjod do/ /

“Monks, this is the old path, the old route, the old trail which seers of old have traveled and traversed. I reached it and on reaching it, I saw aging and death, and I saw the origins of aging and death, the cessation of aging and death, and the path that leads to the cessation of aging and death. I saw birth, becoming, grasping, craving, sensation, contact, the seats of the six senses, name and form, consciousness, and conditioning. And I saw the origins of conditioning, the cessation of conditioning, and the path that leads to the cessation of conditioning. And so, having been perfectly awakened by my perception, [F.112.a] I proclaim it to an array of monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, tīrthikas, ascetics, brahmins, sādhus,[185] and wandering mendicants.

de la dge slong gis kyang yang dag par sgrub pa na sgrub par byed pa yin zhing rigs pa dang ldan pa/ chos dang ldan pa/ dge ba sgrub par byed do/ / dge slong ma dang / dge bsnyen dang / dge bsnyen mas kyang yang dag par sgrub pa na sgrub par byed pa yin zhing / rigs pa dang ldan pa/ chos dang ldan pa/ dge ba sgrub par byed do/ /

“And when a monk perfectly accomplishes it, he too becomes an accomplished adept, sagacious, righteous, and an agent of virtue. And when a nun, a layman, or a laywoman perfectly accomplishes it, they too become accomplished adepts, sagacious, righteous, and agents of virtue.
de ltar na tshangs par spyod pa 'di ni rgya che ba/ skye bo mang po la phan pa/ yang dag par gyur pa/ lha dang mi'i bar dag la yang dag par rab tu bstan pa yin no zhes bton cing / de nas mjug tu/

“Thus it is that such a one who lives purely is magnanimous, of benefit to a great many beings, prodigious,[186] and teaches widely and perfectly among gods and humans.” Saṅgharakṣita closed his sermon with the dedication:

'byung po gang dag 'dir ni lhags gyur cing / / sa'am 'on te bar snang 'khod pa dag / skye dgu rnams la rtag tu byams byed cing / / nyin dang mtshan du chos kyang spyod gyur cig / ces yongs su bsngos pa dang /
“May all who live here gathered On the earth or in the sky Be always kind to creatures, And practice Dharma night and day.”

de dag thams cad kyis bden pa mngon par rtogs ma thag tu phyir mi 'ong ba'i 'bras bu thob ste rdzu 'phrul yang mngon par bsgrubs so/ / de nas de dag thams cad kyis btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho legs par gsungs so/ /
All present realized the truths and in that moment achieved the fruit of a non-returner and with it, miraculous abilities. In one voice they cried out, “Well said, reverend Saṅgharakṣita, well said!”

legs par gsungs so zhes mgrin gcig tu sgra phyung ngo / / de nas lha mo des rdzu 'phrul mngon par 'du bya ba de brtul ba dang / gcig gis gcig mthong bar gyur to/ / de dag gis gcig gis gcig mthong nas smras pa/ kye khyod kyang 'ongs sam/
The goddess then released them from the miraculous spell they were under so they came to see one another again. As they caught sight of one another, they exclaimed, “Oh! You too were here?”
khyod 'ongs sam/ kho bo 'ongs so/ / legs so/ /
“You were here?” [S.46.b] “I was here.” “Good!”

de dag gis 'byor pa rnyed cing rnyed nas smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tshos bdag cag legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po gnang na bdag cag bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar tshangs par spyod pa spyad par bgyi'o/ /

The seers had discovered a mighty state and having discovered it, proclaimed, “Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, if it is permitted, we would receive the going forth, ordination, and monkhood in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya. We would live the holy life in the Blessed One’s presence.”

des 'dzum pa sngon du btang ste smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag khyed spobs pa rgya chen po zhum pa med pa dge ba dang ldan pa legs so legs so/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang phan yon lnga yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos pa kho nar rigs te/ lnga gang zhe na/ bdag gis rang gi don ma 'dres pa rjes su thob par 'gyur ro zhes bya bar yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos par bya ba kho nar rigs pa dang / bdag gang dag gi bran dang / mngag gzhug pa dang / bsgo ba dang / rang dbang med dang / dga' mgur 'gror med pa yin pa de dag gi mchod par bya ba dang / bstod par bya bar 'gyur ro zhes bya bar yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos par bya ba kho nar rigs pa dang / grub pa dang / bde ba bla na med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa thob par 'gyur ro zhes bya bar yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos par bya ba kho nar rigs pa dang / grub pa dang / bde ba bla na med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa 'thob pa las nyams na yang lha rnams kyi nang du skye bar 'gyur ro zhes bya bar yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos par bya ba kho nar rigs pa dang / rab tu byung ba ni sangs rgyas rnams dang / sangs rgyas kyi nyan thos dam pa yang dag par song ba/ yang dag par zhugs pa/ skyes bu dam pa rnams kyis rnam grangs du mas bsngags so zhes bya bar yang dag par rjes su mthong ba'i mkhas pas rab tu 'byung ba la mos par bya ba kho nar rigs so zhes gsungs kyis

Smiling, Saṅgharakṣita said, “Venerables, your great and dauntless self-confidence [F.112.b] is noble. It is excellent! It is excellent! What is more, the Blessed One said, ‘Five advantages rightly come only to the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth.’ What are those five? (1) It is only the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth about whom it may rightly be said, ‘He will pursue his aim without diversion.’ (2) It is only the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth about whom it may rightly be said, ‘I make offerings to and praise those who are slave, agent, or emissary to no one, those who are independent and not in anyone’s service.’ (3) It is only the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth about whom it may rightly be said, ‘He will attain the unsurpassed accomplishment and bliss of nirvāṇa.’ (4) It is only the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth about whom it may rightly be said, ‘Even should he fail to attain the unsurpassed accomplishment and bliss of nirvāṇa, he will be reborn among gods.’ (5) It is only the wise with perfect vision who aspire to going forth about whom it may rightly be said, ‘Buddhas, the saintly disciples of buddhas who have reached perfection and entered perfection, and saintly beings praise renunciants in many ways.’ ”

rab tu byung shig / de'i phyir ci/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar rab tu 'byung ngam/ 'on te kho bo las/ de dag gis smras pa/ bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar ro/ / tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos smras pa/ gal te de lta na tshur sheg /bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'dong ngo / /

Saṅgharakṣita continued, “So, you shall go forth. But will you go forth before the Blessed One or before me?” “Before the Blessed One,” the seers replied. “In that case, come, let us go to the Blessed One.”
de dag gis smras pa/ btsun pa dge 'dun 'tsho ci bdag cag gi rdzu 'phrul gyis bzhud dam/
“Reverend Saṅgharakṣita, shall we travel under our own miraculous powers or under your miraculous powers?”

'on te khyod kyi rdzu 'phrul gyis/ tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos thos nas nyam nga bar gyur te/ des bsams pa/ bdag gi mthus 'di dag gi yon tan gyi tshogs 'di lta bu thob na/ bdag ni gzings lta bur gyur pa lta snyam nas/ de bzhin nyams shing gyur te smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag khyed kho bo la bya ba cung zhig yod kyis/ re zhig yud tsam zhig sdod cig ces de shing ljon pa zhig gi drung du brten nas skyil mo krung bcas te lus drang por bsrang nas dran pa phyogs par bzhag ste 'dug go/ /

Hearing this pained the venerable Saṅgharakṣita, [F.113.a] who thought, “If they have attained such a store of qualities due to my influence, it looks as if I am but a raft to them.” Dispirited, he replied, “Venerables, I have a small task to perform, so please wait here for a bit.” And with that, he sat down at the base of a tree, his legs crossed, his body erect, and rested in mindfulness.
