bcom ldan 'das kyis mang du thos pa la phan yon lnga yod de/ lnga gang zhe na/ phung po la mkhas pa dang / khams la mkhas pa dang / skye mched la mkhas pa dang / rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba la mkhas pa dang / de'i gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa gzhan la rag ma las pa yin no zhes gsungs pas

The Blessed One said, “There are five benefits to being well versed in the teachings. What are they? One becomes knowledgeable about the aggregates, knowledgeable about the constituents, knowledgeable about the seats of the senses, knowledgeable about interdependent arising, and one need not rely on others for instructions or further teachings on them.”

des brtson 'grus brtsams pas 'khor ba'i 'khor lo cha lnga pa g.yo ba dang mi g.yo ba 'di nyid rig ste/ 'du byed kyi rnam pa thams cad nyams pa dang / ltung ba dang / rnam par 'thor ba dang / rnam par 'jig pa'i chos nyid kyis zil gyis mnan cing nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas/ rigs kyi bu dag gang gi phyir skra dang kha spu dag bregs te gos ngur smrig dag bgos nas yang dag pa kho nar dad pas khyim nas khyim med par rab tu 'byung bar byed pa tshangs par spyod pa'i mtha' bla na med pa de tshe de nyid la rang gi mngon par shes pas mngon sum du byas te bsgrubs nas bdag gi skye ba zad do/ / tshangs par spyod pa spyad do/ / bya ba byas so/ / srid pa 'di las gzhan mi shes so zhes go bar byed cing

Thus, by applying himself diligently, Saṅgharakṣita came to understand saṃsāra’s ever-revolving five cycles.[187] It being by nature subject to degradation, decline, dispersal, and destruction, all of Saṅgharakṣita’s conditioning was overwhelmed and he abandoned all disturbing emotions. He perceived that he had, in that very life, actualized the unsurpassed aim of the holy life for which the sons of noble families, with perfect faith, cut their hair, shave their beards, don the saffron robes, and go forth from home into homelessness. With his achievement, he understood, “My births have come to an end, I have lived the holy life, I have done what needed doing, I will know no lives after this one.”

dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan dang ste'ur mnyam pa/ rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing / rig pa dang / mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur to/ /

Thus he became an arhat, free of desire for the three realms, for whom filth was equal to gold, for whom space was equal to the palm of his hand, whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood, and whose knowledge had rent open the shell. He attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. He turned his back on worldly gain, desires, and esteem, and was venerated, honored, and saluted by Indra and the gods who attend him. [F.113.b]

des de dag la smras pa/ shes ldan dag kho bo'i chos gos kyi grwa nas zung shig dang / kho bo'i rdzu 'phrul gyis 'dong bar bya'o/ / de dag de'i chos gos kyi grwa la 'jus pa dang / de nas tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho ngang pa'i rgyal po 'dab ma brkyang pa ltar rdzu 'phrul gyis steng gi nam mkha' la song ngo / /

Saṅgharakṣita said to the seers, “Gentlemen, hold on to the corner of my robe and we shall travel under my miraculous powers.” The seers grabbed hold of his robe, and the venerable Saṅgharakṣita, like a swan spreading its wings, flew with his miraculous powers up into the sky above.
[rigs kyi bu stong po]

d.crumb: Saṅgharakṣita leads an entourage of one thousand to the Buddha

f.d: Saṅgharakṣita leads an entourage of one thousand to the Buddha

ji tsam na tshong pa lnga brgya po de dag rdzas mkhos su 'bebs par byed pa na/ de dag gis de mthong nas de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho khyod byon tam/ byon pa legs so/ / kho bo 'ongs so/ /
Along the way, the five hundred merchants were securing their wares when they saw Saṅgharakṣita and exclaimed, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita! Is that you? Welcome!” “I have come.”

gang du bzhud/ des smras pa/ rigs kyi bu lnga brgya po 'di dag bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'dod pas bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'gro'o/ / de dag gis smras pa/ 'phags pa dge 'dun 'tsho bdag cag kyang rab tu 'byung gis bobs la bdag cag rdzas mkhos su 'bebs kyi bar du re zhig gzhes su gsol/

“Where are you headed?” “These five hundred sons of noble families want monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, so we are going to the Blessed One.” The merchants replied, “Noble Saṅgharakṣita, we too will go forth, so please alight and sit while we secure our wares.”

tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho babs pa dang / de dag gis rdzas mkhos su phab bo/ / de nas des rigs kyi bu stong po de dag khrid nas bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ngo / / de'i tshe bcom ldan 'das dge slong gi 'khor brgya phrag du ma'i gung la bzhugs te chos ston par mdzad do/ / bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho skyes dang chas te thag ring po kho na nas 'ong ba gzigs so/ / gzigs nas kyang dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag khyed kyis dge slong dge 'dun 'tsho thag ring po nas 'ong ba mthong ngam/ btsun pa mthong ngo / / dge slong dag dge slong dge 'dun 'tsho 'di de bzhin gshegs pa la skyes dang bcas shing 'ong ste/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i skyes ni 'di ltar gdul ba las gzhan pa lta bu med do/ /

Saṅgharakṣita descended and they secured their wares. Saṅgharakṣita then led the one thousand sons of noble families to the Blessed One, who was seated in the midst of hundreds of monks, teaching. From off in the distance, the Blessed One saw Saṅgharakṣita approaching with his gifts. Though he saw them, he asked the monks, “Monks, do you see Saṅgharakṣita coming from off in the distance?” “We do, reverend.” “Monks, this monk Saṅgharakṣita comes with gifts for the Tathāgata. There is no gift for the Tathāgata like these, the gift of disciples.”

de nas tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tsho bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal te phyogs gcig tu 'dug go/ / phyogs gcig tu 'dug nas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos 'di skad ces gsol to/ / btsun pa rigs kyi bu stong po 'di dag legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'tshal na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis thugs brtse ba'i slad du 'di dag rab tu dbyung du gsol/ bsnyen par rdzogs par mdzad du gsol/

Saṅgharakṣita went to the Blessed One, bowed his head at his feet, and sat off to one side before [F.114.a] [S.47.a] requesting the Blessed One, “Reverend, these one thousand sons of noble families want monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya. May the Blessed One, out of compassion, allow their goings forth and allow their ordination.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis de dag la dge slong tshur shog ces bya bas rab tu phyung zhing dge slong dag tshur shog tshangs par spyod pa spyod cig ces bka' stsal pa dang / de dag bcom ldan 'das kyi bka'i mjug kho nar skra byi ba dang snam sbyar gyon par gyur te/ skra dang kha spu zhag bdun skyes pa tsam dang / lag pa na lhung bzed dang bya ma bum thogs pa dang / dge slong bsnyen par rdzogs nas lo brgya lon pa'i spyod lam lta bur gnas par gyur to/ / yang smras pa/

The Blessed One allowed goings forth by saying the phrase, “Come, monk,” and so as soon as he said, “Come, monks. Live the holy life,” their hair fell out and they were clad in robes; with but a week’s growth of hair and beard, begging bowls and water jars in hand, settled, with the composure of monks who had been ordained for one hundred years. As was said,
de bzhin gshegs pas tshur shog bka' stsal pas/ / skra byi snam sbyar gyon pa'i lus ldan zhing / / mod la dbang po rab zhir gnas gyur te/ / sangs rgyas dgongs pas lus gzugs bkab par gyur/
Hair tonsured and body clad in robes By the Tathāgata’s call to come forth, That moment, their senses were perfectly stilled And their bodies garbed by the Buddha’s mind.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis de dag la gdams ngag stsal nas/ de dag gis brtson pa dang / 'bad pa dang / brtsal bas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas te/ dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan dang ste'ur mnyam pa/ rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing rig pa dang / mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang / bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang / nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur to/ /

The Blessed One gave them instructions, to which they applied themselves with diligence, effort, and exertion, abandoning all disturbing emotions and actualizing arhatship. Thus they became arhats, free of desire for the three realms, for whom filth was equal to gold, for whom space was equal to the palm of his hand, whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood, and whose knowledge had rent open the shell. They attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. They turned their backs on worldly gain, desires, and esteem, and were venerated, honored, and saluted by Indra and the gods who attend him.
[mthong ba]

d.crumb: The Blessed One explains the causes for the sights Saṅgharakṣita has seen

f.d: The Blessed One explains the causes for the sights Saṅgharakṣita has seen

de nas sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos zhus pa/ btsun pa 'di na bdag gis sems can rtsig pa 'dra ba dag dang / ka ba 'dra ba dag dang / shing ljon pa 'dra ba dag dang / lo ma 'dra ba dag dang / me tog 'dra ba dag dang / 'bras bu 'dra ba dag dang / thag pa 'dra ba dag dang / phyags ma 'dra ba dag dang / phor pa 'dra ba dag dang / gtun 'dra ba dag dang / phru ba 'dra ba dag dang / rked pa chad pa chu rgyus kyis bzung ba mthong na/ btsun pa de dag gis las ci zhig bgyis na/ las de'i rnam par smin pas de 'dra ba dag tu gyur/

The venerable Saṅgharakṣita asked the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, I have seen beings shaped like walls, pillars, trees, [F.114.b] leaves, flowers, fruit, rope, brooms, bowls, mortars and pestles, and pots, as well as beings cut at the waist, their bodies held together by tendons. Reverend, what actions did they perform for it to ripen in such ways?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge 'dun 'tsho sems can de dag nyid kyis las tshogs rnyed pa/ rkyen yongs su bsgyur ba/ 'od pa bzhin du nye bar gnas pa/ gdon mi za bar 'byung bar 'gyur ba dag byas shing bstsags pas de dag nyid kyis las byas shing bsags pa dag gzhan su zhig gis so sor myong bar 'gyur/

“Saṅgharakṣita,” replied the Blessed One, “those being themselves performed the actions‍—which have accrued a heap of karma, whose results have matured, which follow their course like an irrigation channel, which inevitably come to be‍—so who else will experience the actions they themselves have performed and accrued?

dge 'dun 'tsho las byas shing bsags pa dag ni phyi rol gyi sa'i khams la rnam par smin par mi 'gyur/ chu'i khams la mi 'gyur/ me'i khams la mi 'gyur/ rlung gi khams la mi 'gyur/ 'di ltar las dge ba dang mi dge ba byas shing bsags pa dag ni zin pa'i phung po dang / khams dang / skye mched dag la rnam par smin par 'gyur te/

“Saṅgharakṣita, actions which have been performed and accrued do not ripen upon the external elements. They do not ripen upon the element of water, upon the element of fire, nor upon the element of wind. Likewise, virtuous and non-virtuous actions which have been performed and accrued come to fruition upon the aggregates, elements, and seats of the senses of the one who performed them, for:
las rnams bskal pa brgyar yang ni/ / chud mi za ba'ang tshogs dang dus/ / rnyed na lus can rnams la ni/ / 'bras bu dag tu 'gyur ba nyid/ /
“Actions never waste away, Not even after one hundred eons. [S.47.b] When the time and the conditions Are right, they alight upon embodied beings.

dge 'dun 'tsho sngon byung pa 'das pa'i dus na bskal pa bzang po 'di nyid la skye dgu'i tshe lo nyi khri thub pa na ston pa de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'od srung zhes bya ba 'jig rten du byung ste/ de bA rA Na sI na drang srong smra ba ri dgas kyi nags na nye bar rten cing bzhugs pa na de dag de'i nyan thos su gyur to/ /

“Saṅgharakṣita, in a time now passed, during this fortunate eon, when the lifespan of beings was twenty thousand years, the Blessed Buddha Kāśyapa appeared in the world, a teacher, a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha, a knowledgeable and venerable one, a sugata, one who knew the world, an unsurpassed guide who tamed beings, a teacher to gods and men. Those beings you saw were his disciples when he lived and dwelt in the Ṛṣipatana Deer Park near Vārāṇasī.

dge 'dun 'tsho khyod kyis sems can rtsig pa 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de dag ni dge slong dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi rtsig pa mchil mas ma rung bar byas pas las de'i rnam par smin pas rtsig pa 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ / khyod kyis sems can ka ba 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de dag kyang dge slong dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi ka ba snabs kyis ma rung bar byas pas las de'i rnam par smin pas ka ba 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ /

“Saṅgharakṣita, when those beings you saw who were shaped like walls were monks, they defaced a wall belonging to the saṅgha with their spit. [F.115.a] As the fruition of that act, they have come to resemble walls. “When those beings you saw who were shaped like pillars were monks, they defaced a pillar belonging to the saṅgha with their mucus. As the fruition of that act, they have come to resemble pillars.

khyod kyis sems can shing ljon pa 'dra ba dag dang / lo ma 'dra ba dag dang / me tog 'dra ba dag dang / 'bras bu 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de dag kyang dge slong dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi shing ljon pa dang / lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu dag gang zag gi longs spyod du spyad pas las de'i rnam par smin pas shing ljon pa 'dra ba dag dang / lo ma 'dra ba dag dang / me tog 'dra ba dag dang / 'bras bu 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ / khyod kyis sems can thag pa 'dra ba dag dang / phyags ma 'dra ba dag mthong ba de dag kyang dge slong dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag gis dge 'dun gyi thag pa dang phyags ma gang zag gis longs spyod du spyad pas las de'i rnam par smin pas thag pa 'dra ba dag dang / phyags ma 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ /

“When those beings you saw who were shaped like trees, leaves, flowers, and fruit were monks, they used trees, leaves, flowers, and fruit belonging to the saṅgha for their own ends. As the fruition of that act, they have come to resemble trees, leaves, flowers, and fruit. “When those beings you saw who were shaped like rope and brooms were monks, they used rope and brooms belonging to the saṅgha for their own ends. As the fruition of that act, they have come to resemble rope and brooms.

khyod kyis sems can phor pa 'dra ba dag gang dag mthong ba de dag ni dge tshul skom gyi gtsang sbyor du gyur pa na de dag phor pa 'khru bar byed pa'i tshe/ dge slong glo bur du 'ongs pa dag lhags nas de dag gis dge tshul de dag la dris pa/ dge tshul dag ci dge 'dun la skom 'byung bar 'gyur ram/ dge tshul de dag ser snas dkris te smras pa/ kho bo cag gis phor pa bkrus pa ma mthong ngam/ skom 'thungs zin to/ / de dag gis bsams pa/ dus yol ba lta snyam nas/ re ba med par gyur te bzhin gyur cing nyams te dong bas las de'i rnam par smin pas phor pa 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ /

“When those beings you saw who were shaped like bowls were monks, they were in charge of providing clean drinking water. When they were washing the bowls, some arriving monks arrived and asked the monks, ‘Do novices get whatever drinks are provided to the saṅgha?’ “Seized by stinginess towards the novices, they replied, ‘Do you not see we are washing the bowls? The drinks have already been drunk.’ “The novices thought, ‘It would seem we are too late,’ and left dispirited, with expressions of resignation. As the fruition of that act, those monks have come to resemble bowls.

khyod kyis sems can gtun 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de dag kyang dge slong dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag la lhung bzed kyi las dag byung nas de na dge tshul dgra bcom pa cig dam zhag par bskos pa de la de dag gis smras pa/ dge tshul kho bo cag la gtun du 'bru mar gyi tshigs ma nyung ba zhig rdungs te byin cig /des smras pa/ gnas brtan dag bdag brel gyis re zhig yud tsam zhig gzhes shig dang / slad kyis gsol lo/ /

“When those beings you saw who were shaped like mortars and pestles were monks, they were in charge of begging bowls and they said to an arhat novice who had at the time been appointed keeper of the seals,[188] ‘Novice, we have quite a bit of grain to grind in the mortar, [F.115.b] so give it here.’ “The arhat novice replied, ‘Elders, I’m busy at the moment. Please wait a bit. I shall give it to you later.’

de dag mi bzod pa skyes nas kun nas dkris pa drag pos smras pa/ dge tshul gal te kho bo cag gtun la reg tu rung na kho bo cag gis khyod nyid gtun du bcug ste/ brdung bar yang bya na/ 'bru mar tshigs ma nyung zhig lta ci smos/ dge tshul des bsams pa/ 'di dag kun nas dkris pa drag pos dkris pas gal te bdag gis 'di dag la lan btab na lhag par yang rab tu 'khrugs par 'gyur ro snyam nas/ des cang mi smra bar bsdad nas

“Feeling impatient, the monks became enraged and said, ‘Novice, if we wanted to use the mortar, we could toss you into the mortar and grind you too! To say nothing of a bit of grain!’ “The arhat novice thought, ‘They are enraged. If I respond to them, it will only inflame their anger further,’ so he remained silent.

gang gi tshe de dag kun nas dkris pa dang bral ba de'i tshe na gan du song ste smras pa/ gnas brtan dag khyed kyis bdag su lags pa mkhyen tam/ de dag gis smras pa/ shes te/ khyod ni yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gi bstan pa la rab tu byung ba'i dge tshul yin no/ / kho bo cag kyang dge slong yin no/ /

“After a time their rage passed, and when it did he went to them and said, ‘Elders, do you know who I am?’ “They replied, ‘Yes, we know. You are but a novice who has gone forth for the perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa. We, however, are monks.’

gnas brtan dag gal te de ltar lags kyis kyang 'di ltar bdag gis ni rab tu byung bas bgyi ba gang lags pa de bgyis so/ / ci zhig byas/ nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du bgyis so/ / khyed ni 'ching ba mtha' dag gis bcings pa lags la/ bdag ni 'ching ba mtha' dag las nges par grol ba lags na/ khyed kyis ngag gi las rtsub po brjod kyis sdig pa sdig pa las shogs shig dang / de ltar na las bsrabs pa nyid dang / yongs su zad pa dang / yongs su mthar thug par 'gyur ro/ /

“ ‘Elders, though that is so, since going forth, I have done all that needed to be done. What is that? I have abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship. While you are bound by all bonds, I have been definitively freed from all bonds. As you have spoken harshly, you must confess your wrongs as wrong! Doing so will wither away the act, exhaust it, and finally put it to rest.’ “Although the monks confessed their wrongs as wrong, the actions came to fruition, causing them to resemble mortars and pestles.

de dag gis sdig pa sdig pa las bshags kyang las de'i rnam par smin pas gtun 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ / khyod kyis sems can phru ba 'dra ba gang dag mthong ba de dag ni dge 'dun rnams la rim gror byed pa'i lha 'bangs su gyur te/ de dag sman skol bar byed pa na/ dge slong rnams kyis mi snyan par smras pa dang / de dag sems rab tu khros pas phru ba de dag bcag pas/ las de'i rnam par smin pas phru ba 'dra ba dag tu gyur to/ /

“Those beings you saw who were shaped like pots were formerly bondmen in the service of the saṅgha. Once as they were boiling medicinal herbs, [S.48.a] the monks spoke offensively to them, whereupon they broke the pots in anger. As the fruition of that act, they have come to resemble pots.

khyod kyis sems can rked pa chad pa chu rgyus kyis bzung ba gang dag mthong ba de dag kyang dge slong rnyed pa stobs pa dag tu gyur pa na/ de dag ser snas zil gyis non pas rnyed pa bsgyur te/ dbyar gyi rnyed pa gang yin pa de ni dgun gyir bsgyur/ dgun gyi rnyed pa gang yin pa de ni dbyar gyir bsgyur bas las de'i rnam par smin pas rked pa chad pa chu rgyus kyis bzung ba dag tu gyur to/ /

“And when the beings [F.116.a] you saw who were cut at the waist, their bodies held together by tendons, were monks in charge of supplies, they were overcome by stinginess and switched supplies, swapping the summer supplies with those for the winter and switching the winter supplies with those for the summer. As the fruition of that act, they have become beings cut at the waist, their bodies held together by tendons.”
[skal pa]

d.crumb: The Blessed One explains the reasons for Saṅgharakṣita’s good fortune

f.d: The Blessed One explains the reasons for Saṅgharakṣita’s good fortune

dge slong rnams the tshom skyes nas the tshom thams cad gcod pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la zhus pa/ btsun pa tshe dang ldan pa dge 'dun 'tshos las ci zhig bgyis na/ las de'i rnam par smin pas phyug pa nor mang ba longs spyod che ba'i khyim du skyes shing dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du bgyis pa dang / gdul ba'i don chen po bgyis par gyur/

In doubt, the monks asked he who severs all doubts, the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, what is it that Saṅgharakṣita has done, that the ripened fruit of that action has led him to be born into a rich household with ample wealth and possessions, to actualize arhatship, and to inspire the conversion of so many?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag dge 'dun 'tsho nyid kyis las tshogs rnyed pa/ rkyen yongs su bsgyur ba/ 'od pa bzhin du nye bar gnas pa/ gdon mi za bar 'byung bar 'gyur ba dag byas shing bsags pas/ dge slong dge 'dun 'tsho 'di nyid kyis las byas shing bsags pa dag gzhan su zhig gis so sor myong bar 'gyur/ dge slong dag las byas shing bsags pa dag ni phyi rol gyi sa'i khams la rnam par smin par mi 'gyur/ chu'i khams la mi 'gyur/ me'i khams la mi 'gyur/ rlung gi khams la mi 'gyur/ 'di ltar las dge ba dang mi dge ba byas shing bsags pa dag ni zin pa'i phung po dang / khams dang / skye mched dag la rnam par smin par 'gyur te/

“Monks,” replied The Blessed One, “Saṅgharakṣita himself performed the actions‍—which have accrued a heap of karma, whose results have matured, which follow their course like an irrigation channel, which inevitably come to be‍—so who else will experience the actions he himself has performed and accrued? Monks, actions which have been performed and accrued do not ripen upon the external elements. They do not ripen upon the element of water, upon the element of fire, nor upon the element of wind. Likewise, virtuous and non-virtuous actions which have been performed and accrued come to fruition upon the aggregates, elements, and seats of the senses of the one who performed them, for:
las rnams bskal pa brgyar yang ni/ / chud mi za ba'ang tshogs dang dus/ / rnyed na lus can rnams la ni/ / 'bras bu dag tu 'gyur ba nyid/ /
“Actions never waste away, Not even after one hundred eons. When the time and the conditions Are right, they alight upon embodied beings.

dge slong dag sngon byung ba 'das pa'i dus na/ bskal pa bzang po 'di nyid la skye dgu'i tshe lo nyi khri thub pa na ston pa de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba bla na med pa lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'od srung zhes bya ba 'jig rten du byung ste/ de bA rA Na sI na drang srong smra ba ri dgas kyi nags na nye bar rten cing bzhugs so/ / de'i bstan pa la 'di rab tu byung nas zhal ta byed par gyur cing de la lhan cig gnas pa lnga brgya yod par gyur to/ /

“Monks, in a time now passed, during this fortunate eon, when the lifespan of beings was twenty thousand years, the Blessed Buddha Kāśyapa appeared in the world, a teacher, a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha, a knowledgeable and venerable one, a sugata, one who knew the world, an unsurpassed guide who tamed beings, a teacher to gods and men. [F.116.b] While the Blessed Buddha Kāśyapa lived and dwelt in the Ṛṣipatana Deer Park near Vārāṇasī, Saṅgharakṣita went forth into his teachings and served as a custodian, living together with five hundred others.

ri brags na gnas pa'i skye bo'i tshogs de yang phal cher de la mngon par dad par gyur to/ / de nas des tshe ji srid par tshangs par spyod pa spyad pa na yon tan gyi tshogs 'ga' yang ma thob bo/ / de dus gzhan zhig na na bar gyur nas de la rtsa ba dang / sdong bu dang / lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu'i sman dag gis bsnyen bkur byas kyang nad de nye bar zhi bar ma gyur cing nyam dmas nas de 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe smon lam 'di skad ces/ bdag gis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas yon gnas bla na med pa 'od srung la tshe ji srid par tshangs par spyod pa spyad pa na yon tan gyi tshogs 'ga' yang ma thob ste/ bdag gis tshe ji srid par tshangs par spyod pa spyad pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gis bram ze'i khye'u bla ma la/ bram ze'i khye'u khyod ma 'ongs pa'i dus na skye dgu'i tshe lo brgya thub pa na de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das shAkya thub pa zhes bya bar 'gyur ro zhes lung bstan pa de'i bstan pa la bdag rab tu byung nas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byed par gyur cig ces gdab par brtsams so/ /

“Most of the community of people who lived in that hilly fastness came to have great faith in him. Though he lived purely his entire life he never attained any of the store of qualities. Then one day he fell ill and though he was ministered to with medicinal roots, stalks, leaves, flowers, and fruits, the illness would not subside. In despair, as he was dying, he made this prayer: ‘Though I have spent my entire life living the holy life under Kāśyapa, the blessed tathāgata, perfectly awakened Buddha, and unsurpassed object of veneration, I have not attained any of the store of qualities. May these roots of virtue from having spent my entire life living the holy life ensure that I go forth into the teachings of Buddha Śākyamuni, regarding whom the blessed tathāgata and perfectly awakened Buddha Kāśyapa prophesied to the young brahmin Uttara, saying, ‘Young brahmin, in the future, when the lifespan of beings is one hundred years, you will become the tathāgata, the arhat, the perfectly awakened Buddha, the knowledgeable and venerable one, the sugata, the one who knows the world, the unsurpassed guide who tames beings, the teacher to gods and men known as the Blessed Buddha Śākyamuni, and go on to abandon all disturbing emotions and actualize arhatship.’

de nas de'i lhan cig gnas pa dag lhags te dris pa/ mkhan pos yon tan gyi tshogs cung zad brnyes pa mchis sam/ des smras pa med do/ / de dag gis dris pa/ smon lam ji skad btab/ des smras pa/ 'di dang 'di skad ces so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ bdag cag kyang dge ba'i bshes gnyen mkhan po la brten nas bcom ldan 'das de nyid kyi bstan pa la rab tu byung nas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byed par gyur cig /

“The monk caretaker’s wards then approached him and asked, ‘Preceptor, have you attained any of the store of qualities?’ “ ‘No, I have not,’ he replied. [S.48.b] “They asked, ‘What prayers have you made?’ “He replied by explaining the prayer he had made. “They said, [F.117.a] ‘May we too, by taking you, our preceptor, as our spiritual guide, go forth into the teachings of that very Blessed One and go on to abandon all disturbing emotions and actualize arhatship.’

de nas ri brags na gnas pa'i skye bo'i tshogs des 'phags pa de na'o zhes thos nas de dag kyang de'i gan du song ste dris pa/ 'phags pas yon tan gyi tshogs cung zad brnyes pa mchis sam/ des smras pa med do/ / de dag gis smras pa/ smon lam ji skad btab/ des smras pa/ 'di dang 'di skad ces so/ / de dag gis smras pa/ bdag cag kyang dge ba'i bshes gnyen 'phags pa la brten nas bcom ldan 'das de nyid kyi bstan pa la rab tu byung nas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byed par gyur cig /

dge slong dag de la de'i tshe de'i dus na dge slong zhal ta byed par gyur pa gang yin pa de ni dge slong dge 'dun 'tsho 'di nyid yin no/ / de'i lhan cig gnas pa lnga brgya po gang dag yin pa de dag ni drang srong lnga brgya po 'di dag nyid yin no/ / ri brags na gnas pa'i skye bo'i tshogs gang yin pa de dag ni tshong pa lnga brgya po 'di dag yin no/ / 'dis der chos dang ldan pas zhal ta byas pa gang yin pa'i las de'i rnam par smin pas phyug cing nor mang ba longs spyod che ba'i khyim du skyes so/ / 'chi ba'i dus kyi tshe smon lam btab pa des ni nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas shing gdul ba'i don chen po byas par gyur to/ /

“Monks, the monk who served as monk caretaker in that life was none other than the monk Saṅgharakṣita. His five hundred wards are none other than these five hundred seers. The community of people who lived in that hilly fastness are none other than the five hundred merchants. Hence, now the ripened fruit of the venerable custodian’s action has led him to be born into a rich household with ample wealth and possessions. The prayers he made as he lay dying have led to his abandoning all disturbing emotions, actualizing arhatship, and inspiring such a massive conversion.

dge slong dag de ltar na las gcig tu gnag pa rnams kyi rnam par smin pa ni gcig tu gnag pa yin la/ las gcig tu dkar ba rnams kyi rnam par smin pa yang gcig tu dkar ba yin/ las 'dren ma rnams kyi rnam par smin pa yang 'dren ma yin no/ / dge slong dag de lta bas na las gcig tu gnag pa rnams dang 'dren ma rnams spangs te las gcig tu dkar ba rnams la btsal bar bya ste/ dge slong dag khyed kyis de ltar bslab par bya'o/ /

“The ripened fruits of wholly negative actions are wholly negative, while the ripened fruits of wholly positive actions are wholly positive, and the ripened fruits of mixed actions are mixed. Monks, therefore abandon wholly negative and mixed actions and seek wholly positive actions. Monks, this is how you should train.”
[klu sprul gyi dad pa]

d.crumb: The Blessed One explains the reasons for the shape-shifting nāga’s faith

f.d: The Blessed One explains the reasons for the shape-shifting nāga’s faith
dge slong rnams the tshom skyes nas the tshom thams cad gcod pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la zhus pa/ btsun pa klu gzhon nu sprul pas dang po gang du dad pa thob par gyur/
In doubt, the monks asked he who had severed all doubts, the Blessed Buddha, [F.117.b] “Reverend, how did the youthful, shape-shifting nāga first gain faith?”

bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag bskal pa bzang po 'di nyid la skye dgu'i tshe lo nyi khri thub pa na/ ston pa de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul ba'i kha lo sgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das 'od srung zhes bya ba 'jig rten du byung ste/ de dge slong nyi khri'i 'khor dang / bA rA Na sI na drang srong smra ba ri dgas kyi nags na nye bar rten cing bzhugs so/ / de nyan thos rnams la dge slong dag dgon pa dang / shing drung dang / khyim gyis stong pa dang / ri sul dang / ri phug dang / rtsa spyil dang / bla gab med pa dang / dur khrod dang / nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha'i gnas mal 'di dag tu bsam gtan gyis shig /dge slong dag bag yod par sgrubs la phyis 'gyod par mi 'gyur bar gyis shig /'di ni nga'i gdams ngag dang rjes su bstan pa yin no zhes chos ston par mdzad do/ /

The Blessed One replied, “Monks, during this fortunate eon, when the lifespan of beings was twenty thousand years, the Blessed Buddha Kāśyapa appeared in the world, a teacher, a tathāgata, an arhat, a perfectly awakened buddha, a knowledgeable and venerable one, a sugata, one who knew the world, an unsurpassed guide who tamed beings, a teacher to gods and men. He lived and dwelt with a following of twenty thousand monks in the Ṛṣipatana Deer Park near Vārāṇasī. He taught the Dharma to his disciples, saying, ‘Monks, make your beds in forests and at the foot of trees; in uninhabited places, mountain basins, mountain caves, and huts of straw; in the open, in charnel grounds, in jungles, at the foot of mountains, and at the edges of forests, and there practice meditation. Monks, apply yourselves conscientiously and be sure you will have no regrets later. These are my instructions and my guidance.’

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la de skad ces bka' stsal nas/ dge slong rnams dgon pa dang / shing drung dang / khyim gyis stong pa dang / ri sul dang / ri phug dang / rtswa spyil dang / bla gab med pa dang / dur khrod dang / nags khrod dang / ri drung dang / bas mtha'i gnas mal dag tu zhugs so/ / kha cig ni ri rab kyi bang rim na bsam gtan byed/ kha cig ni gser gyi ri bdun po dag na/ kha cig ni mtsho chen po ma dros pa na/ kha cig ni rdzing bu dal gyis 'bab na/ kha cig ni rnal 'byor pa'i skye bo dang rjes su mthun pa'i grong dang / grong rdal dang / yul dang / yul 'khor dang / rgyal po'i pho brang gi phyogs de dang de dag na bsam gtan byed do/ /

“After the Blessed One said this to the monks, the monks went to make their bed in forests and at the foot of trees; in uninhabited places, mountain basins, mountain caves, and huts of straw; in the open, in charnel grounds, in jungles, at the foot of mountains, and at the edges of forests. Some practiced meditation on the slopes of Sumeru. Some practiced meditation on the seven golden mountains, some at Lake Anavatapta, some along gently lapping ponds, and some in villages, towns, regions, countryside, and kingdoms inhabited by like-minded yogis.

ji tsam na klu gzhon nu skyes nas ring po ma lon pa zhig 'dab chags kyi rgyal po 'dab bzangs kyis ri rab kyi bang rim gyi steng du drangs pa dang / ji tsam na des dge slong spyod lam zhi bas bsam gtan dang / klog pa dang / rnal 'byor la rjes su brtson pa dag mthong ngo / / mthong nas kyang de'i sems mngon par dad par gyur to/ / de sems dad pa skyes nas 'phags pa bdag nyid chen po 'di dag ni sdug bsngal gyi bye brag 'di lta bu las grol ba yin no snyam du sems skyed par byed cing / de de dag la sems mngon par dad par byas nas dus la bab pa dang / las drug la brtson pa'i bram ze'i khyim zhig tu skyes nas ji tsam na bsrings shing bskyed de chen por gyur to/ /

“Meanwhile, a young nāga born not long before that [F.118.a] was carried off to the top shelf of Mount Sumeru by the garūḍa Suparṇi. In time, the young nāga saw monks of pacific bearing diligently practicing meditation, recitation, and yoga. Seeing them caused great faith to well up in his mind. With his mind filled with faith, it occurred to him, ‘These great and noble souls have been freed from sufferings such as mine.’ The young nāga placed great faith in them, and eventually his time came, after which he was born into a brahmin family dedicated to the six duties,[189] and in time he grew up under their nurture and care.

de dus gzhan zhig na bcom ldan 'das yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gi gsung rab la rab tu byung nas des brtson pa dang / 'bad pa dang / brtsal bas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas te/ dgra bcom pa khams gsum pa las 'dod chags dang bral ba/ bong ba dang gser du mnyam pa/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil du mtshungs pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ tsan dan dang ste'ur mnyam pa/ rig pas sgo nga'i sbubs dral bar gyur cing / rig pa dang / mngon par shes pa dang / so so yang dag par rig pa thob pa/ srid pa dang / 'dod pa'i rnyed pa dang bkur sti la rgyab kyis phyogs pa/ dbang po dang / nye dbang dang bcas pa'i lha rnams kyis mchod par bya ba dang / rjed par bya ba dang / mngon du smra bar bya bar gyur to/ /

“He later went forth into the perfectly awakened and blessed Buddha Kāśyapa’s teachings and, through diligence, effort, and exertion, abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship. Thus he became an arhat, free of desire for the three realms, [S.49.a] for whom filth was equal to gold, for whom space was equal to the palm of his hand, whose emotions had been cooled as if treated by a balm of sandalwood, and whose knowledge had rent open the shell. He attained knowledge, clairvoyance, and discerning wisdom. He turned his back on worldly gain, desires, and esteem, and was venerated, honored, and saluted by Indra and the gods who attend him.

des bsams pa/ bdag ga las shi 'phos/ gang du skyes/ las gang gis byas snyam na/ des dud 'gro nas shi 'phos shing mi rnams kyi nang du skyes pa dang / nyan thos chen po rnams la sems mngon par dad par byas pas skyes par mthong ngo / /

“On wondering, ‘Whence have I come? Where have I been born? What actions led to this?’ he saw that he had been a creature who had died and passed on, had been born among humans, and that he had given rise to great faith in great disciples.

des pha ma la bsams te/ bdag gi pha ma ga la 'dug snyam na/ klu'i gnas na 'dug par mthong ngo / / ci byed snyam na/ klu'i skye gnas na ngu zhing 'dug par mthong nas de rdzu 'phrul gyis der song ste dri bar brtsams pa/ yab yum ci'i slad du bshum/ de gnyis kyis smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag cag gi klu gzhon nu skyes nas ring po ma lags pa zhig 'dab chags kyi rgyal po 'dab bzangs kyis phrogs na/ de gar mchis ma 'tshal to/ /

“He then thought of his mother and father from his previous life as a young nāga. On wondering, ‘Where are my parents?’ he saw that they were among the nāgas. On wondering, ‘What are they doing?’ he saw that they were crying, still living among the nāgas. Using his miraculous powers, he went there and asked, ‘Father, Mother, why are you sad?’ [F.118.b] “They replied, ‘Noble one, our young nāga was snatched shortly after his birth by the garūḍa Suparṇi. We do not know where to look for him.’

des smras pa/ yab yum de ni bdag nyid lags te/ shi zhing dus la bab nas las drug la brtson pa'i bram ze'i khyim du skyes te/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas 'od srung gi bstan pa la rab tu byung nas nyon mongs pa thams cad spangs pas dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du bgyis so/ /

“He replied, ‘Father, Mother, I am he. After my time came and I died, I was born into a brahmin family dedicated to the six duties. I then went forth into the perfectly awakened and blessed Buddha Kāśyapa’s teachings and, through diligence, effort, and exertion, abandoned all disturbing emotions and actualized arhatship.’

'phags pa de 'dra bar skyon chags par gyur pa de bdag cag gis bde 'gror mchi bar yang ma bsams na/ dgra bcom pa lta ci smos te/ de ni ngo mtshar dang rmad du byung ba lags na/ khyod kyis yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu brnyes sam/ thob bo/ / 'phags pa khyod ni bsod snyoms bzhed pa lags la/ bdag cag ni bsod nams 'tshal ba lags kyis/ khyod 'di nyid du gdugs re re zhing gshegs te/ zhal zas kyi bya ba mdzod la bzhud cig /

“ ‘Noble one, given the wretched form you had, we never imagined you in the higher realms, to say nothing of arhatship! This is indeed amazing and marvelous! Did you find or attain such a store of qualities? Noble one, you are an accepter of alms but we are seekers of merit,[190] so every day you must come to this very place and take your meal before returning.’

des dang du blangs nas des rtag par klu'i gnas su bdud rtsi zos shing ldog par byed do/ / de'i lhan cig gnas pa'i dge tshul de la dge slong rnams kyis smras pa/ dge tshul khyod kyi mkhan po 'di gang du zos shing 'ong / des smras pa/ ma 'tshal to/ /

“After agreeing to that, every day he partook of ambrosia in the land of the nāgas before returning. Some monks asked his novice ward, ‘Novice, where does your preceptor eat and return from?’ “The novice ward replied, ‘I have not inquired.’

de dag gis smras pa/ klu'i gnas su lha'i bdud rtsi zos shing 'ong na khyod ci'i phyir mi 'gro/ des smras pa/ de ni rdzu 'phrul che ba mthu che ba lags pas des mchi na bdag nyid ji ltar mchi/ de dag gis smras pa/ gang gi tshe 'di rdzu 'phrul gyis 'gro ba de'i tshe na khyod kyis 'di'i chos gos kyi grwa nas zung shig /

“ ‘If your preceptor partakes of ambrosia in the land of the nāgas before returning here, why do you not go with him?’ “ ‘How could I accompany him when he uses his miraculous powers and great might to travel there?’ “ ‘When he travels with his miraculous powers, hold on to the corner of his robe.’

des smras pa/ mi ltung ngam/ bzhin bzangs gal te de'i chos gos kyi grwa la ri'i rgyal po ri rab btags na de yang mi ltung na khyod lta ci smos/ de dag gis de spro bar byas nas/ gnas gang du de rdzu 'phrul gyis mi snang bar byed pa der song ste bsdad pa dang / de yang mi snang bar byed nas/ des kyang chos gos kyi grwa nas bzung ste/ de gnyis steng gi nam mkha' la dong ngo / / ji tsam na klu rnams kyis mthong nas de gnyis kyi phyir stan gnyis bshams shing dkyil 'khor yang gnyis byas so/ /

“ ‘Will I not fall?’ “ ‘Dear sir, even if you were to hang Mount Sumeru from the corner of his robe, it would not fall. What need is there to speak of you?’ “With their encouragement, the novice ward went to where his preceptor used his miraculous powers to disappear, and waited. When his preceptor disappeared, the novice ward grabbed hold of the corner of his preceptor’s robe and together they rose into the sky above. After a time, [F.119.a] the nāgas caught sight of them and arranged two seats along with two plates of offerings for them.

des bsams pa/ ci'i phyir stan bshams pa dang / dkyil 'khor gzhan 'di byas snyam nas/ des rgyab tu blta bar brtsams pa dang / ji tsam na dge tshul de mthong nas/ des smras pa/ bu khyod kyang 'ongs sam/ mkhan po mchis so/ / legs so/ /

“The preceptor thought, ‘Why have they set out this second seat and plate of offerings?’ Looking behind him, he saw the novice and asked, ‘Son, you too have come?’ “ ‘Yes, preceptor, I have.’ “ ‘Good.’

klu rnams kyis bsams pa/ 'phags pa 'di ni rdzu 'phrul che ba mthu che ba yin pas lha'i bdud rtsi zhu bar nus na/ 'phags pa 'dis ni zhu bar mi nus kyis/ 'di la kha zas tha mal pa sbyin par bya'o snyam nas/ de rnams kyis gcig la ni lha'i bdud rtsi byin no/ / dge tshul la ni kha zas tha mal pa byin no/ / dge tshul de de'i lhung bzed thogs pa yin pas des mkhan po la lhung bzed blangs pa dang / de 'bras can gyi gzegs ma gcig chags nas/ dge tshul des de khar bcug ste myangs na lha'i bdud rtsi yin nas/ des bsams pa/ klu rnams ni ser sna can yin te/ lhan cig tu 'khod pa gnyis la/ gcig la ni lha'i bdud rtsi byin la/ gcig la ni kha zas tha mal pa byin no snyam mo/ /

“The nāgas thought, ‘This noble one has miraculous powers and great might and so can digest divine ambrosia. But this noble novice cannot. We had better give him ordinary food.’ “To the preceptor, they gave divine ambrosia, but to the novice they gave ordinary food. Because the novice generally tended to the preceptor’s begging bowl, he picked up the preceptor’s begging bowl and on doing so, saw that a single grain of rice had stuck to it. The novice put it in his mouth and on tasting it, knew it to be divine ambrosia. He thought, ‘These nāgas are stingy. Two sit down together and to one they give divine ambrosia but to the other they give ordinary food.’

de nas de mi bzod pa skyes pas bdag gis bcom ldan 'das yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas yon gnas bla na med pa 'od srung gi spyan sngar tshangs par spyod pa spyad pa gang yin pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba 'dis bdag klu 'di gnas 'di nas nyams par byas te 'di nyid du skye bar gyur cig ces smon lam log par btab bo/ /

“Unable to bear it, he made a misguided prayer, ‘May these roots of virtue from living the holy life under the guidance of the perfectly awakened and blessed Buddha Kāśyapa, an unsurpassed object of veneration, ensure that I be born right here after I have left this land of the nāgas.’

las shin tu chen po yongs su rdzogs pa dag ni lus rje ba la mi ltos pas/ tshe de nyid la de'i lag pa gnyis nas chu 'dzag par gyur cing / klu de yang klad pa'i nad kyis btab par gyur nas des 'phrigs te smras pa/ 'phags pa dge tshul 'dis sems mi bzang ba bskyed kyis/ 'di zlog shig / des dge tshul de la 'di skad ces smras so/ /bu 'di dag la sems mi bzang ba bskyed pa bzlog shig / des tshigs su bcad pa smras pa/

“As prodigious and complete actions [S.49.b] are not contingent on a change of body, in that very life water began to drip from the novice’s hands, while the nāga host began to suffer a throbbing headache, prompting him to demand of the preceptor, ‘Noble one, this novice has given rise to an ignoble wish. Make him repudiate it!’ “The preceptor said to the novice, ‘Son, reject your ignoble wish to be among them.’ “Then the novice spoke this verse:
sems ni thag ring gyur pa ste/ / 'di ltar 'di na gnas bzhin du/ / bdag gi lag tu chu 'dzags pas/ / bzlog par bgyi bar mi nus so/ /
“ ‘This wish is so far-reaching, As I stay here in this land [F.119.b] With water falling from my hands I lack the power to reject it.’
des klu de gnas de nas nyams par byas nas de nyid du skyes te/ dge slong dag klu gzhon nu sprul pas dang por der dad pa thob par gyur to// //
“Thus, he lost his life in the land of the nāgas only to be reborn again in that very place. And that, monks, is how the youthful, shape-shifting nāga first gained faith.”
[mu stegs can]
Tīrthikas

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / ji tsam na mu stegs can zhig rgyal byed kyi tshal du phyin pa dang / des de na stan bzang po bshams pa dang / bza' ba dang btung ba bsod pa'i spyi bungs bshams pa mthong nas des bsams pa/ zang zing gi longs spyod ni shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong 'di dag gi bzang la/ chos kyi longs spyod ni bdag cag gi bzang bas de'i phyir 'di dag gi nang du rab tu byung la/ zang zing gi longs spyod ni 'dir bya zhing chos kyi longs spyod ni der bya'o snyam nas/

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a tīrthika arrived at Jetavana. When this tīrthika saw the fine seats arranged there and the array of communal food and drink, he thought, “As far as culinary pleasures are concerned, these ascetic sons of the Śākya have it good. But as far as the wealth of Dharma is concerned, ours is better. So I shall go forth and take my meals here while taking my Dharma among my fellow tīrthika.”
de dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ / des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas so/ /
With that thought, he approached a monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth”; his going forth was allowed, and he was granted ordination.

mu stegs can rnams kyi gso sbyong ni bcu bzhi pa yin la/ dge slong rnams kyi gso sbyong ni bcwa lnga pa yin pas de tshes bcu bzhi la ni mu stegs can rnams kyi gso sbyong nyams su myong bar byed/ tshes bcwa lnga la ni dge sbyong rnams kyi'o/ /

As the tīrthikas’ purification takes place on the fourteenth day of the month, while the monks’ purification takes place on the fifteenth day of the month, he would participate in the tīrthikas’ purification on the fourteenth day and the monks’ on the fifteenth.

ci tsam dus gzhan zhig na zhag bri bar gyur nas/ dge slong rnams kyi gso sbyong bcu bzhi pa la bab pa dang / de la the tsom skyes te/ ci der 'gro bar bya 'am/ 'on te 'di nyid du gso sbyong nyams su myong bar bya snyam pa las/
After some time, a day was skipped[191] and the monks’ purification fell on the fourteenth, which caused him some consternation: “Should I join them there or participate in the purification here?”

de la blo skyes pa shAkya'i bu'i dge sbyong 'di dag ni des pa 'grogs na bde ba yin la bdag gi tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams ni ngang tshul ngan pa yin pas gal te ma song na bdag gi tshul shing yang phyung bar 'gyur/ spang leb khri'u yang bsgyur bar 'gyur/ slong phor yang khas bub par 'gyur/ khar ba yang bor bar 'gyur/ tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa rnams kyi nang nas kyang phyung bar 'gyur ro snyam nas/

Then he had an idea: “These ascetic sons of the Śākya are more easy going, but my fellow brahmacārin are bad-tempered. If I don’t join them, they may even split my tally stick, switch out my seat plank, overturn my alms bowl, throw out my staff, and expel me from among my fellow brahmacārin.”

de mu stegs can rnams kyi nang du song ngo / / ji tsam na dge skos rgan pa'i mtha' logs su 'greng ste/ dge slong rnams bsngos pa na de mi snang nas des dri bar brtsams pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag dge slong ming 'di zhes bya ba zhig 'dir 'ongs sam/ de'i 'dun pa yang 'ongs sam/ de dag gis smras pa/ ma 'ongs so/ /

And so he attended the tīrthikas’ purification. Meanwhile, the disciplinarian stood at the end of the senior monks’ row. [F.120.a] When the monks were counted, the disciplinarian noticed that the monk, who was still committed to his tīrthika order, was missing so he asked, “Venerables, has the monk [monk’s name] come or sent his consent ?”[192] “No.”

bcom ldan 'das kyis phyogs bzhir bltas nas gso sbyong bya'o zhes bka' stsal pas/ dge slong de dag gis phyogs bzhir bltas te gso sbyong byas so/ / de'i 'og tu phyi de nyin par dge slong de 'ongs pa dang / dge slong rnams kyis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod gang nas 'ongs/ des smras pa/ tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa dag gi gan nas so/ / khyod kyi tshangs pa mtshungs par spyod pa dag su yin/ mu stegs can dag yin te/ kho bo zang zing gi longs spyod ni khyed cag gi gan du byed la/ chos kyi longs spyod ni de dag gi gan du byed do zhes zer ba'i skabs de

After looking around him into the four directions, the Blessed One declared, “Let us perform the purification.” The monks then looked around them into the four directions and performed the purification. Later that same day, the monk arrived and the monks asked him, “Venerable, where have you come from?” “From the company of my fellow brahmacārin.” “Who are your fellow brahmacārin?” “The tīrthikas, for I enjoy my food with you and my Dharma with them.”

bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / de na bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag 'di ni mu stegs can zhugs pa yin te/ dge slong dag gang zag mu stegs can zhugs pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag mu stegs can zhugs pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la mu stegs can zhugs pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The monks then asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One decreed, “Monks, this person is a convert to a tīrthika order. A person who is a convert to a tīrthika order will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya. Therefore, you must banish from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who are converts to a tīrthika order. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You are not a convert to a tīrthika order, are you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyis gang zag mu stegs can zhugs pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o zhes bka' stsal na/ btsun pa ji tsam gyis na gang zag mu stegs can zhugs pa bsnyil bar bgyi ba lags/

The venerable Upāli asked the Blessed One, “Reverend, since the Blessed One has said, ‘You must banish from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who are converts to a tīrthika order,’ then reverend, what is it that makes those persons who are converts to a tīrthika order fit for exclusion?”
nye ba 'khor gang tshun chad nas rgyal mtshan 'di 'chang zhing lta ba de la dga' bas der skya rengs 'char bar byed na/ de tsam gyis na gang zag mu stegs can zhugs pa bsnyil bar bya ba yin no// //

“Upāli, he who bears this banner while still being enamored with that view invites the dusk, [S.50.a] and for that alone you must banish from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who are converts to a tīrthika order.”
[ma gsod pa]
Matricides

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i bu byung nas des chung ma la smras pa/ bzang mo 'u bu cag gi bu lon 'khor bar byed pa/ nor spyod pa btsas pas kho bo zong thogs te yul gzhan du 'gro bar bya'o/ / des smras pa/ rje'i sras de bzhin mdzod cig /

The Blessed Buddha [F.120.b] was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself then gave birth to a son, after which the householder said to her, “Noble woman, our debts are spinning out of control and cutting into our savings, so I will take some merchandise to sell in another land.” She replied, “Son of a lord, do as you wish.”
de zong thogs te yul gzhan du song ba dang / de nyid du tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur to/ / des kyang bu de nye du'i stobs dang lag mthus bsnyod cing gsos te bskyed do/ /

The householder departed with his merchandise for another land where, through indiscretion, he came to misfortune. And so his wife, with the help of relatives and by her own industry, fed and nurtured their son as he grew.

de dus gzhan zhig na ne'u ldangs dang lhan cig khyim zhig gi drung du song ba na/ khyim de'i steng na bu mo zhig 'dug pa des de'i steng du me tog gi chun po 'phangs pa dang / des bu mo de mthong ngo / / ne'u ldangs des smras pa/ grogs po khyod kyis khyim der brda ma byas sam/ des smras pa/ de yin te/ kho bos brda byas so/ / des smras pa/ grogs po khyim 'di na ya nga ba yin gyis ma 'jug shig /tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur ta re zhes

In time, the lad went with a peer to a house, where a girl sitting on the house’s roof threw down a bouquet of flowers to catch his notice. His peer asked, “Friend, you haven’t arranged a rendezvous at this house, have you?” “Indeed I have, and that is our signal,” the lad replied. “Friend, this house is ill-omened, don’t go in. I warn you, through indiscretion you will come to suffering.”

des nyin thog thag tu 'phyan du bcug ste/ ma'i gan du khrid nas smras pa/ ma khyod kyi bu 'dis khyim che ge mo zhig tu brda byas pa/ kho bos nyin thog thag tu bsrungs kyis mtshan mo srungs shig /khyim de ni ya nga ba yin gyis 'jug tu ma gzhug cig /tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur ta re/

The lad’s friend then led him on a long detour that took the entire day, eventually leading him back to his mother, to whom the lad’s friend said, “Ma’am, your son here has arranged a rendezvous at a girl’s house. I have safeguarded him the whole day, but you must safeguard him through the night. That house is ill-omened. Do not let him go in. Beware, through indiscretion he will come to suffering.”

des smras pa/ bu khyod kyis kho mo la bsnyad pa khyod kyis legs par byas so/ / des khye'u de khyim gyi nang du mal bcas te gyo mo gnyis dang / chu dang / sa dag bzhag nas khyim der bcug ste/ bdag nyid sgor khri bcas nas nyal lo/ /

She said, “Son, you have done well to inform me.” She arranged a bed for her son in the house, along with two clay chamber pots, water, and fresh earth cover, and installed her son in the house, saying, “I myself will sleep on a cot by the door.”
des smras pa/ ma sgo phye shig / bu ci'i phyir/ gcir 'gro'o/ / des smras pa/ bu 'di nyid du kho mos gyo mo bzhag gis der gcis cig /
“Mother, open the door.” “Why, son?” “I must go out and urinate.” “Son, I have placed a chamber pot there. Urinate in that.”
des yud tsam zhig bsdad de smras pa/ ma sgo phye shig /bu ci'i phyir/ bshang du 'gro'o/ / des smras pa/ bu 'di nyid du kho mos gyo mo dang / chu dang / sa bzhag gis 'di nyid du bshang ba byos shig /

He sat down for a bit and then said, “Mother, open the door.” “Why, son?” [F.121.a] “I must go out and defecate.” “Son, I have placed a chamber pot, water, and fresh earth cover there. Defecate in that.”

des yang yud tsam zhig bsdad de smras pa/ ma sgo phye shig /des smras pa/ bu khyod gang du 'gro 'dod pa kho mos mi shes sam ci/ kho mos sgo dbye bar mi nus so/ / ma kho bos khyod bsad do/ / des smras pa/ bu kho mo shi ba ni bla'i/ kho mo bu shi ba la lta ni mi phod do/ /

Again, he sat for a bit before saying, “Mother, open the door.” “Son, do you think I don’t know where you want to go? I cannot open the door for you.” “Mother, I shall kill you.” “Son, I can face my own death, but I couldn’t bear watching my son die.”

'dod pa sten pas ni sdig pa'i las mi bya ba ci yang med pas snying rje med pa'i sems dang ldan pa/ 'jig rten pha rol btang ba des ral gri shubs nas phyung ste de'i mgo drungs nas bcad de sa la bsgyel to/ / des ma bsad nas song ba dang / sems can sdig pa'i las byas pa 'dar bas/

In the pursuit of passion, there is nothing he would not do. His mind merciless, and forsaking all thought of future lives, he unsheathed his knife and cut off his mother’s head at the neck, which tumbled to the floor. Having killed his mother, he left, trembling like a man who has committed a sin.
bu mo des de la smras pa/ rje'i sras 'di na su yang ma mchis te/ bdag bu mo dang gnyis su bas kyis ma bsnyengs shig /
The girl with whom he had a rendezvous said to him, “Son of a lord, there is no one, there is no other girl but me. Do not be afraid.”

des bsams pa/ de 'di la smras na dga' bar 'gyur ro snyam nas/ des smras pa/ bzang mo kho bos khyod kyi phyir ma bsad do/ / des smras pa/ ci ma ma'am/ 'on te skyed ma mo/ des smras pa/ skyed ma mo'o/ /

Thinking, “She will be pleased if I tell her what I’ve done,” he said, “Noble woman, I have killed my mother for your sake.” “What? Your wet nurse or the woman who gave birth to you?” “The woman who gave birth to me.”

des bsams pa/ 'di yon tan dag mngon par mi shes te ma gsod par byed pas gang gi tshe bdag la khro ba skyes na/ bdag la gnas skabs ci zhig 'byung bar 'gyur snyam nas/ des smras pa/ rje'i sras bdag steng gi khang thog tu 'dzegs nas slar mchi ba'i bar du re zhig yud tsam zhig gzhes shig / des smras pa/ de bzhin gyis shig /de nas de steng gi khang thog tu 'dzegs nas chom rkun pa chom rkun pa zhes sgra phyung ba dang /

“He has killed his mother without regard for her importance to him,” thought the girl. “What chance would I stand if at some point he became angry with me?” Then she said to the lad, “Son of a lord, please wait a moment while I climb up to the roof of the house.” [S.50.b] “Go ahead,” he replied. On reaching the roof, she cried out, “A thief! A thief!”

des 'jigs shing skrag nas bros te rang gi khyim du song nas sgo drung du ral gri bzhag ste chom rkun pa de ni 'di yin te/ kho bo'i ma bsad nas bros so zhes sgra phyung nas des de'i ma'i ro de bkur sti byas te song ngo / /
The lad, scared and frightened, fled back to his own house and laid his knife at the doorstep before crying out, “That thief has been here! He has killed my mother and fled!”

sems can sdig pa'i las byas pas ni brtan pa mi rnyed pas de mu stegs can gyi gnas dang / dka' thub kyi gnas de dang de dag tu song ste dris pa/ shes ldan dag las ci zhig byas na sdig pa'i las zad par 'gyur/ de na kha cig na re mer zhugs shig ces zer ro/ /

After performing rites of veneration over his mother’s corpse, the lad left home. But a person who has done wrong finds no serenity, so he sought out tīrthika communities and communities of ascetics and asked, “Gentlemen, what can one do to expunge an evil act?” [F.121.b]

kha cig na re dug zo shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re g.yang sar mchongs shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re thag pas 'gegs te shi shig ces zer te/ thams cad kyang shi ba'i thabs ston par byed kyi nges par 'byung ba'i thabs ston pa ni 'ga' yang med do/ /

To that, some said, “Immolate yourself”; some said, “Take poison”; some said, “Jump off a cliff”;[193] and some said, “Strangle yourself with a rope.” All of them recommended some form of suicide; none could offer any means of expiation.

de dus gzhan zhig na rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ba dang / des de na dge slong zhig / gang gis sdig pa'i las byas pa/ / dge ba yis ni 'gog byed de/ / nyi zla sprin nas byung ba ltar/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni der snang 'gyur/ /

Later, he went to Jetavana, where he posed his question to a monk, who recited a verse: “He who has done some wrong May curb it through virtue To bring light to this life, As the sun and moon appear from behind clouds.”

zhes kha ton zer ba thos nas/ des bsams pa/ sdig pa'i las kyang dgag par nus kyis 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung ngo snyam nas/ de dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ / des de rab tu byung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas/ des shin tu brtson 'grus brtsams te bklag par brtsams so/ / des klog cing kha ton byed pa na sde snod gsum bklags shing sde snod gsum dang ldan pa/ rigs pa dang grol ba'i spobs pa can du gyur to/ /

On hearing this verse, the lad thought, “Ah! Even wrongdoing can be checked! I shall go forth among these people.” He then approached the monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.” After his going forth was allowed and he was ordained, he applied himself diligently and began to recite the scriptures. In reciting and saying prayers, he recited and memorized the Three Piṭakas and gained the confidence born of knowledge and freedom.

de la dge slong dag gis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod brtson 'grus 'dis ci zhig don du gnyer des smras pa/ sdig pa'i las zad par bya'o/ / khyod kyis sdig pa'i las ci byas/ ma bsad do/ / ci ma ma'am/ 'on te skyed ma mo yin/ des smras pa/ skyed ma mo yin no zhes zer ba'i skabs de

The monks asked him, “Venerable, what motivates such diligence in you?” “I must expunge a wrongdoing,” he replied. “What wrongdoing are you guilty of?” “I killed my mother.” “Your wet nurse or the woman who gave birth to you?” “My birth mother.”

bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag 'di ni gang zag ma bsad pa bsnyil bar 'os pa yin te/ dge slong dag gang zag ma bsad pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag ma bsad pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs pa na des de la ma bsad pa ma yin nam/ zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The monks asked the Blessed One about it, and he said to the monks, “Monks, a person who has killed his mother is fit to be excluded from the community, for a person who has killed his mother will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya. For that reason, monks, you should exclude from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who have killed their mothers. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘Are you a matricide?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

des bsams pa/ ci 'babs par bya'am/ mtha' 'khob tu 'gro bar bya snyam nas/ de mtha' 'khob tu song ste/ khyim bdag cig rjes su 'jug par byas so/ / des mngon par dad pas de'i phyir gtsug lag khang rtsig tu bcug ste/ de phyogs dang yul tha dad pa na 'khod pa'i dge slong dag gnas shing de'i gdams ngag gis mang po dag gis dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas so/ /

The monk who had killed his mother thought, [F.122.a] “Where will I wind up? I must go into the wilds.” And with that, he went into the wilds, where a householder became his follower. Out of deep devotion, the householder had a monastery erected for the monk, where monks from various regions and lands came to live, many of whom went on to actualize arhatship under his guidance.

de dus gzhan zhig na na bar gyur nas rtsa ba dang / sdong bu dang / lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu'i sman dag gis rim gro byas na/ nyam dmas pa nyid du gyur nas/ des lhan cig gnas pa rnams la smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag kho bo'i phyir dge 'dun la bsro khang gyis shig /de rnams kyis de'i phyir bsro khang bgyis so/ /

Sometime later, the monk matricide fell ill. Although the other monks ministered to him with medicinal roots, stalks, leaves, flowers, and fruits, he continued to get worse. The monk matricide then told his wards, “Venerables, prepare a dry sauna for the saṅgha and for me.” His monk apprentices then prepared a dry sauna for him.
bsags pa kun gyi mtha' zad cing / / mthon po rnams kyi mtha' ltung 'gyur/ / phrad pa'i mtha' ni 'bral ba ste/ / gson pa'i mtha' ni 'chi ba yin/ /

zhes bya ba yin pas de shi zhing dus la bab nas sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes so/ / de'i lhan cig gnas pa dgra bcom pa zhig gis bdag gi mkhan po gang du skyes zhes sems par zhugs nas de lha rnams kyi nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na ma mthong zhing mi dang / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas rnams kyi nang du rnam par bltas na de yang ma mthong ngo / / sems can dmyal ba'i nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na/ sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes par mthong nas/

So his time came and he died, and he was reborn among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment. One of his arhat wards entered into meditation to find out where his preceptor had been reborn and began searching for him among the gods, but he did not see him there. Nor did he see him when he looked among humans, animals, and spirits. When he began to search among the denizens of hell, he saw that his preceptor had been reborn among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment.

des bsams pa/ mkhan po ni tshul khrims dang ldan pa mang du thos pa/ chos kyi 'khor sdud sdud pa yin na/ des las ci zhig byas na des sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes snyam nas bsams na ma bsad pa yin par mthong ngo de mnar med pa'i 'od zer dag gis phog pa dang smras pa kye ma bsro khang 'di me re tsha zhes smras pa dang sems can dmyal ba'i srung mas tho ba blangs te mgor bsnun nas skal chad khyod kyi bsro khang ga la yod 'di ltar 'di ni sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med pa yin no/ / zhes smras so/ /

The arhat ward wondered, “If my preceptor was ethical, learned, and attracted a following with the Dharma, what did he do that it should lead him to be reborn among the denizens of Avīci?” [S.51.a] He then saw that it was matricide. Struck by the fiery light of Avīci, the monk matricide cried, “Oh! The heat in this dry sauna is too much!” As soon as he cried out, the guardians of hell lifted their maces and clubbed him on the head, shouting, “Hapless fool! Where is this dry sauna of yours? This is Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment!” [F.122.b]

de dge ba'i sems kyis dus la bab nas rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes so/ / lha'i bu'am/ lha'i bu mo'i chos nyid ni skyes nas ring po ma lon pa la sems gsum skye ste/ gang nas shi 'phos pa dang gang du skyes pa dang las gang gis skyes pa'o/ / des sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang nas shi 'phos pa dang rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes pa dang / dge 'dun la bsro khang gi khrus byas pas skyes pa mthong ngo / /

This virtuous thought[194] brought the former monk matricide’s time in hell to an end, and he was reborn among the gods in the realms of the Four Great Kings. It is in the nature of gods and goddesses to have three thoughts shortly after birth: where they have passed on from, where they have been born, and what action has caused that rebirth. Thus the former monk matricide saw he had passed from among the denizens of hell and been reborn among the gods in the realms of the Four Great Kings due to his having washed the dry sauna for the saṅgha.

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu de 'di snyam du sems te gang gi phyir bdag zhag lon par gnas te bcom ldan 'das la blta ba dang bsnyen bkur bya ba'i phyir nye bar 'gro ba ni bdag gi tshul dang mthun pa ma yin gyis/ bdag zhag lon par ma gnas pa kho nar bcom ldan 'das la blta ba dang / bsnyen bkur bya ba'i phyir nye bar 'gro'o snyam mo/ /

Then the young god, who had formerly been a denizen of hell, had this thought: “It would not be right of me to spend a day here without going to see and pay my respects to the Blessed One. Thus, before the day is out, I shall go to see and pay my respects to the Blessed One.”

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu rna cha gdub kor g.yo zhing dri ma med pa thogs te/ do shal dang se mo dos brgyan pa'i lus kyis lha'i ut+pal dang / pad ma dang / ku mu da dang / pad ma dkar po dag gis thu ba bkang ste kha dog shin tu 'das pas mtshan mo la bab pa dang / bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das la me tog dag gis mngon par gtor te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal nas mtha' gcig tu 'dug pa dang / 'di ltar sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu'i kha dog gi mthus rgyal byed kyi tshal thams cad snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur to/ /

The young god donned a pair of glittering hooped earrings that swung to and fro, adorned his body with two pearl necklaces, one long and one medium in length, filled the folds of his skirt with the dazzling colors of divine blue lotus flowers, lotuses, water lilies, and white lotuses, and when night had fallen, set out to see the Blessed One. On his arrival, he strewed the flowers before the Blessed One and bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet before taking a place off to one side. The colors of the young god filled the whole of Jetavana with a great light.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu'i bsam pa dang / bag la nyal ba dang / khams dang rang bzhin thugs su chud nas gang thos nas sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bus stan de nyid la 'dug bzhin du 'jig tshogs la lta ba'i ri'i rtse mo nyi shu mtho ba ye shes kyi rdo rjes bcom ste/ rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu mngon sum du byas pa de lta bur 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi yang dag par so sor rtogs par byed pa'i chos bstan pa mdzad do/ /

As the young god sat on a seat, the Blessed One intuited his thoughts, propensities, disposition, and nature and proceeded to teach the Dharma he needed to hear in order to fully realize each of the Noble Ones’ four truths, thus actualizing the fruit of a stream enterer by decimating with the lightning bolt of wisdom the mountain of belief in the transient aggregates with its twenty tall peaks. [F.123.a]

des bden pa mthong nas/ btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag la gang mdzad pa 'di lta bu ni bdag la phas kyang ma bgyis/ mas kyang ma bgyis/ rgyal pos kyang ma bgyis/ lha rnams kyis kyang ma bgyis/ sngon gyi pha mes dag gis kyang ma bgyis/ dge sbyong dang bram ze dag gis kyang ma bgyis/ byams pa dang / mdza' bshes dang / rtsa lag gi tshogs kyis kyang ma bgyis te/ khrag dang mchi ma'i rgya mtsho ni bskams/ rus pa'i ri dag las ni bsgral/ ngan song gi sgo dag ni bkum/ mtho ris dang thar pa'i sgo dag ni phye/ sems can dmyal ba dang / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dag nas ni rkang pa phyung / lha dang mi rnams kyi nang du ni bzhag go zhes lan gsum du ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do/ /

Upon seeing the truth, the young god spoke this panegyric thrice: “Reverend, what the Blessed One has done for me, my father did not do for me, nor did my mother, nor did the king, nor did the gods, nor did my ancestors, nor did ascetics or brahmins, nor did my circle of loved ones and friends, nor did my forebears. For the Blessed One has dried up the ocean of blood and tears, freed me from mountains of bones, shut the door to miserable realms, opened the door to higher realms and liberation, dragged me up by the leg from among the denizens of hell, animals, and spirits, and installed me among gods and humans.”
yang smras pa/ khyod mthus rab drag nyes pa mang ldan pa'i/ / ngan song shul bkag bsod nams rab ldan pa'i/ / mtho ris 'gro ba phye zhing bdag gis ni/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i shul yang thob par gyur/ /

The young god spoke again: “Because of you, the path to miserable realms Of terrible and diverse punishments is blocked And the road to higher realms of great merit has opened. I have even found the way to nirvāṇa.
shin tu rnam dag khyod brten bdag gis ni/ / de ring skyon bral dag pa'i mig thob cing / / go 'phang zhi ba 'phags pa dgyes thob ste/ / sdug bsngal rgya mtsho'i pha rol rgal bar gyur/ /
“By relying on you, one of utter purity, I have today gained flawless, pure vision, Have gained the pacific state pleasing to saints, And crossed over the seas of suffering.
'gro bar lha min mi dang lhas mchod pa/ / skye dang rga dang na 'chi bral ba po/ / srid pa stong du mthong bar rab dkon pa/ / thub pa de ring khyod mthong 'bras bu mchis/ /
de nas 'dud byas do shal rab 'phyang bas/ / zhabs la phyag 'tshal rangs pa skyes gyur nas/ / dgra thul g.yas nas yongs su bskor byas te/ / lha yi 'jig rten mngon phyogs mkha' la song / /
“As I bow with my necklace hanging low, Prostrate at your feet, I feel jubilant. Circling the one who has tamed his enemies I turn to the heavens and fly into the sky.”

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu tshong pa khe spogs rnyed pa lta bu dang / zhing pa lo tog 'byor pa lta bu dang / dpa' bo g.yul las rnam par rgyal ba lta bu dang / nad pa nad thams cad las yongs su thar pa lta bur gyur te/ cha lugs gang gis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'ongs pa'i cha lugs de nyid kyis rang gi gnas su song ngo / /

The young god then departed like a trader who has made a profit, a farmer who has reaped his crops, a warrior who has won a battle, or an ill person who has been delivered from all his ills, and, in the dress in which he arrived in the Blessed One’s presence, returned home.

de'i lhan cig gnas pa dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan dgra bcom pa zas kyi gral du 'dug ste/ de'i lhan cig gnas pa gzhan zhig dge 'dun la chu 'grim par byed do/ / ji tsam na dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan des chu kha phor du blangs nas sor mo'i rtse mos reg na shin tu grangs nas des bsams pa/ bdag cag ni chu shin tu grang mo 'di lta bu 'thung na/ mkhan po ni sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med pa na zangs khu bskol ba 'thung ngo snyam nas/

One of the young god’s former wards, an elder in the saṅgha and an arhat, [F.123.b] was seated in the meal row, while another of his wards [S.51.b] was distributing water to the saṅgha. After a time, the saṅgha elder lifted his cup of water. It felt extremely cold to the touch of the tip of his fingers, and he thought, “While we drink water as cold as this, the preceptor drinks molten copper among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment.”

des sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par rnam par blta bar brtsams na mi snang ngo / / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dang / mi dang / sems can dmyal ba gzhan rnams su yang rnam par bltas na/ de rnams na yang mi snang nas/ lha rnams kyi bar gyi nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na/ rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes te lhar gyur pas bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar bden pa mthong bar byas te lha rnams kyi nang na 'dug pa mthong nas 'dzum pa sngon du btang ste/ bcom ldan 'das la dad pa thob nas/ kye ma sangs rgyas/ kye ma chos/ kye ma dge 'dun/ kye ma chos kyi legs par gsungs pa nyid/ 'di ltar sdig pa byed pa log par ltung bar song ba de lta bu dag gis kyang yon tan gyi tshogs 'di lta bu thob bo zhes ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do/ /

Yet when this arhat elder then searched for his preceptor among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment, his preceptor was nowhere to be seen. When the arhat elder searched for him among the animals, spirits, and denizens of other hells, he was nowhere to be seen there either. And so he began to search for him among the gods. There he saw that his preceptor had been reborn among the gods in the realm of the Four Great Kings and, having become a god, saw the truth in the Blessed One’s presence before returning to remain among the gods. Smiling, the arhat elder gained faith in the Blessed One and spoke this panegyric: “O Buddha! O Dharma! O Saṅgha! O the well-spoken Dharma by which even wrongdoers led into such fallen states can attain such a collection of qualities!”

mkhan po gcig pa des de rangs shing mgu ba dang / mchog tu dga' ba mthong nas smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod mkhan po dus la bab pas bdag dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan du gyur to snyam nas rangs shing mgu ba dang mchog tu dga' bar gyur tam/ des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa re zhig khyod kyi dri ba'i lan gdab pa'i dus ma yin gyis/ dge 'dun gyi nang du dris shig dang der khyod kyi dri ba'i lan gdab pa'i dus la bab par 'gyur ro/ /

A student of the same preceptor saw him looking jubilant, pleased, and overjoyed and asked, “Venerable, are you so jubilant, pleased, and overjoyed by the thought that now that the preceptor’s time has come, you are the saṅgha elder?” The arhat elder replied, “Venerable, now is not the time to answer your question. Ask me when we are among the saṅgha and that will prove the time to answer your question.”

ji tsam na dus gzhan zhig na dge slong gi dge 'dun tshogs shing 'khod pa na/ dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan gyis mkhan po gcig pa de la dris pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod kyis de'i tshe ci smras des smras pa/ khyod la kho bos khyod mkhan po dus la bab pas bdag dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan du gyur to snyam nas rangs shing mgu ba dang mchog tu dga' bar gyur tam zhes smras so/ /

Later, after the monks of the saṅgha gathered and were seated, the saṅgha elder asked their preceptor’s student, “Venerable, what was it you wanted to ask me?” “I asked you, ‘Venerable, are you so jubilant, pleased, [F.124.a] and overjoyed by the thought that now that the preceptor’s time has come, you are the saṅgha elder?’ ”

des skabs de dge 'dun gyi nang du de la rgya cher brjod pa dang / de yang yi rangs shing dge slong rnams kyang kye ma sangs rgyas/ kye ma chos/ kye ma dge 'dun/ kye ma chos kyi legs par gsungs pa nyid 'di ltar sdig pa byed pa log par ltung bar song ba de lta bu dag gis kyang yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do// //

While seated among the saṅgha, the arhat elder explained the situation at length to his fellow student. His fellow student then also rejoiced, as did the saṅgha, who spoke this panegyric: “O Buddha! O Dharma! O Saṅgha! O the well-spoken Dharma by which even wrongdoers led into fallen states can attain such a collection of qualities!”
'dul ba gzhi/ bam po bcu gcig pa/
[pha gsod pa]
Patricides

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / mnyan yod na khyim bdag cig 'dug pa des rigs mnyam pa las chung ma blangs nas de de dang lhan cig rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed do/ / rtse bar byed/ dga' bar byed/ dga' mgur spyod par byed pa de'i bu byung nas/

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī, when a householder living in Śrāvastī took a wife of equal caste and together they played with, took pleasure in, and amused one another. The wife with whom he had played, taken pleasure, and amused himself later gave birth to a son.
