de dus gzhan zhig na ne'u ldangs dang lhan cig khyim zhig gi drung du song ba na khyim de'i steng na bu mo zhig 'dug pa des de'i steng du me tog gi chun po 'phangs pa dang / des bu mo de mthong ngo / / ne'u ldangs kyis smras pa/ grogs po khyod kyis khyim der brda ma byas sam/ des smras pa/ de yin te/ kho bos brda byas so/ /

In time, the lad went with a peer to a house, where a girl sitting on the house’s roof threw down a bouquet of flowers to catch his attention. His peer asked, “Friend, you haven’t arranged a rendezvous at this house, have you?” “Indeed I have, and that is our signal,” the lad replied.

des smras pa/ grogs po khyim 'di ni ya nga ba yin gyis ma 'jug shig /tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur ta re zhes des nyin thog thag 'phyan du bcug ste pha'i gan du khrid nas smras pa/ yab khyod kyi bu 'dis khyim che ge mo zhig tu brda byas pa/ kho bos ni nyin thog thag tu bsrungs kyis/ da khyod kyis mtshan mo srungs shig /khyim de ni ya nga ba yin gyis 'jug tu ma gzhug cig /tshul ma yin pas sdug bsngal bar gyur ta re/

“Friend, this house is ill-omened, don’t go in. I warn you, through indiscretion you will come to suffering.” The lad’s friend then led him on a long detour that took the entire day, eventually leading him back to his father, to whom the lad’s friend said, “Sir, your son here has arranged a rendezvous at a girl’s house. I have safeguarded him the whole day so you must safeguard him through the night. That house is ill-omened. Do not let him enter. Beware, through indiscretion he will come to suffering.”

des smras pa/ bu khyod kyis kho bo la bsnyad pa khyod kyis legs par byas so/ / des khye'u de khyim gyi nang du mal bcas te/ gyo mo gnyis dang / chu dang / sa dag bzhag nas khyim der bcug ste/ bdag nyid sgor khri bcas nas nyal lo/ /

“Son, you have done well to inform me.” He arranged a bed for his son in the house, along with two clay chamber pots, water, and fresh earth cover, and installed his son in the house, saying, “I myself will sleep on a cot by the door.”
des smras pa/ yab sgo phye shig /bu ci'i phyir/ gcir 'gro'o/ / des smras pa/ bu 'di nyid du kho bos gyo mo bzhag gis der gci shig /
“Father, open the door.” “Why, son?” “I must go out to urinate.” “Son, [F.124.b] I have placed a chamber pot there. Urinate in that.”

des yud tsam zhig bsdad de smras pa/ yab sgo phye shig / bu ci'i phyir/ bshang du 'gro'o/ / des smras pa/ bu 'di nyid du kho bos gyo mo dang / chu dang / sa dag bzhag gis 'di nyid du bshang ba byos shig /
He sat down for a bit and then said, “Father, open the door.” “Why, son?” “I must go out to defecate.” “Son, I have placed a chamber pot, water, and fresh earth cover there. Defecate in that.”

des yang yud tsam zhig bsdad de smras pa/ yab sgo phye shig /des smras pa/ bu khyod gang du 'gro 'dod pa kho bos mi shes sam ci/ kho bos sgo dbye bar mi nus so/ / yab kho bos khyod bsad do/ / des smras pa/ bu kho bo shi ba ni bla'i/ kho bo bu shi ba la lta ni mi phod do/ /

Again, he sat for a bit before saying, “Father, open the door.” “Son, do you think I don’t know where you want to go? I cannot open the door for you.” “Father, I shall kill you.” “Son, I can face my own death, but I couldn’t bear watching my son die.”

'dod pa sten pas ni sdig pa'i las mi bya ba ci yang med pas snying rje med pa'i sems dang ldan pa 'jig rten pha rol btang ba des ral gri shubs nas phyung ste/ de'i mgo drungs nas bcad de sa la bsgyel to/ / des pha bsad nas song ba dang sems can sdig pa'i las byas pa 'dar bas

In the pursuit of passion, there is nothing he would not do. His mind merciless and forsaking all thought of future lives, he unsheathed his knife and cut off his father’s head at the neck, which tumbled to the floor. Having killed his father, he left, trembling like a man who has committed a sin.
bu mo des de la smras pa/ rje'i sras 'di na su yang ma mchis te/ bdag bu mo dang gnyis su bas kyis ma bsnyengs shig /
The girl with whom he had a rendezvous said to him, “Son of a lord, there is no one, there is no other girl but me. Do not be afraid.”
des bsams pa/ de 'di la smras na dga' bar 'gyur ro snyam nas/ bzang mo kho bos khyod kyi phyir pha bsad do/ /
Thinking, “She will be pleased if I tell her what I’ve done,” he said, “Noble woman, I have killed my father for your sake.”

des smras pa/ ci pha ba'am/ 'on te skyed pha/ des smras pa/ skyed pha'o/ / des bsams pa/ 'di yon tan dag mngon par mi shes te pha gsod par byed pas gang gi tshe bdag la khro ba skyes na/ bdag la gnas skabs ci zhig 'byung bar 'gyur snyam nas

“What? Your foster father or the man who fathered you?” “The man who fathered me.” The girl thought, “He has killed his father without regard for his importance to him. What chance would I stand if at some point he became angry with me?”

des smras pa/ rje'i sras bdag steng gi khang thog tu 'dzegs nas slar mchi ba'i bar du re zhig gzhes shig des smras pa/ de na de bzhin gyis shig de steng gi khang thog tu 'dzegs nas chom rkun pa chom rkun pa zhes bya ba sgra phyung ba dang /
Then she said to the lad, “Son of a lord, please wait a moment while I climb up to the roof of the house.” “Go ahead.” On reaching the roof, she cried out, “A thief! A thief!”

de 'jigs shing skrag nas bros te rang gi khyim du song nas sgo drung du ral gri bzhag ste chom rkun pa de ni 'di yin te/ kho bo'i pha bsad nas bros so zhes sgra phyung nas/ des pha'i ro de bkur sti byas te song ngo / /
The lad, scared and frightened, fled back to his own house, and laid his knife at the doorstep before crying out, “The thief has been here! He has killed my father and fled!”

sems can sdig pa'i las byas pas ni brtan pa mi rnyed pas de mu stegs can gyi gnas dang dka' thub kyi nags de dang de dag tu song ste dris pa/ shes ldan dag las ci zhig byas na des sdig pa'i las zad par 'gyur/

After performing rites of veneration over his father’s corpse, the lad left home. But a person who has done wrong finds no serenity, so he sought out tīrthika communities and communities of ascetics and asked, “Gentlemen, [F.125.a] what can one do to expunge an evil act?”

de na kha cig na re mer zhugs shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re dug zo shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re g.yang sar mchongs shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re chur mchongs shig ces zer ro/ / kha cig na re thag pas 'gegs te shi shig ces zer te/ thams cad kyang shi ba'i thabs ston par byed kyi/ nges par 'byung ba'i thabs ston pa ni 'ga' yang med do/ / de dus gzhan zhig na rgyal byed kyi tshal du song ba dang / des de na dge slong zhig /

To that, some said, “Immolate yourself”; some said, “Take poison”; some said, “Jump off a cliff”; some said, “Drown yourself”; and some said, “Strangle yourself with a rope.” All of them recommended some form of suicide; none could offer any means of expiation. Later, he went to Jetavana, where he posed his question to a monk, who recited a verse:
gang gis sdig pa'i las byas pa/ / dge ba yis ni 'gog byed de/ / nyi zla sprin nas byung ba ltar/ / 'jig rten 'dir ni de snang 'gyur/ /
“He who has done some wrong May curb it through virtue To bring light to this life, As the sun and moon appear from behind clouds.”

zhes kha ton zer ba thos nas des bsams pa/ sdig pa'i las kyang dgag par nus kyis/ 'di dag gi nang du rab tu 'byung bar bya'o snyam nas/ dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ /
On hearing this verse, the lad thought, “Ah! Even wrongdoing can be checked! I shall go forth among these people.” He then approached the monk and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.”

des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas nas des shin tu brtson 'grus brtsams te bklag par brtsams so/ / des klog cing kha ton byed pa na sde snod gsum bklags shing sde snod gsum dang ldan pa/

After his going forth was allowed and he was ordained, he applied himself diligently and began to learn the scriptures. In reciting and saying prayers, he recited and memorized the Three Piṭakas and gained the confidence born of knowledge and freedom.

rigs pa dang grol ba'i spobs pa can du gyur to/ / de la dge slong dag gis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod brtson 'grus 'dis ci zhig don du gnyer/ des smras pa/ sdig pa'i las zad par bya'o/ / khyod kyis sdig pa'i las ci zhig byas/ pha bsad do ci pha ba'am/ 'on te skyed pha yin/ des smras pa/ skyed pha yin no zhes zer ba'i

The monks asked him, “Venerable, what motivates such diligence in you?” “I must expunge a wrongdoing,” he replied. “What wrongdoing are you guilty of?” “I killed my father.” “Your foster father or the man who fathered you?” “The man who fathered me.”

skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag 'di ni gang zag pha bsad pa bsnyil bar 'os pa yin te/ dge slong dag gang zag pha bsad pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag pha bsad pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod par 'ongs na/ des de la pha bsad pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

The monks asked the Blessed One about it, and he said to the monks, “Monks, a person who has killed his father is fit to be excluded from the community. A person who has killed his father will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya. For that reason, you should exclude from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who have killed their fathers. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, [F.125.b] you should ask, ‘Are you a patricide?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

des bsams pa/ ci de 'babs par bya'am/ mtha' 'khob cig tu 'gro bar bya snyam nas/ des mtha' 'khob tu song ste khyim bdag cig rjes su 'jug par byas so/ / des mngon par dad pas de'i phyir gtsug lag khang rtsig tu bcug ste/ der phyogs dang yul tha dad pa na 'khod pa'i dge slong dag gnas shing de'i gdams ngag gis mang po dag gis dgra bcom pa nyid mngon du byas so/ /

The monk who had killed his father thought, “Where will I wind up? I must go into the wilds.” And with that, he went into the wilds, where a householder became his follower. Out of deep devotion, the householder had a monastery erected for the monk, where monks from various regions and lands came to live, many of whom went on to actualize arhatship under his guidance.

de dus gzhan zhig na na bar gyur nas rtsa ba dang / sdong bu dang / lo ma dang / me tog dang / 'bras bu'i sman dag gis rim gro byas na nyam dmas pa nyid du gyur nas/ des lhan cig gnas pa rnams la smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag kho bo'i phyir dge 'dun la bsro khang gyis shig /de rnams kyis de'i phyir bsro khang byas so/ /

Some time later, the monk patricide fell ill. Although the other monks ministered to him with medicinal roots, stalks, leaves, flowers and fruits, he continued to get worse. The monk patricide then told his wards, “Venerables, construct a dry sauna for the saṅgha and for me.” His monk apprentices then built a dry sauna for him.
bsags pa kun gyi mtha' zad cing / / mthon po rnams kyi mtha' ltung 'gyur/ / phrad pa'i mtha' ni 'bral ba ste/ / gson pa'i mtha' ni 'chi ba yin/ /

zhes bya ba yin pas de shi shing dus la bab nas sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes so/ / de'i lhan cig gnas pa dgra bcom pa zhig gis bdag gi mkhan po gang du skyes zhes sems pa la zhugs nas/ des lha rnams kyi nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na ma mthong zhing mi dang / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas rnams kyi nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na/ sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes par mthong nas

So his time came and he died, and he was reborn among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment. One of his arhat wards entered into meditation to find out where his preceptor had been reborn and began searching for him among the gods, but he did not see him there. Nor did he see him when he looked among humans, animals, and spirits. When he began to search among the denizens of hell, he saw that his preceptor had been reborn among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment.

des bsams pa/ mkhan po ni tshul khrims dang ldan pa/ mang du thos pa/ chos kyi 'khor sdud sdud pa yin na des las ci zhig byas na/ des sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par skyes snyam nas bsams na/ pha bsad pa yin par mthong ngo / /

The arhat ward wondered, “If my preceptor was ethical, learned, and attracted a following with the Dharma, what did he do that it should lead him to be reborn among the denizens of Avīci?” He then saw that it was patricide.

de mnar med pa'i 'od zer dag gis phog pa dang smras pa/ kye ma bsro khang 'di me re tsha zhes smras pa dang / sems can dmyal ba'i srung mas tho ba blangs te mgor bsnun nas skal chad khyod la bsro khang ga la yod/ 'di ltar 'di ni sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med pa yin no zhes smras so/ /

Struck by the fiery light of Avīci, the former monk patricide exclaimed, “Oh! The heat in this dry sauna is too much!” As soon as he cried out, the guardians of hell lifted their maces and clubbed him in the head, shouting, “Hapless fool! Where is this dry sauna of yours? [F.126.a] This is Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment!”

de dge ba'i sems kyis dus byas nas rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes so/ / lha'i bu'am lha'i bu mo'i chos nyid ni skyes nas ring po ma lon pa la sems gsum skye ste/ gang nas shi 'phos pa dang / gang du skyes pa dang / las gang gis skyes pa'o/ / des sems can dmyal ba rnams kyi nang nas shi 'phos pa dang / rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes pa dang / dge 'dun la bsro khang gi khrus byas pas skyes pa mthong ngo / /

This virtuous thought[195] brought the monk patricide’s time in hell to an end and he was reborn among the gods in the realms of the Four Great Kings. It is in the nature of gods and goddesses to have three thoughts shortly after birth: where they have passed on from, where they have been born, and what action has caused that rebirth. Thus the former monk patricide saw that he had passed from among the denizens of hell and been reborn among the gods in the realms of the Four Great Kings due to his having washed the dry sauna for the saṅgha.

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu de 'di snyam du sems te/ gang gi phyir bdag zhag lon par gnas te bcom ldan 'das la blta ba dang / bsnyen bkur bya ba'i phyir nye bar 'gro ba ni bdag gi tshul dang mthun pa ma yin gyis/ bdag zhag lon par ma gnas pa kho nar bcom ldan 'das la blta ba dang / bsnyen bkur bya ba'i phyir nye bar 'gro'o snyam mo/ /

The young god then had this thought: “It would not be right of me to spend a day here without going to see and pay my respects to the Blessed One. Thus, before the day is out, I shall go to see and pay my respects to the Blessed One.”

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu rna cha gdub kor g.yo zhing dri ma med pa thogs te/ do shal dang se mo dos brgyan pa'i lus kyis lha'i ut+pal dang / pad ma dang / ku mu da dang / pad ma dkar po dag gis thu ba bkang ste/ kha dog shin tu 'das pas mtshan mo la bab pa dang / bcom ldan 'das ga la ba der song ste phyin nas bcom ldan 'das la me tog gis mngon par gtor te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs gnyis la mgo bos phyag 'tshal nas mtha' gcig tu 'dug pa dang / 'di ltar sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu'i kha dog gi mthus rgyal byed kyi tshal thams cad snang ba rgya chen pos khyab par gyur to/ /

The young god donned a pair of glittering hooped earrings that swung to and fro, adorned his body with two pearl necklaces, one long and one medium in length, filled the folds of his skirt with the dazzling colors of divine blue lotus flowers, lotuses, water lilies, and white lotuses, and when night had fallen, set out for the Blessed One. On his arrival, he strewed the flowers before the Blessed One and bowed his head at the Blessed One’s feet before taking a place off to one side. The colors of the young god filled the whole of Jetavana with a great light.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu'i bsam pa dang / bag la nyal ba dang / khams dang / rang bzhin thugs su chud nas gang thos nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bus stan de nyid la 'dug bzhin du 'jig tshogs la lta ba'i ri'i rtse mo nyi shu mtho ba ye shes kyi rdo rjes bcom ste/ rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu mngon sum du byas pa de lta bur 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi yang dag par so sor rtogs par byed pa'i chos bstan par mdzad do/ /

Then, as the young god sat on a seat, the Blessed One intuited his thoughts, propensities, disposition, and nature and proceeded to teach the Dharma he needed to hear in order to fully realize each of the Noble Ones’ four truths. The young god then actualized the fruit of a stream enterer by decimating with the lightning bolt of wisdom the mountain of belief in the transient aggregates with its twenty tall peaks. [F.126.b]

des bden pa mthong nas btsun pa bcom ldan 'das kyis bdag la gang mdzad pa 'di lta bu ni bdag la phas kyang ma bgyis/ mas kyang ma bgyis/ rgyal pos kyang ma bgyis/ lha rnams kyis kyang ma bgyis/ sngon gyi pha mes dag gis kyang ma bgyis/ dge sbyong dang bram ze dag gis kyang ma bgyis/ byams pa dang / mdza' bshes dang / rtsa lag gi tshogs kyis kyang ma bgyis te/ khrag dang mchi ma'i rgya mtsho ni bskams/ rus pa'i ri dag las ni bsgral/ ngan song gi sgo dag ni bkum/ mtho ris dang thar pa'i sgo dag ni phye/ sems can dmyal ba dang / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dag nas ni rkang pa phyung / lha dang mi rnams kyi nang du ni bzhag go zhes lan gsum ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do/ /

Upon seeing the truth, the young god whose patricide had led him to rebirth in hell spoke this panegyric thrice: “Reverend, what the Blessed One has done for me, my father did not do for me, nor did my mother, nor did the king, nor did the gods, nor did my ancestors, nor did ascetics or brahmins, nor did my circle of loved ones and friends, nor did my forebears. For the Blessed One has dried up the ocean of blood and tears, freed me from mountains of bones, shut the door to miserable realms, opened the door to higher realms and liberation, dragged me up by the leg from among the denizens of hell, animals, and spirits, and installed me among gods and humans.”
yang smras pa/ khyod mthus rab drag nyes pa mang ldan pa'i/ / ngan song shul bkag bsod nams rab ldan pa'i/ / mtho ris 'gro ba phye zhing bdag gis ni/ / mya ngan 'das pa'i shul yang thob par gyur/ /

The young god spoke again: “Because of you, the path to miserable realms Of terrible and diverse punishments is blocked And the road to higher realms of great merit has opened. I have even found the way to nirvāṇa.
shin tu rnam dag khyod brten bdag gis ni/ / de ring skyon bral dag pa'i mig thob cing / / go 'phang zhi ba 'phags pa dgyes thob ste/ / sdug bsngal rgya mtsho'i pha rol rgal bar gyur/ /
“By relying on you, one of utter purity, I Have today gained flawless, pure vision, I have gained the pacific state pleasing to saints And crossed over the seas of suffering.
'gro bar lha min mi dang lhas mchod pa/ / skye dang rga dang na 'chi bral ba po/ / srid pa stong du mthong bar rab dkon pa/ / thub pa de ring khyod mthong 'bras bu mchis/ /
de nas 'dud byas do shal rab 'phyang bas/ / zhabs la phyag 'tshal rangs pa skyes gyur nas/ / dgra thul g.yas nas yongs su bskor byas te/ / lha yi 'jig rten mngon phyogs mkha' la song / /
“As I bow with my necklace hanging low, Prostrate at your feet, I feel jubilant. Circling clockwise he who has tamed his enemies I turn to the heavens and fly into the sky.”

de nas sngon sems can dmyal ba'i lha'i bu tshong pa khe spogs rnyed pa lta bu dang / zhing pa lo tog 'byor pa lta bu dang / dpa' bo g.yul las rnam par rgyal ba lta bu dang / nad pa nad thams cad las yongs su thar ba lta bur gyur te/ cha lugs gang gis bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar 'ongs pa'i cha lugs de nyid kyis rang gi gnas su song ngo / /

The young god then departed like a trader who has made a profit, a farmer who has reaped his crops, a warrior who has won a battle, or an ill person who has been delivered from all his ills, and, in the dress in which he arrived in the Blessed One’s presence, returned home. [F.127.a]

de'i lhan cig gnas pa dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan dgra bcom pa zas kyi gral du 'dug ste de'i lhan cig gnas pa gzhan zhig dge 'dun la chu 'grim par byed do/ / ji tsam na dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan des chu kha phor du blugs nas sor mo'i rtse mos reg na shin tu grangs nas des bsams pa/ bdag cag ni chu shin tu grang mo 'di lta bu 'thung na mkhan po ni sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med pa na zangs khu bskol ba 'thung ngo snyam nas/

One of the young god’s former apprentices, an elder in the saṅgha and an arhat, was seated in the meal row, while another of his apprentices was distributing water to the saṅgha. After a time, the saṅgha elder lifted his cup of water. It felt extremely cold to the touch of the tip of his fingers, and he thought, “While we drink water as cold as this, the preceptor drinks molten copper among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment.”

des sems can dmyal ba chen po mnar med par rnam par blta bar brtsams na mi snang ngo / / dud 'gro dang / yi dgas dang / mi dang / sems can dmyal ba gzhan rnams su yang rnam par bltas na de rnams na yang mi snang nas/ lha rnams kyi nang du rnam par blta bar brtsams na/ rgyal chen bzhi'i ris kyi lha rnams kyi nang du skyes te/ lhar gyur pas bcom ldan 'das kyi spyan sngar bden pa mthong bar byas te/ lha rnams kyi nang na 'dug pa mthong nas 'dzum pa sngon du btang ste/ bcom ldan 'das la dad pa thob nas/ kye ma sangs rgyas/ kye ma chos/ kye ma dge 'dun/ kye ma chos kyi legs par gsungs pa nyid/ 'di ltar sdig pa byed pa/ log par ltung bar song ba de lta bu dag gis kyang yon tan gyi tshogs 'di lta bu thob bo zhes ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do/ /

Yet when this arhat elder, a former apprentice of the monk patricide, then searched for his preceptor among the denizens of Avīci, the Great Hell of Unrelenting Torment, he was nowhere to be seen. When the arhat elder searched for his preceptor among the animals, spirits, and denizens of other hells, he was nowhere to be seen there either. And so he began to search for him among the gods. There he saw his preceptor had been reborn among the gods in the realm of the Four Great Kings and, having become a god, saw the truth in the Blessed One’s presence before returning to remain among the gods. Smiling, the arhat elder gained faith in the Blessed One and spoke this panegyric: “O Buddha! O Dharma! O Saṅgha! O the well-spoken Dharma by which even wrongdoers led into such fallen states can attain such a collection of qualities!”

mkhan po gcig pa des de rangs shing mgu ba dang mchog tu dga' bar mthong nas smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod mkhan po dus la bab pas bdag ni dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan du gyur to snyam nas rangs shing mgu ba dang mchog tu dga' bar gyur tam/

A student of the same preceptor saw him looking jubilant, pleased, and overjoyed and asked, “Venerable, are you so jubilant, pleased, and overjoyed by the thought that now that the preceptor’s time has come, you are the saṅgha elder?”
des smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa re zhig khyod kyi dri ba'i lan gdab pa'i dus ma yin gyis/ dge 'dun gyi nang du dris shig dang / der khyod kyi dri ba'i lan gdab pa'i dus la bab par 'gyur ro/ /
“Venerable, now is not the time to answer your question. Ask me when we are among the saṅgha and that will prove the time to answer your question.”
ji tsam na dus gzhan zhig na dge slong gi dge 'dun tshogs shing 'khod pa na dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan gyis mkhan po gcig pa de la dris pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod kyis de'i tshe ci smras/
Later, after the monks of the saṅgha gathered and were seated, the saṅgha elder asked the student of the same preceptor, “Venerable, what was it you wanted to ask me?”
des smras pa/ khyod la kho bos khyod mkhan po dus la bab pas bdag dge 'dun gyi gnas brtan du gyur to snyam nas rangs shing mgu ba dang mchog tu dga' bar gyur tam zhes smras so/ /
“I asked you, ‘Venerable, are you so jubilant, pleased, and overjoyed by the thought that now that the preceptor’s time has come, you are the saṅgha elder?’ ” [F.127.b]

des skabs de dge 'dun gyi nang du de la rgya cher brjod pa dang de yang yi rangs shing dge slong rnams kyang kye ma sangs rgyas/ kye ma chos/ kye ma dge 'dun/ kye ma chos kyi legs par gsungs pa nyid/ 'di ltar sdig pa byed pa/ log par ltung bar song ba de lta bu dag gis kyang yon tan gyi tshogs de lta bu thob bo zhes ched du brjod pa ched du brjod do// //

While seated among the saṅgha, the arhat elder explained the situation at length to his fellow student. His fellow student then also rejoiced, as did the saṅgha, who spoke this panegyric: “O Buddha! O Dharma! O Saṅgha! O the well-spoken Dharma by which even wrongdoers led into fallen states can attain such a collection of qualities!”
[dgra bcom bsad]
Killing an Arhat
sdom la/ dgra bcom bsad dang dge 'dun dbyen/ / ngan sems kyis ni khrag phyung dang / / pham par 'gyur ba bzhi po dang / / gnas nas dbyung ba gsum yin no/ /
A summary: Killing an arhat, causing a schism in the saṅgha, Maliciously drawing blood, and Suffering one of the four defeats And three types of suspension.
[dgra bcom bsad]
Killing an Arhat

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das kyis ltang brang gi tshal gseb tu ma ga d+hA'i rgyal po bzo sbyangs gzugs can snying po lha brgyad khri dang / ma ga d+hA'i bram ze dang khyim bdag 'bum phrag du ma dag dang lhan cig bden pa dag la bkod pa na/ des rang gi yul du dril bsgrags pa byed du bcug ste/ nga'i yul du sus kyang chom rkun mi bya'o/ / gang zhig byed pa na ngas de yul med par bya zhing skyin pa ni nga nyid kyi mdzod dang bang ba nas sbyin par bya'o zhes bsgo'o/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī. When, in the thick of Yaṣṭī Grove, the Blessed One established in the truths the King of Magadha, Bimbisāra of the Guilds, along with 80,000 gods and hundreds of thousands of Magadhan brahmins and householders, Bimbisāra had the bells rung throughout his land and this pronouncement was read: “No one shall steal in my lands. If anyone does so, I will banish them and provide recompense from my own stores and treasury.”

gang gi tshe bcom ldan 'das kyis ko sa la'i rgyal po gsal rgyal gzhon nu'i dpe'i mdo sdes btul ba de'i tshe na des kyang dril bsgrags pa byed du bcug ste/ nga'i yul du sus kyang chom rkun mi bya'o/ / gang zhig byed na de gsad pa'i gyod la bskrin cing skyin pa ni nga nyid kyi mdzod dang bang ba nas sbyin par bya'o zhes bsgo ba dang /

When the Blessed One used the analogies of the Daharopama Sūtra [196] to subdue Prasenajit, the King of Kosala, Prasenajit too had the bells rung throughout his land and this pronouncement was read: “No one shall steal in my lands. If anyone does so, they will face capital punishment and I will provide recompense from my own stores and treasury.”

de nas yul ma ga d+hA'i chom rkun pa gang dag yin pa dang / yul ko sa la'i chom rkun pa gang yin pa de dag sa mtshams kyi bar du dong ste/ 'khod nas yul ma ga d+hA nas don mthun 'ong ba gang yin pa de yang 'joms par byed do/ / yul ko sa la nas don mthun 'ong ba gang yin pa de yang 'joms par byed do/ /
At this, the robbers and bandits of Magadha and Kosala all moved to the borderlands. From their camps, they sacked merchant caravans traveling between Magadha and Kosala.

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na don mthun bsel ba dang bcas pa yul ma ga d+hA nas yul ko sa lar 'phags pa dang / gang gi tshe sa mtshams kyi bar du phyin pa de'i tshe ded dpon des smras pa/ shes ldan dag rgyal po gsal rgyal de ni gdug pa pha rol gnon pa yin pas bdag cag la skyin pa sbyin du 'jug nus pa yin na/ bdag cag gis ci'i phyir bsel ba la gla sbyin par bya/ 'di dag nyid nas phyir bzlog go zhes

On one occasion, a caravan of merchants set out from Magadha for Kosala with an armed escort. When they reached the borderlands, [F.128.a] their caravan leader said, “Gentlemen, King Prasenajit is belligerent and ruthless. And if he will recompense us our losses, [S.52.a] why do we pay the wages for an armed escort? The escort can turn back now.”

de dag phyir bzlog ste don mthun de tshogs nyung ngur chas pa dang / chom rkun de dag gis kyang bya ma rta btsugs te bsdad pa dang / des de mthong nas shes ldan dag don mthun tshogs nyung ngus 'ongs na ci'i phyir btang snyoms su 'khod ces smras pa dang /

The escort turned back as the caravan of traders continued, reduced in numbers. The bandits, though, had posted a lookout who was lying in wait and when he caught sight of them he asked, “Gentlemen, why do you sit indifferent when a small caravan of traders is approaching?”

de nas chom rkun pa de dag gis der tshong pa kha cig ni srog dang phral lo/ / kha cig ni zong bor te bros so/ / dgra bcom pa dag ni ma bsams par shes pa dang mthong ba mi 'jug pas dgra bcom pa don mthun de dang 'gro ba zhig kyang srog dang phral lo/ /

With that, the bandits set upon the caravan, taking the lives of some merchants as other merchants abandoned their goods and fled. Without reflection, arhats do not have access to prescience and insight; and so the life of an arhat traveling with the merchants was also taken.

de na don mthun gang dag bros pa de dag mgo dang lus rdul gyis yog ste klad pa'i skra yogs nas ku co 'don cing ko sa la'i rgyal po gsal rgyal gyi drung du phyin nas thal mo sbyar te smras pa/ lha khyod kyi yul du bdag cag tshong bar mi rung bar rnam par bzhag go/ /

Those merchants who had fled sought out King Prasenajit, their faces and bodies smeared with dirt, howling, their hair in disarray. Pressing their palms together they said, “Your Majesty, in your lands we have been reduced to a state where we are not fit to be merchants!”
ci zhig byas/ bdag cag chom rkun pa dag gis bcom mo/ / phyogs gang du/ ga ge mo zhig tu'o/ /
“What happened?” “We were sacked by bandits.” “In what region?” “In a region near the borderlands.”

rgyal pos dmag dpon 'phags skyes po la bsgo ba/ rkun rdzas dang chom rkun pa dag myur du khug shig /des dpung gi tshogs yan lag bzhi pa bsgo nas phyir byung ba dang chom rkun pa de dag kyang go cha phud nas bag yangs su sA la'i dgon pa zhig na rkun rdzas bged cing 'khod pa las/ dmag dpon 'phags skyes pos de dag phyogs bzhir bskor nas dbus su dung dang / rnga pa Ta ha'i sgra dag gis skrag paRa byas pa dang / de rnams las kha cig ni rkun rdzas bor te bros so/ / kha cig ni bsad do/ / drug bcu ni gson por bzung ste des rkun rdzas de yang khyer nas rgyal po'i drung du song ste smras pa/ lha chom rkun pa dag ni 'di dag lags so/ / rkun rdzas ni 'di dag lags so/ /

The king commanded his general Virūḍhaka, “Bring me the stolen goods and the bandits. And be quick about it!” As Virūḍhaka set out at the head of the four branches of the armed forces, the bandits were sitting around unconcerned with their armor off in a śāla forest, dividing their spoils. General Virūḍhaka had them surrounded and, once the bandits were hemmed in, struck fear into their hearts with the sound of conchs and war-drums. Some of the bandits abandoned their spoils and fled while some were killed. Taking sixty of the bandits who had been captured alive, General Virūḍhaka returned to the king with the stolen goods and said, “Your Majesty, these are the bandits and these are the stolen goods.”

de nas rgyal pos de rnams la smras pa/ shes ldan dag khyed kyis rgyal pos dril bsgrags pa byed du bcug ste/ nga'i yul du sus kyang chom rkun mi bya'o/ / gang zhig byed na de gsad pa'i gyod la bskrin cing skyin pa ni nga nyid kyi mdzod dang / bang ba nas sbyin no zhes ma thos sam/ de dag gis smras pa/ lha thos so/ / 'o na ci'i phyir tshong pa dag bcom/ lha 'tsho ba ma mchis so/ /

The king then said to the bandits, “Gentlemen, I, the king, had the bells rung and announced, [F.128.b] ‘No one shall steal in my lands. If anyone does so, they will face capital punishment and I will provide recompense from my own stores and treasury.’ Did you not hear?” “We heard, Your Majesty.” “Well then, why did you rob the merchants?” “We have no other means of making a living, Your Majesty.”

ci'i phyir srog dang phral/ 'jigs pa nye bar bstan pa'i slad du'o/ / khyod kyis 'jigs pa de 'dra ba nye bar bstan pa dang / da sngon sus kyang ma mthong ba gang yin pa'i 'jigs pa de 'dra ba nye bar bstan par bya'o/ / de nas rgyal pos blon po rnams la bsgo ba/ shes ldan dag deng la 'di dag thams cad sod cig /

“Why did you take life?” “To instill fear.” “You may have instilled some fear but the fear I instill today shall be like none ever seen before.” The king then ordered his ministers, “Gentlemen, execute all of these men today.”

de dag gis lam po che dang / srang dang / lam gyi bzhi mdo dang / sum mdo rnams su rjes su sgrogs shing gsad par khrid pa na chom rkun pa zhig lam dog par bros te rgyal byed kyi tshal du dge slong gi gan du song ste smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag rab tu 'byung bar 'tshal lo/ / des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas so/ / chom rkun pa de dag kyang bsad do/ /

As they were being led to the execution grounds, their sentences were proclaimed along the high roads and side streets, at intersections and crossroads. In the commotion, one bandit escaped in the midst of a crowded street and approached a monk in Jetavana and said, “Noble one, I want to go forth.” The monk allowed the bandit’s going forth and ordained him while the other bandits were being executed.

bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong dag rang gi rgud pa dang / gzhan gyi rgud pa dang / rang gi 'byor pa dang / gzhan gyi 'byor pa la yang dang yang du so sor rtogs shig /de ci'i phyir zhe na/ dge slong dag rang gi rgud pa dang / gzhan gyi rgud pa ni kun du skyo bar 'gyur ba'i gnas yin la/ rang gi 'byor pa dang / gzhan gyi 'byor ba yang kun du skyo bar 'gyur ba'i gnas yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

The Blessed One had advised, “Monks, again and again you should be able to scrutinize your own failings, others’ failings, your own strengths, and others’ strengths. Why is that so? Because your own failings and others’ failings act as a spur to disenchantment, while your own strengths and others’ strengths also act as a spur to disenchantment.”

zhes gsungs pas ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na dge slong rnams dur khrod rgyur 'dong ba na dge slong de yang de rnams dang lhan cig dur khrod rgyur song ba las des chom rkun pa de dag bsad pa mthong nas mchi mas brnangs te 'dug par gyur pa dang / dge slong rnams kyis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa dag 'di gsar du rab tu byung ba yin yang bsam pa 'di 'dra bar bzang ngo / /

In light of this advice, the monks had taken to visiting the charnel ground. When the time came for the monks to visit the charnel grounds again, the bandit turned monk accompanied them, and there he saw that the other bandits had been executed. He stood still, choked with tears. The monks said, “Venerables, though he has only newly gone forth, he has such a kind heart.”

des skad phyung ste ngu bar brtsams pa dang dge slong rnams kyis smras pa/ tshe dang ldan pa khyod ci'i phyir cho nges 'debs/ des smras pa/ 'di ni bdag gi pha'o/ /'di ni bdag gi phu nu'o/ /'di ni khu bo'o/ /'di ni zhang po'o/ / de rnams kyis smras pa/ 'di rnams kyis dgra bcom pa srog dang phral lam/

When he began to sob, the monks asked, “Venerable, why do you make such a fuss?” The bandit turned monk replied, “This is my father. This is my brother. This is my uncle on my father’s side. This [F.129.a] is my uncle on my mother’s side.” “These men took the life of an arhat,” said the monks.

des smras pa/ phral lo zhes zer ba'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gang zag 'di ni dgra bcom pa bsad pa yin te/ gang zag dgra bcom pa bsad pa ni chos 'dul ba 'di la mi skye ba'i chos can yin pas dge slong dag khyed kyis gang zag dgra bcom pa bsad pa chos 'dul ba 'di las bsnyil bar bya'o/ / 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la dgra bcom pa bsad pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed/ bsnyen par rdzogs par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

When the bandit turned monk admitted they had taken the life of an arhat, the monks asked the Blessed One about it, [S.52.b] and the Blessed One decreed, “Monks, this person has killed an arhat. A person who has killed an arhat will not take root in this Dharma and Vinaya. Therefore, monks, you should exclude from this Dharma and Vinaya those persons who have killed an arhat. If someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You are not a killer of an arhat, are you?’ If you allow going forth and grant ordination without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[dge 'dun dbyen]

d.crumb: Causing a Schism in the Saṅgha

f.d: Causing a Schism in the Saṅgha

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa gang gis sngon rab tu phyung ba na de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyan thos kyi dge 'dun phye ba de gal te legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'tshal na/ rab tu dbyung bar bgyi'am rab tu dbyung bar mi bgyi/

The venerable Upāli asked the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, if a person who caused a schism among the Tathāgata’s saṅgha disciples in a previous ordination career again wants monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, should his going forth be allowed or not?”

nye ba 'khor rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / de lta bas na 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu dbyung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la dge 'dun gyi dbyen byas pa ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

“Upāli, his going forth should not be allowed. Therefore, if someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You have not caused a schism in the saṅgha, have you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”

d.crumb: Maliciously Drawing Blood from a Tathāgata

f.d: Maliciously Drawing Blood from a Tathāgata

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa la ngan sems kyis khrag phyung ba gal te legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'tshal na/ rab tu dbyung bar bgyi'am/ rab tu dbyung bar mi bgyi/

The venerable Upāli asked the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, if a person who has maliciously drawn blood from a tathāgata wants monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya in the Blessed One’s presence, should his going forth be allowed or not?”

nye ba 'khor rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / de lta bas na 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu dbyung bar 'dod pa 'ongs na/ des de la de bzhin gshegs pa la ngan sems kyis khrag phyung ba ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

“Upāli, his going forth should not be allowed. Therefore, if someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You have not maliciously drawn blood from a tathāgata, have you?’ [F.129.b] If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[pham par 'gyur ba bzhi po]

d.crumb: Suffering One of the Four Defeats

f.d: Suffering One of the Four Defeats

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das la tshe dang ldan pa nye ba 'khor gyis zhus pa/ btsun pa sngon gang rab tu 'byung ba na pham par 'gyur ba bzhi las ltung ba gang yang rung ba byung ba de gal te legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po 'tshal na/ rab tu dbyung bar bgyi'am/ rab tu dbyung bar mi bgyi/

The venerable Upāli asked the Blessed Buddha, “Reverend, if a person who has fallen by committing any of the four actions leading to defeat during a previous ordination career wants monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya, should his going forth be allowed or not?”

nye ba 'khor rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / de lta bas na 'ga' zhig gi gan du rab tu 'byung bar 'dong ba 'ongs na/ des de la pham par 'gyur ba bzhi las ltung ba gang yang rung ba byung ba ma yin nam zhes dri bar bya'o/ / ma dris par rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro// //

“Upāli, his going forth should not be allowed. Therefore, if someone wishing to go forth approaches any of you, you should ask, ‘You have not fallen by committing any of the four acts leading to defeat, have you?’ If you allow going forth without asking this, a breach occurs.”
[gnas nas dbyung ba gsum]
Three Types of Suspension

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / de nas bcom ldan 'das kyis dge slong rnams la bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag gal te gang zag ma mthong bas gnas nas phyung ba babs pa zhig yang phyir 'ongs nas/ tshe dang ldan pa dag ltung ba mthong gis bdag rab tu dbyung bar gsol zhes zer na de rab tu dbyung bar bya'o/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī. The Blessed One then said to the monks, “Monks, if a person who has been suspended for refusing to acknowledge an offense[197] returns and says, ‘Venerables, I acknowledge the offense. Please allow my going forth,’ then you should allow his going forth.

rab tu phyung nas tshe dang ldan pa dag ltung ba bshags par byas/ bdag bsnyen par rdzogs par mdzad du gsol zhes zer na bsnyen par rdzogs par bya'o/ / ji ste bsnyen par rdzogs nas ltung ba ma mthong ngo zhes zer na/ gal te dge 'dun tshogs pa yod na yang ma mthong bas gnas nas dbyung bar bya'o/ / gal te tshogs pa med la ji ste bsnyen par rdzogs na legs par bsnyen par rdzogs pa yin te/ 'di ltar gang zag gis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la rab tu 'byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs pa dge slong gi dngos po rnyed par dka' ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Once he has gone forth, if he says, ‘Venerables, I confess my offense. Please grant me ordination,’ then he should be granted ordination. If perchance, after being ordained, he should say, ‘I do not acknowledge the offense,’ then, provided there is a majority within the saṅgha, he should be suspended for refusing to acknowledge the offense. In the event that there is no majority within the saṅgha and he has been ordained, the ordination is to be judged valid, for it is difficult for a person to find monkhood, to go forth and be ordained in the well-proclaimed Dharma and Vinaya.
ma mthong bas gnas nas phyung ba ji lta ba bzhin du phyir mi 'chos pas gnas nas phyung ba dang / sdig pa can gyi lta ba'i rnam pa mi gtong bas gnas nas phyung ba yang de bzhin no// //
The same conditions apply to suspensions meted out for refusing to amend one’s behavior, and suspensions meted out for refusing to give up deviant views.” [F.130.a]
[lag rdum dag ]

d.crumb: Persons whose hands have been cut off

f.d: Persons whose hands have been cut off

sdom la/ lag rdum dag dang rkang rdum dang / / lag sor zlum por 'jas pa dang / / mchu med lus la rma mtshan can/ / rgan ches pa dang gzhon ches dang / / theng po smad 'char zhar ba dang / / lag sor rdum sgur mi'u thung dang / / lba ba lkugs pa 'on pa dang / / rten 'phye dang ni rkang 'bam dang / / bud med kyis dub khur gyis dub/ / mi gang lam gyis dub rnams dang / / ya za ma lug gta' gam dang / / de lta bu yi mi rnams ni/ / drang srong chen pos dgag pa mdzad/ / mdzes pa rab tu dbyung ba dang / / yongs su dag pa bsnyen rdzogs par/ / rdzogs sangs rgyas kyis rab mkhyen te/ / bden pa'i mtshan gyis bka' stsal to/ /

An index: Persons whose hands have been cut off, persons whose legs have been cut off, Persons with hands of webbed fingers, Persons with no lips, persons whose bodies have been branded, scarred by a whip, or tattooed, The very old, the very young, Persons with mobility impairment, persons with degenerative nerve disorders, persons missing an eye, Persons whose hands have been cut off, persons with kyphosis, persons of restricted growth, Persons with goiters, persons with a speech impairment, persons with a hearing impairment, Persons who use mobility aids, persons with elephantiasis, Persons worn out by women, persons worn out by burdens, Persons worn out by the road, Persons with malabsorption syndromes, and persons with chronic fatigue. The great seer forbade People such as this.[198] Knowing all, the Perfectly Awakened One, Whose name denotes truth, proclaimed That going forth is for the beautiful And ordination for the pure.
[lag rdum dag ]

d.crumb: Persons whose hands have been cut off

f.d: Persons whose hands have been cut off

sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das mnyan yod na rgyal byed kyi tshal mgon med zas sbyin gyi kun dga' ra ba na bzhugs so/ / drug sde dag gi kun du spyod pa ni gang rab tu byung ba dang bsnyen par rdzogs par byas pa des ji srid du 'di dag ni gnas ngan len kun du spyod pa dag yin no zhes bya bar mi shes pa de srid du de de dag dang lhan cig gnas par byed la/ gang gi tshe shes par gyur pa de'i tshe dge slong rang bzhin du gnas pa dag dang lhan cig gnas par byed de/ ston pa'i bka' lung gis dus gsum du 'gro ba'i phyir blta ba 'ba' zhig byed do/ /

The Blessed Buddha was staying at Jetavana, Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park near Śrāvastī. As was their wont, the group of six kept as apprentices anyone whose going forth had been allowed and who had been ordained, but who could not recognize a rogue. Once the apprentices could recognize a rogue, they were entrusted as apprentices to monks of good standing. On the advice of the Teacher, they would on occasion simply look in on their apprentices.

de nas de dag gis gros bya bar brtsams pa/ dga' bo nye dga' lhung bzed nag po can 'di dag ni btsas 'phrog pa dang 'dra ste/ bdag cag gis rab tu phyung ba rnams 'di dag gis 'phrog par byed kyis/ da ni lhung bzed nag po can rnams kyis dbrog par mi 'gyur ba gang yin pa de 'dra ba rab tu dbyung bar bya'o zhes gros byas so/ /

When this came up in conversation, Nanda and Upananda said, “These black begging bowl carriers might as well be snatching babies! Everyone we allow to go forth, they up and snatch away! Let’s allow to go forth the sort that these black begging bowl carriers won’t snatch away.”

ji tsam dus gzhan zhig na nye dga' kun du 'khyam pas mi lag rdum zhig mthong nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ci'i phyir rab tu mi 'byung / des smras pa/ 'phags pa bdag lag pa ma tshang ba su zhig gis rab tu 'byin par bgyid/ nye dga'as smras pa/ bzhin bzangs bcom ldan 'das kyi bstan pa la thugs rjes rab tu phye ba yin gyis/ kho bos khyod rab tu dbyung bar bya'o zhes des de rab tu phyung zhing bsnyen par rdzogs par byas so/ /

Some time later, Upananda was out for a stroll [S.53.a] when he saw a man missing his hands and said, “Dear sir, why do you not go forth?” He replied, “Noble one, as I have no hands, no one will allow me to go forth.” “Dear sir, the Blessed One’s teachings are characterized by compassion. I shall allow your going forth.” And with that he allowed his going forth [F.130.b] and ordination.

de nas zhag gnyis sam gsum zhig kun du spyod pa'i chos rnams bslabs nas smras pa/ bzhin bzangs ri dgas kyis ri dgas mi sos/ mnyan yod rgya che la rang gi spyod yul dang yab kyi spyod yul yin pas bsod snyoms rgyus la 'tsho bar gyis shig /des smras pa/ mkhan po ji ltar bsod snyoms rgyu bar bgyi/ des smras pa/ khyod kyis de tsam yang mi shes sam/ ngas khyod la bstan par bya'o zhes

After two or three days of teaching him how Dharma practitioners conduct themselves, Upananda said, “Dear sir, game does not eat other game. The whole of Śrāvastī is your field and fatherland, so seek out alms and live on them.” “Preceptor, how am I to go begging alms?” “Do you not know even that much? I will show you.”

des de'i sham thabs ni srad bus bcings/ chos gos ni tsher mas gtur te bskon/ dpung pa g.yon par ni lhung bzed kyi snod bzhag /dpung pa g.yas par ni khar gsil btags so/ / de nas de mnyan yod du spyod yul du zhugs pa dang bud med kyis brang brdungs nas smras pa/ 'phags pa sus khyod rab tu byung ba'i lag pa gnyis bcad/ des smras pa/ sring mo khyim pa nas kho bo'i lag pa chad de/ rab tu byung nas chad pa ma yin no/ /

Upananda tied the handless monk’s under robe on with a cord, fastened his robe up with a pin, placed his begging bowl in the crook of his left arm, and nestled his khakkhara staff in the crook of his right arm. The handless monk had entered Śrāvastī on his rounds when a woman beat on his chest and cried, “Noble one! Who cut off the hands of a renunciant?” “Sister,” he replied, “my hands were cut off when I was still a householder. They were not cut off after I went forth.”

sus rab tu phyung / des smras pa/ mkhan po nye dga'as so/ / de rnams kyis smras pa/ gnas ngan len kun du spyod pa de ma gtogs pas gzhan su zhig 'di lta bu rab tu 'byin par byed ces zer ba'i skabs de bcom ldan 'das la dge slong rnams kyis gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis dgongs pa/ nyes dmigs gang cung zad ci byung ba de ni dge slong dag lag rdum rab tu 'byin pa las gyur pa yin no snyam nas

“Who allowed your going forth?” “The preceptor Upananda.” The people said, “Who else but a rogue would allow the going forth of someone like him?” The monks then asked the Blessed One about it, and the Blessed One thought, “All those shortcomings ensue from the monks allowing the going forth of those without hands.”

bka' stsal pa/ dge slong dag de lta bas na dge slong gis lag rdum rab tu dbyung bar mi bya bsnyen par rdzogs par mi bya'o/ / rab tu 'byin par byed/ bsnyen par rdzogs par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ / lag rdum ji lta ba de bzhin du rkang rdum dang / lag sor zlum por 'jas pa dang / mchu med pa dang / lus la rma mtshan can dang / rgan ches pa dag kyang de bzhin no/ / dge slong dag gzhon ches pa dag rab tu 'byin par byed nas de dag gis dge 'dun gyi gnas mal bshang gcis ma rung bar byed nas/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de dag kyang rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ /

Then the Blessed One decreed, “Monks, in light of this, monks should not allow going forth, nor grant ordination, to those who are missing hands. A breach occurs if you allow their going forth and grant them ordination. Just as it is so for persons whose hands have been cut off, it is also so for persons missing a leg, persons with hands of webbed fingers, persons with no lips, persons whose bodies have been branded, scarred by a whip, or tattooed,[199] or the very old. Monks, if you allow the going forth of those who are too young, they will spoil the saṅgha’s bedding with urine and feces.” The Blessed One decreed, “Their going forth should not be allowed either.” [F.131.a]

theng po dag rab tu 'byin par byed nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de dag kyang rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / smad 'chal dang / zhar ba dang / lag sor rdum po dang / sgur po dang / mi'u thung dang / lba ba can dang / lkugs pa dang / 'on pa dang / rten 'phye dang / rkang 'bam dag rab tu 'byin par byed nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de lta bu dag kyang rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ /

“The going forth of persons with mobility impairments is also being allowed,” the Blessed One said. “Neither should their going forth be allowed.” “The going forth of loose women, persons missing an eye, persons whose hands have been cut off, persons with kyphosis, persons of restricted growth, persons with goiters, persons who are speech impaired, persons who are hearing impaired, persons who use mobility aids, and persons with elephantiasis are also being allowed,” the Blessed One said. “People such as they should not be allowed to go forth. If you allow them to go forth, a breach occurs.”

dge slong dag bud med kyis dub pa dang / khur gyis dub pa dang / lam gyis dub pa dang / ya za ma lug dang / gta' gam ba dag rab tu 'byin par byed nas bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ de lta bu dag kyang rab tu dbyung bar mi bya'o/ / rab tu 'byin par byed na 'gal tshabs can du 'gyur ro/ / bsdu bar bya ba'i skabs so/ /

“Monks, the going forth of those worn out by women, those worn out by burdens, those worn out by the road, persons with malabsorption syndromes, and persons with chronic fatigue are also being allowed,” the Blessed One said. “The going forth of such people should not be allowed. If you allow their going forth, a breach occurs.” There are also other cases that warrant further exclusion.[200]
rab tu 'byung ba'i gzhi rdzogs s+ho// //
Thus concludes “The Chapter on Going Forth.”
['gyur byang ]
Colophon

kha che'i mkhan po sarba dz+nyA de ba dang / rgya gar gyi mkhan po bid+yA ka ra pra b+ha dang / kha che'i mkhan po d+harmA ka ra dang / lo ts+tsha ba ban de dpal gyi lhun pos bsgyur cing / rgya gar gyi mkhan po bid+yA ka ra pra b+ha dang / zhu chen gyi lots+tsha ba ban de dpal brtsegs kyis bsgyur cing zhus te gtan la phab pa'o// //

This was translated by the Kashmiri preceptor Sarvajñādeva, the Indian preceptor Vidyākaraprabha, the Kashmiri preceptor Dharmākara, and the translator Bandé Palgyi Lhünpo.
